Arm N Randomized Detail: 53 randomized, 2 excluded "never began" treatment
Treatment Description: Eight intravenous infusions of ketamine at a standard dose for treatment of depression, given over 40 minutes
Dose: 0.5 mg/kg
Citation: Abdallah CG, Roache JD, Gueorguieva R, et al. Dose-related effects of ketamine for antidepressant-resistant symptoms of posttraumatic stress disorder in veterans and active duty military: a double-blind, randomized, placebo-controlled multi-center clinical trial. Neuropsychopharmacology. 2022 Jul;47(8):1574-81. doi: 10.1038/s41386-022-01266-9. PMID: 35046508.

Arm N Randomized Detail: 55 randomized, 2 excluded "never began" treatment
Treatment Description: Eight intravenous infusions of ketamine at a lower dose, given over 40 minutes; expected to act as either treatment or active control
Dose: 0.2 mg/kg
Citation: Abdallah CG, Roache JD, Gueorguieva R, et al. Dose-related effects of ketamine for antidepressant-resistant symptoms of posttraumatic stress disorder in veterans and active duty military: a double-blind, randomized, placebo-controlled multi-center clinical trial. Neuropsychopharmacology. 2022 Jul;47(8):1574-81. doi: 10.1038/s41386-022-01266-9. PMID: 35046508.

Arm N Randomized Detail: 55 randomized, 1 excluded "never began" treatment
Treatment Description: Eight intravenous infusions of placebo (normal saline), given over 40 minutes
Citation: Abdallah CG, Roache JD, Gueorguieva R, et al. Dose-related effects of ketamine for antidepressant-resistant symptoms of posttraumatic stress disorder in veterans and active duty military: a double-blind, randomized, placebo-controlled multi-center clinical trial. Neuropsychopharmacology. 2022 Jul;47(8):1574-81. doi: 10.1038/s41386-022-01266-9. PMID: 35046508.

Treatment Description: Participated in training service dogs for fellow veterans. Sessions with trainer and dog included grooming and bonding, educational lectures, dog training, and debrief.
Citation: Abraham PA, Kazman JB, Bonner JA, et al. Effects of training service dogs on service members with PTSD: A pilot-feasibility randomized study with mixed methods. Military Psychology. 2022;34(2):187-96. doi: 10.1080/08995605.2021.1984126.

Treatment Description: Waitlist
Citation: Abraham PA, Kazman JB, Bonner JA, et al. Effects of training service dogs on service members with PTSD: A pilot-feasibility randomized study with mixed methods. Military Psychology. 2022;34(2):187-96. doi: 10.1080/08995605.2021.1984126.

Treatment Description: Patient asked to make eye movements or exposed to bilateral tones or tapping while recalling traumatic events, with focus on most recent traumatic events with an extended time perspective.
Treatment Duration Detail: range of completed sessions was 2 to 7, indicating total of 7 sessions for treatment
Citation: Acarturk C, Konuk E, Cetinkaya M, et al. The efficacy of eye movement desensitization and reprocessing for post-traumatic stress disorder and depression among Syrian refugees: results of a randomized controlled trial. Psychol Med. 2016 Sep;46(12):2583-93. doi: 10.1017/S0033291716001070. PMID: 27353367.

Treatment Description: Patients not allowed to receive any treatment, including through follow-up period (until assessment at 5 weeks posttreatment)
Citation: Acarturk C, Konuk E, Cetinkaya M, et al. The efficacy of eye movement desensitization and reprocessing for post-traumatic stress disorder and depression among Syrian refugees: results of a randomized controlled trial. Psychol Med. 2016 Sep;46(12):2583-93. doi: 10.1017/S0033291716001070. PMID: 27353367.

Treatment Description: Trauma-focused CBT according to the manual by Foa, Hembree, & Rothbaum, 2007
Citation: Acierno RE, Knapp RG, Tuerk PW, et al. A non-inferiority trial of prolonged exposure for posttraumatic stress disorder: in person versus home-based telehealth. Behav Res Ther. 2017;89:57-65. doi: 10.1016/j.brat.2016.11.009. PMID: 27894058.

Treatment Description: Trauma-focused CBT according to the manual by Foa, Hembree, & Rothbaum, 2007
Citation: Acierno RE, Knapp RG, Tuerk PW, et al. A non-inferiority trial of prolonged exposure for posttraumatic stress disorder: in person versus home-based telehealth. Behav Res Ther. 2017;89:57-65. doi: 10.1016/j.brat.2016.11.009. PMID: 27894058.

Treatment Name: Prolonged exposure therapy delivered via telehealth
Treatment Description: Trauma-focused CBT according to the manual by Foa, Hembree, & Rothbaum, 2007, provided per PE protocol and delivered by home-based telemedicine.
Citation: Acierno R, Jaffe AE, Gilmore AK, et al. A randomized clinical trial of in-person vs. home-based telemedicine delivery of prolonged exposure for PTSD in military sexual trauma survivors. J Anxiety Disord. 2021 Oct;83:102461. doi: 10.1016/j.janxdis.2021.102461. PMID: 34391978.

Treatment Name: Prolonged exposure therapy delivered in person
Treatment Description: Trauma-focused CBT according to the manual by Foa, Hembree, & Rothbaum, 2007, provided per PE protocol and delivered in-person.
Citation: Acierno R, Jaffe AE, Gilmore AK, et al. A randomized clinical trial of in-person vs. home-based telemedicine delivery of prolonged exposure for PTSD in military sexual trauma survivors. J Anxiety Disord. 2021 Oct;83:102461. doi: 10.1016/j.janxdis.2021.102461. PMID: 34391978.

Treatment Description: Trauma-focused CBT with patients constructing a detailed chronological account of his/her biography, with particular attention on traumatic experiences. Therapy aims to reorganize fragmented report of traumatic experiences into a coherent narrative with details about current and past emotional, physiological, cognitive, and behavioral reactions.
Session Length: NR (session continues until trauma-related fear reaction shows a significant diminution; mean session length was 108 [SD 17.0] minutes)
Completed Treatment Definition: did not drop out of treatment
Citation: Adenauer H, Catani C, Gola H, et al. Narrative exposure therapy for PTSD increases top-down processing of aversive stimuli -- evidence from a randomized controlled treatment trial. BMC Neurosci. 2011 Dec 19;12:127. doi: 10.1186/1471-2202-12-127. PMID: 22182346.

Treatment Duration Detail: "For the participants in the WLC group, the time spans between pre- and posttests were individually matched with the NET group"
Citation: Adenauer H, Catani C, Gola H, et al. Narrative exposure therapy for PTSD increases top-down processing of aversive stimuli -- evidence from a randomized controlled treatment trial. BMC Neurosci. 2011 Dec 19;12:127. doi: 10.1186/1471-2202-12-127. PMID: 22182346.

Treatment Description: Sequences of large-magnitude, rhythmic saccadic eye movements while holding in mind the most salient aspect of a traumatic memory. (As described in: Shapiro F. Eye movement desensitization: a new treatment for post-traumatic stress disorder. J Behav Ther Exp Psychiatry. 1989 Sep;20(3):211-7. PubMed PMID: 2576656.)
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: Study reports droout and exclusions, including participants who "refused to continue the study to the end" but unclear if treatment attrition or attrition from measurement
Citation: Ahmadi K, Hazrati M, Ahmadizadeh MJ, et al. REM desensitization as a new therapeutic method for post-traumatic stress disorder: a randomized controlled trial. Acta Med Indones. 2015 Apr;47(2):111-9.  PMID: 26260553.

Treatment Description: Patients wore glasses during sleep that possess sensors with the ability to detect infrared waves that during the rapid eye movements (REM) period and which activates a musical instrument which delivers a light music
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: Study reports droout and exclusions, including participants who "refused to continue the study to the end" but unclear if treatment attrition or attrition from measurement
Citation: Ahmadi K, Hazrati M, Ahmadizadeh MJ, et al. REM desensitization as a new therapeutic method for post-traumatic stress disorder: a randomized controlled trial. Acta Med Indones. 2015 Apr;47(2):111-9.  PMID: 26260553.

Treatment Description: Received no therapy
Citation: Ahmadi K, Hazrati M, Ahmadizadeh MJ, et al. REM desensitization as a new therapeutic method for post-traumatic stress disorder: a randomized controlled trial. Acta Med Indones. 2015 Apr;47(2):111-9.  PMID: 26260553.

Treatment Description: Stimulation applied to bilateral dorsolateral prefrontal cortex
Session Length: 20 Hz for 2 seconds with inter-train interval of 28 seconds. Total train of 30, 1200 pulse per 15-minute session
Frequency: Three times a week for first 2 weeks, then 2 times a week for 2 weeks
Citation: Ahmadizadeh MJ, Rezaei M. Unilateral right and bilateral dorsolateral prefrontal cortex transcranial magnetic stimulation in treatment post-traumatic stress disorder: a randomized controlled study. Brain Res Bull. 2018;140:334-40. doi: 10.1016/j.brainresbull.2018.06.001. PMID: 29883597.

Treatment Description: Stimulation applied to right dorsolateral prefrontal cortex
Session Length: 20 Hz for 2 seconds with inter-train interval of 28 seconds. Total train of 60, 2400 pulse per 30-minute session
Frequency: Three times a week for first 2 weeks, then 2 times a week for 2 weeks
Citation: Ahmadizadeh MJ, Rezaei M. Unilateral right and bilateral dorsolateral prefrontal cortex transcranial magnetic stimulation in treatment post-traumatic stress disorder: a randomized controlled study. Brain Res Bull. 2018;140:334-40. doi: 10.1016/j.brainresbull.2018.06.001. PMID: 29883597.

Treatment Description: Participants received stimulation that induced a contraction of the abductor pollicis brevis muscle, then magnetic coil switched to a sham coil with identical looks and sounds but prevents magnetic energy from plastic shell
Frequency: Three times a week for first 2 weeks, then 2 times a week for 2 weeks
Citation: Ahmadizadeh MJ, Rezaei M. Unilateral right and bilateral dorsolateral prefrontal cortex transcranial magnetic stimulation in treatment post-traumatic stress disorder: a randomized controlled study. Brain Res Bull. 2018;140:334-40. doi: 10.1016/j.brainresbull.2018.06.001. PMID: 29883597.

Treatment Description: Ten tDCS sessions delivered to the right (cathode) and left (anode) dorsolateral prefrontal cortex, with brain areas localized using EEG, over 10 consecutive weekdays
Session Length: 20 minute treatment with 2mA delivered to scalp electrodes
Citation: Ahmadizadeh MJ, Rezaei M, Fitzgerald PB. Transcranial direct current stimulation (tDCS) for post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD): a randomized, double-blinded, controlled trial. Brain research bulletin. 2019;153:273-8. PMID: 31560945.

Treatment Description: Ten sham treatment sessions, with scalp electrodes applied to the dorsolateral prefrontal cortex, over 10 consecutive weekdays.  Current ramped up for 30s and then ramped down.
Citation: Ahmadizadeh MJ, Rezaei M, Fitzgerald PB. Transcranial direct current stimulation (tDCS) for post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD): a randomized, double-blinded, controlled trial. Brain research bulletin. 2019;153:273-8. PMID: 31560945.

Treatment Description: Alpha-1 receptor blocker; titrated over 10 days, then maintained at 15 mg for duration of study
Dose: 15 mg; titration: increased from 1 mg to 15 mg over first 10 days
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, accidents, natural or manmade disasters, other (not specified)
Citation: Ahmadpanah M, Sabzeiee P, Hosseini SM, et al. Comparing the effect of prazosin and hydroxyzine on sleep quality in patients suffering from posttraumatic stress disorder. Neuropsychobiology. 2014 Jul;69(4):235-42. doi: 10.1159/000362243. PMID: 24993832.

Treatment Description: Histamine H-1 blocker; increased from 10 mg over first 10 days to 100 mg, maintained at 100 mg for duration of study
Dose: Initiated at 10 mg, increased to 100 mg
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, accidents, natural or manmade disasters, other (not specified)
Citation: Ahmadpanah M, Sabzeiee P, Hosseini SM, et al. Comparing the effect of prazosin and hydroxyzine on sleep quality in patients suffering from posttraumatic stress disorder. Neuropsychobiology. 2014 Jul;69(4):235-42. doi: 10.1159/000362243. PMID: 24993832.

Treatment Description: Identical shape and color to prazosin and hydroxyzine
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, accidents, natural or manmade disasters, other (not specified)
Citation: Ahmadpanah M, Sabzeiee P, Hosseini SM, et al. Comparing the effect of prazosin and hydroxyzine on sleep quality in patients suffering from posttraumatic stress disorder. Neuropsychobiology. 2014 Jul;69(4):235-42. doi: 10.1159/000362243. PMID: 24993832.

Treatment Description: Group sessions of CBT for PTSD based on Clark and Beck's method; all patients also received "SSRIs, neuroleptics, or benzodiazepines"
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: Received allocated intervention (n=14) minus discontinued intervention (n=0)
Trauma Detail (Study level): intimate partner violence, accidents, illness/medical procedure
Citation: Akbarian F, Bajoghli H, Haghighi M, et al. The effectiveness of cognitive behavioral therapy with respect to psychological symptoms and recovering autobiographical memory in patients suffering from post-traumatic stress disorder. Neuropsychiatr Dis Treat. 2015;11:395-404. doi: 10.2147/NDT.S79581. PMID: 25737635.

Treatment Description: All patients received "SSRIs, neuroleptics, or benzodiazepines;" control patients visited treatment center for medical and medication check
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: Received allocated intervention (n=14) minus discontinued intervention (n=0)
Trauma Detail (Study level): intimate partner violence, accidents, illness/medical procedure
Citation: Akbarian F, Bajoghli H, Haghighi M, et al. The effectiveness of cognitive behavioral therapy with respect to psychological symptoms and recovering autobiographical memory in patients suffering from post-traumatic stress disorder. Neuropsychiatr Dis Treat. 2015;11:395-404. doi: 10.2147/NDT.S79581. PMID: 25737635.

Treatment Description: Anticonvulsant drug; augmentation of participant's existing pharmacotherapy (such as neuroleptics, TCAs, benzodiazepines, SSRIs, sodium valproate, or carbamazepine)
Dose: 12.5 to 500 mg; titration: 12.5 or 25 mg initial dose, increased in increments of 25 to 50 mg every 3 to 4 days until clinical response up to maximum dose of 500 mg
Citation: Akuchekian S, Amanat S. The Comparison of Topiramate and Placebo in the Treatment of Posttraumatic Stress Disorder: A Randomized, Double- Blind Study. J Res Med Sci. 2004;9(5):240-4.

Treatment Description: Identical in appearance to topiramate 50 mg form; augmentation of participant's existing pharmacotherapy (such as neuroleptics, tricyclic antidepressants, benzodiazepines, SSRIs, sodium valproate, or carbamazepine).
Dose: Titration details NR (Topiramate group started at 12.5 or 25 mg with maximum dose of 500 mg)
Citation: Akuchekian S, Amanat S. The Comparison of Topiramate and Placebo in the Treatment of Posttraumatic Stress Disorder: A Randomized, Double- Blind Study. J Res Med Sci. 2004;9(5):240-4.

Treatment Description: Patient asked to focus on traumatic memory, then therapist queries for salient negative and positive cognitions related to the targeted memory while patients move his/her eyes to the therapist's index finger
Citation: Aldahadha B, Al-Harthy H, Sulaiman S. The Efficacy of Eye Movement Desensitization Reprocessing in Resolving the Trauma Caused by the Road Accidents in the Sultanate of Oman. Journal of Instructional Psychology. 2012;39(3/4):146-58.

Treatment Description: No EMDR training
Citation: Aldahadha B, Al-Harthy H, Sulaiman S. The Efficacy of Eye Movement Desensitization Reprocessing in Resolving the Trauma Caused by the Road Accidents in the Sultanate of Oman. Journal of Instructional Psychology. 2012;39(3/4):146-58.

Treatment Description: Patients narrate their biography and encouraged to relive their trauma-related emotions until habituation was achieved
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: "All participants completed the treatment."
Citation: Alghamdi M, Hunt NC, Thomas SA. The effectiveness of narrative exposure therapy with traumatised firefighters in Saudi Arabia: a randomized controlled study. Behav Res Ther. 2015 Mar;66:64-71. doi: 10.1016/j.brat.2015.01.008. PMID: 25701801.

Alghamdi M, Hunt NC, Thomas SA. The effectiveness of narrative exposure therapy with traumatised firefighters in Saudi Arabia: a randomized controlled study. Behav Res Ther. 2015 Mar;66:64-71. doi: 10.1016/j.brat.2015.01.008. PMID: 25701801.

Treatment Description: Internet-based CBT program with minimal therapeutic contact, adapted from cognitive processing therapy and prolonged exposure therapy. Lesson content included psychoeducation, writing and reading a trauma narrative, situational exposure, and tools including controlled breathing and progressive muscle relaxation. Therapist contact included response via phone or email to patient request or to symptom deterioration (mean 38 minutes spent per patient over 10 weeks). Participants also received automated email reminders.
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: 14 participants out of 25 randomized (21 participants started treatment)
Psychotherapy Sessions Completed Detail: Number of sessions completed per participant provided in publication
Trauma Detail (Study level): Combat-related; Child physical abuse; Child sexual abuse; Rape/sexual assault; Illness/medical procedure; Other (severe human suffering; witnessed violent death; unexpected loss of others; harm/injury to others; other stressor)
Citation: Allen AR, Smith J, Hobbs MJ, et al. Internet-delivered cognitive behaviour therapy for post-traumatic stress disorder: a randomised controlled trial and outcomes in routine care. Behav Cogn Psychother. 2022 Nov;50(6):649-55. doi: 10.1017/S1352465822000285. PMID: 35924312.

Treatment Description: Waitlist
Trauma Detail (Study level): Combat-related; Child physical abuse; Child sexual abuse; Rape/sexual assault; Illness/medical procedure; Other (severe human suffering; witnessed violent death; unexpected loss of others; harm/injury to others; other stressor)
Citation: Allen AR, Smith J, Hobbs MJ, et al. Internet-delivered cognitive behaviour therapy for post-traumatic stress disorder: a randomised controlled trial and outcomes in routine care. Behav Cogn Psychother. 2022 Nov;50(6):649-55. doi: 10.1017/S1352465822000285. PMID: 35924312.

Treatment Description: Remotely delivered training balancing attention between threatening and neutral stimuli. Two images of faces presented, one with neutral and one with angry expression, with arrowhead pointing right (‘>’) or left (‘<’) by one of the faces until response. Arrowhead appeared next to each image with equal probability.
Trauma Detail (Study level): Combat-related; Rape/sexual assault; Accidents; Illness/medical procedure; Community/school violence; Terrorism/political violence/forced displacement
Citation: Alon Y, Azriel O, Pine DS, et al. A randomized controlled trial of supervised remotely-delivered attention bias modification for posttraumatic stress disorder. Psychol Med. 2022 Feb 8:1-10. doi: 10.1017/S003329172200023X. PMID: 35132952.

Treatment Description: Remotely delivered training directing attention away from threatening stimulus. Two images of faces presented, one with neutral and one with angry expression, with arrowhead pointing from angry to neutral face.
Trauma Detail (Study level): Combat-related; Rape/sexual assault; Accidents; Illness/medical procedure; Community/school violence; Terrorism/political violence/forced displacement
Citation: Alon Y, Azriel O, Pine DS, et al. A randomized controlled trial of supervised remotely-delivered attention bias modification for posttraumatic stress disorder. Psychol Med. 2022 Feb 8:1-10. doi: 10.1017/S003329172200023X. PMID: 35132952.

Treatment Description: Group counseling program consisting of four domains: alienation; loss and grief; hope and hopelessness; psychological problems. Sessions targeted these domains and used psycho-education techniques and teaching coping strategies.
Treatment Duration Detail: "program was implemented for 1.5 months, two sessions per week"
Citation: Alsheikh Ali ASS. Efficiency of Intervention Counseling Program on the Enhanced Psychological Well-being and Reduced Post-traumatic Stress Disorder Symptoms Among Syrian Women Refugee Survivors. Clin Pract Epidemiol Ment Health. 2020 Jul 30;16(Suppl-1):134-141. doi: 10.2174/1745017902016010134. PMID: 33029190; PMCID: PMC7536727.

Treatment Description: No psychological support or psychiatric medications
Citation: Alsheikh Ali ASS. Efficiency of Intervention Counseling Program on the Enhanced Psychological Well-being and Reduced Post-traumatic Stress Disorder Symptoms Among Syrian Women Refugee Survivors. Clin Pract Epidemiol Ment Health. 2020 Jul 30;16(Suppl-1):134-141. doi: 10.2174/1745017902016010134. PMID: 33029190; PMCID: PMC7536727.

Treatment Description: Manualized therapy using 12-session protocol focused on teaching skills to identify and challenge trauma-related beliefs; up to 3 additional sessions offered based on clinical need to address residual symptoms.
Trauma Detail (Study level): Accidents; Child physical abuse; Child sexual abuse; Rape/sexual assault; Community/school violence; Natural or manmade disasters; Terrorism/political violence/forced displacement; Other (traumatic loss)
Citation: Angelakis S, Weber N, Nixon RDV. Comorbid posttraumatic stress disorder and major depressive disorder: The usefulness of a sequential treatment approach within a randomised design. J Anxiety Disord. 2020 Dec;76:102324. doi: 10.1016/j.janxdis.2020.102324. Epub 2020 Oct 20. PMID: 33137600.

Arm N Randomized Detail: 18 allocated, 1 "withdrawn due to medication status"
Standardized Treatment Name: Behavioral activation (BA) followed by Cognitive Processing Therapy (CPT)
Treatment Description: BA (5 sessions) followed by CPT (10 sessions). BA: manualized therapy for depression "focused on the link between behavior and mood and involved psychoeducation, activity monitoring, and scheduling of mastery and pleasure tasks"; CPT: manualized therapy focused on teaching skills to identify and challenge trauma-related beliefs, content delivery was modified to fit content of 12-session protocol into 10 sessions.
Treatment Duration Detail: 15 sessions total; 10 sessions CPT (12 hours total) + 5 sessions BA (5 hours total)
Trauma Detail (Study level): Accidents; Child physical abuse; Child sexual abuse; Rape/sexual assault; Community/school violence; Natural or manmade disasters; Terrorism/political violence/forced displacement; Other (traumatic loss)
Citation: Angelakis S, Weber N, Nixon RDV. Comorbid posttraumatic stress disorder and major depressive disorder: The usefulness of a sequential treatment approach within a randomised design. J Anxiety Disord. 2020 Dec;76:102324. doi: 10.1016/j.janxdis.2020.102324. Epub 2020 Oct 20. PMID: 33137600.

Standardized Treatment Name: Cognitive Processing Therapy (CPT) followed by Behavioral activation (BA)
Treatment Description: CPT (10 sessions) followed by BA (5 sessions). Same content as arm B, in reverse order. CPT: manualized therapy focused on teaching skills to identify and challenge trauma-related beliefs, content delivery was modified to fit content of 12-session protocol into 10 sessions; BA: manualized therapy for depression "focused on the link between behavior and mood and involved psychoeducation, activity monitoring, and scheduling of mastery and pleasure tasks".
Treatment Duration Detail: 15 sessions total; 5 sessions BA (5 hours total) + 10 sessions CPT (12 hours total)
Trauma Detail (Study level): Accidents; Child physical abuse; Child sexual abuse; Rape/sexual assault; Community/school violence; Natural or manmade disasters; Terrorism/political violence/forced displacement; Other (traumatic loss)
Citation: Angelakis S, Weber N, Nixon RDV. Comorbid posttraumatic stress disorder and major depressive disorder: The usefulness of a sequential treatment approach within a randomised design. J Anxiety Disord. 2020 Dec;76:102324. doi: 10.1016/j.janxdis.2020.102324. Epub 2020 Oct 20. PMID: 33137600.

Treatment Description: Acetylcholinesterase inhibitor; augmentation of treatment with citalopram and valproate; randomized following 4-week run-in with citalopram and valproate; rivastigmine 3 mg (total daily dose) for 4 weeks then 6 mg (total daily dose) for 8 weeks.
Dose: 3 mg (total daily dose 6 mg); titration: 1.5 mg for 4 weeks (total daily dose 3 mg) then 3 mg for 8 weeks (total daily dose 6 mg)
Citation: Ardani AR, Hosseini G, Bordbar MRF, et al. Effect of rivastigmine augmentation in treatment of male patients with combat-related chronic posttraumatic stress disorder: a randomized controlled trial. J Clin Psychopharmacol. 2017 Feb;37(1):54-60. doi: 10.1097/jcp.0000000000000624. PMID: 27930500.

Treatment Description: Placebo identical to rivastigmine; after 4-week run-in with citalopram and valproate, randomized to placebo for 8 weeks in addition to treatment with citalopram and valproate.
Citation: Ardani AR, Hosseini G, Bordbar MRF, et al. Effect of rivastigmine augmentation in treatment of male patients with combat-related chronic posttraumatic stress disorder: a randomized controlled trial. J Clin Psychopharmacol. 2017 Feb;37(1):54-60. doi: 10.1097/jcp.0000000000000624. PMID: 27930500.

Treatment Description: After 4-week run-in with citalopram and valproate, randomized to no additional medications for 8 weeks, and continued routine medications (citalopram and valproate as established in run-in).
Citation: Ardani AR, Hosseini G, Bordbar MRF, et al. Effect of rivastigmine augmentation in treatment of male patients with combat-related chronic posttraumatic stress disorder: a randomized controlled trial. J Clin Psychopharmacol. 2017 Feb;37(1):54-60. doi: 10.1097/jcp.0000000000000624. PMID: 27930500.

Treatment Description: Imaginal exposure portion based on program by Foa & Rothbaum (1989) with 60 minutes of imagery work each session; 3 sessions of imaginal exposure only, then 6 sessions focused on identifying and imagining reacting as they wished they had done, until a satisfying response could be used repetitively in imagery.
Trauma Detail (Study level): rape/sexual assault, accidents, community/school violence, other (witnessing trauma of others, unspecified childhood trauma)
Citation: Arntz A, Tiesema M, Kindt M. Treatment of PTSD: a comparison of imaginal exposure with and without imagery rescripting. J Behav Ther Exp Psychiatry. 2007 Dec;38(4):345-70. doi: 10.1016/j.jbtep.2007.10.006. PMID: 18005935.

Treatment Description: Based on the program by Foa & Rothbaum (1989) with 60 minutes of imagery exposure, but no in vivo exposure. Homework to listen to audiotaped exposure session 5 days per week and complete Standard Homework Diary Forms, which were reviewed at each therapy session.
Trauma Detail (Study level): rape/sexual assault, accidents, community/school violence, other (witnessing trauma of others, unspecified childhood trauma)
Citation: Arntz A, Tiesema M, Kindt M. Treatment of PTSD: a comparison of imaginal exposure with and without imagery rescripting. J Behav Ther Exp Psychiatry. 2007 Dec;38(4):345-70. doi: 10.1016/j.jbtep.2007.10.006. PMID: 18005935.

Treatment Description: Waitlist group created when waiting time to treatment increased "to about 3 months" at which time participants were informed they would start treatment after waiting period.
Trauma Detail (Study level): rape/sexual assault, accidents, community/school violence, other (witnessing trauma of others, unspecified childhood trauma)
Citation: Arntz A, Tiesema M, Kindt M. Treatment of PTSD: a comparison of imaginal exposure with and without imagery rescripting. J Behav Ther Exp Psychiatry. 2007 Dec;38(4):345-70. doi: 10.1016/j.jbtep.2007.10.006. PMID: 18005935.

Treatment Description: Trauma-focused protocol targeting reconsolidation of traumatic memories; "employs a 'rewinding' technique - where the participant imagines that they are in a cinema watching a film of her/his traumatic event, the participant then enters the screen and relives their trauma memory in reverse very quickly. It is theorised that this rewinding may utilise mechanisms such as exposure, extinction, and reconsolidation to alleviate PTSD symptoms"
Treatment Duration Detail: Up to 3 sessions over 8 weeks, specific timing NR
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: Not further described
Psychotherapy Sessions Completed Detail: Provided only for combined arms after waitlist received intervention
Trauma Detail (Study level): Rape/sexual assault; Illness/medical procedure; Accidents; Community/school violence; Combat-related; Child physical abuse; Other ("serious injury, harm, or death you caused to someone else"; "severe human suffering", "sudden violent death", "any other very stressful event or experience")
Citation: Astill Wright L, Barawi K, Kitchiner N, et al. Rewind for posttraumatic stress disorder: a randomised controlled trial. Depress Anxiety. 2023;2023, Article ID 6279649:1-11. doi: 10.1155/2023/6279649.

Treatment Description: Waitlist
Trauma Detail (Study level): Rape/sexual assault; Illness/medical procedure; Accidents; Community/school violence; Combat-related; Child physical abuse; Other ("serious injury, harm, or death you caused to someone else"; "severe human suffering", "sudden violent death", "any other very stressful event or experience")
Citation: Astill Wright L, Barawi K, Kitchiner N, et al. Rewind for posttraumatic stress disorder: a randomised controlled trial. Depress Anxiety. 2023;2023, Article ID 6279649:1-11. doi: 10.1155/2023/6279649.

Treatment Description:
PE: manualized therapy consisting of psychoeducation, breathing retraining, in vivo exposure, imagery exposure, and processing; 2 introductory sessions and imagery exposure and processing during remaining sessions (6 to maximum of 13 sessions).







TAU: participants continued any treatment received before the study, including supportive counseling and medication; patients were asked to not change medication or dosages for duration of treatment.
Trauma Detail (Study level): rape/sexual assault, accidents, community/school violence
Citation: Asukai N, Saito A, Tsuruta N, et al. Efficacy of exposure therapy for Japanese patients with posttraumatic stress disorder due to mixed traumatic events: A randomized controlled study. J Trauma Stress. 2010 Dec;23(6):744-50. doi: 10.1002/jts.20589. PMID: 21171135.

Treatment Description: TAU while on waitlist; continuation of any treatment received before the study, including supportive counseling and medication; patients were asked to not change medication or dosages for duration of treatment
Trauma Detail (Study level): rape/sexual assault, accidents, community/school violence
Citation: Asukai N, Saito A, Tsuruta N, et al. Efficacy of exposure therapy for Japanese patients with posttraumatic stress disorder due to mixed traumatic events: A randomized controlled study. J Trauma Stress. 2010 Dec;23(6):744-50. doi: 10.1002/jts.20589. PMID: 21171135.

Standardized Treatment Name: Concurrent Treatment for PTSD and Substance Use Disorder Using Prolonged Exposure (COPE)
Treatment Description: Integrates Prolonged Exposure and CBT for SUD; sessions include psychoeducation, in vivo exposure and imaginal exposure; abstinence is not required to participate but is strongly encouraged.
Treatment Duration Detail: total 12 sessions; frequency and duration not stated specifically but end of treatment assessments done at week 12
Trauma Detail (Study level): Combat-related, Rape/sexual assault, Accidents, Community/school violence, Natural or manmade disasters, Terrorism/policital violence/forced displacement; Other (physical assault, assault with a weapon, unwanted or uncomfortable sexual experience, captivity, severe human suffering, sudden violent death of someone close, sudden unexpected death of someone close, other very stressful event or experience)
Citation: Back SE, Killeen T, Badour CL, et al. Concurrent treatment of substance use disorders and PTSD using prolonged exposure: a randomized clinical trial in military veterans. Addict Behav. 2019 Mar;90:369-77. doi: 10.1016/j.addbeh.2018.11.032. PMID: 30529244.

Treatment Description: Manualized evidence-based treatment; "teaches skills to help manage cravings and high-risk situations that commonly precipitate substance use."
Treatment Duration Detail: total 12 sessions; frequency and duration not stated specifically but end of treatment assessments done at week 12
Trauma Detail (Study level): Combat-related, Rape/sexual assault, Accidents, Community/school violence, Natural or manmade disasters, Terrorism/policital violence/forced displacement; Other (physical assault, assault with a weapon, unwanted or uncomfortable sexual experience, captivity, severe human suffering, sudden violent death of someone close, sudden unexpected death of someone close, other very stressful event or experience)
Citation: Back SE, Killeen T, Badour CL, et al. Concurrent treatment of substance use disorders and PTSD using prolonged exposure: a randomized clinical trial in military veterans. Addict Behav. 2019 Mar;90:369-77. doi: 10.1016/j.addbeh.2018.11.032. PMID: 30529244.

Treatment Description: Doxazosin immediate-release capsules formulated with 25 mg riboflavin to monitor adherence.
Dose: 16 mg; Titration: initiated at 1 mg/day and dose doubled every week (2 mg at week 2, 4 mg at week 3, 8 mg at week 4, 16 mg during weeks 5-12). Downward titration at the end of week 12: 8 mg on day 1, 6 mg on day 2, 4 mg on day 3, 2 mg on day 4, and 1 mg on day 5
Treatment Duration Detail: Not counting downward titration after 12 weeks
Participants Adhered Percent Detail: 75.5% (n/N NR, data missing for 9) with no difference between medication groups
Dose at Study End Point Detail: overall 87.9% reached full dose of 16 mg, with no signficant differences by group
Citation: Back S, Flanagan J, Mintz J, et al. A double-blind randomized controlled trial of doxazosin for co-occurring PTSD and alcohol use disorder in veterans. J Clin Psychiatry. 2023 Mar;84(2):21m14367. doi: 10.4088/JCP.21m14367. PMID: 36883885.

Treatment Description: Capsules color-matched, opaque, and identically sized compared with doxazosin capsules.
Dose: matched to active (doxasozin)
Treatment Duration Detail: Not counting downward titration after 12 weeks
Participants Adhered Percent Detail: 75.5% (n/N NR, data missing for 9) with no difference between medication groups
Dose at Study End Point Detail: overall 87.9% reached full dose of 16 mg, with no signficant differences by group
Citation: Back S, Flanagan J, Mintz J, et al. A double-blind randomized controlled trial of doxazosin for co-occurring PTSD and alcohol use disorder in veterans. J Clin Psychiatry. 2023 Mar;84(2):21m14367. doi: 10.4088/JCP.21m14367. PMID: 36883885.

Treatment Description: Computerized cognitive training strategies to alter biases in attention. Intervention utilized the dot-probe task to train attention bias away from threat
Session Length: Each session consisted of 160 trials with 500 millisecond centrally-presented fixation cross, then replaced by a pair of words presented for 500 millisecond
Citation: Badura-Brack AS, Naim R, Ryan TJ, et al. Effect of attention training on attention bias variability and PTSD symptoms: randomized controlled trials in Israeli and U.S. combat veterans. Am J Psychiatry. 2015 Dec;172(12):1233-41. doi: 10.1176/appi.ajp.2015.14121578. PMID: 26206075.

Treatment Description: Repeated trials train patients to normalize fluctuations in threat-related attention bias
Session Length: Each session consisted of 160 trials with 500 millisecond centrally-presented fixation cross, then replaced by a pair of words presented for 500 millisecond
Citation: Badura-Brack AS, Naim R, Ryan TJ, et al. Effect of attention training on attention bias variability and PTSD symptoms: randomized controlled trials in Israeli and U.S. combat veterans. Am J Psychiatry. 2015 Dec;172(12):1233-41. doi: 10.1176/appi.ajp.2015.14121578. PMID: 26206075.

Treatment Description: Computerized cognitive training strategies to alter biases in attention. Intervention utilized the dot-probe task with pairs of angry and neutral faces to train attention bias away from threat
Session Length: Each session consisted of 120 trials with 500 millisecond centrally-presented fixation cross, followed by a face pair display for 500 millisecond
Citation: Badura-Brack AS, Naim R, Ryan TJ, et al. Effect of attention training on attention bias variability and PTSD symptoms: randomized controlled trials in Israeli and U.S. combat veterans. Am J Psychiatry. 2015 Dec;172(12):1233-41. doi: 10.1176/appi.ajp.2015.14121578. PMID: 26206075.

Treatment Description: Repeated trials train patients to normalize fluctuations in threat-related attention bias
Session Length: Each session consisted of 120 trials with 500 millisecond centrally-presented fixation cross, followed by a face pair display for 500 millisecond
Citation: Badura-Brack AS, Naim R, Ryan TJ, et al. Effect of attention training on attention bias variability and PTSD symptoms: randomized controlled trials in Israeli and U.S. combat veterans. Am J Psychiatry. 2015 Dec;172(12):1233-41. doi: 10.1176/appi.ajp.2015.14121578. PMID: 26206075.

Treatment Description: Manualized group treatment focused on psychoeducation and skill-building, to enable patients to cope with PTSD symptoms, strengthen emotional regulation, and improve interpersonal functioning. Each group included 9 participants and 2 therapists. Sessions included exercises, such as grounding, relaxation, or mindfulness. Homework between sessions. All patients also received adjunctive conventional individual treatment; individual treatment determined by therapist, not protocolled.
Trauma Detail (Study level): Child physical abuse; Child sexual abuse; Child other abuse
Citation: Baekkelund H, Karlsrud I, Hoffart A, et al. Stabilizing group treatment for childhood-abuse related PTSD: a randomized controlled trial. Eur J Psychotraumatol. 2021 Jan 22;12(1):1859079. doi: 10.1080/20008198.2020.1859079. PMID: 33537118.

Treatment Description: All patients received adjunctive conventional individual treatment during the waiting period; individual treatment determined by therapist, not protocolled.. All patients in the control group were offered the experimental group treatment after the waiting period.
Completed Treatment Definition: Did not drop out (during waiting period)
Trauma Detail (Study level): Child physical abuse; Child sexual abuse; Child other abuse
Citation: Baekkelund H, Karlsrud I, Hoffart A, et al. Stabilizing group treatment for childhood-abuse related PTSD: a randomized controlled trial. Eur J Psychotraumatol. 2021 Jan 22;12(1):1859079. doi: 10.1080/20008198.2020.1859079. PMID: 33537118.

Treatment Description: Quetiapine monotherapy in addition to weekly PE therapy delivered as a standard of care in ten manualized 90-minute sessions following the model by Foa et al.  2-week dose reduction of current psychotropic medications followed by titration with flexible dosing of quetiapine starting at 25 mg and titrated up to 200 mg daily based on tolerability; quetiapine stabilization period of 2 weeks prior to starting PE therapy, with dose maintained throughout PE.
Dose: 25 to 200 mg (flexible dosing starting at 25 mg and titrated up to 200 mg daily based on tolerability)
Treatment Duration Detail: 10 session weekly PE was preceded by 2 week run-in of pharmacotherapy
Completed Treatment Definition: Completed until session 10 or therapist reported that patient completed treatment
Citation: Baig MR, Wilson JL, Beck RD, et al. Quetiapine as an adjunct to enhance engagement in prolonged exposure therapy for PTSD in veterans: A randomized, pilot trial. Journal of Behavioral and Cognitive Therapy. 2022 doi: 10.1016/j.jbct.2022.04.001.

Treatment Description: TAU medication management in addition to weekly PE therapy delivered as a standard of care in ten manualized 90-minute sessions following the model by Foa et al. TAU stabilized for 2-week period prior to starting PE, and maintained throughout PE.
Treatment Duration Detail: 10 session weekly PE was preceded by 2 week run-in of TAU
Completed Treatment Definition: Completed until session 10 or therapist reported that patient completed treatment
Citation: Baig MR, Wilson JL, Beck RD, et al. Quetiapine as an adjunct to enhance engagement in prolonged exposure therapy for PTSD in veterans: A randomized, pilot trial. Journal of Behavioral and Cognitive Therapy. 2022 doi: 10.1016/j.jbct.2022.04.001.

Treatment Description: Reversible MAOI with SSRI activity; flexible dose with titration
Dose: 150 mg; flexible dosing, titration: starting dose NR, titrated up to 150 mg
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, rape/sexual assault, accidents, community/school violence, natural or manmade disasters, other (not specified)
Citation: Baker DG, Diamond BI, Gillette GM, et al. A double-blind, randomized, placebo-controlled, multi-center study of brofaromine in the treatment of post-traumatic stress disorder. Psychopharmacology (Berl). 1995 Dec;122(4):386-9. doi: 10.1007/BF02246271. PMID: 8657838.

Treatment Description: Placebo
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, rape/sexual assault, accidents, community/school violence, natural or manmade disasters, other (not specified)
Citation: Baker DG, Diamond BI, Gillette GM, et al. A double-blind, randomized, placebo-controlled, multi-center study of brofaromine in the treatment of post-traumatic stress disorder. Psychopharmacology (Berl). 1995 Dec;122(4):386-9. doi: 10.1007/BF02246271. PMID: 8657838.

Treatment Description: Anticonvulsant; augmentation of standard medications of SSRIs (citalopram 20 to 40 mg per day or sertraline 50 to 200 mg per day) and sodium valproate (1000 to 1800 mg per day)
Dose: 150 mg (total daily dose 300 mg); titration: 75 mg per day for one week, then 75 mg twice daily for one week, then 150 mg twice daily
Citation: Baniasadi M, Hosseini G, Fayyazi Bordbar MR, et al. Effect of pregabalin augmentation in treatment of patients with combat-related chronic posttraumatic stress disorder: a randomized controlled trial. J Psychiatr Pract. 2014 Nov;20(6):419-27. doi: 10.1097/01.pra.0000456590.12998.41. PMID: 25406046.

Treatment Description: Placebo augmentation of standard medications of SSRIs (citalopram 20 to 40 mg per day or sertraline 50 to 200 mg per day) and sodium valproate (1000 to 1800 mg per day)
Citation: Baniasadi M, Hosseini G, Fayyazi Bordbar MR, et al. Effect of pregabalin augmentation in treatment of patients with combat-related chronic posttraumatic stress disorder: a randomized controlled trial. J Psychiatr Pract. 2014 Nov;20(6):419-27. doi: 10.1097/01.pra.0000456590.12998.41. PMID: 25406046.

Treatment Description: Shorter version of CBT with cognitive intervention limited to explanation of treatment rationale, focusing on reduction of fear and avoidance, and shifting focus from habituation to anxiogenic stimuli to enhancement of sense of control over traumatic stressor
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: Unclear if dropout reported is from treatment or from measurement
Citation: Basoglu M, Salcioglu E, Livanou M, et al. Single-session behavioral treatment of earthquake-related posttraumatic stress disorder: a randomized waiting list controlled trial. J Trauma Stress. 2005;18(1):1-11. doi: 10.1002/jts.20011. PMID: 16281190.

Treatment Description: Participants completed a 6-week waiting period then were re-assessed
Citation: Basoglu M, Salcioglu E, Livanou M, et al. Single-session behavioral treatment of earthquake-related posttraumatic stress disorder: a randomized waiting list controlled trial. J Trauma Stress. 2005;18(1):1-11. doi: 10.1002/jts.20011. PMID: 16281190.

Treatment Description: Treatment rationale, treatment target setting, and self-exposure instructions provided in first session. Then patients were exposed to simulated earthquake tremors with ability to control intensity, and instructed to confront their fear until they felt in control
Session Length: 60 for first session, variable for simulation (mean 33 minutes, SD 18)
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: Unclear if dropout reported is from treatment or from measurement
Citation: Basoglu M, Salcioglu E, Livanou M. A randomized controlled study of single-session behavioural treatment of earthquake-related post-traumatic stress disorder using an earthquake simulator. Psychological Medicine. 2007;37(2):203-13. doi: 10.1017/S0033291706009123. PMID: 17254365.

Treatment Description: Participants assessed at week 4 and 8 after randomization, then received treatment
Citation: Basoglu M, Salcioglu E, Livanou M. A randomized controlled study of single-session behavioural treatment of earthquake-related post-traumatic stress disorder using an earthquake simulator. Psychological Medicine. 2007;37(2):203-13. doi: 10.1017/S0033291706009123. PMID: 17254365.

Treatment Description: Anticonvulsant medication + weekly medication management manualized counseling to promote adherence and reduce alcohol use
Dose: 25 to 300 mg per day flexible dosing determined by tolerability; titration schedule: 25 mg/day for 1 week, increased to 50 mg/day in week 2, then increased in 50 mg/day increments each week to maximum of 300 mg/day in week 6, final dose maintained weeks 6 through 11, then tapered and discontinued in week 12.
Participant Adherence Definition: Self-report and pill count, medication adherence rate calculated as total dose reported taken/total dose prescribed x 100
Participants Adhered Percent Detail: mean medication adherence rate 63.1% (SD 20.3%)
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, other ("civilian related trauma")
Citation: Batki SL, Pennington DL, Lasher B, et al. Topiramate treatment of alcohol use disorder in veterans with posttraumatic stress disorder: a randomized controlled pilot trial. Alcohol Clin Exp Res. 2014 Aug;38(8):2169-77. doi: 10.1111/acer.12496. PMID: 25092377.

Treatment Description: Placebo identical to topiramate
Dose: dose as topiramate-equivalent; 25 to 300 mg per day flexible dosing determined by tolerability; titration schedule: 25 mg/day for 1 week, increased to 50 mg/day in week 2, then increased in 50 mg/day increments each week to maximum of 300 mg/day in week 6, final dose maintained weeks 6 through 11, then tapered and discontinued in week 12.
Participant Adherence Definition: Self-report and pill count, medication adherence rate calculated as total dose reported taken/total dose prescribed x 100
Participants Adhered Percent Detail: mean medication adherence rate 60.2% (SD 21.5%)
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, other ("civilian related trauma")
Citation: Batki SL, Pennington DL, Lasher B, et al. Topiramate treatment of alcohol use disorder in veterans with posttraumatic stress disorder: a randomized controlled pilot trial. Alcohol Clin Exp Res. 2014 Aug;38(8):2169-77. doi: 10.1111/acer.12496. PMID: 25092377.

Treatment Name: MI for smoking cessation + PTSD home telehealth care management program
Treatment Description: MI-based written smoking cessation curricula on home telehealth Health Buddy computer program and weekly telephone smoking cessation MI counseling by a nurse in addition to PTSD home telehealth care management program and nurse care manager. Mi-based smoking cessation curricula used MI material. A participant's response to a question dictated a different reply based on his or her stage of change. Nurse care managers used responses to promote identified health behavior change, and participants acquire a positive behavior (tobacco cessation)
Session Length:
PTSD Health Buddy: 2 minutes;



MI counseling sessions: NR (average duration of call: 16.7 minutes)
Frequency: PTSD Health Buddy: daily; MI counseling sessions: weekly
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: n=87 described for mean number and duration of MI counseling calls, but treatment completion not defined; study/assessment completion reported
Citation: Battaglia C, Peterson J, Whitfield E, et al. Integrating motivational interviewing into a home telehealth program for veterans with posttraumatic stress disorder who smoke: a randomized controlled trial. J Clin Psychol. 2016 Mar;72(3):194-206. doi: 10.1002/jclp.22252. PMID: 26783736.

Treatment Name: PTSD home telehealth care management program
Treatment Description: PTSD home telehealth care management services with a device called the Health Buddy, designed to help those with PTSD self-monitor and self-manage. This computer-like device is 12x8x4 inches with a LCD screen. Patient read information and four large buttons for responding to questions. Patient responses transmitted overnight to a secure data center and the next day's curriculum was downloaded to device. Control nurse care managers read patients responses daily, monitored changes in health status, placed outreach phone calls to patients with urgent needs, and coordinated care with primary medical and/or mental health providers.
Citation: Battaglia C, Peterson J, Whitfield E, et al. Integrating motivational interviewing into a home telehealth program for veterans with posttraumatic stress disorder who smoke: a randomized controlled trial. J Clin Psychol. 2016 Mar;72(3):194-206. doi: 10.1002/jclp.22252. PMID: 26783736.

Treatment Description: Multicomponent intervention consisting of Flinders Program, usual care, self-help materials, and optional participation in the Stanford Chronic Disease Self-Management group program.
Frequency: Varied (RN visits at 1, 3, 6, 9 months with phone calls at 4.5 and 7.5 months; standard group weekly over 2.5 hours for 6 weeks)
Citation: Battersby MW, Beattie J, Pols RG, et al. A randomised controlled trial of the Flinders Program™ of chronic condition management in Vietnam veterans with co-morbid alcohol misuse, and psychiatric and medical conditions. Aust N Z J Psychiatry. 2013 May;47(5):451-62. doi: 10.1177/0004867412471977. PMID: 23307806.

Treatment Description: Services available included "crisis intervention, alcohol-related education and counselling, pharmacological interventions, and cognitive behavioural and group pro- grams."
Citation: Battersby MW, Beattie J, Pols RG, et al. A randomised controlled trial of the Flinders Program™ of chronic condition management in Vietnam veterans with co-morbid alcohol misuse, and psychiatric and medical conditions. Aust N Z J Psychiatry. 2013 May;47(5):451-62. doi: 10.1177/0004867412471977. PMID: 23307806.

Treatment Description: Based on Blanchard and Hickling's individual CBT with modifications: treatment extended; detailed manual developed to standardize treatment; imaginal exposure assigned as homework and exposure to target trauma (MVA) conducted in writing; emphasis placed on teaching the principles of extinction to facilitate exposure during homework; treatment delivered by two therapists. Included: psychoeducation; exposure; mindfulness meditation; progressive muscle relaxation; cognitive therapy interventions and assertion training; behavioral activation; and, relapse prevention training.
Citation: Beck JG, Coffey SF, Foy DW, et al. Group cognitive behavior therapy for chronic posttraumatic stress disorder: an initial randomized pilot study. Behav Ther. 2009 Mar;40(1):82-92. doi: 10.1016/j.beth.2008.01.003. PMID: 19187819.

Treatment Description: Telephone contact by project coordinator using structured script to assess PTSD symptomatology and suicidality; minimal support provided; no active intervention administered.
Citation: Beck JG, Coffey SF, Foy DW, et al. Group cognitive behavior therapy for chronic posttraumatic stress disorder: an initial randomized pilot study. Behav Ther. 2009 Mar;40(1):82-92. doi: 10.1016/j.beth.2008.01.003. PMID: 19187819.

Treatment Name: Trauma-focused psychotherapy with music and imagery
Treatment Description: Trauma-focused adapation of the Bonny Method of Guided Imagery and Music; focuses on spontaneous imagery stimulated by listening to music in an altered state of consciousness. Sessions included verbal communication and optional 5-20 minutes of music and imagery work, and were followed by verbal processing with the therapist. Also received standard therapy following best-practice guidelines for PTSD treatment; includes elements of trauma-focused CBT, psychodynamic, and narrative approaches
Treatment Duration Detail: Supplemental treatment sessions allowed, up to 20 sessions total
Psychotherapy Sessions Completed Detail:
Received 16 sessions: 68.4%



Received 17-20 sessions: 26.3%



Received 12-15 sessions: 0%
Trauma Detail (Study level): Terrorism/political violence/forced displacement; Other (child abuse, unspecified); Other (adult abuse, unspecified)
Citation: Beck BD, Meyer SL, Simonsen E, et al. Music therapy was noninferior to verbal standard treatment of traumatized refugees in mental health care: results from a randomized clinical trial. Eur J Psychotraumatol. 2021 Jul 6;12(1):1930960. doi: 10.1080/20008198.2021.1930960. PMID: 34285768.

Treatment Description: Standard therapy following best-practice guidelines for PTSD treatment; includes elements of trauma-focused CBT, psychodynamic, and narrative approaches
Treatment Duration Detail: Supplemental treatment sessions allowed, up to 20 sessions total
Psychotherapy Sessions Completed Detail:
Received 16 sessions: 17.1%



Received 17-20 sessions: 31.4%



Received 12-15 sessions: 14.3%
Trauma Detail (Study level): Terrorism/political violence/forced displacement; Other (child abuse, unspecified); Other (adult abuse, unspecified)
Citation: Beck BD, Meyer SL, Simonsen E, et al. Music therapy was noninferior to verbal standard treatment of traumatized refugees in mental health care: results from a randomized clinical trial. Eur J Psychotraumatol. 2021 Jul 6;12(1):1930960. doi: 10.1080/20008198.2021.1930960. PMID: 34285768.

Treatment Description: Antidepressant with a monocyclic aminoketone structure and weak norepinephrine and dopamine reuptake inhibitor.
Dose: 100 to 300 mg total daily dose; titration: 100 mg for first 2 weeks, then if indicated, dosing increased to 100 mg twice daily. At week 4, if indicated, dosing increased to 150 mg twice daily
Dose at Study End Point Mean: 300 mg for completers, 180 mg for noncompleters
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, child sexual abuse, child physical abuse, intimate partner violence, rape/sexual assault, accidents, illness/medical procedure, other (homicide, death/suicide of a loved one)
Citation: Becker ME, Hertzberg MA, Moore SD, et al. A placebo-controlled trial of bupropion SR in the treatment of chronic posttraumatic stress disorder. J Clin Psychopharmacol. 2007 Apr;27(2):193-7. doi: 10.1097/JCP.0b013e318032eaed. PMID: 17414245.

Treatment Description: Placebo
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, child sexual abuse, child physical abuse, intimate partner violence, rape/sexual assault, accidents, illness/medical procedure, other (homicide, death/suicide of a loved one)
Citation: Becker ME, Hertzberg MA, Moore SD, et al. A placebo-controlled trial of bupropion SR in the treatment of chronic posttraumatic stress disorder. J Clin Psychopharmacol. 2007 Apr;27(2):193-7. doi: 10.1097/JCP.0b013e318032eaed. PMID: 17414245.

Treatment Name: Trauma Management Therapy with Exposure Therapy
Standardized Treatment Name: Trauma Management Therapy with exposure therapy
Treatment Description: Intensive exposure therapy including imaginal and in vivo exposure. Social and emotional rehabilitation involves general social skills training with anger management skills
Session Length:
Individual exposure sessions: NR







Group social and emotional rehabilitation sessions: 90 minutes
Frequency:
Individual exposure sessions: 3 times weekly for 5 weeks







Group social and emotional rehabilitation sessions: twice weekly for 2 weeks, then once weekly for 10 weeks (14 total sessions)
Completed Treatment Definition: completing all individual exposure sessions and 75% of group sessions
Citation: Beidel DC, Frueh BC, Uhde TW, et al. Multicomponent behavioral treatment for chronic combat-related posttraumatic stress disorder: a randomized controlled trial. J Anxiety Disord. 2011 Mar;25(2):224-31. doi: 10.1016/j.janxdis.2010.09.006. PMID: 20951543.

Treatment Description: Intensive exposure therapy including imaginal and in vivo exposure, then therapist lead group psychoeducation and traditional "rap" group sessions where participants share experiences and garner support from other group members
Session Length:
Individual exposure sessions: NR







Group psychoeducation sessions: 90 minutes
Frequency:
Individual exposure sessions: 3 times weekly for 5 weeks







Group social and emotional rehabilitation sessions: twice weekly for 2 weeks, then once weekly for 10 weeks (14 total sessions)
Completed Treatment Definition: completing all individual exposure sessions and 75% of group sessions
Citation: Beidel DC, Frueh BC, Uhde TW, et al. Multicomponent behavioral treatment for chronic combat-related posttraumatic stress disorder: a randomized controlled trial. J Anxiety Disord. 2011 Mar;25(2):224-31. doi: 10.1016/j.janxdis.2010.09.006. PMID: 20951543.

Treatment Description: Training protocol individualized using NeuroGuide's Symptom Checklist-Neural Network Match method, with 3 networks and 5 metrics for each participant. Audiovisual feedback by participant watching a movie and the screen and volume zoom in/out based on physiological measures and set thresholds (used Zukor Media Player). Reward provision used Z-Tunes method with 2 selection criteria: 1) 70% of targeted metrics within set z-score range; 2) average of remaining 30% were moving in direction of z=0 (negative slope); z-score threshold adjusted during each session for reward rate of 24 to 36 rewards per minute.
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: Final sample includes only participants who completed the study, unclear if all participants completed treatment
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, rape/sexual assault, community/school violence, illness/medical procedure, natural or manmade disasters, child other abuse, other ("work-related trauma [e.g. first responders]")
Citation: Bell AN, Moss D, Kallmeyer RJ. Healing the neurophysiological roots of trauma: a controlled study examining loreta z-score neurofeedback and HRV biofeedback for chronic PTSD. NeuroRegulation. 2019;6(2):54-70. doi: 10.15540/nr.6.2.54.

Treatment Description: Participants guided to breathe at resonant frequency and increase heartrate variability metrics using audiovisual feedback (participant watching a movie and the screen and volume zoom in/out based on physiological measures and set thresholds, used Zukor Media Player) and breath pacer on training screen.
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: Final sample includes only participants who completed the study, unclear if all participants completed treatment
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, rape/sexual assault, community/school violence, illness/medical procedure, natural or manmade disasters, child other abuse, other ("work-related trauma [e.g. first responders]")
Citation: Bell AN, Moss D, Kallmeyer RJ. Healing the neurophysiological roots of trauma: a controlled study examining loreta z-score neurofeedback and HRV biofeedback for chronic PTSD. NeuroRegulation. 2019;6(2):54-70. doi: 10.15540/nr.6.2.54.

Treatment Description: Taught in same format as offered in the community; no modifications to address PTSD symptoms specifically. Comprised of an introductory lecture, personal interview, 4 core instruction sessions (individual followed by 3 group sessions over 4 consecutive days), then weekly group sessions. Daily meditation at home encouraged.
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: additional information: 85% completed at least 3 additional refresher sessions (total of 8 TM sessions)
Psychotherapy Sessions Completed Detail: 85% completed at least 8 sessions (not defined as treatment completion)
Trauma Detail (Study level): Combat-related; Rape/sexual assault; Illness/medical procedure; Natural or manmade disasters; Other (other traumatic event)
Citation: Bellehsen M, Stoycheva V, Cohen BH, et al. A pilot randomized controlled trial of transcendental meditation as treatment for posttraumatic stress disorder in veterans. J Trauma Stress. 2021 Mar 18;18:18. doi: 10.1002/jts.22665. PMID: 33734493.

Treatment Description: Not described. Control group was offered an opportunity to learn transcendental mediation after study participation.
Trauma Detail (Study level): Combat-related; Rape/sexual assault; Illness/medical procedure; Natural or manmade disasters; Other (other traumatic event)
Citation: Bellehsen M, Stoycheva V, Cohen BH, et al. A pilot randomized controlled trial of transcendental meditation as treatment for posttraumatic stress disorder in veterans. J Trauma Stress. 2021 Mar 18;18:18. doi: 10.1002/jts.22665. PMID: 33734493.

Standardized Treatment Name: Imagery rehearsal training (IRT) + Trauma-focused cognitive behavioral therapy (TF-CBT)
Treatment Description: Imagery rehearsal therapy sessions intended to alter the association between sleep and nightmares by rehearsing an alternate dream script in the daytime; followed by series of CBT sessions that included exposure to traumatic memories and to feared objects, activities and situations
Session Length: Session length: 60 minutes for imagery rehearsal; 60 to 90 minutes for CBT
Trauma Detail (Study level): child sexual abuse, rape/sexual assault
Citation: Belleville G, Dube-Frenette M, Rousseau A. Efficacy of imagery rehearsal therapy and cognitive behavioral therapy in sexual assault victims with posttraumatic stress disorder: a randomized controlled trial. J Trauma Stress. 2018 Aug;31(4):591-601. doi: 10.1002/jts.22306. PMID: 30070398.

Treatment Description: CBT sessions included exposure to traumatic memories and to feared objects, activities and situations. Sessions followed a 5-week waiting period including weekly check-in phone calls of about 5 minutes' duration.
Trauma Detail (Study level): child sexual abuse, rape/sexual assault
Citation: Belleville G, Dube-Frenette M, Rousseau A. Efficacy of imagery rehearsal therapy and cognitive behavioral therapy in sexual assault victims with posttraumatic stress disorder: a randomized controlled trial. J Trauma Stress. 2018 Aug;31(4):591-601. doi: 10.1002/jts.22306. PMID: 30070398.

Treatment Description: Therapist provided same psychoeducation as control group, explaining PTSD-related symptoms and dysfunctions that frequently occur. Patient, assisted by the therapist, construct a chronological report of his own biography with special focus on traumatic experience.
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: abstract and "No refusals to participate or dropouts were recorded"
Citation: Bichescu D, Neuner F, Schauer M, et al. Narrative exposure therapy for political imprisonment-related chronic posttraumatic stress disorder and depression. Behav Res Ther. 2007 Sep;45(9):2212-20. doi: 10.1016/j.brat.2006.12.006. PMID: 17288990.

Treatment Description: Therapist explain PTSD-related symptoms and dysfunctions that frequently occur, no further treatment offered
Treatment Duration Detail: Single session; posttreatment assessment at 6 months
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: abstract and "No refusals to participate or dropouts were recorded"
Citation: Bichescu D, Neuner F, Schauer M, et al. Narrative exposure therapy for political imprisonment-related chronic posttraumatic stress disorder and depression. Behav Res Ther. 2007 Sep;45(9):2212-20. doi: 10.1016/j.brat.2006.12.006. PMID: 17288990.

Treatment Name: Multimodular motion-assisted memory desensitization and reconsolidation
Standardized Treatment Name: Multi-modular motion-assisted memory desensitization and reconsolidation (3MDR)
Treatment Description: 3MDR is "based on known therapeutic principles of virtual reality exposure therapy and eye movement desensitization and reprocessing (EMDR), embedded in a novel context in which the patient walks on a treadmill whilst immersing in and interacting with a series of self-selected images that are displayed on a large screen"; study treatment protocol involved projection of purpose-built tunnels to walk in and projection of self-selected digital pictures integrated into the software used for treatment.
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: Received allocated intervention (n=21) minus discontinued intervention (n=11)
Trauma Detail (Study level): Combat-related, Rape/sexual assault, Community/school violence, Other ("severe human suffering", "serious injury, harm or death you caused to someone", "fire or explosion", "exposure to a war zone, sudden violent death, sudden unexpected death of smoeone close to you", "captivity")
Citation: Bisson JI, van Deursen R, Hannigan B, Kitchiner N, Barawi K, Jones K, Pickles T, Skipper J, Young C, Abbott LR, van Gelderen M, Nijdam MJ, Vermetten E. Randomized controlled trial of multi-modular motion-assisted memory desensitization and reconsolidation (3MDR) for male military veterans with treatment-resistant post-traumatic stress disorder. Acta Psychiatr Scand. 2020 Aug;142(2):141-151. doi: 10.1111/acps.13200. Epub 2020 Jun 28. PMID: 32495381.

Treatment Description: Waitlist for 12 weeks, then participants received experimental treatment (multimodular motion-assisted memory desensitization and reconsolidation)
Trauma Detail (Study level): Combat-related, Rape/sexual assault, Community/school violence, Other ("severe human suffering", "serious injury, harm or death you caused to someone", "fire or explosion", "exposure to a war zone, sudden violent death, sudden unexpected death of smoeone close to you", "captivity")
Citation: Bisson JI, van Deursen R, Hannigan B, Kitchiner N, Barawi K, Jones K, Pickles T, Skipper J, Young C, Abbott LR, van Gelderen M, Nijdam MJ, Vermetten E. Randomized controlled trial of multi-modular motion-assisted memory desensitization and reconsolidation (3MDR) for male military veterans with treatment-resistant post-traumatic stress disorder. Acta Psychiatr Scand. 2020 Aug;142(2):141-151. doi: 10.1111/acps.13200. Epub 2020 Jun 28. PMID: 32495381.

Treatment Description: 8-step online guided self-help program (using Spring web-based program), including "psychoeducation, grounding techniques, management of anxiety, behavioural activation, imaginal exposure, cognitive restructuring, in vivo exposure, and prevention of relapse." Audio narrated with keywords and images displayed; interactive, user input determines feedback. Tools include building a fear ladder and writing a trauma narrative. Therapist meets with patient at start of treatment, with 4 subsequent meetings for guidance and review, usually in person. Four telephone or email contacts between sessions.
Session Length: 1 hour for first session, 30 minutes for later sessions
Treatment Duration Detail: Guided internet program took "about 8 weeks," with one session with therapist at the start and 4 subsequent sessions; end of treatment assessment at 16 weeks post-randomization to match arm B
Psychotherapy Sessions Completed Detail: "Average" of 5 sessions, IQR 3 to 5; average 208.4 (SD 69.3) minutes of contact with therapist; 5 participants attended no sessions
Trauma Detail (Study level): Child physical abuse; Child sexual abuse; Rape/sexual assault; Accidents; Illness/medical procedure; Community/school violence; Natural or manmade disasters; Other ("Serious incident not transportation; Sudden unexpected death of someone close; Sudden violent death; Life threatening injury; Captivity; Severe human suffering; Serious injury, harm, or death caused to someone; Other unwanted sexual experience; Any other stressful event or experience")
Citation: Bisson JI, Ariti C, Cullen K, et al. Guided, internet based, cognitive behavioural therapy for post-traumatic stress disorder: pragmatic, multicentre, randomised controlled non-inferiority trial (RAPID). BMJ. 2022;377:e069405. doi: 10.1136/bmj-2021-069405. PMID: 35710124.

Treatment Description: Cognitive therapy for PTSD; up to 12 sessions, with assignments between sessions, including modifying negative appraisals, discussing trauma memories, stopping unhelpful behaviors and cognitive strategies, and "when possible, visiting the site of the trauma with the therapist to update the trauma memory."
Treatment Duration Detail: Up to 12 weekly sessions; end of treatment assessment at 16 weeks post-randomization (allowing  extra time for participants to complete sessions)
Completed Treatment Definition: Completing ≥8 sessions or judged to need <8 sessions
Psychotherapy Sessions Completed Detail: "Average" of 9 sessions, IQR 6 to 12; average 767.0 (SD 278.2) minutes of contact with therapist; 3 participants attended no sessions
Trauma Detail (Study level): Child physical abuse; Child sexual abuse; Rape/sexual assault; Accidents; Illness/medical procedure; Community/school violence; Natural or manmade disasters; Other ("Serious incident not transportation; Sudden unexpected death of someone close; Sudden violent death; Life threatening injury; Captivity; Severe human suffering; Serious injury, harm, or death caused to someone; Other unwanted sexual experience; Any other stressful event or experience")
Citation: Bisson JI, Ariti C, Cullen K, et al. Guided, internet based, cognitive behavioural therapy for post-traumatic stress disorder: pragmatic, multicentre, randomised controlled non-inferiority trial (RAPID). BMJ. 2022;377:e069405. doi: 10.1136/bmj-2021-069405. PMID: 35710124.

Arm N Randomized Detail: 78 allocated to intervention after psychoeducation session; 21 excluded due to not meeting IES-R criteria (no assessment done or score <33)
Treatment Description:
Group traumatic episode protocol (G-TEP); uses bilateral stimulation and "aims to treat a traumatic episode in order to reduce traumatic stress, promote adaptive treatment, build resilience and prevent post-traumatic complications". Based on the Adaptive
Information Processing theoretical model and the 8 phases of EMDR processing.
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: denominator is N allocated and not excluded for IES score (N=57)
Citation: Bizouerne C, Dozio E, Dlasso E, et al. Randomized controlled trial: Comparing the effectiveness of brief group cognitive behavioural therapy and group eye movement desensitisation and reprocessing interventions for PTSD in internally displaced persons, administered by paraprofessionals in Northern Iraq. Eur J Trauma Dissociation. 2023;7(4) doi: 10.1016/j.ejtd.2023.100362.

Arm N Randomized Detail: 77 allocated to intervention after psychoeducation session; 24 excluded due to not meeting IES-R criteria (no assessment done or score <33)
Treatment Description: Group-based, trauma-focused cognitive behavior therapy adapted to the cultural and contextual specificities of Kurdistan
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: denominator is N allocated and not excluded for IES score (N=53)
Citation: Bizouerne C, Dozio E, Dlasso E, et al. Randomized controlled trial: Comparing the effectiveness of brief group cognitive behavioural therapy and group eye movement desensitisation and reprocessing interventions for PTSD in internally displaced persons, administered by paraprofessionals in Northern Iraq. Eur J Trauma Dissociation. 2023;7(4) doi: 10.1016/j.ejtd.2023.100362.

Treatment Description: Manualized treatment with emphasis on helping the patient understand PTSD as a reaction to trauma and to normalize patient's view of his/her symptoms. Treatment included progressive muscle relaxation, reading aloud description of the MVA, in vivo exposure, and behavioral activation to counteract the numbing symptoms
Treatment Duration Detail: planned 8 to 12 sessions total with an expected mode of 10
Citation: Blanchard EB, Hickling EJ, Devineni T, et al. A controlled evaluation of cognitive behavioural therapy for posttraumatic stress in motor vehicle accident survivors. Behav Res Ther. 2003 Jan;41(1):79-96.  PMID: 12488121.

Treatment Description: Manualized treatment with emphasis on helping the patient understand PTSD as a reaction to trauma and to normalize patient's view of his/her symptoms. Therapist provided support on issues raised, including interpersonal or relationship issues, work issues, etc.
Treatment Duration Detail: planned 8 to 12 sessions total with an expected mode of 10
Citation: Blanchard EB, Hickling EJ, Devineni T, et al. A controlled evaluation of cognitive behavioural therapy for posttraumatic stress in motor vehicle accident survivors. Behav Res Ther. 2003 Jan;41(1):79-96.  PMID: 12488121.

Treatment Description: Waitlist
Citation: Blanchard EB, Hickling EJ, Devineni T, et al. A controlled evaluation of cognitive behavioural therapy for posttraumatic stress in motor vehicle accident survivors. Behav Res Ther. 2003 Jan;41(1):79-96.  PMID: 12488121.

Standardized Treatment Name: Acceptance and Commitment Therapy (ACT) + expressive writing
Treatment Description: Participants listened to audio recording that included an acceptance-based rationale and a guided mindfulness exercise. Participants then completed 2 expressive writing exercises
Citation: Boals A, Murrell AR, Berntsen D, et al. Experimentally reducing event centrality using a modified expressive writing intervention. J Contextual Behav Sci. 2015 Oct;4(4):269-76. doi: 10.1016/j.jcbs.2015.10.001.

Treatment Description: Participants listened to audio recording that included CBT rationale and a guided imagery exercise. Participants then completed 2 expressive writing exercises
Citation: Boals A, Murrell AR, Berntsen D, et al. Experimentally reducing event centrality using a modified expressive writing intervention. J Contextual Behav Sci. 2015 Oct;4(4):269-76. doi: 10.1016/j.jcbs.2015.10.001.

Treatment Description: Participants listened to audio recording on history of baseball then completed 2 writing sessions about time management
Citation: Boals A, Murrell AR, Berntsen D, et al. Experimentally reducing event centrality using a modified expressive writing intervention. J Contextual Behav Sci. 2015 Oct;4(4):269-76. doi: 10.1016/j.jcbs.2015.10.001.

Treatment Description: Magnetic stimulation applied to the left Dorsolateral Pre-frontal Cortex
Dose: 20 Hz at 80% of patient's motor threshold; 1600 pulses per session
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: Study reports on dropouts, states all dropouts were due to travel difficulty for treatments; remainder appear to be treatment completers
Trauma Detail (Study level): rape/sexual assault, community/school violence, other (death or severe disease of relative, perceived physical harm/psychological distress)
Citation: Boggio PS, Rocha M, Oliveira MO, et al. Noninvasive brain stimulation with high-frequency and low-intensity repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation treatment for posttraumatic stress disorder. J Clin Psychiatry. 2010 Aug;71(8):992-9. doi: 10.4088/JCP.08m04638blu. PMID: 20051219.

Treatment Description: Magnetic stimulation applied to the right dorsolateral prefrontal cortex
Dose: 21 Hz at 80% of patient's motor threshold; 1600 pulses per session
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: Study reports on dropouts, states all dropouts were due to travel difficulty for treatments; remainder appear to be treatment completers
Trauma Detail (Study level): rape/sexual assault, community/school violence, other (death or severe disease of relative, perceived physical harm/psychological distress)
Citation: Boggio PS, Rocha M, Oliveira MO, et al. Noninvasive brain stimulation with high-frequency and low-intensity repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation treatment for posttraumatic stress disorder. J Clin Psychiatry. 2010 Aug;71(8):992-9. doi: 10.4088/JCP.08m04638blu. PMID: 20051219.

Treatment Description: Administered the same TMS methodology as intervention groups only without magnetic stimulation from the coil. The sham TMS had a small electrical stimulator to mimic scalp sensation.
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: Study reports on dropouts, states all dropouts were due to travel difficulty for treatments; remainder appear to be treatment completers
Trauma Detail (Study level): rape/sexual assault, community/school violence, other (death or severe disease of relative, perceived physical harm/psychological distress)
Citation: Boggio PS, Rocha M, Oliveira MO, et al. Noninvasive brain stimulation with high-frequency and low-intensity repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation treatment for posttraumatic stress disorder. J Clin Psychiatry. 2010 Aug;71(8):992-9. doi: 10.4088/JCP.08m04638blu. PMID: 20051219.

Standardized Treatment Name: Dialectical Behavior Therapy (DBT) + Trauma-focused cognitive behavioral therapy (TF-CBT)
Treatment Description: Integrated trauma-focused cognitive and exposure-based interventions described by Foa et al (2007) and Ehlers & Clark (2000). Intervention included individual exposure-based treatment plus the following weekly group treatments: skills training, self-esteem intervention, mindfulness sessions, PTSD-specific psychoeducation, and non-specific group interventions (music therapy, art therapy)
Session Length:
Individual sessions: 45 minutes







Group sessions: 90 minutes skills training, 60 minutes self-esteem intervention, 25 minutes mindfulness, 60 minutes PTSD-specific psychoeducation, and 90 minutes non-specific interventions
Frequency:
Individual sessions: twice weekly







Group sessions: weekly
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: flow diagram in supplemental materials
Citation: Bohus MJ, Dyer AS, Priebe K, et al. Dialectical behaviour therapy for post-traumatic stress disorder after childhood sexual abuse in patients with and without borderline personality disorder: a randomised controlled trial. Psychother Psychosom. 2013 Jun;82(4):221-33. doi: 10.1159/000348451. PMID: 23712109.

Treatment Description: Participants received 6 months of any treatment of their choice except DBT-PTSD
Citation: Bohus MJ, Dyer AS, Priebe K, et al. Dialectical behaviour therapy for post-traumatic stress disorder after childhood sexual abuse in patients with and without borderline personality disorder: a randomised controlled trial. Psychother Psychosom. 2013 Jun;82(4):221-33. doi: 10.1159/000348451. PMID: 23712109.

Arm N Randomized Detail: 103 randomized but 5 later found ineligible and excluded
Standardized Treatment Name: Dialectical Behavior Therapy (DBT) + Trauma-focused cognitive behavioral therapy (TF-CBT)
Treatment Description: DBT for PTSD based on standard DBT with additional trauma-focused cognitive-behavioral interventions, and techniques drawn from compassion-focused therapy and acceptance and commitment therapy. Includes identifying patients' typical escape strategies in response to trauma-related stimuli, skills-assisted exposure to traumatic memories, and exercises on acceptance of the past and grief. Individual therapy, plus homework and telephone consultation as needed. Up to 45 weekly sessions over a year, followed by a booster phase of 3 monthly sessions.
Frequency: Weekly for a year then monthly for 3 months
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: n=24 discontinued intervention, n=1 lost to follow-up before receiving intervention
Trauma Detail (Study level): Child physical abuse, Child sexual abuse
Citation: Bohus M, Kleindienst N, Hahn C, et al. Dialectical behavior therapy for posttraumatic stress disorder (DBT-PTSD) compared with cognitive processing therapy (CPT) in complex presentations of PTSD in women survivors of childhood abuse: a randomized clinical trial.
