JAMA Psychiatry. 2020 Jul 22;22:22. doi: 10.1001/jamapsychiatry.2020.2148. PMID: 32697288.

Arm N Randomized Detail: 97 randomized but 2 later found ineligible and excluded
Treatment Description: Trauma-focused cognitive therapy attempting to challenge dysfunctional trauma-associated cognitions and emotion. Follows a session by session protocol including original 12 CPT sessions and exploring themes such as trust, safety, and guilt. Later sessions identify and challenge "stuck points" not resolved in previous sessions. Individual therapy, plus homework and telephone consultation as needed. Up to 45 weekly sessions over a year, followed by a booster phase of 3 monthly sessions.
Frequency: Weekly for a year then monthly for 3 months
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: n=32 discontinued intervention, n=5 lost to follow-up before receiving intervention
Trauma Detail (Study level): Child physical abuse, Child sexual abuse
Citation: Bohus M, Kleindienst N, Hahn C, et al. Dialectical behavior therapy for posttraumatic stress disorder (DBT-PTSD) compared with cognitive processing therapy (CPT) in complex presentations of PTSD in women survivors of childhood abuse: a randomized clinical trial. JAMA Psychiatry. 2020 Jul 22;22:22. doi: 10.1001/jamapsychiatry.2020.2148. PMID: 32697288.

Treatment Description: Computerized cognitive training designed to prevent interfering thoughts from entering consciousness and removing them once they come to mind by improving cognitive performance on a working memory capacity test involving testing of sentence accuracy and memory under a condition of high proactive interference with item memoranda that were words for all trials; 3 blocks of training (45 trials) completed per session.
Completed Treatment Definition: Received intervention and did not discontinue intervention
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: Flow diagram; study also reports for completer sample but this appears to be assessment/measure completion
Citation: Bomyea J, Stein MB, Lang AJ. Interference control training for PTSD: A randomized controlled trial of a novel computer-based intervention. J Anxiety Disord. 2015 Aug;34:33-42. doi: 10.1016/j.janxdis.2015.05.010. PMID: 26114901.

Treatment Description: Computerized cognitive training designed to prevent interfering thoughts from entering consciousness and removing them once they come to mind by improving cognitive performance on a working memory capacity test involving testing of sentence accuracy and memory under a condition of low proactive interference with item memoranda that alternated between words and numbers every 3 trials; 3 blocks of training (45 trials) completed per session.
Completed Treatment Definition: Received intervention and did not discontinue intervention
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: Flow diagram; study also reports for completer sample but this appears to be assessment/measure completion
Citation: Bomyea J, Stein MB, Lang AJ. Interference control training for PTSD: A randomized controlled trial of a novel computer-based intervention. J Anxiety Disord. 2015 Aug;34:33-42. doi: 10.1016/j.janxdis.2015.05.010. PMID: 26114901.

Treatment Name: High interference control (HIC) working memory training (WMT)
Treatment Description: Reading span task which requires participants to remember item stimuli presented while doing a secondary problem solving or processing task. All items to be remembered were from the same category, requiring higher interference control but the same amount of overall working memory capacity. All stimuli were affectively neutral. Participants completed 45 self-paced trials each visit.
Citation: Bomyea J, Caudle MM, Bartolovich AL, Simmons AN, Jak AJ, Golshan S. Randomized controlled trial of computerized working memory training for Veterans with PTSD. J Psychiatr Res. 2025 Jan;181:350-357. doi: 10.1016/j.jpsychires.2024.11.072. Epub 2024 Nov 29. PMID: 39642474.

Treatment Name: Low interference control (LIC) working memory training (WMT)
Treatment Description: Reading span task which requires participants to remember item stimuli presented while doing a secondary problem solving or processing task. All items to be remembered alternated categories every three trials, requiring less interference control but the same amount of overall working memory capacity. All stimuli were affectively neutral. Participants completed 45 self-paced trials each visit.
Citation: Bomyea J, Caudle MM, Bartolovich AL, Simmons AN, Jak AJ, Golshan S. Randomized controlled trial of computerized working memory training for Veterans with PTSD. J Psychiatr Res. 2025 Jan;181:350-357. doi: 10.1016/j.jpsychires.2024.11.072. Epub 2024 Nov 29. PMID: 39642474.

Arm N Randomized Detail: Stage 1 randomization
Treatment Description: THC 12% and CBD <0.05%; independent testing showed THC 9% instead. Participants provided with 37.8 grams (1.8 grams/day) for the three-week ad libitum treatment period along with a metal pipe for treatment delivery (smoked). Unused drug returned to clinic weekly for measurement, with option for patients to use it in an open-label Stage 3.
Dose: Ad libitum self-administration (smoked) up to maximum 1.8 g/day
Dose at Study End Point Detail: mean amount used in total over the 3-week treatment period
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, other (not specified)
Citation: Bonn-Miller MO, Sisley S, Riggs P, et al. The short-term impact of 3 smoked cannabis preparations versus placebo on PTSD symptoms: A randomized cross-over clinical trial. PLoS One. 2021;16(3):e0246990. doi: 10.1371/journal.pone.0246990. PMID: 33730032.

Arm N Randomized Detail: Stage 1 randomization
Treatment Description: CBD 11% and THC 0.50%. Participants provided with 37.8 grams (1.8 grams/day) for the three-week ad libitum treatment period along with a metal pipe for treatment delivery (smoked). Unused drug returned to clinic weekly for measurement, with option for patients to use it in an open-label Stage 3.
Dose: Ad libitum self-administration (smoked) up to maximum 1.8 g/day

Dose: Ad libitum self-administration (smoked) up to maximum 1.8 g/day

Arm N Randomized Detail: Stage 1 randomization
Treatment Description: THC <0.03% and CBD <0.01%. Participants provided with 37.8 grams (1.8 grams/day) for the three-week ad libitum treatment period along with a metal pipe for treatment delivery (smoked). Unused drug returned to clinic weekly for measurement, with option for patients to use it in an open-label Stage 3.

Treatment Description: Education on PTSD symptoms and skills on how to choose and silently repeat a mantram - a word or phrase with spiritual associations chosen by the participant from a provided list. Repetition on Mantram is intended to train attention. Includes concepts of "slowing down" and "one-pointed attention". Used as a "pause button" for the mind to decrease reactivity to stress.
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: Provided for overall sample only, and unclear if delayed treatment group was considered as completers for waiting period or after receipt of intervention following waiting period; n/N not reported. "Eighty-six percent of participants, including the controls, completed the intervention and rated the program with “moderate to high” satisfaction." Study/assessment completion reported.
Citation: Bormann JE, Thorp S, Wetherell JL, et al. A spiritually based group intervention for combat veterans with posttraumatic stress disorder: feasibility study. J Holist Nurs. 2008 Jun;26(2):109-16. doi: 10.1177/0898010107311276. PMID: 18356284.

Treatment Description: Usual medical care with weekly or monthly case manager and/or primary care provider visits and medication management.
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: Provided for overall sample only, and unclear if delayed treatment group was considered as completers for waiting period or after receipt of intervention following waiting period; n/N not reported. "Eighty-six percent of participants, including the controls, completed the intervention and rated the program with “moderate to high” satisfaction." Study/assessment completion reported.
Citation: Bormann JE, Thorp S, Wetherell JL, et al. A spiritually based group intervention for combat veterans with posttraumatic stress disorder: feasibility study. J Holist Nurs. 2008 Jun;26(2):109-16. doi: 10.1177/0898010107311276. PMID: 18356284.

Treatment Description:
Mantram Repetition Program is a portable, meditation-based intervention that teaches concentrative meditation, slowing down, and one-pointed attention for training attention and regulating emotion; group sessions contained lectures, discussion, sharing, questions and answers, and homework.







TAU consisted of case management as needed to evaluate mental health status and to monitor treatments
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: Reports study drop out only (did not complete assessments), also referred to as just "drop out" in text and unclear if this is also treatment drop out; drop out rate 7.04% (7/51)
Citation: Bormann JE, Thorp SR, Wetherell JL, et al. Meditation-based mantram intervention for veterans with posttraumatic stress disorder: A randomized trial. Psychol Trauma. 2013 May;5(3):259-67. doi: 10.1037/a0027522.

Treatment Description: Case management as needed to evaluate mental health status and to monitor treatments
Citation: Bormann JE, Thorp SR, Wetherell JL, et al. Meditation-based mantram intervention for veterans with posttraumatic stress disorder: A randomized trial. Psychol Trauma. 2013 May;5(3):259-67. doi: 10.1037/a0027522.

Treatment Description: Education on choosing a mantram (word or phrase with a spiritual meaning), slowing down thoughts, one-pointed attention for emotional self-regulation and relaxation. Instructions and in-session and out-of-session experiential homework. Applying skills for emotional self-regulation and symptom management (putting space between reactivity and behaviors). Discussion, storytelling, weekly assignments. Discuss obstacles to practicing and develop methods to sustain practicing.
Trauma Detail (Study level): "related to military service"
Citation: Bormann JE, Thorp SR, Smith E, et al. Individual treatment of posttraumatic stress disorder using mantram repetition: a randomized clinical trial. Am J Psychiatry. 2018 Oct 1;175(10):979-88. doi: 10.1176/appi.ajp.2018.17060611. PMID: 29921143.

Treatment Description: Supportive, present-focused, nondirective psychotherapy; manualized treatment. Discuss current problems and use problem-solving techniques. Record daily stressors in diary to use for discussion during sessions. Set goals for current and future treatment.
Trauma Detail (Study level): "related to military service"
Citation: Bormann JE, Thorp SR, Smith E, et al. Individual treatment of posttraumatic stress disorder using mantram repetition: a randomized clinical trial. Am J Psychiatry. 2018 Oct 1;175(10):979-88. doi: 10.1176/appi.ajp.2018.17060611. PMID: 29921143.

Treatment Description: Phased protocol: phase 1, patient recalls a trauma memory and is guided to imagine a different ending, such as someone intervening to stop the abuse; phase 2, patient as adult imagined as intervening; phase 3, patient re-experiences event as a child with adult intervening.
Treatment Duration Detail: 6 weeks, with 8 weeks permitted; stopping before 6 weeks allowed if site coordinator agreed treatment no longer necessary
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: completed imagery rescripting condition within 8 weeks
Trauma Detail (Study level): Child physical abuse; Child sexual abuse; Child other abuse; Intimate partner violence; Other ("serious injury/death"); Other (not described)
Citation: Boterhoven de Haan KL, Lee CW, Fassbinder E, et al. Imagery rescripting and eye movement desensitisation and reprocessing as treatment for adults with post-traumatic stress disorder from childhood trauma: randomised clinical trial. Br J Psychiatry. 2020 11;217(5):609-15. doi: 10.1192/bjp.2020.158. PMID: 32892758.

Treatment Description: Phased protocol including identifying key memory components of trauma to be processed, active trauma processing, and assessment of current triggers and anticipatory anxiety
Treatment Duration Detail: 6 weeks, with 8 weeks permitted; stopping before 6 weeks allowed if site coordinator agreed treatment no longer necessary
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: completed EMDR condition within 8 weeks
Trauma Detail (Study level): Child physical abuse; Child sexual abuse; Child other abuse; Intimate partner violence; Other ("serious injury/death"); Other (not described)
Citation: Boterhoven de Haan KL, Lee CW, Fassbinder E, et al. Imagery rescripting and eye movement desensitisation and reprocessing as treatment for adults with post-traumatic stress disorder from childhood trauma: randomised clinical trial. Br J Psychiatry. 2020 11;217(5):609-15. doi: 10.1192/bjp.2020.158. PMID: 32892758.

Treatment Description: Standard-length internet-based cognitive behavioral intervention guided by a therapist. Three components with 10 structured writing assignments: written imaginal exposure, describing traumatic event in detail (4 assignments); cognitive restructuring, reflecting on guilt, automatic cognitions, and unrealistic assumptions (4 assignments); and cognitive processing, including reflecting on the meaning of the trauma and social sharing (writing a supportive letter to oneself at the time of trauma) (2 assignments). Therapists (with experience in psychosocial counselling or bachelor's degree in psychology) gave instructions and written feedback on assignments, and were available by telephone for technical problems and emergencies.
Completed Treatment Percent Detail:
Of N=110 randomized



Of N=83 who started treatment, 77.1% completed ≥6 writing assignments
Trauma Detail (Study level): Rape/sexual assault; Other (sexual intercourse before age 18 with someone 5 years older; proximity to death); Other (NR)
Citation: Bottche M, Wagner B, Vohringer M, et al. Is only one cognitive technique also effective? Results from a randomized controlled trial of two different versions of an internet-based cognitive behavioural intervention for post-traumatic stress disorder in Arabic-speaking countries. Eur J Psychotraumatol. 2021 Jul 15;12(1):1943870. doi: 10.1080/20008198.2021.1943870. PMID: 34345377.

Treatment Description: Shorter internet-based cognitive behavioral intervention guided by a therapist. Two components with 6 structured writing assignments, excluding cognitive restructuring: written imaginal exposure, describing traumatic event in detail (4 assignments); and cognitive processing, including reflecting on the meaning of the trauma and social sharing (writing a supportive letter to oneself at the time of trauma) (2 assignments). Therapists (with experience in psychosocial counselling or bachelor's degree in psychology) gave instructions and written feedback on assignments, and were available by telephone for technical problems and emergencies.
Completed Treatment Percent Detail:
Of N=112 randomized



Of N=92 who started treatment, 82.6% completed 6 writing assignments
Trauma Detail (Study level): Rape/sexual assault; Other (sexual intercourse before age 18 with someone 5 years older; proximity to death); Other (NR)
Citation: Bottche M, Wagner B, Vohringer M, et al. Is only one cognitive technique also effective? Results from a randomized controlled trial of two different versions of an internet-based cognitive behavioural intervention for post-traumatic stress disorder in Arabic-speaking countries. Eur J Psychotraumatol. 2021 Jul 15;12(1):1943870. doi: 10.1080/20008198.2021.1943870. PMID: 34345377.

Treatment Name: Observed and  Experiential Integration - Switching component
Standardized Treatment Name: Observed and  Experiential Integration - Switching component
Treatment Description: Participant instructed to close his/her eyes and envision the traumatic incident. When patient experiences physical or emotional signs of distress, instruction is given to uncover the nondominant eye and cover the dominant eye. Dominant/nondominant eye is alternatingly covered or both uncovered.
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: Study did not provide specific information on treatment completion; there is no indication of any treatment dropouts, all participants included in analysis
Trauma Detail (Study level): rape/sexual assault, intimate partner violence, accidents, community/school violence
Citation: Bradshaw RA, McDonald MJ, Grace R, et al. A randomized clinical trial of Observed and Experiential Integration (OEI): a simple, innovative intervention for affect regulation in clients with PTSD. Traumatology (Tallahass Fla). 2014 Sep;20(3):161-71. doi: 10.1037/h0099401.

Trauma Detail (Study level): rape/sexual assault, intimate partner violence, accidents, community/school violence
Citation: Bradshaw RA, McDonald MJ, Grace R, et al. A randomized clinical trial of Observed and Experiential Integration (OEI): a simple, innovative intervention for affect regulation in clients with PTSD. Traumatology (Tallahass Fla). 2014 Sep;20(3):161-71. doi: 10.1037/h0099401.

Treatment Description: SSRI; flexible dosing titrated in 50-mg increments based on clinical response and tolerability at no less than weekly intervals. Followed a 2-week single-blind placebo run-in period.
Dose: 50 to 200 mg; titration: 25 mg for 1 week then increased to 50 mg, further increases in 50-mg increments with maximum 200 mg dose
Participant Adherence Definition: compliance monitored by counts of returned medication
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, rape/sexual assault, accidents, community/school violence, natural or manmade disasters, other (seeing someone hurt or die, kidnapping)
Citation: Brady K, Pearlstein T, Asnis GM, et al. Efficacy and safety of sertraline treatment of posttraumatic stress disorder: a randomized controlled trial. JAMA. 2000 Apr;283(14):1837-44. doi: 10.1001/jama.283.14.1837. PMID: 10770145.

Treatment Description: Matched placebo. Followed a 2-week single-blind placebo run-in period.
Participant Adherence Definition: compliance monitored by counts of returned medication
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, rape/sexual assault, accidents, community/school violence, natural or manmade disasters, other (seeing someone hurt or die, kidnapping)
Citation: Brady K, Pearlstein T, Asnis GM, et al. Efficacy and safety of sertraline treatment of posttraumatic stress disorder: a randomized controlled trial. JAMA. 2000 Apr;283(14):1837-44. doi: 10.1001/jama.283.14.1837. PMID: 10770145.

Standardized Treatment Name: Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) for alcohol use + sertraline
Treatment Description: SSR; 50 mg tablets. Also received weekly CBT targeting alcohol dependence.
Dose: 150 mg; titration: 50 mg for 2 days, 100 mg for 2 days, then 150 mg for the rest of the study
Participant Adherence Definition: 100 mg riboflavin tablets given with study drugs; also monitored by pill count
Trauma Detail (Study level): rape/sexual assault, accidents, community/school violence, other (childhood trauma not specified)
Citation: Brady KT, Sonne SC, Anton RF, et al. Sertraline in the treatment of co-occurring alcohol dependence and posttraumatic stress disorder. Alcohol Clin Exp Res. 2005 Mar;29(3):395-401. doi: 10.1097/01.ALC.0000156129.98265.57. PMID: 15770115.

Standardized Treatment Name: Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) for alcohol use
Treatment Description: Placebo tablets matched sertraline tablets. Also received weekly CBT targeting alcohol dependence.
Participant Adherence Definition: 100 mg riboflavin tablets given with study drugs; also monitored by pill count
Trauma Detail (Study level): rape/sexual assault, accidents, community/school violence, other (childhood trauma not specified)
Citation: Brady KT, Sonne SC, Anton RF, et al. Sertraline in the treatment of co-occurring alcohol dependence and posttraumatic stress disorder. Alcohol Clin Exp Res. 2005 Mar;29(3):395-401. doi: 10.1097/01.ALC.0000156129.98265.57. PMID: 15770115.

Treatment Description: Detailed narration of traumatic experiences that processes and contextualises traumatic memories and helps individuals to establish a coherent autobiographical narrative of their experiences. Three sessions of psychoeducation delivered prior to NET. Allowed up to 4 additional non-NET sessions to address urgent or risk issues arising during treatment. Goal of up to 20 sessions of NET.
Treatment Duration Detail:
mean timeframe for NET session delivery (220.6 days, SD 65.27)

maximum 20 sessions (range 13-26 sessions)
Citation: Brady F, Chisholm A, Walsh E, et al. Narrative exposure therapy for survivors of human trafficking: feasibility randomised controlled trial. BJPsych Open. 2021 Nov;7(6):e196. doi: 10.1192/bjo.2021.1029.

Treatment Description: Psychoeducation and waitlist. Three sessions of psychoeducation delivered by therapist or trained assistant psychologists prior to 5-month waitlist period.
Treatment Duration Detail: 5 months waiting period;  psychoeducation sessions before waiting period started
Citation: Brady F, Chisholm A, Walsh E, et al. Narrative exposure therapy for survivors of human trafficking: feasibility randomised controlled trial. BJPsych Open. 2021 Nov;7(6):e196. doi: 10.1192/bjo.2021.1029.

Arm N Randomized Detail: 7 assigned to alprazolam in first treatment period
Treatment Description: Benzodiazepine; titration over 2 weeks then steady dose for 3 weeks, followed by 2-week taper for patients taking alprazolam in first period (not included in treatment period)
Dose: 1.5 to 6 mg; titration: initiated at 1.5 mg, titrated over 2 weeks to maximum 6 mg
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, accidents, terrorism/political violence/forced displacement
Citation: Braun P, Greenberg D, Dasberg H, et al. Core symptoms of posttraumatic stress disorder unimproved by alprazolam treatment. J. Clin. Psychiatry. 1990 Jun;51(6):236-8.  PMID: 2189869.

Arm N Randomized Detail: 9 assigned to placebo in first treatment period
Treatment Description: Placebo
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, accidents, terrorism/political violence/forced displacement
Citation: Braun P, Greenberg D, Dasberg H, et al. Core symptoms of posttraumatic stress disorder unimproved by alprazolam treatment. J. Clin. Psychiatry. 1990 Jun;51(6):236-8.  PMID: 2189869.

Treatment Description: Mindfulness-based Stress Reduction based on Kabat-Zinn approach tailored to PTSD and veterans. Elements include body scan meditation, sitting meditation, hatha yoga via group sessions and home practice
Session Length: 2.5 hour sessions plus one 6-hour session during week 6
Completed Treatment Definition: completed the group and study procedures
Citation: Bremner JD, Mishra S, Campanella C, et al. A pilot study of the effects of mindfulness-based stress reduction on post-traumatic stress disorder symptoms and brain response to traumatic reminders of combat in Operation Enduring Freedom/Operation Iraqi Freedom combat veterans with post-traumatic stress disorder. Front Psychiatry. 2017 Aug 25;8:157. doi: 10.3389/fpsyt.2017.00157. PMID: 28890702.

Treatment Description: Psychoeducation and group support
Session Length: NR (same total number of hours as Mindfulness-based Stress Reduction group)
Completed Treatment Definition: completed the group and study procedures
Citation: Bremner JD, Mishra S, Campanella C, et al. A pilot study of the effects of mindfulness-based stress reduction on post-traumatic stress disorder symptoms and brain response to traumatic reminders of combat in Operation Enduring Freedom/Operation Iraqi Freedom combat veterans with post-traumatic stress disorder. Front Psychiatry. 2017 Aug 25;8:157. doi: 10.3389/fpsyt.2017.00157. PMID: 28890702.

Treatment Description: Transcutaneous vagus nerve stimulation on both sides using handheld VNS device applied to skin over cervical part of nerve, identified by palpation of carotid artery. Initial 3 days of treatment given by researcher and paired with exposure; exposure comprised of patient-made voice recordings retelling traumatic experiences. Day 1 included neutral and trauma scripts and VNS; Days 2 & 3 included mental stress (public speaking and mental arithmetic) and VNS. Patients self-administered treatment at home twice daily for 3 months with the addition of traumatic script twice a week.
Dose: 5kHz sine bursts, repeated at frequency 25 Hz; peak output 0 to 30V, increased to maximum tolerable without pain
Session Length: 5 minutes (2 minutes per side, 1 minute rest interval)
Trauma Detail (Study level): Combat-related; Child sexual abuse; Rape/sexual assault; Community/school violence; Other ("injury or death of someone close to them; "husband left for hockey game, never returned"; failed suicide; "mother attempted suicide multiple times in childhood")
Citation: Bremner JD, Wittbrodt MT, Gurel NZ, et al. Transcutaneous cervical vagal nerve stimulation in patients with posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD): a pilot study of effects on PTSD symptoms and interleukin-6 response to stress. J Affect Disord Rep. 2021 Dec;6:100190. doi: 10.1016/j.jadr.2021.100190. PMID: 34778863.

Treatment Name: Sham transcutaneous cervical vagal nerve stimulation
Treatment Description: Sham transcutaneous vagus nerve stimulation on both sides using handheld VNS device applied to skin over cervical part of nerve, identified by palpation of carotid artery. Initial 3 days of treatment given by researcher and paired with exposure; exposure comprised of patient-made voice recordings retelling traumatic experiences. Day 1 included neutral and trauma scripts and sham VNS; Days 2 & 3 included mental stress (public speaking and mental arithmetic) and sham VNS. Patients self-administered sham treatment at home twice daily for 3 months with the addition of traumatic script twice a week.
Dose: 0.2 Hz pulses producing a mild sensation; peak output 0 to 14V
Session Length: 5 minutes (2 minutes per side, 1 minute rest interval)
Trauma Detail (Study level): Combat-related; Child sexual abuse; Rape/sexual assault; Community/school violence; Other ("injury or death of someone close to them; "husband left for hockey game, never returned"; failed suicide; "mother attempted suicide multiple times in childhood")
Citation: Bremner JD, Wittbrodt MT, Gurel NZ, et al. Transcutaneous cervical vagal nerve stimulation in patients with posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD): a pilot study of effects on PTSD symptoms and interleukin-6 response to stress. J Affect Disord Rep. 2021 Dec;6:100190. doi: 10.1016/j.jadr.2021.100190. PMID: 34778863.

Treatment Description: Sessions with counsellor and using the PTSD Coach app. "The registered counsellor was trained in a standard support method (assisting with language and technology difficulties and not providing therapeutic support)." Sessions included review of the past week and homework, accessing and using selected portions of the application, and homework assignment. Participants were encouraged to use the app outside of sessions and to review material covered in the session. PTSD Coach app: free mobile application includes psychoeducation, symptom monitoring and management with 21 symptom management tools (e.g. mindfulness and stress management exercises), and encouragement to seek treatment if indicated.
Psychotherapy Sessions Completed Detail:
4 sessions: 87.50% (28/32)
3 sessions: 6.25% (2/32)
2 sessions:  6.25% (2/32)
PTSD Coach app usage ranged from 70 to 86% for any use during past week (assessed and reported for each session separately)
Trauma Detail (Study level): Rape/sexual assault; Accidents; Illness/medical procedure; Community/school violence; Other ("traumatic loss of loved one"; "life-threatening injury")
Citation: Brocker E, Olff M, Suliman S, et al. A counsellor-supported 'PTSD Coach' intervention versus enhanced Treatment-as-Usual in a resource-constrained setting: A randomised controlled trial. Glob Ment Health (Camb). 2024;11:e7. doi: 10.1017/gmh.2023.92. PMID: 38283877.

Treatment Description: Detailed referral letter provided for psychological support in primary care setting. Counsellor contacted clinics and arranged appointments, followed up with participants on treatment accessed, and tracked symptoms including suicidality.
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: After 4 week intervention period, 27% had received support or had scheduled appointments, 47% were still waiting for linkages to care at their local clinic and 23% were lost to follow-up
Trauma Detail (Study level): Rape/sexual assault; Accidents; Illness/medical procedure; Community/school violence; Other ("traumatic loss of loved one"; "life-threatening injury")
Citation: Brocker E, Olff M, Suliman S, et al. A counsellor-supported 'PTSD Coach' intervention versus enhanced Treatment-as-Usual in a resource-constrained setting: A randomised controlled trial. Glob Ment Health (Camb). 2024;11:e7. doi: 10.1017/gmh.2023.92. PMID: 38283877.

Treatment Description: After the patient has learned relaxation techniques, they are encouraged to re-experience the traumatic event. The patient is then confronted with the previously avoided stimuli, which beforehand are categorized in hierarchies, and learns skills to strengthen the feeling of control.
Trauma Detail (Study level): accidents, community/school violence, illness/medical procedure, other (loss of loved one, undefined)
Citation: Brom D, Kleber RJ, Defares PB. Brief psychotherapy for posttraumatic stress disorders. J Consult Clin Psychol. 1989;57(5):607-12.  PMID: 2571625.

Treatment Description: Treatment goal was to bring the patient in contact with the reality of the traumatic event and to bring about a decrease in the conditioned responses triggered by the event
Trauma Detail (Study level): accidents, community/school violence, illness/medical procedure, other (loss of loved one, undefined)
Citation: Brom D, Kleber RJ, Defares PB. Brief psychotherapy for posttraumatic stress disorders. J Consult Clin Psychol. 1989;57(5):607-12.  PMID: 2571625.

Treatment Description: Aim of this therapy is limited to the solving of the intrapsychic conflicts resulting from the traumatic experience, with the therapist playing an active role.
Trauma Detail (Study level): accidents, community/school violence, illness/medical procedure, other (loss of loved one, undefined)
Citation: Brom D, Kleber RJ, Defares PB. Brief psychotherapy for posttraumatic stress disorders. J Consult Clin Psychol. 1989;57(5):607-12.  PMID: 2571625.

Trauma Detail (Study level): accidents, community/school violence, illness/medical procedure, other (loss of loved one, undefined)
Citation: Brom D, Kleber RJ, Defares PB. Brief psychotherapy for posttraumatic stress disorders. J Consult Clin Psychol. 1989;57(5):607-12.  PMID: 2571625.

Treatment Description: Body awareness with psychotherapy
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: "completed the process"; n=5 discontinued during treatment period
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, accidents, illness/medical procedure, community/school violence terrorism/political violence/forced displacement, other (death or injury of family member, threat)
Citation: Brom D, Stokar Y, Lawi C, et al. Somatic experiencing for posttraumatic stress disorder: a randomized controlled outcome study. J Trauma Stress. 2017 Jun;30(3):304-12. doi: 10.1002/jts.22189. PMID: 28585761.

Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, accidents, illness/medical procedure, community/school violence terrorism/political violence/forced displacement, other (death or injury of family member, threat)
Citation: Brom D, Stokar Y, Lawi C, et al. Somatic experiencing for posttraumatic stress disorder: a randomized controlled outcome study. J Trauma Stress. 2017 Jun;30(3):304-12. doi: 10.1002/jts.22189. PMID: 28585761.

Treatment Description: Beta blocker taken 90 minutes prior to trauma reactivation; all patients in study underwent trauma reactivation, writing a trauma narrative at the first visit which they read aloud at each visit.
Dose: 1.67 mg/kg: 0.67 mg/kg short-acting plus 1.0 mg/kg long-acting
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related. rape/sexual assault, accidents, illness/medical procedure, community/school violence, other (war zone, captivity, life threat, sudden unexpected death, other trauma not specified)
Citation: Brunet A, Saumier D, Liu A, et al. Reduction of PTSD Symptoms with pre-reactivation propranolol therapy: a randomized controlled trial. Am J Psychiatry. 2018 May 1doi: 10.1176/appi.ajp.2017.17050481. PMID: 29325446.

Treatment Description: All patients in study underwent trauma reactivation, writing a trauma narrative at the first visit which they read aloud at each visit 90 minutes after receiving medication.
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related. rape/sexual assault, accidents, illness/medical procedure, community/school violence, other (war zone, captivity, life threat, sudden unexpected death, other trauma not specified)
Citation: Brunet A, Saumier D, Liu A, et al. Reduction of PTSD Symptoms with pre-reactivation propranolol therapy: a randomized controlled trial. Am J Psychiatry. 2018 May 1doi: 10.1176/appi.ajp.2017.17050481. PMID: 29325446.

Treatment Name: Prolonged Imaginal Exposure with Cognitive Restructuring
Treatment Description: Psychoeducation and education about cognitive restructuring (first session); 6 sessions consisted of 25 minutes of cognitive restructuring including monitoring of thoughts and affective states, modifying thoughts, and identification and modification of underlying beliefs, followed by 45 minutes of imaginal exposure with patient-provided narrative of trauma experience, and homework included daily exercise of imaginal exposure; the final session focused om relapse prevention using both IE and CR strategies.
Trauma Detail (Study level): accidents, community/school violence
Citation: Bryant RA, Moulds ML, Guthrie RM, et al. Imaginal exposure alone and imaginal exposure with cognitive restructuring in treatment of posttraumatic stress disorder. J Consult Clin Psychol. 2003 Aug;71(4):706.  PMID: 12924676.

Treatment Description: Psychoeducation and trauma narrative (first session); 6 sessions consisted of 45 minutes of imaginal exposure with patient-provided narrative of trauma experience,25 minutes of supportive counseling, and monitored homework included daily exercise of imaginal exposure; the final session focused om relapse prevention using exposure-based strategies. Cognitive restructuring was not provided in any sessions.
Trauma Detail (Study level): accidents, community/school violence
Citation: Bryant RA, Moulds ML, Guthrie RM, et al. Imaginal exposure alone and imaginal exposure with cognitive restructuring in treatment of posttraumatic stress disorder. J Consult Clin Psychol. 2003 Aug;71(4):706.  PMID: 12924676.

Treatment Description: Therapy in unconditionally supportive role with trauma education and general problem-solving skills; homework to keep diary of current problems and mood states. Cognitive restructuring and imaginal exposure techniques were specifically avoided.
Trauma Detail (Study level): accidents, community/school violence
Citation: Bryant RA, Moulds ML, Guthrie RM, et al. Imaginal exposure alone and imaginal exposure with cognitive restructuring in treatment of posttraumatic stress disorder. J Consult Clin Psychol. 2003 Aug;71(4):706.  PMID: 12924676.

Treatment Description: Exposure to traumatic memories using personal narrative of trauma, discussion of exposure experience, and homework for daily repetition of exposure exercise with monitoring; relapse prevention using imaginal exposure-based strategies. Each session was comprised of: 40 minutes of imaginal exposure, 50 minutes of supportive counseling, and 10 minutes of homework assignments.
Trauma Detail (Study level): accidents, community/school violence
Citation: Bryant RA, Moulds ML, Guthrie RM, et al. A randomized controlled trial of exposure therapy and cognitive restructuring for posttraumatic stress disorder. J Consult Clin Psychol. 2008 Aug;76(4):695-703. doi: 10.1037/a0012616. PMID: 18665697.

Treatment Description: Hierarchy of feared situations, in vivo exercises during sessions when appropriate, and daily homework assignments for approaching and remaining in feared situations until anxiety decreased by 50%; relapse prevention using in vivo exposure-based strategies. Each session comprised of: 25 minutes in vivo exposure instructions, 65 minutes of supportive counseling, and 10 minutes of homework assignments.
Trauma Detail (Study level): accidents, community/school violence
Citation: Bryant RA, Moulds ML, Guthrie RM, et al. A randomized controlled trial of exposure therapy and cognitive restructuring for posttraumatic stress disorder. J Consult Clin Psychol. 2008 Aug;76(4):695-703. doi: 10.1037/a0012616. PMID: 18665697.

Treatment Description: Development of hierarchy of feared situations, imaginal exposure to traumatic memories, in vivo exposure exercises (in vivo exercises during sessions when appropriate, homework assignments for approaching and remaining in feared situations until anxiety decreased by 50%), and relapse prevention using both imaginal exposure and in vivo exposure strategies. Each session comprised of: 40 minutes of imaginal exposure, 25 minutes of in vivo exposure, 25 minutes of supportive counseling, and 10 minutes of homework assignments.
Trauma Detail (Study level): accidents, community/school violence
Citation: Bryant RA, Moulds ML, Guthrie RM, et al. A randomized controlled trial of exposure therapy and cognitive restructuring for posttraumatic stress disorder. J Consult Clin Psychol. 2008 Aug;76(4):695-703. doi: 10.1037/a0012616. PMID: 18665697.

Treatment Name: Imaginal exposure + In vivo exposure + Cognitive restructuring
Treatment Description:
Sessions comprised of 25 minutes cognitive restructuring, 40 minutes of imaginal exposure, 25 minutes of in vivo exposure, and 10 minutes of homework assignments. Final session for relapse prevention using strategies from all 3 approaches.







Imaginal exposure: exposure to traumatic memories using personal narrative of trauma, discussion of exposure experience.







In vivo exposure: hierarchy of feared situations, in vivo exercises during sessions when appropriate, assignments to approaching and remaining in feared situations until anxiety decreased by 50%.







Cognitive restructuring: identification and monitoring of dysfunctional, unrealistic, and catastrophic thoughts, and affect states and use of Socratic questioning, probabilistic reasoning and evidence-based thinking to modify thoughts.
Trauma Detail (Study level): accidents, community/school violence
Citation: Bryant RA, Moulds ML, Guthrie RM, et al. A randomized controlled trial of exposure therapy and cognitive restructuring for posttraumatic stress disorder. J Consult Clin Psychol. 2008 Aug;76(4):695-703. doi: 10.1037/a0012616. PMID: 18665697.

Treatment Description: Individual sessions including education about trauma reactions, anxiety management techniques (including Thai meditation), prolonged imaginal exposure, in vivo exposure to avoided situations, cognitive restructuring (modified to recognize ongoing and realistic threat of terrorist attacks), and relapse prevention.
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: no treatment drop-outs
Citation: Bryant RA, Ekassawin S, Chakkraband MLS, et al. A randomized controlled effectiveness trial of cognitive behavior therapy for post-traumatic stress disorder in terrorist-affected people in Thailand. World Psychiatry. 2011 Oct;10(3):205-9.  PMID: 21991280.

Treatment Description: Supportive counseling without anxiety management, exposure, or cognitive restructuring.
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: no treatment drop-outs
Citation: Bryant RA, Ekassawin S, Chakkraband MLS, et al. A randomized controlled effectiveness trial of cognitive behavior therapy for post-traumatic stress disorder in terrorist-affected people in Thailand. World Psychiatry. 2011 Oct;10(3):205-9.  PMID: 21991280.

Standardized Treatment Name: Emotion Regulation Training followed by Trauma-focused cognitive behavioral therapy (TF-CBT)
Treatment Description:
Emotion regulation training (4 sessions) followed by CBT (7 sessions), with one introductory session for psychoeducation.







Emotion regulation training: individualized strategies with emotion tolerance skills, breathing retraining, or progressive muscle relaxation.







CBT: cognitive restructuring, imaginal exposure, in vivo exposure, hierarchy of feared events, and relapse prevention.
Trauma Detail (Study level): accidents, community/school violence
Citation: Bryant RA, Mastrodomenico JA, Hopwood S, et al. Augmenting cognitive behaviour therapy for post-traumatic stress disorder with emotion tolerance training: a randomized controlled trial. Psychol Med. 2013 Oct;43(10):2153-60. doi: 10.1017/S0033291713000068. PMID: 23406821.

Standardized Treatment Name: Supportive counseling followed by Trauma-focused cognitive behavioral therapy (TF-CBT)
Treatment Description:
Supportive counseling (4 sessions) followed by CBT (7 sessions), with one introductory session for psychoeducation.







Supportive counseling: non-directive with patient-led approach; avoided specific strategies and components of emotional regulation.







CBT: cognitive restructuring, imaginal exposure, in vivo exposure, hierarchy of feared events, and relapse prevention.
Trauma Detail (Study level): accidents, community/school violence
Citation: Bryant RA, Mastrodomenico JA, Hopwood S, et al. Augmenting cognitive behaviour therapy for post-traumatic stress disorder with emotion tolerance training: a randomized controlled trial. Psychol Med. 2013 Oct;43(10):2153-60. doi: 10.1017/S0033291713000068. PMID: 23406821.

Treatment Description: CBT included psychoeducation, CBT skills building, prolonged imaginal exposure, in vivo exposure, cognitive restructuring and relapse prevention.
Session Length: 90 minutes with 40 minutes of imaginal exposure
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: Study reports treatment sessions attended but only for group including waitlist participants who received treatment after waiting period; stduy/asssessment completion reported (27/33 completed 3-month assessment)
Trauma Detail (Study level): emergency service personnel including police, firefighters, and paramedics; exposure to fatality
Citation: Bryant RA, Kenny L, Rawson N, et al. Efficacy of exposure-based cognitive behaviour therapy for post-traumatic stress disorder in emergency service personnel: a randomised clinical trial. Psychol Med. 2019 Jul;49(9):1565-73. doi: 10.1017/S0033291718002234. PMID: 30149825.

Treatment Description: CBT included psychoeducation, CBT skills building, brief imaginal exposure, in vivo exposure, cognitive restructuring and relapse prevention.
Session Length: 60 minutes with 10 minutes of imaginal exposure
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: Study reports treatment sessions attended but only for group including waitlist participants who received treatment after waiting period; stduy/asssessment completion reported (29/33 completed 3-month assessment)
Trauma Detail (Study level): emergency service personnel including police, firefighters, and paramedics; exposure to fatality
Citation: Bryant RA, Kenny L, Rawson N, et al. Efficacy of exposure-based cognitive behaviour therapy for post-traumatic stress disorder in emergency service personnel: a randomised clinical trial. Psychol Med. 2019 Jul;49(9):1565-73. doi: 10.1017/S0033291718002234. PMID: 30149825.

Treatment Description: WL participants underwent a 3-month waiting period while CBT patients received treatment; WL patients then randomized to active treatment.
Trauma Detail (Study level): emergency service personnel including police, firefighters, and paramedics; exposure to fatality
Citation: Bryant RA, Kenny L, Rawson N, et al. Efficacy of exposure-based cognitive behaviour therapy for post-traumatic stress disorder in emergency service personnel: a randomised clinical trial. Psychol Med. 2019 Jul;49(9):1565-73. doi: 10.1017/S0033291718002234. PMID: 30149825.

Treatment Description: Sessions included psychoeducation (1st session), cognitive reframing with weekly homework (sessions 2-9), exposure therapy consisting of 20 minutes reliving the trauma memory (sessions 3-8), and in vivo exposure (sessions 4-9, not further described). Following each therapy session, therapist supervised participants in 20 minutes of aerobic exercise on a high-stepper exercise platform (about 10 minutes to achieve target heart rate and 10 minutes sustaining this exertion level).
Treatment Duration Detail: Each session 90 minutes exposure therapy + 20 minutes exercise
Trauma Detail (Study level): Accidents; Community/school violence
Citation: Bryant RA, Dawson KS, Azevedo S, et al. Augmenting trauma-focused psychotherapy for post-traumatic stress disorder with brief aerobic exercise in Australia: a randomised clinical trial. Lancet Psychiatry. 2023;10(1):21-9. doi: 10.1016/S2215-0366(22)00368-6. PMID: 36436532.

Treatment Description: Sessions included psychoeducation (1st session), cognitive reframing with weekly homework (sessions 2-9), exposure therapy consisting of 20 minutes reliving the trauma memory (sessions 3-8), and in vivo exposure (sessions 4-9, not further described). Following each therapy session, therapist instructed participants in 20 minutes of non-strenuous stretching of limbs.
Treatment Duration Detail: Each session 90 minutes exposure therapy + 20 minutes stretching
Trauma Detail (Study level): Accidents; Community/school violence
Citation: Bryant RA, Dawson KS, Azevedo S, et al. Augmenting trauma-focused psychotherapy for post-traumatic stress disorder with brief aerobic exercise in Australia: a randomised clinical trial. Lancet Psychiatry. 2023;10(1):21-9. doi: 10.1016/S2215-0366(22)00368-6. PMID: 36436532.

Standardized Treatment Name: Trauma-focused cognitive behavioral therapy (TF-CBT) + memory specificity training
Treatment Description: Manualized therapy modeled on previous TF-CBT programs for first responders. Inlcuded psychoeducation about PTSD, training retrieval of specific memories, cognitive reframing, challenging maladaptive trauma-related thoughts, skills training to assist with specific problems (e.g. anger, panic, depression, sleep difficulties), in vivo exposure to avoided situations; imaginal exposure to the trauma memory, and relapse prevention. Participants were given a workbook to practice retrieval of positive memories between sessions.
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: Study reports completion of study assessments/measurement, no information on treatment completion
Citation: Bryant RA, Dawson KS, Yadav S, Tran J, Choi-Christou J, Rawson N, Tockar J, Stech E, Garber B, Broomfield C, Harrison A, Keyan D, Azevedo S. Augmenting trauma-focused cognitive behavior therapy for post-traumatic stress disorder with memory specificity training: a randomized controlled trial. World Psychiatry. 2025 Feb;24(1):113-119. doi: 10.1002/wps.21280. PMID: 39810665.

Treatment Description: TF-CBT was the same as for TF-CBT + memory specificity group except participants received non-directive counseling instead of memory specificity training; no workbook for memory retrieval.
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: Study reports completion of study assessments/measurement, no information on treatment completion
Citation: Bryant RA, Dawson KS, Yadav S, Tran J, Choi-Christou J, Rawson N, Tockar J, Stech E, Garber B, Broomfield C, Harrison A, Keyan D, Azevedo S. Augmenting trauma-focused cognitive behavior therapy for post-traumatic stress disorder with memory specificity training: a randomized controlled trial. World Psychiatry. 2025 Feb;24(1):113-119. doi: 10.1002/wps.21280. PMID: 39810665.

Standardized Treatment Name: Trauma-focused cognitive behavioral therapy (TF-CBT) + sertraline and/or mianserin
Treatment Description: Manualized CBT including methods from acceptance and commitment therapy, mindfulness exercises, and in vivo and visualized exposure. Doctor adjusts SSRI and provides psychoeducation at each consultation, which was manualized and cover the illness, treatment, sleep, lifestyle, physical activity and social relations, pain, cognitive function, and influence of illness on the family. Patients have weekly consultation with doctor for first 2 months, then monthly consultation for 4 months. Participants reporting sleeping problems were supplemented with mianserin (atypical antipsychotic). Participants with too many side effects from sertraline were switched to mianserin.
Dose:
Sertraline: 25 to 200mg; titration: initial dose 2 mg, increased in 25 to 50 mg increments every 1 to 2 weeks with maximum dose of 200 mg



Mianserin: 10 to 30 mg
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: "completers" reported in text, sum reported across arms matches number completed treatment reported in abstract results
Citation: Buhmann CB, Nordentoft M, Ekstrom M, et al. The effect of flexible cognitive-behavioural therapy and medical treatment, including antidepressants on post-traumatic stress disorder and depression in traumatised refugees: pragmatic randomised controlled clinical trial. Br J Psychiatry. 2016 Mar;208(3):252-9. doi: 10.1192/bjp.bp.114.150961. PMID: 26541687.

Treatment Description: Manualized CBT including methods from acceptance and commitment therapy, mindfulness exercises, and in vivo and visualized exposure.
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: "completers" reported in text, sum reported across arms matches number completed treatment reported in abstract results

The effect of flexible cognitive-behavioural therapy and medical treatment, including antidepressants on post-traumatic stress disorder and depression in traumatised refugees: pragmatic randomised controlled clinical trial.
