Standardized Treatment Name: Eye Movement Desensitization and Reprocessing (EMDR) + progressive muscle relaxation (PMR) + group psychoeducation
Treatment Description: Individual trauma-specific therapy sessions using EMDR, plus relaxation therapy using PMR, and group psychoeducation sessions. Participants also had occupational therapy (100 minutes per day), sports therapy (50 minutes per day), and physiotherapy (100 minutes per week).
Frequency: EMDR: twice per week; PMR: daily; Group psychoeducation: NR (total 250 minutes per week)
Citation: Butler O, Willmund G, Gleich T, et al. Hippocampal gray matter increases following multimodal psychological treatment for combat-related post-traumatic stress disorder. Brain Behav. 2018 May;8(5):e00956. doi: 10.1002/brb3.956. PMID: 29761009.

Treatment Description: Waiting list control group
Citation: Butler O, Willmund G, Gleich T, et al. Hippocampal gray matter increases following multimodal psychological treatment for combat-related post-traumatic stress disorder. Brain Behav. 2018 May;8(5):e00956. doi: 10.1002/brb3.956. PMID: 29761009.

Treatment Description: Based on gestalt therapy and consisted of 4 phases (safety, stability, confrontation, and integration). Therapist help patients identify and resolve the disruptions of contact so patient will be able to experience continuity of self and regain ability to shape interactions with the environment. Therapy includes exposure to traumatic event (confrontation phase)
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: 4.1% did not start treatment, 8.1% dropped out of treatment
Trauma Detail (Study level): accidents, illness/medical procedure, other ("interpersonal", "loss", not specified)
Citation: Butollo WH, Karl R, König J, et al. A randomized controlled clinical trial of dialogical exposure therapy versus cognitive processing therapy for adult outpatients suffering from PTSD after type I trauma in adulthood. Psychother Psychosom. 2016 Jan;85(1):16-26. doi: 10.1159/000440726. PMID: 26610167.

Arm N Randomized Detail: 74 randomized to CPT, excluded 7 patients treated as pilot case
Treatment Description: CBT targeting dysfunctional cognitions about the traumatic event, includes written exposure component.
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: 6.0% declined treatment, 9.0% dropped out of treatment
Trauma Detail (Study level): accidents, illness/medical procedure, other ("interpersonal", "loss", not specified)
Citation: Butollo WH, Karl R, König J, et al. A randomized controlled clinical trial of dialogical exposure therapy versus cognitive processing therapy for adult outpatients suffering from PTSD after type I trauma in adulthood. Psychother Psychosom. 2016 Jan;85(1):16-26. doi: 10.1159/000440726. PMID: 26610167.

Treatment Description: Atypical antipsychotic; binds to serotonin receptor subtypes with substantial affinities greater than its dopamine affinities. Effective serotonin receptor antagonist.
Dose: 5 to 20 mg; titration: initial dose of 5 mg for 1 week, then 10 mg for 3 weeks, 15 mg for 2 weeks, up to potential maximum dose of 20 mg
Dose at Study End Point Mean: 14.1 mg/day (mean peak daily dosage during study)
Trauma Detail (Study level): MST, child physical abuse, rape/sexual assault, intimate partner violence, community/school violence, other (military harassment, "nurse in Vietnam", "Persian Gulf" [non-combat trauma])
Citation: Butterfield M, Becker M, Connor K, et al. Olanzapine in the treatment of post-traumatic stress disorder: a pilot study. Int Clin Psychopharmacol. 2001;16(4):197-203.  PMID: 11459333.

Treatment Description: Placebo
Dose at Study End Point Mean: 13.9 mg (mean peak daily dosage during study)
Trauma Detail (Study level): MST, child physical abuse, rape/sexual assault, intimate partner violence, community/school violence, other (military harassment, "nurse in Vietnam", "Persian Gulf" [non-combat trauma])
Citation: Butterfield M, Becker M, Connor K, et al. Olanzapine in the treatment of post-traumatic stress disorder: a pilot study. Int Clin Psychopharmacol. 2001;16(4):197-203.  PMID: 11459333.

Treatment Description: Follows standard EMDR protocol (Shapiro 2001) including 8 stages. Goals include stabilization through psychoeducation, with resources including a "safe place" technique; identification and reprocessing of disturbing memories; and integration of resources into daily life.
Completed Treatment Definition: Did not drop out from treatment
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: "We did not have any patient dropouts from the treatment."
Citation: Capezzani L, Ostacoli L, Cavallo M, et al. EMDR and CBT for cancer patients: comparative study of effects on PTSD, anxiety, and depression. J EMDR Prac Res. 2013;7(3):134-43. doi: 10.1891/1933-3196.7.3.134.

Treatment Description: Techniques/therapeutic approaches used according to symptoms, phase of psychotherapy: Rational Emotive Imagery (Ellis 1994), prolonged exposure (in vivo or imaginative), progressive relaxation with breathing exercises, homework, and diary entries. Goals include stabilization through psychoeducation; shifting attention from intrusive thoughts; and cognitive restructuring of negative thoughts.
Completed Treatment Definition: Did not drop out from treatment
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: "We did not have any patient dropouts from the treatment."
Citation: Capezzani L, Ostacoli L, Cavallo M, et al. EMDR and CBT for cancer patients: comparative study of effects on PTSD, anxiety, and depression. J EMDR Prac Res. 2013;7(3):134-43. doi: 10.1891/1933-3196.7.3.134.

Treatment Description: Manual-guided intervention designed to improve both PTSD and substance use, adapted for veterans and delivered in both individual and group format (sessions 1-4 delivered individually and sessions 5-12 in group format).
Trauma Detail (Study level): MST, combat-related, child sexual abuse, rape/sexual assault
Citation: Capone C, Presseau C, Saunders E, et al. Is integrated CBT effective in reducing PTSD symptoms and substance use in Iraq and Afghanistan veterans? Results from a randomized clinical trial. Cognit Ther Res. 2018;42(6):735-46. doi: 10.1007/s10608-018-9931-8.

Treatment Description: Continuation of "usual VA care, such as medication management and individual or group psychotherapy in the substance use treatment program or PTSD clinics…"; trauma-focused treatments were not prohibited but more often treatments included skills training or supportive therapy.
Trauma Detail (Study level): MST, combat-related, child sexual abuse, rape/sexual assault
Citation: Capone C, Presseau C, Saunders E, et al. Is integrated CBT effective in reducing PTSD symptoms and substance use in Iraq and Afghanistan veterans? Results from a randomized clinical trial. Cognit Ther Res. 2018;42(6):735-46. doi: 10.1007/s10608-018-9931-8.

Treatment Description: Second-generation antipsychotic
Dose: 10 to 15 mg; titration: 5 mg for first week, 7.5 mg for second week, then 10 mg for 2 weeks, dose maintained for next 4 weeks or titrated up to 15 mg
Trauma Detail (Study level): intimate partner violence, community/school violence
Citation: Carey P, Suliman S, Ganesan K, et al. Olanzapine monotherapy in posttraumatic stress disorder: efficacy in a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled study. Hum Psychopharmacol. 2012 Jul;27(4):386-91. doi: 10.1002/hup.2238. PMID: 22730105.

Treatment Description: Matching placebo
Trauma Detail (Study level): intimate partner violence, community/school violence
Citation: Carey P, Suliman S, Ganesan K, et al. Olanzapine monotherapy in posttraumatic stress disorder: efficacy in a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled study. Hum Psychopharmacol. 2012 Jul;27(4):386-91. doi: 10.1002/hup.2238. PMID: 22730105.

Treatment Description: Manual-based intervention according to Shapiro 1995. Each session included 20 to 28 back-and-forth motions while participants listened to traumatic scripts and focused on related images, negative cognitions and bodily sensations, and finally on the positive cognition
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: study reports no participants dropped out after randomization and prior to posttreatment assessment, but unclear if dropout from treatment or from measurement
Citation: Carlson JG, Chemtob CM, Rusnak K, et al. Eye Movement Desensitization and Reprocessing (EMDR) treatment for combat-related posttraumatic stress disorder. J Trauma Stress. 1998 Jan;11(1):3-24. doi: 10.1023/A:1024448814268. PMID: 9479673.

Treatment Description: Electromyographic electrode placement and feedback administration followed manualized protocol by Carlson, Basilio, & Heaukulani 1983. Biofeedback included a pure tone on the  headphones. Participants were also given a recorded cassette containing modified progressive relaxation instructions and written instructions for daily home use
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: n=1 participant dropped out after randomization and prior to posttreatment assessment, but unclear if dropout from treatment or from measurement
Citation: Carlson JG, Chemtob CM, Rusnak K, et al. Eye Movement Desensitization and Reprocessing (EMDR) treatment for combat-related posttraumatic stress disorder. J Trauma Stress. 1998 Jan;11(1):3-24. doi: 10.1023/A:1024448814268. PMID: 9479673.

Completed Treatment Percent Detail: no participants dropped out after randomization and prior to posttreatment assessment, but unclear if dropout from treatment or from measurement
Citation: Carlson JG, Chemtob CM, Rusnak K, et al. Eye Movement Desensitization and Reprocessing (EMDR) treatment for combat-related posttraumatic stress disorder. J Trauma Stress. 1998 Jan;11(1):3-24. doi: 10.1023/A:1024448814268. PMID: 9479673.

Arm N Randomized Detail: 70 randomized, 62 with pretreatment data included for ITT sample
Treatment Description: Manualized program including relaxation, attention diversion, and behavioral activation. Participants in both groups also received 10 sessions with a medical doctor for psychoeducation and pharmacotherapy.
Treatment Duration Detail: 16 psychotherapy sessions total, mean duration 6.8 (SD 1.60) months (inclusive of the additional 10 sessions with medical doctor); treatment program aimed to last 6-7 months
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: of n=70 randomized
Citation: Carlsson J, Sonne C, Vindbjerg E, et al. Stress management versus cognitive restructuring in trauma-affected refugees - A pragmatic randomised study. Psychiatry Res. 2018 Aug;266:116-23. doi: 10.1016/j.psychres.2018.05.015. PMID: 29859498

Arm N Randomized Detail: 70 randomized, 64 with pretreatment data included for ITT sample
Treatment Description: Manualized intervention consisting of psychoeducation and cognitive restructuring of negative thoughts resulting from traumatic experiences and exposure. Participants in both groups also received 10 sessions with a medical doctor for psychoeducation and pharmacotherapy.
Treatment Duration Detail: 16 psychotherapy sessions total, mean duration 6.8 (SD 1.84) months (inclusive of the additional 10 sessions with medical doctor); treatment program aimed to last 6-7 months
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: of n=70 randomized
Citation: Carlsson J, Sonne C, Vindbjerg E, et al. Stress management versus cognitive restructuring in trauma-affected refugees - A pragmatic randomised study. Psychiatry Res. 2018 Aug;266:116-23. doi: 10.1016/j.psychres.2018.05.015. PMID: 29859498

Treatment Description: Manualized group music therapy employing methods used in psychodynamic music therapy, combination of active and receptive activities and emphasis on free improvisation. Patients were introduced to instruments and encouraged to improvise and therapists gave improvised instrumental support; verbal reflection on thoughts and feelings was encouraged; therapists used supportive psychotherapeutic interventions; personal statements about symptoms were highlighted and made relevant to the whole group.
Trauma Detail (Study level): child sexual abuse, rape/sexual assault, community/school violence, terrorism/political violence/forced displacement, other (torture)
Citation: Carr C, D'Ardenne P, Sloboda A, et al. Group music therapy for patients with persistent post-traumatic stress disorder -- an exploratory randomized controlled trial with mixed methods evaluation. Psychol Psychother. 2012 Jun;85(2):179-202. doi: 10.1111/j.2044-8341.2011.02026.x. PMID: 22903909.

Treatment Description: Maintained on clinic caseload with access to mental health care; assessments conducted by telephone. Received music therapy intervention after waiting period and completion of end of evaluation assessment.
Trauma Detail (Study level): child sexual abuse, rape/sexual assault, community/school violence, terrorism/political violence/forced displacement, other (torture)
Citation: Carr C, D'Ardenne P, Sloboda A, et al. Group music therapy for patients with persistent post-traumatic stress disorder -- an exploratory randomized controlled trial with mixed methods evaluation. Psychol Psychother. 2012 Jun;85(2):179-202. doi: 10.1111/j.2044-8341.2011.02026.x. PMID: 22903909.

Treatment Description: Comprised of 3 rounds of cyclical breathing. Treatment also includes psychoeducation about stress reduction and group processes. Intervention consisted of a week-long workshop, followed by weekly group sessions for the first month and monthly group session for the next 5 months
Session Length: 22 hours total during weeklong workshop, 2 hours subsequent group session
Frequency: Daily during weeklong workshop, weekly for subsequent 1 month, then monthly for next 5 months
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: of n=16 randomized, n=1 withdrew before or during intervention; another n=1 refused post-intervention testing (considering this participant as completed treatment)
Citation: Carter JJ, Gerbarg PL, Brown RP, et al. Multi-component yoga breath program for Vietnam veteran post traumatic stress disorder: randomized controlled trial. J Trauma Stress Disord Treat. 2013 Jul 31;2(3)doi: 10.4172/2324-8947.1000108.

Carter JJ, Gerbarg PL, Brown RP, et al. Multi-component yoga breath program for Vietnam veteran post traumatic stress disorder: randomized controlled trial. J Trauma Stress Disord Treat. 2013 Jul 31;2(3)doi: 10.4172/2324-8947.1000108.

Treatment Description: Three-module treatment including imaginal exposure (trauma narrative writing and identification of coping strategies), cognitive restructuring (from CPT), and behavioral skills development
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: flow diagram reports "did not receive full tx" (n=12) and "received tx" (n=32); treatment completion = "received tx"
Trauma Detail (Study level): MST, combat-related, other (not specified)
Citation: Castillo DT, Chee CL, Nason E, et al. Group-delivered cognitive/exposure therapy for PTSD in women veterans: a randomized controlled trial. Psychol Trauma. 2016 May;8(3):404-12. doi: 10.1037/tra0000111. PMID: 26854355.

Treatment Description: Unstructured, nondirective individual support, which excluded treatment such as trauma review, cognitive restructuring, or behavioral treatment techniques
Trauma Detail (Study level): MST, combat-related, other (not specified)
Citation: Castillo DT, Chee CL, Nason E, et al. Group-delivered cognitive/exposure therapy for PTSD in women veterans: a randomized controlled trial. Psychol Trauma. 2016 May;8(3):404-12. doi: 10.1037/tra0000111. PMID: 26854355.

Treatment Description: SSRI
Dose: 60 mg; titration: initiated at 10 mg/day, increased by 10 mg every 2 weeks until 60 mg, then maintained for weeks 8 through 12 if tolerated and clinically indicated
Citation: Celik C, Ozdemir B, Ozmenler KN, et al. Efficacy of paroxetine and amitriptyline in posttraumatic stress disorder: an open-label comparative study. Klinik Psikofarmakol Bülteni. 2011 Sep;21(3):179-85. doi: 10.5455/bcp.20110627111141.

Treatment Description: TCA
Dose: Initiated at 25 mg/day for first 3 days, followed by 50 mg/day on days 4 to 7, then 75 mg/day for following 2 weeks. Dose could be increased to 100 mg/day as necessary for weeks 3 and 4, then to 200 mg/day at end of week 5
Citation: Celik C, Ozdemir B, Ozmenler KN, et al. Efficacy of paroxetine and amitriptyline in posttraumatic stress disorder: an open-label comparative study. Klinik Psikofarmakol Bülteni. 2011 Sep;21(3):179-85. doi: 10.5455/bcp.20110627111141.

Treatment Description: Adapted from Resick & Schnicke's (1993) CPT manual to include schema-discrepant and schema-congruent beliefs, and a session on assertiveness/communications, sexual intimacy, and social support. Intervention included weekly group sessions and individual therapy session in the first 9 and last week of intervention
Session Length:
Group session: 90 minutes







Individual session: 60 minutes
Citation: Chard KM. An evaluation of cognitive processing therapy for the treatment of posttraumatic stress disorder related to childhood sexual abuse. J Consult Clin Psychol. 2005 Oct;73(5):965-71. doi: 10.1037/0022-006X.73.5.965. PMID: 16287396.

Treatment Description: Telephone call to assess current emotional state and give supportive, nondirective, brief counseling if experiencing a crisis
Citation: Chard KM. An evaluation of cognitive processing therapy for the treatment of posttraumatic stress disorder related to childhood sexual abuse. J Consult Clin Psychol. 2005 Oct;73(5):965-71. doi: 10.1037/0022-006X.73.5.965. PMID: 16287396.

Treatment Description: Atypical antidepressant (alpha-2 agonist); dose could be adjusted after 1, 2, and 6 weeks of treatment
Dose: Initiated at 15 mg; maximum dose NR
Citation: Chung MY, Min KH, Jun YJ, et al. Efficacy and tolerability of mirtazapine and sertraline in Korean veterans with posttraumatic stress disorder: a randomized open label trial. Hum Psychopharmacol. 2004 Oct;19(7):489-94. doi: 10.1002/hup.615. PMID: 15378676.

Treatment Description: SSRI; dose could be adjusted after 1, 2, and 6 weeks' therapy, maximum dose NR
Dose: Initiated at 50 mg; maximum dose NR
Citation: Chung MY, Min KH, Jun YJ, et al. Efficacy and tolerability of mirtazapine and sertraline in Korean veterans with posttraumatic stress disorder: a randomized open label trial. Hum Psychopharmacol. 2004 Oct;19(7):489-94. doi: 10.1002/hup.615. PMID: 15378676.

Treatment Description: Brief exposure therapy with a somatic and cognitive component. The subject pairs the traumatic memory with a self-acceptance statement, then taps a sequence of points on his/her body repeatedly until subjective units of distress decreases to 0. All subjects also received the standard of care at VA.
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: Flow diagram notes n=1 dropped out after 3 sessions, remainder "received EFT intervention" (no other treatment dropouts noted)
Citation: Church D, Hawk C, Brooks AJ, et al. Psychological trauma symptom improvement in veterans using Emotional Freedom Techniques. J Nerv Ment Dis. 2013 Feb;201(2):153-60. doi: 10.1097/NMD.0b013e31827f6351. PMID: 23364126.

Completed Treatment Percent Detail: 86.21% completed WL period
Citation: Church D, Hawk C, Brooks AJ, et al. Psychological trauma symptom improvement in veterans using Emotional Freedom Techniques. J Nerv Ment Dis. 2013 Feb;201(2):153-60. doi: 10.1097/NMD.0b013e31827f6351. PMID: 23364126.

Treatment Description:
Both treatment groups combined for analysis.







Trauma-focused group therapy: goal of treatment is to help survivors work through and integrate their traumatic abuse experiences; involves: reconstructing traumatic experiences; integrating the affect associated with the trauma; modifying negative views of self which arose due to the abuse; integration of traumatic history into conscious awareness of self and others.







Present-focused group therapy: goal to help survivors identify and modify maladaptive patterns of behavior which had arisen as a result of their traumatic past; treatment assumption that by focusing on the present, survivors can alter their current functioning and thereby address the impact of their abuse history.
Citation: Classen CC, Koopman C, Nevill-Manning K, et al. A preliminary report comparing trauma-focused and present-focused group therapy against a wait-listed condition among childhood sexual abuse survivors with PTSD. J Aggress Maltreat Trauma. 2001 Jun;4(2):265-88. doi: 10.1300/J146v04n02_12.

Classen CC, Koopman C, Nevill-Manning K, et al. A preliminary report comparing trauma-focused and present-focused group therapy against a wait-listed condition among childhood sexual abuse survivors with PTSD. J Aggress Maltreat Trauma. 2001 Jun;4(2):265-88. doi: 10.1300/J146v04n02_12.

Standardized Treatment Name: Skills Training in Affect and Interpersonal Regulation (STAIR) + exposure therapy
Treatment Description: STAIR is CBT targeting development of emotion management and interpersonal skills. Topics include labeling and identifying feelings, emotion management, distress tolerance, acceptance of feelings, identification of trauma-based interpersonal schemas and conflict between trauma-generated feelings and current interpersonal goals, and role play related to issue of power and control. PE followed technique described by Foa & Rothbaum (1998), except in vivo exposure to rape-related cues was eliminated, while postexposure stabilization check, postexposure emotion-focused processing, and identification of negative interpersonal schemas and addressed with skills from STAIR.
Frequency: STAIR: weekly; Modified PE: twice weekly
Trauma Detail (Study level): child physical abuse, child sexual abuse
Citation: Cloitre M, Koenen KC, Cohen LR, et al. Skills training in affective and interpersonal regulation followed by exposure: a phase-based treatment for PTSD related to childhood abuse. J Consult Clin Psychol. 2002 Oct;70(5):1067-74. doi: 10.1037//0022-006X.70.5.1067. PMID: 12362957.

Treatment Description: Study coordinator monitored participants through phone session
Trauma Detail (Study level): child physical abuse, child sexual abuse
Citation: Cloitre M, Koenen KC, Cohen LR, et al. Skills training in affective and interpersonal regulation followed by exposure: a phase-based treatment for PTSD related to childhood abuse. J Consult Clin Psychol. 2002 Oct;70(5):1067-74. doi: 10.1037//0022-006X.70.5.1067. PMID: 12362957.

Standardized Treatment Name: Skills Training in Affect and Interpersonal Regulation (STAIR) + exposure therapy
Treatment Description: STAIR (8 sessions) followed by exposure treatment (8 sessions). Exposure treatment was modified from prolonged exposure protocol with interpersonal skills practice instead of in vivo exposure to trauma stimuli, and meaning analysis introduced after the exposure.
Trauma Detail (Study level): child physical abuse, child sexual abuse, child other abuse, intimate partner violence, rape/sexual assault, community/school violence, other ("other interpersonal victimization")
Citation: Cloitre M, Stovall-McClough KC, Nooner K, et al. Treatment for PTSD related to childhood abuse: a randomized controlled trial. Am J Psychiatry. 2010 Aug;167(8):915-24. doi: 10.1176/appi.ajp.2010.09081247. PMID: 20595411.

Standardized Treatment Name: Skills Training in Affect and Interpersonal Regulation (STAIR) + supportive therapy
Treatment Description: STAIR (8 sessions) followed by supportive counseling (8 sessions). Supportive counseling with client-directed discussion of abuse history-related life problems.
Trauma Detail (Study level): child physical abuse, child sexual abuse, child other abuse, intimate partner violence, rape/sexual assault, community/school violence, other ("other interpersonal victimization")
Citation: Cloitre M, Stovall-McClough KC, Nooner K, et al. Treatment for PTSD related to childhood abuse: a randomized controlled trial. Am J Psychiatry. 2010 Aug;167(8):915-24. doi: 10.1176/appi.ajp.2010.09081247. PMID: 20595411.

Treatment Description: Supportive counseling (8 sessions) and exposure treatment (8 sessions). Supportive counseling with client-directed discussion of abuse history-related life problems. Exposure treatment was modified from prolonged exposure protocol with interpersonal skills practice instead of in vivo exposure to trauma stimuli, and meaning analysis introduced after the exposure.
Trauma Detail (Study level): child physical abuse, child sexual abuse, child other abuse, intimate partner violence, rape/sexual assault, community/school violence, other ("other interpersonal victimization")
Citation: Cloitre M, Stovall-McClough KC, Nooner K, et al. Treatment for PTSD related to childhood abuse: a randomized controlled trial. Am J Psychiatry. 2010 Aug;167(8):915-24. doi: 10.1176/appi.ajp.2010.09081247. PMID: 20595411.

Arm N Randomized Detail: 86 in Supplemental Table, unclear reason for discrepancy
Standardized Treatment Name: Skills Training in Affect and Interpersonal Regulation (STAIR)
Treatment Description:
Manualized, strengths-based treatment that "focuses on
improving emotion management skills, interpersonal skills, and
social cognition." Delivered virtually via videoconferencing. Five sessions on awareness and management of emotions; seven on interpersonal problems, including identifying & changing maladaptive relationship patterns, resolving conflict, and increasing intimacy; final session includes exercises in compassion for self and others. Homework includes practicing skills and tracking life events.
Citation: Cloitre M, Morabito D, Macia K, et al. A home-based telehealth randomized controlled trial of skills training in affective and interpersonal regulation versus present-centered therapy for women veterans who have experienced military sexual trauma. J Consult Clin Psychol. 2024 Jan 15;15:15. doi: 10.1037/ccp0000872. PMID: 38227462.

Arm N Randomized Detail: 88 in Supplemental Table, unclear reason for discrepancy
Treatment Description: Treatment delivered virtually via videoconferencing; includes psychoeducation and discussion of client-initiated subjects, with clinician practicing active listening, reflection, and "informal problem solving." Homework included diary of daily activities.
Treatment Duration Detail:
"number and length of the sessions are adapted to be compatible with the
treatment being studied"
Citation: Cloitre M, Morabito D, Macia K, et al. A home-based telehealth randomized controlled trial of skills training in affective and interpersonal regulation versus present-centered therapy for women veterans who have experienced military sexual trauma. J Consult Clin Psychol. 2024 Jan 15;15:15. doi: 10.1037/ccp0000872. PMID: 38227462.

Treatment Description: Manualized intervention according to Foa & Rothbaum 1998. Intervention includes participants repeatedly describe their trauma. All participants were required to be in alcohol addition treatment, not delivered as part of the study. Treatment at the centers from which participants were recruited was delivered outpatient and included three times per week group coping-skills-based therapy for addiction and once every 1 or 2 weeks individual treatment for addiction.
Completed Treatment Definition: attending all laboratory and clinical sessions
Trauma Detail (Study level): child physical abuse, child sexual abuse
Citation: Coffey SF, Stasiewicz PR, Hughes PM, et al. Trauma-focused imaginal exposure for individuals with comorbid posttraumatic stress disorder and alcohol dependence: revealing mechanisms of alcohol craving in a cue reactivity paradigm. Psychol Addict Behav. 2006 Dec;20(4):425-35. doi: 10.1037/0893-164X.20.4.425. PMID: 17176177.

Treatment Description: Participants listened to an imagery-based relaxation audiotape during treatment session. All participants were required to be in alcohol addition treatment, not delivered as part of the study. Treatment at the centers from which participants were recruited was delivered outpatient and included three times per week group coping-skills-based therapy for addiction and once every 1 or 2 weeks individual treatment for addiction.
Completed Treatment Definition: attending all laboratory and clinical sessions
Trauma Detail (Study level): child physical abuse, child sexual abuse
Citation: Coffey SF, Stasiewicz PR, Hughes PM, et al. Trauma-focused imaginal exposure for individuals with comorbid posttraumatic stress disorder and alcohol dependence: revealing mechanisms of alcohol craving in a cue reactivity paradigm. Psychol Addict Behav. 2006 Dec;20(4):425-35. doi: 10.1037/0893-164X.20.4.425. PMID: 17176177.

Treatment Name: Modified PE with trauma-focused motivational enhancement session, plus standard SUD TAU
Standardized Treatment Name: Motivational enhancement session followed by Prolonged Exposure (PE) + Treatment as usual (TAU) for substance use
Treatment Description: Prior to first PE session, participants received a 90-minute motivational enhancement therapy consisting of eliciting/developing discrepancy, presenting feedback, and future directions. Traditional PE according to Foa et al. (2007) consisting of imaginal and in vivo exposure techniques, psychoeducation about PTSD and its relationship with SUD, and breathing retraining. If participant's PTSD symptoms did not decrease by 70% by the end of 9 sessions, additional 3 sessions were offered. Standard SUD treatment consisted of daily group therapy for 3 hours, daily recreation therapy, Alcohol Anonymous and Narcotics Anonymous meetings, individual drug counseling sessions, and completion of drug counseling homework.
Trauma Detail (Study level): child sexual abuse, child physical abuse, rape/sexual assault, accidents, natural or manmade disasters
Citation: Coffey SF, Schumacher JA, Nosen E, et al. Trauma-focused exposure therapy for chronic posttraumatic stress disorder in alcohol and drug dependent patients: a randomized controlled trial. Psychol. Addict Behav. 2016 Nov;30(7):778-90. doi: 10.1037/adb0000201. PMID: 27786516.

Treatment Name: Modified PE plus standard SUD TAU
Treatment Description: Prior to first PE session, participants received a 60-minute relaxation session. Traditional PE according to Foa et al. (2007) consisting of imaginal and in vivo exposure techniques, psychoeducation about PTSD and its relationship with SUD, and breathing retraining. If participant's PTSD symptoms did not decrease by 70% by the end of 9 sessions, additional 3 sessions were offered. Standard SUD treatment consisted of daily group therapy for 3 hours, daily recreation therapy, Alcohol Anonymous and Narcotics Anonymous meetings, individual drug counseling sessions, and completion of drug counseling homework.
Trauma Detail (Study level): child sexual abuse, child physical abuse, rape/sexual assault, accidents, natural or manmade disasters
Citation: Coffey SF, Schumacher JA, Nosen E, et al. Trauma-focused exposure therapy for chronic posttraumatic stress disorder in alcohol and drug dependent patients: a randomized controlled trial. Psychol. Addict Behav. 2016 Nov;30(7):778-90. doi: 10.1037/adb0000201. PMID: 27786516.

Treatment Name: Healthy lifestyle sessions plus standard SUD TAU
Standardized Treatment Name: Healthy lifetsyle session +  Treatment as usual (TAU) for substance use
Treatment Description: Prior to first education session, participants received a 60-minute relaxation session. Education on health-related topics included sleep hygiene, progressive muscle relaxation, starting/maintaining an exercise program, personal role identification, healthy eating and nutrition, diabetes, monitoring goals and values, cancer, and HIV. If participant's PTSD symptoms did not decrease by 70% by the end of Session 9, additional 3 sessions were offered. Standard SUD treatment consisted of daily group therapy for 3 hours, daily recreation therapy, Alcohol Anonymous and Narcotics Anonymous meetings, individual drug counseling sessions, and completion of drug counseling homework.
Trauma Detail (Study level): child sexual abuse, child physical abuse, rape/sexual assault, accidents, natural or manmade disasters
Citation: Coffey SF, Schumacher JA, Nosen E, et al. Trauma-focused exposure therapy for chronic posttraumatic stress disorder in alcohol and drug dependent patients: a randomized controlled trial. Psychol. Addict Behav. 2016 Nov;30(7):778-90. doi: 10.1037/adb0000201. PMID: 27786516.

Treatment Description:
rTMS performed with Magstim stimulator with 9-cm diameter. Motor threshold was determined in each subject once which was defined as lowest stimulation intensity capable of inducing a visible movement at least five times out of 10. 







Treatment was administered over the right dorsolateral prefrontal cortex (defined as 5 cm anterior to the motor cortex - following a parasagittal line)







Stimulus intensity was 80% of subject's motor threshold intensity
Dose: 1 Hz for 5 seconds with intertrain interval of 55 seconds
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, accidents, rape/sexual assault, community/school violence, other (occupational, unexpected death of relative)
Citation: Cohen H, Kaplan Z, Kotler M, et al. Repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation of the right dorsolateral prefrontal cortex in posttraumatic stress disorder: a double-blind, placebo-controlled study. Am J Psychiatry. 2004 Mar;161(3):515-24. doi: 10.1176/appi.ajp.161.3.515. PMID: 14992978.

Treatment Description:
rTMS performed with Magstim stimulator with 9-cm diameter. Motor threshold was determined in each subject once which was defined as lowest stimulation intensity capable of inducing a visible movement at least five times out of 10. 







Treatment was administered over the right dorsolateral prefrontal cortex (defined as 5 cm anterior to the motor cortex - following a parasagittal line)







Stimulus intensity was 80% of subject's motor threshold intensity.
Dose: 1 Hz for 2 seconds per train with intertrain interval of 55 seconds
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, accidents, rape/sexual assault, community/school violence, other (occupational, unexpected death of relative)
Citation: Cohen H, Kaplan Z, Kotler M, et al. Repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation of the right dorsolateral prefrontal cortex in posttraumatic stress disorder: a double-blind, placebo-controlled study. Am J Psychiatry. 2004 Mar;161(3):515-24. doi: 10.1176/appi.ajp.161.3.515. PMID: 14992978.

Treatment Description: Sham rTMS
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, accidents, rape/sexual assault, community/school violence, other (occupational, unexpected death of relative)

Treatment Description: Veterans chose a repetitive nightmare related to their war-zone experiences, alter the nightmare script during waking hours using imagery techniques, and mentally research the revised script daily
Citation: Cook JM, Harb GC, Gehrman PR, et al. Imagery rehearsal for posttraumatic nightmares: a randomized controlled trial. J Trauma Stress. 2010 Oct;23(5):553-63. doi: 10.1002/jts.20569. PMID: 20839311.

Treatment Description: Contains psychoeducation about PTSD nightmares and sleep disturbances and elements of CBT for insomnia

Treatment Description: Standard therapy including imaginal or in vivo exposure, relaxation techniques, and cognitive therapy targeting anxious cognitions, automatic thoughts, dysfunctional beliefs, vulnerability schemas and emotions related to the trauma
Trauma Detail (Study level): rape/sexual assault, accidents, illness/medical procedure, community/school violence, other (not specified)
Citation: Cottraux J, Note I, Yao S-N, et al. Randomized controlled comparison of cognitive behavior therapy with Rogerian supportive therapy in chronic post-traumatic stress disorder: a 2-year follow-up. Psychother Psychosom. 2008 Jan;77(2):101-10. doi: 10.1159/000112887. PMID: 18230943.

Treatment Description: Therapy does not include any active component of CBT (e.g., relaxation, exposure advice, structured cognitive therapy). Therapist used active listening with an empathic attitude, and had unconditionally positive regard for the patients. Therapist reassured patients when they expressed anxiety and emphasize the importance to ventilate problems verbally
Trauma Detail (Study level): rape/sexual assault, accidents, illness/medical procedure, community/school violence, other (not specified)

Treatment Name: Cognitive behavioral therapy with positive memory evocation (CBT-M+)
Standardized Treatment Name: Trauma-focused cognitive behavioral therapy (TF-CBT) + positive memory evocation
Treatment Description: Manualiized, multicomponent trauma-focused CBT with positive memory evocation. CBT included the following components: psychoeducation about IPV; breathing control training exercises; activity scheduling; techniques to improve self-esteem and re-evaluated biased cognitions; imaginal exposure; and, relapse prevention. Positive memory evocation task with positive autobiographical memories in sessions 4-7 after exposure to trauma memories, using breath control training to facilitate transition between tasks.
Citation: Crespo M, Hernández-Lloreda MJ, Hornillos C, Miguel-Alvaro A, Sánchez-Ferrer S, Antón AA. Evocation of positive memories as complement to trauma-focused cognitive-behavioural therapy for intimate partner violence against women. Eur J Psychotraumatol. 2024;15(1):2419699. doi: 10.1080/20008066.2024.2419699. Epub 2024 Nov 12. PMID: 39529598.

Treatment Name: Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) + placebo evocation task
Treatment Description: Manualiized, multicomponent trauma-focused CBT including the following components: psychoeducation about IPV; breathing control training exercises; activity scheduling; techniques to improve self-esteem and re-evaluated biased cognitions; imaginal exposure; and, relapse prevention. Also included a placebo task consisting of evocation of neutral images matching timing and duration for positive memory evocation task in CBT-M+ group.
Citation: Crespo M, Hernández-Lloreda MJ, Hornillos C, Miguel-Alvaro A, Sánchez-Ferrer S, Antón AA. Evocation of positive memories as complement to trauma-focused cognitive-behavioural therapy for intimate partner violence against women. Treatment Description: Text messaging program for PTSD self-care. Contents included psychoeducation; addressing anxiety, intrusive thoughts, insomnia, and other PTSD symptoms; preventing thoughts of suicide; diet; substance use; relaxation and breathing exercises, and meditation. Contact information for psychiatric providers given to participants for direct communication as needed, and clinical psychiatry nurse also contacted participants monthly. Participants allowed to freely visit physician/psychiatrist.
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: Unclear, reports loss to follow-up/intervention (n=4) but does not provide information on timing (if did not receive text intervention or only to post-treatment assessment)
Citation: Darvish A, Khodadadi-Hassankiadeh N, Abdoosti S, Ghapandar Kashani M. Treatment Description: Routine psychiatric care including mental support and initial treatment (e.g. medication, education, anger management, relaxation, and effective social relationship); able to freely visit physician/psychiatrist.

Treatment Description: MBSR sessions included body scan meditation, sitting meditation, and mindful stretching. Six-hour retreat prior to week 6 included extended practices and mindful walking and eating. Participants given two guided meditation CDs to practice at home.

Treatment Description: Therapy was psycho-educational and addressed symptoms of PTSD and the effects of PTSD on daily life. Allowed shared support and positive experiences with other veterans. The groups had a present focus that avoided discussion of traumas. Participants were assigned to keep a journal and had a lunch gathering to partially control for the MBSR retreat.
Trauma Detail (Study level): Combat-related; Rape/sexual assault; Other (noncombat military, civilian)
Citation: Davis LL, Whetsell C, Hamner MB, et al. A multisite randomized controlled trial of mindfulness-based stress reduction in the treatment of posttraumatic stress disorder. Psychiatric Research and Clinical Practice. 2018b Nov 5;1(2):39-48. doi: 10.1176/appi.prcp.20180002..

Treatment Description: Yoga instruction including components of Hatha Yoga: postures (asanas), breathing practices (pranayama), and relaxation. Home practice support included instructional DVD and audio device, handout with figures depicting sequence of poses, and a yoga mat and eye pillow.

Treatment Description: Designed primarily as an attention control, but in order for the program to be perceived as a credible treatment, it matched the physical activity of the yoga program with low intensity walking in addition to didactics and discussion of wellness topics

Dose:
Dose: 15 to 45 mg/day



Titration: initiated at 15 mg/day, increased weekly by 15 mg to maximum 45 mg/day; minimum target dose 30 mg/day

Treatment Description: Placebo matched in appearance and following same dosing (titration, maximum dosing) as mirtazapine
Trauma Detail (Study level): Combat-related, Other (not specified)
Citation: Davis LL, Pilkinton P, Lin C, et al. A randomized, placebo-controlled trial of mirtazapine for the treatment of posttraumatic stress disorder in veterans. J Clin Psychiatry. 2020 10 20;81(6):20. doi: 10.4088/JCP.20m13267. PMID: 33084254

Arm N Randomized Detail: 23 couples
Treatment Description: Manualized mindfulness-based adaptation of CBCT for couples, with Phases 1 and 2 given via multicouple group therapy during weekend retreats (7 sessions), followed by 9 individual couple sessions including Phase 3 of CBCT. Phases 1 and 2 include awareness training, and education about PTSD and relationships, communication, anger, conflict management, and approaching rather than avoiding trauma-related issues. Phase 3 facilitates making meaning of the trauma and challenging trauma-related cognitions. Mindfulness integrated throughout CBCT protocol.
Session Length:
Phase 1 & 2: NR for sessions, 2 days for retreat



Post-retreat: 90 minutes (total 13.5 hours, 9 sessions)
Frequency:
Phase 1 & 2: 7 sessions over 2 days



Phase 3: weekly
Trauma Detail (Study level): Combat-related; Other (TBI)
Citation: Davis LW, Luedtke BL, Monson C, et al. Testing adaptations of cognitive-behavioral conjoint therapy for PTSD: a randomized controlled pilot study with veterans. Couple Family Psychol. 2021 Jun;10(2):71-86. doi: 10.1037/cfp0000148.

Arm N Randomized Detail: 23 couples
Treatment Description: Modified version of CBCT for couples, including communication skills training from Phases 1 and 2 given via multicouple group therapy during weekend retreats (7 sessions), followed by two more multicouple group sessions reviewing communication skills. No PTSD-specific or mindfulness interventions.
Session Length:
Phase 1 & 2: NR for sessions, 2 days for retreat



Follow-up sessions: 90 minutes
Frequency:
Phase 1 & 2: 7 sessions over 2 days



Follow-up: 2 sessions 1 month apart
Trauma Detail (Study level): Combat-related; Other (TBI)
Citation: Davis LW, Luedtke BL, Monson C, et al. Testing adaptations of cognitive-behavioral conjoint therapy for PTSD: a randomized controlled pilot study with veterans. Couple Family Psychol. 2021 Jun;10(2):71-86. doi: 10.1037/cfp0000148.

Arm N Randomized Detail: n=148 in efficacy sample analyzed
Treatment Description:
One week placebo run-in period (placebo + placebo) followed by sertraline + brexpiprazole. 
Brexpiprazole: atypical antipscyhotic, flexibly dosed at 2-3 mg per day taken orally at same time as sertraline. Titration: week 1, 0.5 mg/day; week 2, 1.0 mg/day; week 3, 2 mg/day; week 4, option to stay at 2 mg/day or increase to 3 mg/day (both for remainder of trial) based on efficacy and tolerability; a one-time dose decrease to 2 mg/day was permissible up to the Week 6 visit.
Sertraline: SSRI, 150 mg per day taken orally at same time as brexpiprazole. Titration: week 1, 50 mg/day; week 2, 100 mg/day; week 3 on, 150 mg/day.
Washout for prohibited medications (including psychotropic agents) during screening period.
Dose:
Brexpiprazole: 2 to 3 mg/day. Titration: week 1, 0.5 mg/day; week 2, 1.0 mg/day; week 3, 2 mg/day; week 4, option to stay at 2 mg/day or increase to 3 mg/day based on efficacy and tolerability
Sertraline: 150 mg/day. Titration: week 1, 50 mg/day; week 2, 100 mg/day; week 3 on, 150 mg/day.
Treatment Duration Detail: Total treatment duration for evaluation of primary endpoint is 9 weeks (week 1 to week 10). Study duration total 12 weeks, includes 1 week placebo run-in, 9 weeks active treatment start to blinded endpoint, plus 2 weeks treatment from blinded endpoint to study end.
Dose at Study End Point Detail: for n=205 treated
Trauma Detail (Study level): Rape/sexual assault; Accidents; Community/school violence; Other (exposure to sudden death; 'other')
Citation: Davis LL, Behl S, Lee D, et al. Brexpiprazole and Sertraline Combination Treatment in Posttraumatic Stress Disorder: A Phase 3 Randomized Clinical Trial. JAMA Psychiatry. 2024 Dec 18;18:18. doi: 10.1001/jamapsychiatry.2024.3996. PMID: 39693081.

Arm N Randomized Detail: n=134 in efficacy sample analyzed
Treatment Description:
One week placebo run-in period (placebo + placebo) followed by sertraline + placebo. 
Placebo: matching placebo
Sertraline: SSRI, 150 mg per day taken orally at same time as brexpiprazole. Titration: week 1, 50 mg/day; week 2, 100 mg/day; week 3 on, 150 mg/day.
Washout for prohibited medications (including psychotropic agents) during screening period.
Dose: 150 mg/day. Titration: week 1, 50 mg/day; week 2, 100 mg/day; week 3 on, 150 mg/day.
Treatment Duration Detail: Total treatment duration for evaluation of primary endpoint is 9 weeks (week 1 to week 10). Study duration total 12 weeks, includes 1 week placebo run-in, 9 weeks active treatment start to blinded endpoint, plus 2 weeks treatment from blinded endpoint to study end.
Trauma Detail (Study level): Rape/sexual assault; Accidents; Community/school violence; Other (exposure to sudden death; 'other')
Citation: Davis LL, Behl S, Lee D, et al. Brexpiprazole and Sertraline Combination Treatment in Posttraumatic Stress Disorder: A Phase 3 Randomized Clinical Trial. JAMA Psychiatry. 2024 Dec 18;18:18. doi: 10.1001/jamapsychiatry.2024.3996. PMID: 39693081.

Treatment Description: Mindfulness-based mobile application, expands Mindfulness Coach app by adding mindfulness-based relapse prevention content, for a total of 16 modules. App contains a self-guided training program with psychoeducation on topics related to mindfulness, audio-guided mindfulness exercises, self-assessments, journals, goal setting and customizable reminders, and access to support and crisis resources. Participants asked to complete 2 modules per week, and received text/email reminders to use the app every other week from the program coordinator.
Completed Treatment Definition: Completing 75% or more of the modules
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: Also reports number completing different percentages of modules (less than 25% of modules, 25-49%, and 50-74% of modules) and average number of times participants logged into app
Citation: Davis JP, Pedersen ER, Borsari B, Bowen S, Owen JE, Sedano A, Tran DD, Saba S, Fitzke RE, Delacruz J, Canning L. Effects of a mobile mindfulness smartphone app on posttraumatic stress disorder symptoms and alcohol use problems for veterans: A pilot randomized controlled trial. J Consult Clin Psychol. 2025 Feb;93(2):96-109. doi: 10.1037/ccp0000940. PMID: 39913485.

Treatment Description: Participants received stress management content, with no mindfulness components, via link sent weekly. Designed as an active control condition in mindfulness-based intervention trials. Content topics included effects of stress on physiology, sleep, and the immune system; psychoeducation for time management, nutrition, and developing an exercise routine.
Citation: Davis JP, Pedersen ER, Borsari B, Bowen S, Owen JE, Sedano A, Tran DD, Saba S, Fitzke RE, Delacruz J, Canning L. Effects of a mobile mindfulness smartphone app on posttraumatic stress disorder symptoms and alcohol use problems for veterans: A pilot randomized controlled trial. J Consult Clin Psychol. 2025 Feb;93(2):96-109. doi: 10.1037/ccp0000940. PMID: 39913485.

Treatment Description: Trauma-focused writing using exposure and cognitive reprocessing, considered a form of tauma reprocessing. Participants instructed to write about the traumatic experience they felt was contributing the most to their current symptoms; some instructions adapted from 'Interapy' protocol. Sessions included check-in, 20 minutes of writing, and debrief; supportive nondirective counseling during check-in and debrief.
Session Length:
Session 1: 60-90 minutes
Sessions 2-3: 40-60 minutes
Writing portion: 20 minutes each session
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: did not drop out before or during intervention
Psychotherapy Sessions Completed Detail: Gives number that dropped out prior to given session numbers, but for overall sample only (not by arm)
Trauma Detail (Study level): Accidents; Combat-related; Community/school violence; Illness/medical procedure; Intimate partner violence; Natural or manmade disasters;  Rape/sexual assault; Other ("war zone", child abuse [not further specified], "vicarious trauma", "witnessing traumatic death of other/tramatic loss", "adoption trauma", "other")
Citation: Dawson RL, Nixon RDV, Calear AL, Sivanathan D, O'Kearney R. Efficacy of two brief trauma-focussed writing interventions in comparison to positive experiences writing: A randomized controlled trial. J Affect Disord. 2024 Aug 1;358:449-457. doi: 10.1016/j.jad.2024.05.014. Epub 2024 May 10. PMID: 38734242.

Treatment Description: Trauma-focused writing, with instructions adapted from disclosure and written exposure therapy protocols, theorized to be a form of repeated exposure to the trauma. Participants instructed to write in depth about their thoughts, feelings and sensations related to a traumatic event that they felt  contributed the most to current symptoms. Sessions included check-in, 20 minutes of writing, and debrief; supportive nondirective counseling during check-in and debrief.
Session Length:
Session 1: 60-90 minutes
Sessions 2-3: 40-60 minutes
Writing portion: 20 minutes each session
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: did not drop out before or during intervention
Psychotherapy Sessions Completed Detail: Gives number that dropped out prior to given session numbers, but for overall sample only (not by arm)
Trauma Detail (Study level): Accidents; Combat-related; Community/school violence; Illness/medical procedure; Intimate partner violence; Natural or manmade disasters;  Rape/sexual assault; Other ("war zone", child abuse [not further specified], "vicarious trauma", "witnessing traumatic death of other/tramatic loss", "adoption trauma", "other")
Citation: Dawson RL, Nixon RDV, Calear AL, Sivanathan D, O'Kearney R. Efficacy of two brief trauma-focussed writing interventions in comparison to positive experiences writing: A randomized controlled trial. J Affect Disord. 2024 Aug 1;358:449-457. doi: 10.1016/j.jad.2024.05.014. Epub 2024 May 10. PMID: 38734242.

Treatment Description: Non-trauma focused writing. Participants instructed to write in depth about a past positive experience, and encouraged to imagine themselves in the event and to reexperience the thoughts and feelings that occurred during the event; instructions from Intensely Positive Experiences writing protocol. Participants given the same instructions given each session. Sessions included check-in, 20 minutes of writing, and debrief; supportive nondirective counseling during check-in and debrief.
Session Length:
Session 1: 60-90 minutes
Sessions 2-3: 40-60 minutes
Writing portion: 20 minutes each session
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: did not drop out before or during intervention
Psychotherapy Sessions Completed Detail: Gives number that dropped out prior to given session numbers, but for overall sample only (not by arm)
Trauma Detail (Study level): Accidents; Combat-related; Community/school violence; Illness/medical procedure; Intimate partner violence; Natural or manmade disasters;  Rape/sexual assault; Other ("war zone", child abuse [not further specified], "vicarious trauma", "witnessing traumatic death of other/tramatic loss", "adoption trauma", "other")
Citation: Dawson RL, Nixon RDV, Calear AL, Sivanathan D, O'Kearney R. Efficacy of two brief trauma-focussed writing interventions in comparison to positive experiences writing: A randomized controlled trial. J Affect Disord. 2024 Aug 1;358:449-457. doi: 10.1016/j.jad.2024.05.014. Epub 2024 May 10. PMID: 38734242.

Treatment Description:
Concurrent individual CPT and art therapy.
CPT: sessions 1 through 8 of manualized treatment (Resick, Monson, & Chard, 2007) "designed to challenge negative cognitions associated with trauma" .
Art therapy: followed protocol by Campbell (2014) and involving "psychoeducation, goal setting, creating a sense of safety, creating and processing one’s visual trauma narrative, identifying and addressing symptoms and triggers, integrating the trauma with the rest of their experiences, identifying grief and loss caused by combat trauma, reconstructing worldviews and self-concept, and reviewing artworks and recovery-oriented goals... participants were given six directives to construct the visual trauma narrative: 1) Create an image of a time before the trauma that you felt peaceful and safe—a positive memory; 2) Create an image of the last moment you remember directly before the trauma; 3) Create an image of what happened during the trauma; 4) Create an image of a moment you can remember right after the trauma; 5) Create an image of a time when you were safe from the physical threats of war; 6) Create an image of a time when you tried to self-soothe."
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: flow diagram, also described as study completers
Citation: Decker KP, Deaver SP, Abbey V, et al. Quantitatively improved treatment outcomes for combat-associated PTSD with adjunctive art therapy: randomized controlled trial. Art Therapy. 2018;35(4):184-94. doi: 10.1080/07421656.2018.1540822.

Treatment Description:
Concurrent individual CPT and supportive psychotherapy.



CPT: sessions 1 through 8 of manualized treatment (Resick, Monson, & Chard, 2007) "designed to challenge negative cognitions associated with trauma".



Supportive psychotherapy: "focused on present-centered concerns, with the goal of reinforcing healthy and adaptive patterns of thoughts and behaviors to reduce symptoms of PTSD and depression"
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: flow diagram, also described as study completers
Citation: Decker KP, Deaver SP, Abbey V, et al. Quantitatively improved treatment outcomes for combat-associated PTSD with adjunctive art therapy: randomized controlled trial. Art Therapy. 2018;35(4):184-94. doi: 10.1080/07421656.2018.1540822.

Treatment Description: Combined CPT and smoking cessation; "smoking was conceptualized and integrated into treatment as an avoidance behavior that interferes with processing PTSD symptoms". Participants taught to apply cognitive restructuring skills from CPT to smoking cessation. Smoking cessation content followed Integrated Care for Smoking Cessation treatment manual, and was identical to that of the Present-focused smoking cessation arm except for use of cognitive restructuring skills in the CPT arm.
Citation: Dedert EA, Resick PA, Dennis PA, et al. Pilot trial of a combined cognitive processing therapy and smoking cessation treatment. J Addict Med. 2019 Jul/Aug;13(4):322-30. doi: 10.1097/ADM.0000000000000502. PMID: 30664539.

Treatment Description: Cognitive behavioral smoking cessation treatment following the Integrated Care for Smoking Cessation manual; treatment is present-focused. "The smoking cessation treatment in this arm was identical to the smoking cessation component of the [combined CPT + smoking cessation] group, except that the [present-focused smoking cessation] arm did not utilize formal cognitive restructuring to address smoking triggers."
Citation: Dedert EA, Resick PA, Dennis PA, et al. Pilot trial of a combined cognitive processing therapy and smoking cessation treatment. J Addict Med. 2019 Jul/Aug;13(4):322-30. doi: 10.1097/ADM.0000000000000502. PMID: 30664539.

Treatment Description:
D-cycloserine prior to PE sessions







PE: standardized program including prolonged imaginal exposure (30 minutes each session), in vivo exposure assignments and homework of exposure using recorded session audiotape.







D-cycloserine: glutamatergic N-methyl-D-aspartate receptor partial agonist, taken 1 hour prior to start of each PE session
Dose: 50 mg
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, rape/sexual assault, accidents, other (violent nonsexual assault; "miscellaneous")
Citation: de Kleine RA, Hendriks GJ, Kusters WJ, et al. A randomized placebo-controlled trial of D-cycloserine to enhance exposure therapy for posttraumatic stress disorder. Biol Psychiatry. 2012 Jun 1;71(11):962-8. doi: 10.1016/j.biopsych.2012.02.033. PMID: 22480663.

Treatment Description:
Placebo prior to PE sessions







PE: standardized program including prolonged imaginal exposure (30 minutes each session), in vivo exposure assignments and homework of exposure using recorded session audiotape.







Placebo: identical in appearance to D-cycloserine, taken 1 hour prior to start of each PE session
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, rape/sexual assault, accidents, other (violent nonsexual assault; "miscellaneous")
Citation: de Kleine RA, Hendriks GJ, Kusters WJ, et al. A randomized placebo-controlled trial of D-cycloserine to enhance exposure therapy for posttraumatic stress disorder. Biol Psychiatry. 2012 Jun 1;71(11):962-8. doi: 10.1016/j.biopsych.2012.02.033. PMID: 22480663.

Treatment Description: Online CBM training completed at home. Participant responded to a series of 40 scripted vignettes representing domains of the PTCI. Sentence completion format: two sentences, with second sentence including a word fragment to be completed. Participant typed a missing letter which gave the sentence a positive meaning.
Trauma Detail (Study level): Child physical abuse; Child sexual abuse; Child other abuse; Rape/sexual assault; Intimate partner violence; Community/school violence
Citation: de Kleine RA, Woud ML, Ferentzi H, et al. Appraisal-based cognitive bias modification in patients with posttraumatic stress disorder: a randomised clinical trial. Eur J Psychotraumatol. 2019 Jul 8;10(1):1625690. doi: 10.1080/20008198.2019.1625690. PMID: 31448063.

Treatment Description: Online control training completed at home. Pesponded to a series of 40 scripted vignettes representing domains of the PTCI. Sentence completion format: two sentences, with second sentence including a word fragment to be completed. Participant typed a missing letter which gave the sentence a neutral meaning.
Trauma Detail (Study level): Child physical abuse; Child sexual abuse; Child other abuse; Rape/sexual assault; Intimate partner violence; Community/school violence
Citation: de Kleine RA, Woud ML, Ferentzi H, et al. Appraisal-based cognitive bias modification in patients with posttraumatic stress disorder: a randomised clinical trial. Eur J Psychotraumatol. 2019 Jul 8;10(1):1625690. doi: 10.1080/20008198.2019.1625690. PMID: 31448063.

Treatment Description: Therapy with in vivo homework, using fear extinction through engaging with the traumatic memory. Identical to standard therapy but sessions delivered over 2 weeks. Intervention adapted during COVID-19 restrictions to include telehealth treatment (same format and duration of therapy but using online video platforms)
Treatment Duration Detail: Reported as both 2 weeks and 10 days (may be weekdays only)
Trauma Detail (Study level): Combat-related; Other (trauma occurring during military service but not required to be specific to deployment)
Citation: Dell L, Sbisa AM, Forbes A, et al. Effect of massed v. standard prolonged exposure therapy on PTSD in military personnel and veterans: a non-inferiority randomised controlled trial. Psychol Med. 2022 Apr 20:1-8. doi: 10.1017/S0033291722000927. PMID: 35440345.

Treatment Description: Standard manualised therapy with in vivo homework, using fear extinction through engaging with the traumatic memory. Delivered over 10 weeks. Intervention adapted during COVID-19 restrictions to include telehealth treatment (same format and duration of therapy but using online video platforms)
Trauma Detail (Study level): Combat-related; Other (trauma occurring during military service but not required to be specific to deployment)
Citation: Dell L, Sbisa AM, Forbes A, et al. Effect of massed v. standard prolonged exposure therapy on PTSD in military personnel and veterans: a non-inferiority randomised controlled trial. Psychol Med. 2022 Apr 20:1-8. doi: 10.1017/S0033291722000927. PMID: 35440345.

Treatment Description: Participants track extreme hand movements while holding in mind a representative picture of the traumatic event. On average, 24 back-and-forth sweeps were given for each set until subjective units of distress decrease to 0. Eye movement desensitization repeated until no more imaginal picture arises
Citation: Devilly GJ, Spence SH, Rapee RM. Statistical and reliable change with eye movement desensitization and reprocessing: treating trauma within a veteran population. Behav. Ther. 1998 Summer;29(3):435-55. doi: 10.1016/S0005-7894(98)80042-7.

Treatment Name: Reactive Eye Dilation Desensitization and Reprocessing
Treatment Description: Participant concentrates on the imaginal picture and accompanying body sensation while concentrating on a black box emitting flashing light at rate of 4 flashes per second.
Citation: Devilly GJ, Spence SH, Rapee RM. Statistical and reliable change with eye movement desensitization and reprocessing: treating trauma within a veteran population. Behav. Ther. 1998 Summer;29(3):435-55. doi: 10.1016/S0005-7894(98)80042-7.

Treatment Description: Participants continued their usual treatment without additional support from research therapist
Citation: Devilly GJ, Spence SH, Rapee RM. Statistical and reliable change with eye movement desensitization and reprocessing: treating trauma within a veteran population. Behav. Ther. 1998 Summer;29(3):435-55. doi: 10.1016/S0005-7894(98)80042-7.

Arm N Randomized Detail: 15 randomized, 12 completers analyzed
Treatment Description: Variant of CBT utilizing components from SIT (stress inoculation training), PE (prolonged exposure) and in-depth cognitive therapy
Treatment Duration Detail: 9 sessions, frequency NR; unclear treatment duration; arm C (control) had post-treatment assessment at 5 weeks
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: 2 participants completed 8 sessions (implies remaining 10 participants completed 9 sessions)
Trauma Detail (Study level): Accidents; Natural or manmade disasters; Rape/sexual assault; Community/school violence; Other ("war zone")
Citation: Devilly GJ, Spence C. The relative efficacy and treatment distress of EMDR and a cognitive-behavior trauma treatment protocol in the amelioration of posttraumatic stress disorder. J Anxiety Disord. 1999 2016-09-15;13(1-2):131-57. doi: 10.1016/S0887-6185(98)00044-9. PMID: 10225505.

Arm N Randomized Detail: 17 randomized, 11 completers analyzed
Treatment Description: Protocol using EMDR and exploring associated trauma and personal history
Treatment Duration Detail: 8 sessions, frequency NR; unclear treatment duration; arm C (control) had post-treatment assessment at 5 weeks
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: 2 participants completed 7 sessions (implies remaining 9 participants completed 8 sessions)
Trauma Detail (Study level): Accidents; Natural or manmade disasters; Rape/sexual assault; Community/school violence; Other ("war zone")
Citation: Devilly GJ, Spence C. The relative efficacy and treatment distress of EMDR and a cognitive-behavior trauma treatment protocol in the amelioration of posttraumatic stress disorder. J Anxiety Disord. 1999 2016-09-15;13(1-2):131-57. doi: 10.1016/S0887-6185(98)00044-9. PMID: 10225505.

Treatment Name: Exposure therapy with virtual reality plus D-cycloserine
Treatment Description: Participants recounted their trauma while wearing a virtual reality helmet with a computer simulation of the September 11th attacks. Graded scenarios increased in intensity and detail, target of 45 minutes "in the virtual world". D-cycloserine: antibiotic, also used as a cognitive enhancer, given 90 minutes before sessions beginning with session 2.
Dose: 100 mg
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: reports number completed the intervention; none dropped out from this arm
Participant Adherence Definition: verbal inquiry about medication ingestion before session
Citation: Difede J, Cukor J, Wyka KE, et al. D-cycloserine augmentation of exposure therapy for post-traumatic stress disorder: a pilot randomized clinical trial. Neuropsychopharmacology. 2014 Apr;39(5):1052-108. doi: 10.1038/npp.2013.317. PMID: 24217129.

Treatment Name: Exposure therapy with virtual reality plus placebo
Treatment Description: Participants recounted their trauma while wearing a virtual reality helmet with a computer simulation of the September 11th attacks. Graded scenarios increased in intensity and detail, goal 45 minutes "in the virtual world". Matched placebo given 90 minutes prior to start of therapy beginning at session 2.
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: reports number completed the intervention; from this arm, n=3 dropped out (after sessions 3, 6 and 7)
Participant Adherence Definition: verbal inquiry about medication ingestion before session
Citation: Difede J, Cukor J, Wyka KE, et al. D-cycloserine augmentation of exposure therapy for post-traumatic stress disorder: a pilot randomized clinical trial. Neuropsychopharmacology. 2014 Apr;39(5):1052-108. doi: 10.1038/npp.2013.317. PMID: 24217129.

Arm N Randomized Detail: See Study Comments
Treatment Description:
VRE: first 2 sessions, therapists collected information, explained PTSD, gave rationale for treatment, and taught breathing retraining. Following 7 sessions included exposure using VR equipment that allowed movement through a virtual environment, and simulated settings and  sounds, visual stimuli, and tactile stimuli (e.g. vibration). Patient recounted trauma and therapist adjusted setting and stimuli to simulate the traumatic memory. 

DCS: partial NMDA agonist mediating learning, memory, and fear extinction; given when patient arrived, 30 minutes before session, starting at session 3
Citation: Difede J, Rothbaum BO, Rizzo AA, et al. Enhancing exposure therapy for posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD): a randomized clinical trial of virtual reality and imaginal exposure with a cognitive enhancer. Translational psychiatry. 2022;12(1):299. doi: 10.1038/s41398-022-02066-x. PMID: 35896533.

Arm N Randomized Detail: See Study Comments
Treatment Description:
VRE: first 2 sessions, therapists collected information, explained PTSD, gave rationale for treatment, and taught breathing retraining. Following 7 sessions included exposure using VR equipment that allowed movement through a virtual environment, and simulated settings and  sounds, visual stimuli, and tactile stimuli (e.g. vibration). Patient recounted trauma and therapist adjusted setting and stimuli to simulate the traumatic memory. 

Placebo: given when patient arrived, 30 minutes before session, starting at session 3

Translational psychiatry. 2022;12(1):299. doi: 10.1038/s41398-022-02066-x. PMID: 35896533.

Arm N Randomized Detail: See Study Comments
Treatment Description:
PE: first 2 sessions, therapists collected information, explained PTSD, gave rationale for treatment, and taught breathing retraining; in remaining 7 sessions, patients "instructed to close their

eyes, imagine the scene of their trauma, and repeatedly recount the

trauma vividly, aloud, and in the present tense."

DCS: partial NMDA agonist mediating learning, memory, and fear extinction; given when patient arrived, 30 minutes before session, starting at session 3
Citation: Difede J, Rothbaum BO, Rizzo AA, et al. Enhancing exposure therapy for posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD): a randomized clinical trial of virtual reality and imaginal exposure with a cognitive enhancer. Translational psychiatry. 2022;12(1):299. doi: 10.1038/s41398-022-02066-x. PMID: 35896533.

Arm N Randomized Detail: See Study Comments
Treatment Description:
PE: first 2 sessions, therapists collected information, explained PTSD, gave rationale for treatment, and taught breathing retraining; in remaining 7 sessions, patients "instructed to close their

eyes, imagine the scene of their trauma, and repeatedly recount the

trauma vividly, aloud, and in the present tense."

Placebo: given when patient arrived, 30 minutes before session, starting at session 3

Treatment Description: HBOT administered in a multiplace chamber (HAUX-Life-Support GmbH). Exposure to 100% oxygen at 2 atmospheres absolute (ATA), with 5-minute air breaks every 20 minutes. Continued baseline psychotherapy and pharmacotherapy; no additional psychotherapy given.
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: n=1 stopped after 20 sessions, n=3 had frequent interruptions due to illness
Citation: Doenyas-Barak K, Catalogna M, Kutz I, et al. Hyperbaric oxygen therapy improves symptoms, brain's microstructure and functionality in veterans with treatment resistant post-traumatic stress disorder: a prospective, randomized, controlled trial. PLoS One. 2022 Feb 22;17(2):e0264161. doi: 10.1371/journal.pone.0264161. PMID: 35192645.

Treatment Description: No intervention; continued baseline psychotherapy and pharmacotherapy.
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: n=15 completed control protocol
Citation: Doenyas-Barak K, Catalogna M, Kutz I, et al. Hyperbaric oxygen therapy improves symptoms, brain's microstructure and functionality in veterans with treatment resistant post-traumatic stress disorder: a prospective, randomized, controlled trial. PLoS One. 2022 Feb 22;17(2):e0264161. doi: 10.1371/journal.pone.0264161. PMID: 35192645.

Arm N Randomized Detail: n=34 randomized, 28 analyzed; 2 withdrawn for illicit substance/alcohol use during trial, 4 withdrew consent
Treatment Description: Hyperbaric oxygen treatment; 60 daily sessions, with 90 minutes of exposure to 100% oxygen at 2 atmospheres absolute (ATA) with 5-minute air breaks every 20 minutes. Groups of 4-6 participants, since HBOT chambers accommodate up to 6 subjects.
Dose: 100% oxygen at 2 atmospheres absolute
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: n=28 included in analysis, "all participants except 8 patients in the sham group completed at least 50 sessions"; so using n=28 for completers (n=28 analyzed minus n=0 [all noncompleters in sham group]); completers 82.35% (28/34)
Citation: Doenyas-Barak K, Kutz I, Lang E, Assouline A, Hadanny A, Aberg KC, Levi G, Beberashvili I, Mayo A, Efrati S. Hyperbaric Oxygen Therapy for Veterans With Combat-Associated Posttraumatic Stress Disorder: A Randomized, Sham-Controlled Clinical Trial. J Clin Psychiatry. 2024 Nov 10;85(4):24m15464. doi: 10.4088/JCP.24m15464. PMID: 39566051.

Arm N Randomized Detail: n=29 randomized, 28 analyzed; 1  withdrew consent
Treatment Description: Sham hyperbaric oxygen treatment; 60 daily sessions, with 90 minutes of exposure to 21% oxygen at 1.02 atmospheres absolute (ATA). Compression to 1.2 ATA was performed for the first 5 minutes to achieve blinding and have subjects perform pressure equalization, this was followed by slow decompression to 1.02 ATA in the next 5 minutes (minimum pressure required to keep chanber door closed). Groups of 4-6 participants, since HBOT chambers accommodate up to 6 subjects.
Dose: 21% oxygen at 1.02 atmospheres absolute
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: n=28 included in analysis, "all participants except 8 patients in the sham group completed at least 50 sessions"; so using n=20 for completers (n=28 analyzed minus n=8); completers 68.97% (20/29)
Citation: Doenyas-Barak K, Kutz I, Lang E, Assouline A, Hadanny A, Aberg KC, Levi G, Beberashvili I, Mayo A, Efrati S. Hyperbaric Oxygen Therapy for Veterans With Combat-Associated Posttraumatic Stress Disorder: A Randomized, Sham-Controlled Clinical Trial. J Clin Psychiatry. 2024 Nov 10;85(4):24m15464. doi: 10.4088/JCP.24m15464. PMID: 39566051.

Standardized Treatment Name: Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) without a trauma focus
Treatment Description: Participants received individual treatment as usual by a psychotherapist, psychiatric nurse, or psychiatrist. In addition, participants received a stabilizing group CBT program based on manual by Zlotnick et al. (1997). Group session included psychoeducation aimed at attaining a sense of cognitive mastery, cognitive behavioral skills focused on identifying and modifying dysfunctional behavior, thoughts, and beliefs about the trauma. Treatment focused on the present, positive reinforcement, and empowerment, and avoided sharing individual trauma histories
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: Study reports attrition from measurement and completer analysis, no information specifically for treatment completion
Trauma Detail (Study level): child sexual abuse, child physical abuse
Citation: Dorrepaal E, Thomaes K, Smit JH, et al. Stabilizing group treatment for complex posttraumatic stress disorder related to child abuse based on psychoeducation and cognitive behavioural therapy: a multisite randomized controlled trial. Psychother Psychosom. 2012;81(4):217-25. doi: 10.1159/000335044. PMID: 22585094.

Treatment Description: Participants received individual treatment by a psychotherapist, psychiatric nurse, or psychiatrist
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: Study reports attrition from measurement and completer analysis, no information specifically for treatment completion
Trauma Detail (Study level): child sexual abuse, child physical abuse
Citation: Dorrepaal E, Thomaes K, Smit JH, et al. Stabilizing group treatment for complex posttraumatic stress disorder related to child abuse based on psychoeducation and cognitive behavioural therapy: a multisite randomized controlled trial. Psychother Psychosom. 2012;81(4):217-25. doi: 10.1159/000335044. PMID: 22585094.

Treatment Description: Manualized therapy delivered in person or by secure video chat. Comprised of "education about common reactions to trauma, breathing retraining, prolonged (repeated) imaginal exposure to trauma memories, repeated in vivo exposure to situations that participants are avoiding due to trauma-related fear, and discussion of thoughts and feelings related to the trauma." "Treatment also entails processing, consisting of a discussion following imaginal exposure,which aims to address participants’ unrealistic beliefs about themselves, the world, and other people and to “make sense” of the trauma." In vivo exposure practice was limited by mobility and environmental factors during inpatient hospitalization; exercises included "listening to audio clips of repeated gunshots or ambulance sirens, watching videos or looking at pictures of automobile accidents, and practicing sitting in or transferring into a car shell that was on the therapy floor of the hospital."
Completed Treatment Definition: Completed allocated number of sessions (all planned sessions)
Psychotherapy Sessions Completed Detail: All participants completed at least one PE session; 50% (8) participants received at least 3 PE sessions (at least one session with exposure)
Trauma Detail (Study level): Spinal cord injury (traumatic or nontraumatic)
Citation: Douglas ME, Bennett M, Jones KA, Pogue JR, Chauvette GV, Sikka S, Driver S, Hamilton R, Curcio N, Patel S, Wierzchowski A, Adams M, Thomas EV, Turner E, Leonard K, Carl E, Foreman M, Warren AM, Powers MB. Prolonged exposure for posttraumatic stress disorder following spinal cord injury: A randomized controlled trial. Rehabil Psychol. 2024 Aug 29. doi: 10.1037/rep0000580. Epub ahead of print. PMID: 39207423.

Arm N Randomized Detail: 14 randomized, 13 analyzed
Treatment Description: Standard clinical treatment for spinal cord injury inpatients at the rehabilitation hopsital; "includes an evaluation by a licensed clinical psychologist or master’s level therapist and continued follow-up treatment as needed. The content of individual therapy sessions varies, but typical inpatient mental health sessions predominantly address psychological adjustment to disability and management of mood and anxiety. TAU did not include PE or other exposure-based therapies."
Trauma Detail (Study level): Spinal cord injury (traumatic or nontraumatic)
Citation: Douglas ME, Bennett M, Jones KA, Pogue JR, Chauvette GV, Sikka S, Driver S, Hamilton R, Curcio N, Patel S, Wierzchowski A, Adams M, Thomas EV, Turner E, Leonard K, Carl E, Foreman M, Warren AM, Powers MB. Prolonged exposure for posttraumatic stress disorder following spinal cord injury: A randomized controlled trial. Rehabil Psychol. 2024 Aug 29. doi: 10.1037/rep0000580. Epub ahead of print. PMID: 39207423.

Treatment Description: Gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA) alpha receptor agonist indicated for the treatment of sleep, given at bedtime
Dose: 3 mg
Trauma Detail (Study level): Rape/sexual assault; Accidents; Illness/medical procedure; Community/school violence; Natural or manmade disasters; Other (observed violence to or death of a loved one)
