Treatment Description: Individual psychotherapy adapted from IPT to address needs of depressed women with childhood sexual abuse histories in the community health setting. The 4 adaptations to the IPT protocol are: 1) expanded treatment period to 16 sessions over 32 weeks; 2) used engagement analysis to "help patients identify and problem-solve social, practical, and psychological barriers to treatment participation"; 3) used a sociocultural formulation "to help patients identify ways in which cultural and economic influences (e.g., family beliefs, ethnic identities, religious practices, racism, and poverty) may affect their interpersonal problems and depression"; 4) an "interpersonal-patterns" problem area replaced the "interpersonal deficits" problem  area, "the interpersonal-patterns problem area is used to help patients recognize longstanding patterns of behavior and emotion commonly seen among individuals with trauma histories that could undermine social health"
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: Study reports attrition from measurement and completer analysis, no information specifically for treatment completion
Citation: Duberstein PR, Ward EA, Chaudron LH, et al. Effectiveness of interpersonal psychotherapy-trauma for depressed women with childhood abuse histories. J Consult Clin Psychol. 2018 Oct;86(10):868-78. doi: 10.1037/ccp0000335. PMID: 30265045.

Treatment Description: Clinician choice of psychotherapy among treatments typically used in a community mental health clinic; therapists were not restricted from "reasonable therapeutic activities or interventions"
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: reports asssessment/study completion only
Citation: Duberstein PR, Ward EA, Chaudron LH, et al. Effectiveness of interpersonal psychotherapy-trauma for depressed women with childhood abuse histories. J Consult Clin Psychol. 2018 Oct;86(10):868-78. doi: 10.1037/ccp0000335. PMID: 30265045.

Treatment Description:
Single ketamine infusion followed by 4 sessions of PE.
Ketamine: single infusion over 40 minutes
PE: initial session (prior to ketamine) included information on the disorder and building exposure hierarchy; 4 sessions of exposure therapy following ketamine (started one day after ketamine infusion) included imaginal exposure, recall and reconsolidation of the traumatic memory, and in vivo exposure (for a total of 5 sessions).
Dose: 0.5 mg/kg, single infusion over 40 minutes
Treatment Duration Detail:
Ketamine: single infusion
PE: 5 consecutive days
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: flow diagram, n=14 randomized minus n=2 did not complete therapy
Trauma Detail (Study level): Combat-related; Rape/sexual assault; Community/school violence; Other (not specified)
Citation: Duek O, Korem N, Li Y, et al. Long term structural and functional neural changes following a single infusion of Ketamine in PTSD. Neuropsychopharmacology. 2023 Jun 03;03:03. doi: 10.1038/s41386-023-01606-3. PMID: 37270621.

Treatment Description:
Single midazolam infusion followed by 4 sessions of PE.
Midazolam: single infusion over 40 minutes
PE: initial session (prior to midazolam) included information on the disorder and building exposure hierarchy; 4 sessions of exposure therapy following midazolam (started one day after midazolam infusion) included imaginal exposure, recall and reconsolidation of the traumatic memory, and in vivo exposure (for a total of 5 sessions).
Dose: 0.045 mg/kg, single infusion over 40 minutes
Treatment Duration Detail:
Midazolam: single infusion
PE: 5 consecutive days
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: flow diagram, n=14 randomized minus n=1 did not complete therapy
Trauma Detail (Study level): Combat-related; Rape/sexual assault; Community/school violence; Other (not specified)

Treatment Description: Based on Ehlers and Clark's model that addresses excessively negative appraisals of the traumatic event or its sequelae, disturbance in autobiographical memory, and dysfunctional cognitive and behavioral strategies. Includes behavioral activation early in therapy.
Completed Treatment Definition: completed ≥6 sessions or ended therapy earlier as agreed by the therapist because of noticeable improvement
Psychotherapy Sessions Completed Detail: patients received additional average 2.0 [SD 3.2] sessions after 12-week period for a total of 7.8 [SD 5.1] sessions
Trauma Detail (Study level): terrorism/political violence/forced displacement, community/school violence, accidents
Citation: Duffy M, Gillespie K, Clark DM. Post-traumatic stress disorder in the context of terrorism and other civil conflict in Northern Ireland: randomised controlled trial. BMJ. 2007 Jun 2;334(7604):1147-50. doi: 10.1136/bmj.39021.846852.BE. PMID: 17495988.

Dose: 350 mg

Treatment Description: Vortioxetine 10-20 mg/day. Initiated at 10 mg/day for 4 weeks, then optional increase to 20 mg/day at discretion of study psychiatrist based on effectiveness and tolerability; dose reductions allowed for intolerabe adverse effects.
Dose: 10-20 mg/day; initial dose 10 mg/day for 4 weeks, then optional increase to 20 mg/day
Participants Adhered Percent Detail: Patients recorded daily administration in a diary which was reviewed by treatment team to assess adherence.

Arm N Randomized Detail: 55 randomized, 4 declined to enter treatment and were excluded from analysis; data reported for n=51 randomized and entered treatment
Treatment Description: Manualized therapy with education on depression (including effects of activity and thoughts on mood, attributions for positive and negative events, goal setting, and self-reinforcement for gains), group discussion, and homework including self-monitoring positive activities and mood. All participants also received Trauma Recovery Program care prior to and throughout the course of the study, includes PTSD education and anger management, and medication as indicated.
Completed Treatment Definition: Attending ≥7 sessions and the posttest interview
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: Percent completed of participants randomized and entered treatment (34/51)
Citation: Dunn NJ, Rehm LP, Schillaci J, et al. A randomized trial of self-management and psychoeducational group therapies for comorbid chronic posttraumatic stress disorder and depressive disorder. J Trauma Stress. 2007 Jun;20(3):221-37. doi: 10.1002/jts.20214. PMID: 17598141.

Arm N Randomized Detail: 56 randomized, 6 declined to enter treatment and were excluded from analysis; data reported for n=50 randomized and entered treatment
Treatment Description: Manualized therapy with education on PTSD and depression, but no instruction on behavior change. Weekly homework, session feedback, and self-assessment. All participants also received Trauma Recovery Program care prior to and throughout the course of the study, includes PTSD education and anger management, and medication as indicated.
Completed Treatment Definition: Attending ≥7 sessions and the posttest interview
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: Percent completed of participants randomized and entered treatment (44/50)
Citation: Dunn NJ, Rehm LP, Schillaci J, et al. A randomized trial of self-management and psychoeducational group therapies for comorbid chronic posttraumatic stress disorder and depressive disorder. J Trauma Stress. 2007 Jun;20(3):221-37. doi: 10.1002/jts.20214. PMID: 17598141.

Treatment Description: Treatment according to the Australian Guidelines for the treatment of Adult with Acute Stress Disorder for PTSD (Australian Centre for Posttraumatic Mental Health. Australian Guidelines for the Treatment of Adults with Acute Stress Disorder and Post-traumatic Stress Disorder. Melbourne, VIC: ACPMH; 2007). Treatment included psychoeducation, anxiety management by deep breathing and progressive muscle relaxation, cognitive restructuring, imaginal exposure, graded in vivo exposure, and relapse prevention.
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: completed all 10 sessions by posttreatment assessment; another n=1 completed treatment between posttreatment assessment and 6 month follow-up (not included in entered value)
Citation: Dunne RL, Kenardy JA, Sterling M. A randomized controlled trial of cognitive-behavioral therapy for the treatment of PTSD in the context of chronic whiplash. Clin J Pain. 2012 Nov-Dec;28(9):755-65. doi: 10.1097/AJP.0b013e318243e16b. PMID: 22209798.

Treatment Description: Manualized protocol founded on prolonged imaginal exposure techniques using a hierarchy of feared situations from those eliciting the least anxiety or discomfort to those that are the most difficult

Treatment Description: Treatment seeks to modify negative thoughts associated with rape. Coping skills training includes progressive muscular relaxation, thought-stopping, cognitive distractions, and instruction in gradual exposure
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: "There were no refusals of treatment or dropouts from the program. "
Citation: Echeburua E, de Corral P, Sarasua B, et al. Treatment of acute posttraumatic stress disorder in rape victims: an experimental study. J Anxiety Disord. 1996 May-Jun;10(3):185-99. doi: 10.1016/0887-6185(96)89842-2.

Treatment Description: Progressive muscular relaxation training according to Bernstein & Borkovec (1973)
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: "There were no refusals of treatment or dropouts from the program. "

Treatment Description: A behavioral intervention that promotes behavioral and neural changes in response inhibition; "computerized training program that randomizes visual stimuli (letters: E, A, M, O, S, T, colors: Blue, Cyan, Green, Red, White) as Go and No-Go stimuli in which participants are instructed to respond as fast as possible to a set of stimuli (Go) while withholding their responses to another set of stimuli (No-Go)".
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: study reports on study completers only, not stated if these participants also completed treatment sessions ("training and waitlist groups of this study consisted of individuals who completed pre- and -post training sessions"
Citation: Echiverri-Cohen A, Spierer L, Perez M, et al. Randomized-controlled trial of response inhibition training for individuals with PTSD and impaired response inhibition. Behav Res Ther. 2021 Aug;143:103885. doi: 10.1016/j.brat.2021.103885. PMID: 34089923.

Treatment Description: Waitlist
Citation: Echiverri-Cohen A, Spierer L, Perez M, et al. Randomized-controlled trial of response inhibition training for individuals with PTSD and impaired response inhibition. Behav Res Ther. 2021 Aug;143:103885. doi: 10.1016/j.brat.2021.103885. PMID: 34089923.

Treatment Description: TF-CBT include psychoeducation, relaxation, social problem solving, cognitive restructuring, real life exposure and the development of the trauma narrative

Treatment Description: Manualized treatment; goal is to modify excessively negative appraisals, correct the autobiographical memory disturbance, and remove the problematic behavior and cognitive responses.
Frequency: Weekly for 3 months, followed by up to 3 monthly booster sessions
Treatment Duration Detail: 3 months (weekly sessions), plus up to 3 months (booster sessions)
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: intervention phase is first 3 months with weekly sessions
Citation: Ehlers A, Clark DM, Hackmann A, et al. A randomized controlled trial of cognitive therapy, a self-help booklet, and repeated assessments as early interventions for posttraumatic stress disorder. Arch Gen Psychiatry. 2003;60(10):1024-32. doi: 10.1001/archpsyc.60.10.1024. PMID: 14557148.

Treatment Description: Participants were given a 64-page booklet providing cognitive behavioral principles for the treatment of PTSD (Understanding Your Reactions to Trauma) and an additional 4-page sheet which focused on common avoidance behaviors and safety-seeking behaviors after motor vehicle accidents; one meeting with a clinician to explain use of the booklet and provide motivation to follow advice in the booklet.
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: intervention phase is first 3 months
Citation: Ehlers A, Clark DM, Hackmann A, et al. A randomized controlled trial of cognitive therapy, a self-help booklet, and repeated assessments as early interventions for posttraumatic stress disorder. Arch Gen Psychiatry. 2003;60(10):1024-32. doi: 10.1001/archpsyc.60.10.1024. PMID: 14557148.

Treatment Description: Single meeting with clinician covering rationale and protocol for assessments and monitoring; regular monitoring with the same assessments and timing as other arms.
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: intervention phase is first 3 months
Citation: Ehlers A, Clark DM, Hackmann A, et al. A randomized controlled trial of cognitive therapy, a self-help booklet, and repeated assessments as early interventions for posttraumatic stress disorder. Arch Gen Psychiatry. 2003;60(10):1024-32. doi: 10.1001/archpsyc.60.10.1024. PMID: 14557148.

Treatment Description: Individualized version of the model developed for each participant, with up to 12 sessions and up to 3 monthly booster sessions; "cognitive therapy for PTSD aims to modify excessively negative appraisals, correct the autobiographical memory disturbance, and remove the problematic behavioural and cognitive strategies." Techniques utilized include imaginal reliving, cognitive restructuring, stimulus discrimination procedures, and imagery transformation.
Treatment Duration Detail: 12 sessions could be completed within 13 weeks
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: no patient dropped out
Psychotherapy Sessions Completed Detail: weekly sessions: mean 10 (SD 2.9); monthly booster sessions: mean 2.4 (SD 1.1)
Trauma Detail (Study level): Accidents; Community/school violence; Other ("witness death")
Citation: Ehlers A, Clark DM, Hackmann A, McManus F, Fennell M. Cognitive therapy for post-traumatic stress disorder: development and evaluation. Behav Res Ther. 2005 Apr;43(4):413-31. doi: 10.1016/j.brat.2004.03.006. PMID: 15701354.

Treatment Description: Waitlist, offered active intervention after completion of waitlist period; contact information provided for emergencies.
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: no patient dropped out
Trauma Detail (Study level): Accidents; Community/school violence; Other ("witness death")
Citation: Ehlers A, Clark DM, Hackmann A, McManus F, Fennell M. Cognitive therapy for post-traumatic stress disorder: development and evaluation. Behav Res Ther. 2005 Apr;43(4):413-31. doi: 10.1016/j.brat.2004.03.006. PMID: 15701354.

Treatment Description: Intensive delivery (5 to 7 days) of Ehlers and Clark’s model of cognitive therapy aimed at reducing the patient’s sense of current threat by identifying and modifying excessively negative appraisals of the trauma, elaborating the trauma memory and discriminating triggers of intrusive re-experiencing, and reducing the use of cognitive strategies and behaviors that maintain the problem. Up to 2 sessions one week and one month after intensive period and up to 3 optional monthly booster sessions.
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: Dropouts were defined as attending fewer than eight sessions unless earlier completion was agreed with the therapist
Trauma Detail (Study level): child other abuse, rape/sexual assault, accidents, community/school violence, natural or manmade disasters, other (traumatic death of others, not specified)
Citation: Ehlers A, Hackmann A, Grey N, et al. A randomized controlled trial of 7-day intensive and standard weekly cognitive therapy for PTSD and emotion-focused supportive therapy. Am J Psychiatry. 2014 Mar;171(3):294-304. doi: 10.1176/appi.ajp.2013.13040552. PMID: 24480899.

Treatment Description: Standard delivery of Ehlers and Clark’s model of cognitive therapy aimed at reducing the patient’s sense of current threat by identifying and modifying excessively negative appraisals of the trauma, elaborating the trauma memory and discriminating triggers of intrusive re-experiencing, and reducing the use of cognitive strategies and behaviors that maintain the problem.
Treatment Duration Detail: plus optional monthly booster session for 3 months
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: Dropouts were defined as attending fewer than eight sessions unless earlier completion was agreed with the therapist

Treatment Description: Series of trauma-focused online therapy modules with therapist support through online and text messages and weekly phone calls (weekly during first 12 weeks [weekly treatment phase] then 3 monthly phone calls over the next 3 months [booster phase]. Includes changing problematic appraisals, updating trauma memories, identifying triggers, and changing unhelpful behaviors. No stress reduction training. Therapists released 2-3 modules each week; 18 modules released to all participants, and another 16 optional modules released by the therapist on per-participant basis.
Session Length: Therapist phone calls and messages: weekly during first 12 weeks [weekly treatment phase] then 3 monthly phone calls over the next 3 months [booster phase]
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: Received minimum treatment dose, defined as completing core procedures relating to (1) rationale and psychoeducation, (2) activities in everyday life, and (3) at least one core technique addressing trauma memories: 90.2%
Psychotherapy Sessions Completed Detail:
mean number of weekly phone calls with therapist during 3 months of weekly calls
also reported-
total therapist time (phone calls and messages), weekly treatment and booster phases: mean 6.7 (SD 3.0) hours
total time patient logged in, weekly treatment and booster phases: mean 24.1 (SD 23.1) hours
Trauma Detail (Study level): Combat-related; Child physical abuse; Child sexual abuse; Child other abuse; Rape/sexual assault; Accidents; Illness/medical procedure; Community/school violence; Natural or manmade disasters; Other (death, severe illness, or harm of significant other; professionals witnessing harm to others)
Citation: Ehlers A, Wild J, Warnock-Parkes E, et al. Treatment Name: Internet-delivered stress management therapy for PTSD (iStress-PTSD)
Treatment Description: Stress-management therapy program adapted for the study for PTSD, with therapist support through online and text messages and weekly phone calls (weekly during first 12 weeks [weekly treatment phase] then 3 monthly phone calls over the next 3 months [booster phase].  Includes psychoeducation, coping skills, problem-solving, applied relaxation training, challenging irrational thoughts, mindfullness, sleep improvement, and in vivo exposure; however, does not specifically address trauma appraisal and memories. Therapists released 2-3 modules each week; 18 modules released to all participants, and can choose from an additional 5 challenge areas with 3-4 modules each.
Session Length: Therapist phone calls and messages: weekly during first 12 weeks [weekly treatment phase] then 3 monthly phone calls over the next 3 months [booster phase]

also reported-

total time patient logged in, weekly treatment and booster phases: mean 16.2 (SD 14.3) hours

Treatment Description: Cognitive rehabilitation combining "[goal management training], content-free cueing, and the n-back task, delivers these via a mobile device, and involves support of a family member or friend." Three home visits by a clinical facilitator; mobile applications ("Mind Jogger" for cueing, and "IQ Boost" for n-back task). Family member/friend attended home visits, were given goal management training educational materials, and instructed to provide support and encouragement to veteran participant.

Home visits: 60 to 90 minutes
Cognitive and goal management training: NR

Treatment Description:
Acupuncture: Hair-thin, solid needles manually inserted into subcutaneous tissue or muscle at specified points. Acupoints include: Urinary Bladder, Liver, Large Intestine, Kidney, Heart, Pericardium, Ren, Du, Ear Shenmen, and Yingtang. 







Usual PTSD care: care as outlined in the VA/DoD Clinical Practice Guideline for Management of Post-Traumatic Stress.
Citation: Engel CC, Cordova EH, Benedek DM, et al. Randomized effectiveness trial of a brief course of acupuncture for posttraumatic stress disorder. Med Care. 2014 Dec;52(12 Suppl 5):S57-64. doi: 10.1097/mlr.0000000000000237. PMID: 25397825.

Treatment Description: Medications and psychotherapy as guided by existing standards, outlined in VA/DoD Clinical Practice Guideline for Management of Post-Traumatic Stress.
Citation: Engel CC, Cordova EH, Benedek DM, et al. Randomized effectiveness trial of a brief course of acupuncture for posttraumatic stress disorder. Med Care. 2014 Dec;52(12 Suppl 5):S57-64. doi: 10.1097/mlr.0000000000000237. PMID: 25397825.

Treatment Name: Delivery of Self Training and Education for Stressful Situations-Primary Care version
Treatment Description:
Online CBT-based and stress inoculation training approach in a Nurse-guided format.







Includes online educational information about PTSD, stress, and trauma. Homework activities on strategies to manage stress and anger, and to promote better sleep hygiene. Training in cognitive reframing techniques.
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: Treatment completion not defined; reports by number of logins completed (also reported: n=28 completed at least 6 logins, and n=18 at least 12 logins)
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, MST
Citation: Engel CC, Litz B, Magruder KM, et al. Delivery of self training and education for stressful situations (DESTRESS-PC): a randomized trial of nurse assisted online self-management for PTSD in primary care. Gen Hosp Psychiatry. 2015 Jul-Aug;37(4):323-8. doi: 10.1016/j.genhosppsych.2015.04.007. PMID: 25929985.

Treatment Description: Consists of usual primary care PTSD treatment augmented with low intensity care management, feedback to the primary care provider, and training of the clinic providers in management of PTSD.
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: Reports drop out from measurement only
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, MST
Citation: Engel CC, Litz B, Magruder KM, et al. Delivery of self training and education for stressful situations (DESTRESS-PC): a randomized trial of nurse assisted online self-management for PTSD in primary care. Gen Hosp Psychiatry. 2015 Jul-Aug;37(4):323-8. doi: 10.1016/j.genhosppsych.2015.04.007. PMID: 25929985.

Treatment Description: Integrated, collaborative care for PTSD and depression with telecare central specialist support/services. Nurse care managers provided basic psychosocial support, monitored/encouraged medication and psychotherapy adherence, connected participants to specialty services, and helped participants make evidence-based treatment decisions; stepped pharmacologic and specialty mental health services with online cognitive-behavioral self-management, CBT by telephone with psychologist, and site therapists for face-to-face psychotherapy; central symptom registry for identification of those in need of treatment change; central specialist/services with psychiatrist for treatment monitoring and suggestions to primary care provider, psychologist delivering CBT by telephone and training/coaching care managers, and care manager to support other care managers and participants who moved, left the military, etc.
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: No treatment completion defined or reported, only study/assessment completion; process of care outcomes also reported
Psychotherapy Sessions Completed Detail: Study reports patient-reported mental health service use (Table 4): individual therapy visits, telephone contacts, depression medication use, and PTSD medication use, as mean (SE) for each by time period (3 mo prior to enrollment; 0-3 mo; 3-6 mo; 6-12 mo.)
Citation: Engel CC, Jaycox LH, Freed MC, et al. Centrally assisted collaborative telecare for posttraumatic stress disorder and depression among military personnel attending primary care: a randomized clinical trial. JAMA Intern Med. 2016 Jul 1;176(7):948-56. doi: 10.1001/jamainternmed.2016.2402. PMID: 27294447.

Treatment Name: Re-Engineering Systems of Primary Care Treatment in the Military
Treatment Description: Treatment as usual with the RESPECT-Mil program. Integrated mental health for PTSD and depression using 3-component model: 1) screening at each clinic visit and use of symptom severity tools for diagnosis and assessment; 2) monthly contact by nurse care managers, who provided symptom status to the primary care clinician; 3) increased access to non-primary care clinic-based mental health specialists.
Psychotherapy Sessions Completed Detail: Study reports patient-reported mental health service use (Table 4): individual therapy visits, telephone contacts, depression medication use, and PTSD medication use, as mean (SE) for each by time period (3 mo prior to enrollment; 0-3 mo; 3-6 mo; 6-12 mo.)
Citation: Engel CC, Jaycox LH, Freed MC, et al. Centrally assisted collaborative telecare for posttraumatic stress disorder and depression among military personnel attending primary care: a randomized clinical trial. JAMA Intern Med. 2016 Jul 1;176(7):948-56. doi: 10.1001/jamainternmed.2016.2402. PMID: 27294447.

Treatment Description: EMDR following Shapiro's eight-phase standard protocol; no stabilization period. Session 1: "therapist and patient developed a standardized case conceptualization"; sessions 2-9: "memories processed with eye movements applied as the dual-attention stimulus". All participants received TAU at discretion of their clinical team including treatment for psychotic disorders; treatment could include antipsychotic medication and multidisciplinary treatment by psychiatrists, psychologists, social workers, occupational therapists, nurses, and cultural worker.
Completed Treatment Definition: Completing 6 or more sessions of fulfilling criteria for early completion
Trauma Detail (Study level): Rape/sexual assault; Community/school violence; Other ("index offense" [not further specified], childhood abuse [not further specified], unspecified Other)
Citation: Every-Palmer S, Flewett T, Dean S, et al. Eye movement desensitization and reprocessing (EMDR) therapy compared to usual treatment for posttraumatic stress disorder in adults with psychosis in forensic settings: Randomized controlled trial. Psychol Trauma. 2024 Jan 15;15:15. doi: 10.1037/tra0001643. PMID: 38227442.

Treatment Description: TAU at discretion of their clinical team including treatment for psychotic disorders; treatment could include antipsychotic medication and multidisciplinary treatment by psychiatrists, psychologists, social workers, occupational therapists, nurses, and cultural worker.
Trauma Detail (Study level): Rape/sexual assault; Community/school violence; Other ("index offense" [not further specified], childhood abuse [not further specified], unspecified Other)
Citation: Every-Palmer S, Flewett T, Dean S, et al. Eye movement desensitization and reprocessing (EMDR) therapy compared to usual treatment for posttraumatic stress disorder in adults with psychosis in forensic settings: Randomized controlled trial. Psychol Trauma. 2024 Jan 15;15:15. doi: 10.1037/tra0001643. PMID: 38227442.

Treatment Description: Treatment followed the "Patient Manual and Therapy Manual" by Falsetti and Resnick. Treatment included components of CPT adapted from Resick & Schnicke (1993) and "Mastery of Your Anxiety and Panic" by Barlow & Craske (1988, 1994). Participants were presented with cognitive-behavioral models of PTSD and panic, and participated in exposures directed at physiological, cognitive, and behavioral channels of anxiety.
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: n=7 did not attend a single treatment session and excluded from analysis, n=8 dropped out, remainder (n=14) described as completer sample
Trauma Detail (Study level): child sexual abuse, rape/sexual assault, community/school violence, natural or manmade disasters
Citation: Falsetti SA, Resnick HS, Davis JL. Multiple channel exposure therapy for women with PTSD and comorbid panic attacks. Cogn Behav Ther. 2008;37(2):117-30. doi: 10.1080/16506070801969088. PMID: 18470742.

Treatment Description: Participants were contacted by phone every 2 weeks and offered supportive counseling
Trauma Detail (Study level): child sexual abuse, rape/sexual assault, community/school violence, natural or manmade disasters
Citation: Falsetti SA, Resnick HS, Davis JL. Multiple channel exposure therapy for women with PTSD and comorbid panic attacks. Cogn Behav Ther. 2008;37(2):117-30. doi: 10.1080/16506070801969088. PMID: 18470742.

Treatment Description: SSRI; titrated in 12.5 mg increments (1 capsule) to maximum of 5 capsules as tolerated over 8-week medication adjustment period
Dose: 12.5 to 62.5 mg; titration: initiated at 12.5 mg, titrated to maximum 62.5 mg over 8 weeks
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, child physical abuse, child sexual abuse, rape/sexual assault, community/school violence, other (witnessing trauma)
Citation: Fani N, Kitayama N, Ashraf A, et al. Neuropsychological functioning in patients with posttraumatic stress disorder following short-term paroxetine treatment. Psychopharmacol Bull. 2009 Jan 1;42(1):53-68.  PMID: 19204651.

Treatment Description: Placebo started at 1 capsule per day, increased by 1 capsule per study visit as tolerated, up to 5 capsules per day during 8 week medication adjustment period.
Dose: 1 to 5 capsules (paroxetine equivalent 12.5 to 62.5 mg); titration: initiated at 1 capsule increased as tolerated to maximum of 5 capsules over 8 weeks
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, child physical abuse, child sexual abuse, rape/sexual assault, community/school violence, other (witnessing trauma)
Citation: Fani N, Kitayama N, Ashraf A, et al. Neuropsychological functioning in patients with posttraumatic stress disorder following short-term paroxetine treatment. Psychopharmacol Bull. 2009 Jan 1;42(1):53-68.  PMID: 19204651.

Treatment Description: Aims to make positive self-representations in long-term memory more accessible through the constant activation of these self-representations, leading to strengthened positive self-representations and inhibition of negative memory representations.
Citation: Farahimanesh S, Moradi A, Sadeghi M, et al. Comparing the efficacy of competitive memory training (COMET) and memory specificity training (MEST) on posttraumatic stress disorder among newly diagnosed cancer patients. Cognit Ther Res. 2021;45(5):918-28. doi: 10.1007/s10608-020-10175-4.

Treatment Description: Focuses on developing memory specificity and reducing overgeneral memories; improving the precision of retrieving specific personal events from autobiographical memory
Citation: Farahimanesh S, Moradi A, Sadeghi M, et al. Comparing the efficacy of competitive memory training (COMET) and memory specificity training (MEST) on posttraumatic stress disorder among newly diagnosed cancer patients. Cognit Ther Res. 2021;45(5):918-28. doi: 10.1007/s10608-020-10175-4.

Treatment Description: Treatment included education about post-trauma reactions, relaxation training, imaginal exposure therapy with cognitive restructuring, instruction for self-directed graduated in-vivo behavior practice.
Citation: Fecteau GW, Nicki RM. Cognitive behavioural treatment of post traumatic stress disorder after motor vehicle accident. Behav. Cogn. Psychother. 1999 Jul;27(3):201-14.
Fecteau GW, Nicki RM. Cognitive behavioural treatment of post traumatic stress disorder after motor vehicle accident. Behav. Cogn. Psychother. 1999 Jul;27(3):201-14.

Treatment Description: Antagonist of glutamate NMDA receptor; single intravenous infusion given over 40 minutes
Dose: 0.5 mg/kg
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related. rape/sexual assault, accidents, community/school violence, other (fire, witnessed assault or death, witnessed 9/11 attacks)
Citation: Feder A, Parides MK, Murrough JW, et al. Efficacy of intravenous ketamine for treatment of chronic posttraumatic stress disorder: a randomized clinical trial. JAMA Psychiatry. 2014 Jun;71(6):681-8. doi: 10.1001/jamapsychiatry.2014.62. PMID: 24740528.

Treatment Description: Benzodiazepine; single intravenous infusion given over 40 minutes
Dose: 0.045 mg/kg
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related. rape/sexual assault, accidents, community/school violence, other (fire, witnessed assault or death, witnessed 9/11 attacks)
Citation: Feder A, Parides MK, Murrough JW, et al. Efficacy of intravenous ketamine for treatment of chronic posttraumatic stress disorder: a randomized clinical trial. JAMA Psychiatry. 2014 Jun;71(6):681-8. doi: 10.1001/jamapsychiatry.2014.62. PMID: 24740528.

Treatment Description: Intravenous infusions of ketamine given over 40 minutes, with 6 infusions over 2 weeks
Dose: 0.5 mg/kg IV infusion over 40 minutes
Trauma Detail (Study level): Combat-related; Rape/sexual assault; Accidents; Community/school violence; Terrorism/political violence/forced displacement; Other ("witnessed violent assault or death")
Citation: Feder A, Costi S, Rutter SB, et al. A randomized controlled trial of repeated ketamine administration for chronic posttraumatic stress disorder. Am J Psychiatry. 2021 02 01;178(2):193-202. doi: 10.1176/appi.ajp.2020.20050596. PMID: 33397139.

Treatment Description: Midazolam 0.045 mg/kg given as a psychoactive placebo control; Intravenous infusions given over 40 minutes, with 6 infusions over 2 weeks
Dose: 0.045 mg/kg IV infusion over 40 minutes
Trauma Detail (Study level): Combat-related; Rape/sexual assault; Accidents; Community/school violence; Terrorism/political violence/forced displacement; Other ("witnessed violent assault or death")
Citation: Feder A, Costi S, Rutter SB, et al. A randomized controlled trial of repeated ketamine administration for chronic posttraumatic stress disorder. Am J Psychiatry. 2021 02 01;178(2):193-202. doi: 10.1176/appi.ajp.2020.20050596. PMID: 33397139.

Treatment Description: Ketamine given intravenously with an infusion pump
Dose: 0.5 mg/kg
Trauma Detail (Study level): Combat-related; Rape/sexual assault; Accidents; Community/school violence; Terrorism/political violence/forced displacement; Other (witnessed violent assault or death)
Citation: Feder A, Costi S, Rutter SB, et al. A Randomized Controlled Trial of Repeated Ketamine Administration for Chronic Posttraumatic Stress Disorder. Focus. 2023 Jul;21(3):296-305. doi: 10.1176/appi.focus.23021014. PMID: 37404970.

Treatment Description: Midazolam given intravenously with an infusion pump
Dose: 0.045 mg/kg
Trauma Detail (Study level): Combat-related; Rape/sexual assault; Accidents; Community/school violence; Terrorism/political violence/forced displacement; Other (witnessed violent assault or death)
Citation: Feder A, Costi S, Rutter SB, et al. A Randomized Controlled Trial of Repeated Ketamine Administration for Chronic Posttraumatic Stress Disorder. Focus. 2023 Jul;21(3):296-305. doi: 10.1176/appi.focus.23021014. PMID: 37404970.

Standardized Treatment Name: Sertraline + simulated transcutaneous electrical acupoint stimulation
Treatment Description: SSRI + adhesive electrode pads placed 1 cm radial to Nei-Guan (PC6) with minimum stimulation fro 30 seconds then ramped off over next 15 seconds
Dose: Sertraline initiated at 25 mg/day titrated up to 100 mg/d over 7 days
Completed Treatment Definition: Completed the full 12 weeks of treatment and assessment
Participants Adhered Percent Detail: reported 95% across all groups
Dose at Study End Point Detail: median 96.4 mg/d
Trauma Detail (Study level): rape/sexual assault, accidents, community/school violence, natural or manmade disasters, other (death of family members)
Citation: Feng B, Zhang Y, Luo LY, et al. Transcutaneous electrical acupoint stimulation for post-traumatic stress disorder: assessor-blinded, randomized controlled study. Psychiatry Clin Neurosci. 2019 Apr;73(4):179-86. doi: 10.1111/pcn.12810. PMID: 30565342.

Standardized Treatment Name: Trauma-focused cognitive behavioral therapy (TF-CBT) + simulated transcutaneous electrical acupoint stimulation
Treatment Description: Trauma-focused CBT+ adhesive electrode pads placed 1 cm radial to Nei-Guan (PC6) with minimum stimulation fro 30 seconds then ramped off over next 15 seconds
Session Length:
CBT session length: 45 minutes;



TEAS session length: NR
Completed Treatment Definition: Completed the full 12 weeks of treatment/full CBT sessions and assessment
Trauma Detail (Study level): rape/sexual assault, accidents, community/school violence, natural or manmade disasters, other (death of family members)
Citation: Feng B, Zhang Y, Luo LY, et al. Transcutaneous electrical acupoint stimulation for post-traumatic stress disorder: assessor-blinded, randomized controlled study. Psychiatry Clin Neurosci. 2019 Apr;73(4):179-86. doi: 10.1111/pcn.12810. PMID: 30565342.

Standardized Treatment Name: Trauma-focused cognitive behavioral therapy (TF-CBT) + active transcutaneous electrical acupoint stimulation
Treatment Description: Trauma-focused CBT + TEAS delivered to bilateral Nei-Guan (PC6) point on anterior forearm. Battery-drive TEAS (Shenzhen Ryan Medical Device model SNH-138) simulated at 50 Hz with pulse width of 50 microseconds and amplitude 0 to 100 mA titrated to strong but comfortable level
Session Length:
CBT session length: 45 minutes;



TEAS session length: NR
Completed Treatment Definition: Completed the full 12 weeks of treatment/full CBT sessions and assessment
Trauma Detail (Study level): rape/sexual assault, accidents, community/school violence, natural or manmade disasters, other (death of family members)
Citation: Feng B, Zhang Y, Luo LY, et al. Transcutaneous electrical acupoint stimulation for post-traumatic stress disorder: assessor-blinded, randomized controlled study. Psychiatry Clin Neurosci. 2019 Apr;73(4):179-86. doi: 10.1111/pcn.12810. PMID: 30565342.

Standardized Treatment Name: Sertraline + Trauma-focused cognitive behavioral therapy (TF-CBT) + active transcutaneous electrical acupoint stimulation
Treatment Description: SSRI + trauma-focused CBT +TEAS delivered to bilateral Nei-Guan (PC6) point on anterior forearm. Battery-drive TEAS (Shenzhen Ryan Medical Device model SNH-138) simulated at 50 Hz with pulse width of 50 microseconds and amplitude 0 to 100 mA titrated to strong but comfortable level
Dose: Sertraline initiated at 25 mg/day titrated up to 100 mg/d over 7 days
Session Length:
CBT session length: 45 minutes;



TEAS session length: NR
Frequency: CBT and TEAS: weekly; Sertraline: daily
Completed Treatment Definition: Completed the full 12 weeks of treatment/full CBT sessions and assessment
Participants Adhered Percent Detail: reported 95% across all groups
Dose at Study End Point Detail: median 96.4 mg/day
Trauma Detail (Study level): rape/sexual assault, accidents, community/school violence, natural or manmade disasters, other (death of family members)
Citation: Feng B, Zhang Y, Luo LY, et al. Transcutaneous electrical acupoint stimulation for post-traumatic stress disorder: assessor-blinded, randomized controlled study. Psychiatry Clin Neurosci. 2019 Apr;73(4):179-86. doi: 10.1111/pcn.12810. PMID: 30565342.

Treatment Description: Treatment adhered to manual by Foa, Hearst-Ikeda, Dancu, Hembree & Jaycox (1997), which included breathing retraining, and imaginal and in vivo exposure. In session 8, participants with <70% improvement on PTSD outcome were encouraged to participate in additional 3 PE sessions
Completed Treatment Definition: Completed at least 9 treatment protocol sessions
Trauma Detail (Study level): child physical abuse, child sexual abuse, rape/sexual assault, intimate partner violence, community/school violence
Citation: Feske U. Treating low-income and minority women with posttraumatic stress disorder: a pilot study comparing prolonged exposure and treatment as usual conducted by community therapists. J Interpers Violence. 2008 Aug;23(8):1027-40. doi: 10.1177/0886260507313967. PMID: 18292398.

Treatment Description: Individual counseling session and group treatment session (e.g., anger management)
Session Length:
Individual session: 60 minutes







Group session: 90 minutes
Completed Treatment Definition: Completed at least 9 treatment protocol sessions
Trauma Detail (Study level): child physical abuse, child sexual abuse, rape/sexual assault, intimate partner violence, community/school violence
Citation: Feske U. Treating low-income and minority women with posttraumatic stress disorder: a pilot study comparing prolonged exposure and treatment as usual conducted by community therapists. J Interpers Violence. 2008 Aug;23(8):1027-40. doi: 10.1177/0886260507313967. PMID: 18292398.

Treatment Name: Trauma-focused intensive therapy + amygdala electrical finger print neurofeedback
Treatment Description:
Intensive trauma-focused therapy plus neurofeedback (concurrent)
Intensive trauma-focused therapy: included weekly individual psychotherapy, skills group, and psychotropic medication; incorporated skills from DBT including psychoeducation, emotion regulation training, and trauma processing.
Neurofeedback: training sessions to down-regulate amygdala-related activity through feedback via 3D audiovisual animated scenario
Frequency:
Psychotherapy: weekly
Neurofeedback: twice a week for 2 weeks, then weekly for 6 weeks
Completed Treatment Definition: Completed at least 6 of 10 neurofeedback sessions
Citation: Fine NB, Helpman L, Armon DB, et al. Amygdala-related EEG Neuro-Feedback as an add-on Therapy for treatment-resistant Childhood Sexual Abuse PTSD: feasibility Study. Psychiatry Clin Neurosci. 2023 doi: 10.1111/pcn.13591. PMID: 37615935.

Treatment Description: Intensive trauma-focused therapy: included weekly individual psychotherapy, skills group, and psychotropic medication; incorporated skills from DBT including psychoeducation, emotion regulation training, and trauma processing.
Citation: Fine NB, Helpman L, Armon DB, et al. Amygdala-related EEG Neuro-Feedback as an add-on Therapy for treatment-resistant Childhood Sexual Abuse PTSD: feasibility Study. Psychiatry Clin Neurosci. 2023 doi: 10.1111/pcn.13591. PMID: 37615935.

Treatment Description:
PE augmented with oxytocin







PE: individual, manualized, trauma-focused CBT







Oxytocin: hypothalamic neuropeptide; self-administered intranasal spray 45 minutes prior to PE therapy (sessions 2 through 9)
Dose: 40 IU
Participant Adherence Definition: medication administration observed by research staff
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, rape/sexual assault, accidents, terrorism/political violence/forced displacement, other (assault)
Citation: Flanagan JC, Sippel LM, Wahlquist A, et al. Augmenting prolonged exposure therapy for PTSD with intranasal oxytocin: a randomized, placebo-controlled pilot trial. J Psychiatr Res. 2018 Mar;98:64-9. doi: 10.1016/j.jpsychires.2017.12.014. PMID: 29294429.

Treatment Description:
PE with placebo augmentation







PE: individual, manualized, trauma-focused CBT







Placebo: matching placebo 45 minutes prior to PE therapy (sessions 2 through 9)
Participant Adherence Definition: medication administration observed by research staff
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, rape/sexual assault, accidents, terrorism/political violence/forced displacement, other (assault)
Citation: Flanagan JC, Sippel LM, Wahlquist A, et al. Augmenting prolonged exposure therapy for PTSD with intranasal oxytocin: a randomized, placebo-controlled pilot trial. J Psychiatr Res. 2018 Mar;98:64-9. doi: 10.1016/j.jpsychires.2017.12.014. PMID: 29294429.

Treatment Description: Individual sessions with female therapist. Two sessions devoted to information gathering, description of treatment method and rationale, and explanation for origin of fear and anxiety. Seven sessions comprised of breathing exercises, deep muscle relaxation, thought stopping to counter ruminative or obsessive thinking, cognitive restructuring, guided self-dialogue, covert modeling, and role-playing.
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: analyzed/described sample limited to participants who started treatment, n=3 dropped out, remainder described as completers
Citation: Foa EB, Rothbaum BO, Riggs DS, et al. Treatment of posttraumatic stress disorder in rape victims: a comparison between cognitive-behavioral procedures and counseling. J Consult Clin Psychol. 1991 Oct;59(5):715-23.  PMID: 1955605.

Treatment Description: Individual sessions with female therapist. Two sessions devoted to information gathering, explanation of treatment rationale and treatment planning. Seven sessions comprised of imaginal exposure in which participants were instructed to imagine reliving the assault in vivid detail while describing it aloud, using present tense, and repeating for approximately 60 minutes of the session. Homework as at least once daily listening to tape-recorded narrative, with additional homework including in vivo exposure.
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: analyzed/described sample limited to participants who started treatment, n=4 dropped out, remainder described as completers
Citation: Foa EB, Rothbaum BO, Riggs DS, et al. Treatment of posttraumatic stress disorder in rape victims: a comparison between cognitive-behavioral procedures and counseling. J Consult Clin Psychol. 1991 Oct;59(5):715-23.  PMID: 1955605.

Treatment Description: Individual sessions with female therapist. Two sessions devoted to information gathering, explanation of treatment rationale and treatment planning. Seven sessions in which participants were taught a general problem-solving technique with therapists in unconditionally supportive role. Homework with diary-keeping of daily problems and attempts at problem solving. Participants were immediately redirected to focus on current daily problems if discussion of assault occurred.
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: analyzed/described sample limited to participants who started treatment, n=3 dropped out, remainder described as completers
Citation: Foa EB, Rothbaum BO, Riggs DS, et al. Treatment of posttraumatic stress disorder in rape victims: a comparison between cognitive-behavioral procedures and counseling. J Consult Clin Psychol. 1991 Oct;59(5):715-23.  PMID: 1955605.

Foa EB, Rothbaum BO, Riggs DS, et al. Treatment of posttraumatic stress disorder in rape victims: a comparison between cognitive-behavioral procedures and counseling. J Consult Clin Psychol. 1991 Oct;59(5):715-23.  PMID: 1955605.

Treatment Description: Individual treatment following manual; 2 sessions included information gathering, treatment rationale, construction of in vivo exposure hierarchy, and in vivo homework; remaining sessions included homework review, imaginal exposure, and homework assignment; homework to listen to tape recordings of imaginal exposure from sessions, and in vivo exposure.
Session Length:
120 minutes for 2 sessions



90 minutes for 7 sessions
Completed Treatment Definition: did not drop out of treatment
Trauma Detail (Study level): rape/sexual assault, community/school violence
Citation: Foa EB, Dancu CV, Hembree EA, et al. A comparison of exposure therapy, stress inoculation training, and their combination for reducing posttraumatic stress disorder in female assault victims. J Consult Clin Psychol. 1999;67(2):194.  PMID: 10224729.

Treatment Description: Individual treatment following manual, program adapted from Veronen and Kilpatrick (1983); 2 sessions included information gathering, breathing retraining, and treatment rationale and planning; remaining 7 sessions focused on coping skills for management of assault-related anxiety and postassault problems; coping skills included: deep muscle relaxation, cue-controlled and differential relaxation, thought stopping, cognitive restructuring, guided self-dialogue, covert modeling, and role-play. Homework to practice the coping skills to manage anxiety and fear in daily activities. Explicit in vivo homework instructions were omitted.
Session Length:
120 minutes for 2 sessions



90 minutes for 7 sessions
Completed Treatment Definition: did not drop out of treatment
Trauma Detail (Study level): rape/sexual assault, community/school violence
Citation: Foa EB, Dancu CV, Hembree EA, et al. A comparison of exposure therapy, stress inoculation training, and their combination for reducing posttraumatic stress disorder in female assault victims. J Consult Clin Psychol. 1999;67(2):194.  PMID: 10224729.

Treatment Description: Individual treatment following manual; combination of PE and SIT included education, training on SIT coping skills, in vivo exposure, and imaginal exposure; homework assigned for exposure and coping skill practice
Session Length: 120 minutes for first 2 sessions, 90 minutes for remaining 7 sessions
Completed Treatment Definition: did not drop out of treatment
Trauma Detail (Study level): rape/sexual assault, community/school violence
Citation: Foa EB, Dancu CV, Hembree EA, et al. A comparison of exposure therapy, stress inoculation training, and their combination for reducing posttraumatic stress disorder in female assault victims. J Consult Clin Psychol. 1999;67(2):194.  PMID: 10224729.

Treatment Description: Waitlist participant were instructed to call if experiencing any problems; contacted once during the waiting period by a therapist to determine their current status.
Trauma Detail (Study level): rape/sexual assault, community/school violence
Citation: Foa EB, Dancu CV, Hembree EA, et al. A comparison of exposure therapy, stress inoculation training, and their combination for reducing posttraumatic stress disorder in female assault victims. J Consult Clin Psychol. 1999;67(2):194.  PMID: 10224729.

Treatment Description: Sessions involved imaginal exposure and participants were taught to identify and challenge erroneous beliefs
Completed Treatment Definition: Attended ≥8 therapy sessions and completed a posttreatment assessment
Trauma Detail (Study level): rape/sexual assault, intimate partner violence, child sexual abuse
Citation: Foa EB, Hembree EA, Cahill SP, et al. Randomized trial of prolonged exposure for posttraumatic stress disorder with and without cognitive restructuring: outcome at academic and community clinics. J Consult Clin Psychol. 2005;73(5):953. doi: 10.1037/0022-006X.73.5.953. PMID: 16287395.

Treatment Description: Each session began with reviewing homework and ended with assigning homework. Sessions involved imaginal exposure
Completed Treatment Definition: Attended ≥ 8 therapy sessions and completed a posttreatment assessment
Trauma Detail (Study level): rape/sexual assault, intimate partner violence, child sexual abuse
Citation: Foa EB, Hembree EA, Cahill SP, et al. Randomized trial of prolonged exposure for posttraumatic stress disorder with and without cognitive restructuring: outcome at academic and community clinics. J Consult Clin Psychol. 2005;73(5):953. doi: 10.1037/0022-006X.73.5.953. PMID: 16287395.

Treatment Description: Participants informed their treatment will begin in 9 weeks
Trauma Detail (Study level): rape/sexual assault, intimate partner violence, child sexual abuse
Citation: Foa EB, Hembree EA, Cahill SP, et al. Randomized trial of prolonged exposure for posttraumatic stress disorder with and without cognitive restructuring: outcome at academic and community clinics. J Consult Clin Psychol. 2005;73(5):953. doi: 10.1037/0022-006X.73.5.953. PMID: 16287395.

Treatment Description: Prolonged exposure with repeated imaginal exposures, processing the memory, and homework including in vivo exposure. Naltrexone starting dose given for a minimum of 3 days and titrated up within 1 week. All patients also received supportive counseling including medication management, adherence monitoring, and education about alcohol dependency.
Dose: Start at 50 mg up to 100 mg
Frequency: Psychotherapy: weekly for 12 weeks then biweekly; Naltrexone: daily
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: not reported for PE sessions (see treatment adherence for supportive counseling completion); 35% dropped out of the study prior to end of treatment period
Participant Adherence Definition: ≥80% adherence to medication and attendance at supportive counseling. Naltrexone given with 100 mg riboflavin, and urine riboflavin tests were used to monitor medication compliance; pill counts also used
Trauma Detail (Study level): Combat-related; Rape/sexual assault; Community/school violence; Other (not specified)
Citation: Foa EB, Yusko DA, McLean CP, et al. Concurrent naltrexone and prolonged exposure therapy for patients with comorbid alcohol dependence and PTSD: a randomized clinical trial. JAMA. 2013 Aug 7;310(5):488-95. doi: 10.1001/jama.2013.8268. PMID: 23925619.

Treatment Description: Prolonged exposure with repeated imaginal exposures, processing the memory, and homework including in vivo exposure. Placebo identical to naltrexone given at starting dose for a minimum of 3 days and titrated up within 1 week. All patients also received supportive counseling including medication management, adherence monitoring, and education about alcohol dependency.
Dose: Start with placebo tablet identical to 50 mg naltrexone, titrate up to 100 mg
Frequency: Psychotherapy: weekly for 12 weeks then biweekly; Placebo: daily
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: not reported for PE sessions (see treatment adherence for supportive counseling completion); 38% dropped out of the study prior to end of treatment period
Participant Adherence Definition: ≥80% adherence to medication and attendance at supportive counseling. Placebo given with 100 mg riboflavin, and urine riboflavin tests were used to monitor medication compliance; pill counts also used

Dose: Start at 50 mg up to 100 mg
Frequency: Psychotherapy: weekly for 12 weeks then biweekly; Naltrexone: daily
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: see treatment adherence; 31% dropped out of the study prior to end of treatment period

Treatment Description: Placebo identical to naltrexone starting dose given for a minimum of 3 days and titrated up within 1 week. All patients also received supportive counseling including medication management, adherence monitoring, and education about alcohol dependency.
Dose: Start with placebo tablet identical to 50 mg naltrexone, titrate up to 100 mg
Frequency: Psychotherapy: weekly for 12 weeks then biweekly; Placebo: daily

Standardized Treatment Name: Prolonged Exposure (PE) + smoking cessation counseling + varenicline
Treatment Description: Smoking cessation counseling (20 to 30 minutes) followed by PE (90 minutes) including imaginal exposure and in vivo exposure with weekly homework. Varenicline dose titrated, with 0.5 mg/day for 3 days, 1.0 mg/day for 4 days, then 2.0 mg/day through day 84. Medication initiated at baseline, and smoking quit date planned about one week later.
Dose: Dose: 1.0 mg (after titration)
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: Study reports loss to follow-up; no data on treatment completion specifically
Participant Adherence Definition: percent of prescribed number of pills taken, verified by pill count and Timeline Follow Back Interview
Trauma Detail (Study level): Combat-related; Child sexual abuse; Rape/sexual assault; Accidents; Illness/medical procedure; Community/school violence; Natural or manmade disasters; Other (imprisonment, torture, other)
Citation: Foa EB, Asnaani A, Rosenfield D, et al. Concurrent varenicline and prolonged exposure for patients with nicotine dependence and PTSD: a randomized controlled trial. J Consult Clin Psychol. 2017 Sep;85(9):862-72. doi: 10.1037/ccp0000213. PMID: 28569519.

Treatment Description: Smoking cessation counseling plus varenicline, dose titrated with 0.5 mg/day for 3 days, 1.0 mg/day for 4 days, then 2.0 mg/day through day 84. Medication initiated at baseline and smoking quit date planned about one week later.
Dose: Dose: 1.0 mg (after titration)
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: Study reports loss to follow-up; no data on treatment completion specifically
Participant Adherence Definition: percent of prescribed number of pills taken, verified by pill count and Timeline Follow Back Interview

Treatment Description: CBT consisting of imaginal exposure followed by processing thoughts and feelings related to the imaginal exposure, in-vivo exposure, psychoeducation about PTSD, and controlled breathing training.
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, other (not specified)
Citation: Foa EB, McLean CP, Zang Y, et al. Effect of prolonged exposure therapy delivered over 2 weeks vs 8 weeks vs present-centered therapy on PTSD symptom severity in military personnel: a randomized clinical trial. JAMA. 2018 Jan 23;319(4):354-64. doi: 10.1001/jama.2017.21242. PMID: 29362795.

Treatment Description: CBT consisting of imaginal exposure followed by processing thoughts and feelings related to the imaginal exposure, in-vivo exposure, psychoeducation about PTSD, and controlled breathing training
Frequency: Twice weekly for first and last weeks, once weekly for other weeks
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, other (not specified)
Citation: Foa EB, McLean CP, Zang Y, et al. Effect of prolonged exposure therapy delivered over 2 weeks vs 8 weeks vs present-centered therapy on PTSD symptom severity in military personnel: a randomized clinical trial. JAMA. 2018 Jan 23;319(4):354-64. doi: 10.1001/jama.2017.21242. PMID: 29362795.

Treatment Description: Non-trauma-focused treatment focusing on current life problems that may or may not be PTSD-related.
Frequency: Twice weekly for first and last weeks, once weekly for other weeks
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, other (not specified)
Citation: Foa EB, McLean CP, Zang Y, et al. Effect of prolonged exposure therapy delivered over 2 weeks vs 8 weeks vs present-centered therapy on PTSD symptom severity in military personnel: a randomized clinical trial. JAMA. 2018 Jan 23;319(4):354-64. doi: 10.1001/jama.2017.21242. PMID: 29362795.

Treatment Description: Therapist call participants to ask about well-being, offer support as needed, and received contact information in case symptoms worsened.
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: all participants also completed postassessment
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, other (not specified)
Citation: Foa EB, McLean CP, Zang Y, et al. Effect of prolonged exposure therapy delivered over 2 weeks vs 8 weeks vs present-centered therapy on PTSD symptom severity in military personnel: a randomized clinical trial. JAMA. 2018 Jan 23;319(4):354-64. doi: 10.1001/jama.2017.21242. PMID: 29362795.

Treatment Description: Therapy followed published PE manual; treatment followed same protocol as 90-minute PE intervention with the following changes: imaginal exposure length reduced from 40 to 20 minutes and session length reduced from 90 to 60 minutes; content was abridged but no content was omitted.
Treatment Duration Detail: up to 15 sessions, treatment could end earlier if participant scored ≤19 on PCL-5
Trauma Detail (Study level): Combat-related; Rape/sexual assault; Other (not specified)
Citation: Foa EB, Bredemeier K, Acierno R, et al. The efficacy of 90-min versus 60-min sessions of prolonged exposure for PTSD: A randomized controlled trial in active-duty military personnel. J Consult Clin Psychol. 2022;90(6):503-12. doi: 10.1037/ccp0000739. PMID: 35771512.

Treatment Description: Therapy followed published PE manual; treatment consisting of psychoeducation about PTSD, in vivo exposure, and 40 minutes of imaginal exposure, followed by processing thoughts and feelings related to the imaginal experience.
Treatment Duration Detail: up to 15 sessions, treatment could end earlier if participant scored ≤19 on PCL-5
Trauma Detail (Study level): Combat-related; Rape/sexual assault; Other (not specified)
Citation: Foa EB, Bredemeier K, Acierno R, et al. The efficacy of 90-min versus 60-min sessions of prolonged exposure for PTSD: A randomized controlled trial in active-duty military personnel. J Consult Clin Psychol. 2022;90(6):503-12. doi: 10.1037/ccp0000739. PMID: 35771512.

Treatment Description: Manualized procedures according to Foa, Hembree, & Rothbaum 2007. Participants with adequate response to treatment, defined as <30% of PCL-C score at baseline (i.e. 70% reduction from baseline), were given the option to terminate treatment after Session 9. Nonresponders continued through Session 12
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: n=24 completed treatment, of those, n=16 completed 12 sessions
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, illness/medical procedure, community/school violence, natural or manmade disasters, rape/sexual assault
Citation: Fonzo GA, Goodkind MS, Oathes DJ, et al. PTSD psychotherapy outcome predicted by brain activation during emotional reactivity and regulation. Am J Psychiatry. 2017 Dec 1;174(12):1163-74. doi: 10.1176/appi.ajp.2017.16091072. PMID: 28715908.

Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, illness/medical procedure, community/school violence, natural or manmade disasters, rape/sexual assault
Citation: Fonzo GA, Goodkind MS, Oathes DJ, et al. PTSD psychotherapy outcome predicted by brain activation during emotional reactivity and regulation. Am J Psychiatry. 2017 Dec 1;174(12):1163-74. doi: 10.1176/appi.ajp.2017.16091072. PMID: 28715908.

Treatment Description: Computerized training on 11 cogntiive/affective remediation training tasks, accessed via website; participants instructed to train on each of the tasks for 3-4 minutes, for a total of 35045 minutes per day.Tasks trained: selective attention, working memory, task shifting, processing speed, positive emotion recognition/resisting negative emotion distraction, attention towards positive affective stimuli, identification of emotional faces, and identification of complex emotional stimuli.
Completed Treatment Definition: completing 30 or more training days of 30 minutes each
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: proportion of randomized sample; 77% completed out of N=31 that completed posttreatment assessment
Citation: Fonzo GA, Fine NB, Wright RN, et al. Internet-delivered computerized cognitive & affective remediation training for the treatment of acute and chronic posttraumatic stress disorder: two randomized clinical trials. J Psychiatr Res. 2019 sept 2019;115:82-9. doi: 10.1016/j.jpsychires.2019.05.007. PMID: 31125916.

Treatment Description: Engaging computer games for attention control, accessed via website; administration was the same as for active intervention; games did not train any cognitive of affective functions.
Completed Treatment Definition: completing 30 or more sessions of 30 minutes each
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: proportion of randomized sample; 75% completed out of N=24 that completed posttreatment assessment
Citation: Fonzo GA, Fine NB, Wright RN, et al. Internet-delivered computerized cognitive & affective remediation training for the treatment of acute and chronic posttraumatic stress disorder: two randomized clinical trials. J Psychiatr Res. 2019 sept 2019;115:82-9. doi: 10.1016/j.jpsychires.2019.05.007. PMID: 31125916.

Treatment Description: Manualized treatment addressing key themes including safety, trust, power and control, self-esteem, and intimacy with cognitive therapy and written exposure
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: reported value is equal to n randomized minus those who did not complete allocated intervention
Trauma Detail (Study level): "military-related"
Citation: Forbes D, Lloyd D, Nixon RDV, et al. A multisite randomized controlled effectiveness trial of cognitive processing therapy for military-related posttraumatic stress disorder. J Anxiety Disord. 2012 Apr;26(3):442-52. doi: 10.1016/j.janxdis.2012.01.006. PMID: 22366446..

Treatment Description: Varied according to therapist: 14% psychoeducation and supportive counseling; 52% nontrauma-focused symptom management interventions; 34% CBT which included elements of exposure
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: reported value is equal to n randomized minus those who did not complete allocated intervention
Trauma Detail (Study level): "military-related"
Citation: Forbes D, Lloyd D, Nixon RDV, et al. A multisite randomized controlled effectiveness trial of cognitive processing therapy for military-related posttraumatic stress disorder. J Anxiety Disord. 2012 Apr;26(3):442-52. doi: 10.1016/j.janxdis.2012.01.006. PMID: 22366446..

Treatment Name: Trauma Affect Regulation: Guide for Education and Therapy
Standardized Treatment Name: Trauma Affect Regulation: Guide for Education and Therapy
Treatment Description: Manualized therapy (Ford, 2015) including psychoeducation, eliciting day triggers for PTSD alarm reactions and teaching skills to inhibit impulsive emotional and behavioral reactions. Intervention teaches the "Slow down, Orient Self-check" skill and other skills to replace alarm reaction with emotional self-regulation.
Citation: Ford JD, Grasso DJ, Greene CA, et al. Randomized clinical trial pilot study of prolonged exposure versus present centred affect regulation therapy for PTSD and anger problems with male military combat veterans. Clin Psychol Psychother. 2018 Sep;25(5):641-9. doi: 10.1002/cpp.2194. PMID: 29687524.

Treatment Description: Intervention according to manualized guidelines (Foa, Hembree, & Rothbaum, 2007), including psychoeducation, breathing retraining, imaginal and in vivo exposure
Citation: Ford JD, Grasso DJ, Greene CA, et al. Randomized clinical trial pilot study of prolonged exposure versus present centred affect regulation therapy for PTSD and anger problems with male military combat veterans. Clin Psychol Psychother. 2018 Sep;25(5):641-9. doi: 10.1002/cpp.2194. PMID: 29687524.

Treatment Description: Off-site PTSD care team used telemedicine technology to support the PTSD treatment delivered by clinic providers. Specific components: Home-based telephone nurse care manager (e.g., symptom monitoring, education, medication adherence) and telephone pharmacist; clinic-based telepsychology and telepsychiatry service
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: No treatment completion defined or reported. Study evaluated and reports results for process of care outcomes, including proportion prescribed medications, psychiatry encounters, and CPT attendance.
Participant Adherence Definition:
Pharmacologic component: patient self-report ≥80% adherence







Nonpharmacologic component: attended ≥8 CPT sessions
Participants Adhered Percent Detail: Pharmacologic: 59.41% first 6 months; 57.43% second 6 months; Nonpharmacologic: 27.1%
Citation: Fortney JC, Pyne JM, Kimbrell TA, et al. Telemedicine-based collaborative care for posttraumatic stress disorder: a randomized clinical trial. JAMA Psychiatry. 2015 Jan;72(1):58-67. doi: 10.1001/jamapsychiatry.2014.1575. PMID: 25409287.

Treatment Description: Care received at distant VA and local community-based outpatient clinic with no home-based or telemedicine support

Participant Adherence Definition:
Pharmacologic component: patient self-report ≥80% adherence



Nonpharmacologic component: attended ≥8 CPT sessions
Participants Adhered Percent Detail: Pharmacologic: 67.01% first 6 months; 67.37% second 6 months; Nonpharmacologic: 5.3%

Treatment Description: PE therapy delivered via streaming-video calls using Tango (free application downloaded to the phone which uses the 3G network); no changes made to PE treatment other than mode of delivery. Participants loaned an iPhone 4 with service plans for duration of treatment.
Citation: Franklin CL, Cuccurullo LA, Walton JL, et al. Face to face but not in the same place: a pilot study of prolonged exposure therapy. J Trauma Dissociation. 2017 Jan-Feb;18(1):116-30. doi: 10.1080/15299732.2016.1205704. PMID: 27348462.

Treatment Description: PE therapy delivered via computer-based teleconferencing equipment at rural VA community-based outpatient clinics; no changes made to PE treatment other than mode of delivery.
Citation: Franklin CL, Cuccurullo LA, Walton JL, et al. Face to face but not in the same place: a pilot study of prolonged exposure therapy. J Trauma Dissociation. 2017 Jan-Feb;18(1):116-30. doi: 10.1080/15299732.2016.1205704. PMID: 27348462.

Treatment Description: Treatment offered through the study. This could be referring clinician's choice of therapy, excluding evidence-based psychotherapy for PTSD; therapies which occurred: supportive psychotherapy or medication management, typically provided by psychiatrists, masters'-level social workers, psychology interns/fellows, and psychologists at the community clinic.
Completed Treatment Definition: remained in treatment for 12-week duration of the study
Citation: Franklin CL, Cuccurullo LA, Walton JL, et al. Face to face but not in the same place: a pilot study of prolonged exposure therapy. J Trauma Dissociation. 2017 Jan-Feb;18(1):116-30. doi: 10.1080/15299732.2016.1205704. PMID: 27348462.

Treatment Description: SSRI; started at 25 mg/day for 1 week, increased to 50 mg/day in week 2, weekly increases of 50 mg/day based on response and tolerability
Dose: Initiated at 25 mg, titrated to maximum 200 mg
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, rape/sexual assault, accidents, community/school violence, other (injury, fire, seeing someone hurt or die, "miscellaneous")
Citation: Friedman MJ, Marmar CR, Baker DG, et al. Randomized, double-blind comparison of sertraline and placebo for posttraumatic stress disorder in a Department of Veterans Affairs setting. J Clin Psychiatry. 2007 May;68(5):711-20. PMID: 17503980.

Treatment Description: Placebo matched sertraline
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, rape/sexual assault, accidents, community/school violence, other (injury, fire, seeing someone hurt or die, "miscellaneous")

Treatment Description: SSRI; dose increased according to response and tolerability
Dose: 20 to 50 mg; titration: 10 mg for 1 week then increased weekly in 10-mg increments
Trauma Detail (Study level): rape/sexual assault, accidents, community/school violence
Citation: Frommberger UH, Stieglitz R-D, Nyberg E, et al. Comparison between paroxetine and behaviour therapy in patients with posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD): a pilot study. Int. J. Psychiatry Clin. Pract. 2004;8(1):19-24. doi: 10.1080/13651500310004803. PMID: 24937579.

Treatment Description:
CBT comprised psychoeducation,



behavioral assessment, relaxation training, stress inoculation training, exposure in sensu (prolonged exposure) and in vivo and cognitive restructuring. Methods and training provided by Edna Foa.
Trauma Detail (Study level): rape/sexual assault, accidents, community/school violence
Citation: Frommberger UH, Stieglitz R-D, Nyberg E, et al. Comparison between paroxetine and behaviour therapy in patients with posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD): a pilot study. Int. J. Psychiatry Clin. Pract. 2004;8(1):19-24. doi: 10.1080/13651500310004803. PMID: 24937579.

Treatment Description: Neurofeedback  interface consisting of an individually-tailored audio script of the personal traumatic narrative; first 5 sessions using neutral interface; "upon reaching a predetermined neuromodulation success criterion, NF training was further guided by a pre-recorded edited script of the personal traumatic experience including trauma hot-spots, thoughts, emotions, and physical sensations. Successful down-regulation of AmygEFP was reflected by the reduced sound volume of the traumatic script
Frequency: Twice weekly for 2 weeks and then once per week
Trauma Detail (Study level): Accidents; Combat-related; Community/school violence; Terrorism/political violence/forced displacement; Other ("life threatening injury", "witness trauma", "traumatic grief", "repeated exposure")
Citation: Fruchtman-Steinbok T, Keynan JN, Cohen A, et al. Amygdala electrical-finger-print (AmygEFP) neurofeedback guided by individually-tailored trauma script for post-traumatic stress disorder: proof-of-concept. Neuroimage Clin. 2021 Oct 15;32:102859. doi: 10.1016/j.nicl.2021.102859. PMID: 34689055.

Treatment Description: Neutral neurofeedback interface; "neurofeedback guided by a non-trauma-related interace (interleaved audiovisual animated scenario) and neutral auditory feedback"
Frequency: Twice weekly for 2 weeks and then once per week
Trauma Detail (Study level): Accidents; Combat-related; Community/school violence; Terrorism/political violence/forced displacement; Other ("life threatening injury", "witness trauma", "traumatic grief", "repeated exposure")
Citation: Fruchtman-Steinbok T, Keynan JN, Cohen A, et al. Treatment Description: No neurofeedback
Frequency: Twice weekly for 2 weeks and then once per week
