Standardized Treatment Name: Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) without a trauma focus
Treatment Description: Treatment specifically targeted social skills training (e.g., assertion, social communication, anger management), and activities to increase social participation
Citation: Frueh BC, Monnier J, Yim E, et al. A randomized trial of telepsychiatry for post-traumatic stress disorder. J. Telemed. Telecare. 2007 Apr 1;13(3):142-7. doi: 10.1258/135763307780677604. PMID: 17519056.

Standardized Treatment Name: Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) without a trauma focus
Treatment Description: Treatment specifically targeted social skills training (e.g., assertion, social communication, anger management), and activities to increase social participation
Citation: Frueh BC, Monnier J, Yim E, et al. A randomized trial of telepsychiatry for post-traumatic stress disorder. J. Telemed. Telecare. 2007 Apr 1;13(3):142-7. doi: 10.1258/135763307780677604. PMID: 17519056.

Treatment Description: Mindfulness taught in group format and included four practices: sitting meditation, walking meditation, movement similar to hatha yoga, and a body scan. Eight sessions plus "intensive retreat," not further described.
Completed Treatment Definition: Attended all 8 sessions and the intensive retreat
Psychotherapy Sessions Completed Detail: 52% attended at least half of the classes
Citation: Gallegos AM, Heffner KL, Cerulli C, et al. Effects of mindfulness training on posttraumatic stress symptoms from a community-based pilot clinical trial among survivors of intimate partner violence. Psychol Trauma. 2020 Nov;12(8):859-68. doi: 10.1037/tra0000975. PMID: 32969703.

Treatment Description: Participants given health education manual including information on diet, exercise, sleep, stress management, and communication, with phone check-ins with a research assistant.
Citation: Gallegos AM, Heffner KL, Cerulli C, et al. Effects of mindfulness training on posttraumatic stress symptoms from a community-based pilot clinical trial among survivors of intimate partner violence. Psychol Trauma. 2020 Nov;12(8):859-68. doi: 10.1037/tra0000975. PMID: 32969703.

Treatment Description:
Modified application of traditional CPT (Resick, Monson, & Chard, 2008); primary modifications: length of intervention individually tailored with conclusion based on predefined specified end-state criterion (4 to 18 possible sessions); up to 2 optional "stressor sessions" offered when a participant experienced a significant psychosocial stressor or emergency during the course of therapy, and participant's choice whether to use the stressor session.



End-state criterion for termination of treatment: PDS ≤20, BDI ≤18, agreement between the therapist and participant that treatment goals had been attained, and negative PTSD status on CAPS by blind rater.
Trauma Detail (Study level): child sexual abuse, child physical abuse, rape/sexual assault, community/school violence, intimate partner violence
Citation: Galovski TE, Blain LM, Mott JM, et al. Manualized therapy for PTSD: flexing the structure of cognitive processing therapy. J Consult Clin Psychol. 2012 Dec;80(6):968-81. doi: 10.1037/a0030600. PMID: 23106761.

Treatment Description: Daily monitoring of PTSD and depressive symptoms; 3 phone interviews for CAPS administration and inquiry into progress on symptom monitoring, overall symptom severity, and general distress but without cognitive therapy or other trauma-focused intervention.
Treatment Duration Detail: 10 weeks symptom monitoring, then crossed over to active treatment (modified CPT; data for crossover not entered)
Trauma Detail (Study level): child sexual abuse, child physical abuse, rape/sexual assault, community/school violence, intimate partner violence
Citation: Galovski TE, Blain LM, Mott JM, et al. Manualized therapy for PTSD: flexing the structure of cognitive processing therapy. J Consult Clin Psychol. 2012 Dec;80(6):968-81. doi: 10.1037/a0030600. PMID: 23106761.

Standardized Treatment Name: Sleep-directed hypnosis followed by Cognitive Processing Therapy (CPT)
Treatment Description:
Sleep-directed hypnosis for 3 weeks followed by 12 weeks of CPT.







Scripted hypnosis targeting sleep impairment (no trauma-related material) with focus on sleep onset difficulty and mid-sleep awakening and inability to fall back to sleep; utilized psychoeducation, hypnotic trance using eye fixation technique, guided imagery and redirection of mental activity. Participants instructed to practice daily using audiotape of hypnosis session.







CPT targeting interpretations of the trauma itself and then current and future maladaptive and inaccurate beliefs about world, self and others; patients taught to identify, question, challenge and replace faulty assumptions and thoughts about traumatic event and its implications in their current life.
Psychotherapy Sessions Completed Detail: practiced autohypnosis during sleep intervention phase: mean 4.7 times
Trauma Detail (Study level): child sexual abuse, child physical abuse, rape/sexual assault, community/school violence, intimate partner violence
Citation: Galovski TE, Harik JM, Blain LM, et al. Augmenting cognitive processing therapy to improve sleep impairment in PTSD: a randomized controlled trial. J Consult Clin Psychol. 2016 Feb;84(2):167-77. doi: 10.1037/ccp0000059. PMID: 26689303.

Standardized Treatment Name: Sleep and symptom monitoring followed by Cognitive Processing Therapy (CPT)
Treatment Description:
Sleep and symptom monitoring for 3 weeks followed by 12 weeks of CPT.







Daily monitoring of PTSD, depressive symptoms, and sleep, with weekly phone checks.







CPT targeting interpretations of the trauma itself and then current and future maladaptive and inaccurate beliefs about world, self and others; patients taught to identify, question, challenge and replace faulty assumptions and thoughts about traumatic event and its implications in their current life.
Session Length:
Symptom monitoring: NA







CPT sessions: 60 minutes
Trauma Detail (Study level): child sexual abuse, child physical abuse, rape/sexual assault, community/school violence, intimate partner violence
Citation: Galovski TE, Harik JM, Blain LM, et al. Augmenting cognitive processing therapy to improve sleep impairment in PTSD: a randomized controlled trial. J Consult Clin Psychol. 2016 Feb;84(2):167-77. doi: 10.1037/ccp0000059. PMID: 26689303.

Treatment Description: Treatment includes psychoeducation for anxiety management and exposure to traumatic event through a Z800 head-mounted display (e-Magin Corp) that displays a footpath surrounded by dense vegetation where participants had to follow a column of virtual soldiers. Ambush, gun firing, motor, and waiting for evacuation near an injured soldier were added gradually each session
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: Study reported drop-out, unclear if treatment attrition or attrition to measuremen
Citation: Gamito P, Oliveira J, Rosa P, et al. PTSD elderly war veterans: a clinical controlled pilot study. Cyberpsychol Behav Soc Netw. 2010 Feb;13(1):43-8. doi: 10.1089/cyber.2009.0237. PMID: 20528292.

Treatment Description: Treatment includes psychoeducation for anxiety management and imaginal exposure
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: Study reported drop-out, unclear if treatment attrition or attrition to measuremen
Citation: Gamito P, Oliveira J, Rosa P, et al. PTSD elderly war veterans: a clinical controlled pilot study. Cyberpsychol Behav Soc Netw. 2010 Feb;13(1):43-8. doi: 10.1089/cyber.2009.0237. PMID: 20528292.
Gamito P, Oliveira J, Rosa P, et al. PTSD elderly war veterans: a clinical controlled pilot study. Cyberpsychol Behav Soc Netw. 2010 Feb;13(1):43-8. doi: 10.1089/cyber.2009.0237. PMID: 20528292.

Treatment Description: EEG biofeedback with sensors placed at T3-T4. Training parameters followed flexible, principle-based manual with defined rules to adjust reward frequency and training time; reward frequency adjusted based on the participant's clinical response (number of over- or under-arousal symptoms); training time increased in 3-minute increments when participant reported positive change.
Dose:
inhibit frequencies: 4 to 7 Hz and 22 to 36 Hz



reward frequency: 12 to 15 Hz
Trauma Detail (Study level): child physical abuse, child sexual abuse, child other abuse, other (not specified)
Citation: Gapen MA, van der Kolk BA, Hamlin E, et al. A pilot study of neurofeedback for chronic PTSD. Appl Psychophysiol Biofeedback. 2016 Sep;41(3):251-61. doi: 10.1007/s10484-015-9326-5. PMID: 26782083.

Treatment Description: EEG biofeedback with sensors placed at T4-P4. Training parameters followed flexible, principle-based manual; inhibit frequencies: 4-7 Hz and 22-36 Hz; reward frequency: initial 12-15 Hz, adjusted based on the participant's clinical response (number of over- or under-arousal symptoms); training time increased in 3-minute increments when participant reported positive change.
Dose:
inhibit frequencies: 4 to 7 Hz and 22 to 36 Hz



reward frequency: 12 to 15 Hz
Trauma Detail (Study level): child physical abuse, child sexual abuse, child other abuse, other (not specified)
Citation: Gapen MA, van der Kolk BA, Hamlin E, et al. A pilot study of neurofeedback for chronic PTSD. Appl Psychophysiol Biofeedback. 2016 Sep;41(3):251-61. doi: 10.1007/s10484-015-9326-5. PMID: 26782083.

Treatment Description: Activity-based sport intervention (sailing) that seeks to empower participant, change negative self-image, enhance self-efficacy, hope, and the ability to enjoy life, to develop control over symptoms, and improve social and emotional regulation skills. Each session began with a summary of previous lesson, followed by sailing in a group and different sea-related activities. Session ends with a debrief and discussion of sailing-related and personal issues
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: "Of the 28 present at the first session 22 finished the 12-month program", "All NAR participants were present in at least 40 sessions"; and n=6 dropped out after first session
Citation: Gelkopf M, Hasson-Ohayon I, Bikman M, et al. Nature adventure rehabilitation for combat-related posttraumatic chronic stress disorder: a randomized control trial. Psychiatry Res. 2013 Oct 30;209(3):485-93. doi: 10.1016/j.psychres.2013.01.026. PMID: 23541513.

Gelkopf M, Hasson-Ohayon I, Bikman M, et al. Nature adventure rehabilitation for combat-related posttraumatic chronic stress disorder: a randomized control trial. Psychiatry Res. 2013 Oct 30;209(3):485-93. doi: 10.1016/j.psychres.2013.01.026. PMID: 23541513.

Treatment Description: Treatment followed The EFT Manual (Craig & Fowlie 1995; Church, 2013) where therapists guided participants through traumatic emotional events until emotional intensity reduces via office or telephone sessions or televideo conferencing calls. All participants received usual care by primary care provider
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: n=5 withdrew after 3 sessions; n=27 received all 6 sessions
Citation: Geronilla L, Minewiser L, Mollon P, et al. EFT (Emotional Freedom Techniques) remediates PTSD and psychological symptoms in veterans: A randomized controlled replication trial. Energy Psychology. 2016;8(2):29.

Treatment Description: Participants received usual care by primary care provider and completed a 30-day waiting period
Citation: Geronilla L, Minewiser L, Mollon P, et al. EFT (Emotional Freedom Techniques) remediates PTSD and psychological symptoms in veterans: A randomized controlled replication trial. Energy Psychology. 2016;8(2):29.

Treatment Description: Individualized psychotherapy, consisting of psychoeducation, imaginary guidance, writing assignments and mementos, domain of meaning or integration, and a farewell ritual
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: no participants dropped out, treatment sessions "delivered as planned", and "no treatment dropouts"
Trauma Detail (Study level): occupational events
Citation: Gersons BP, Carlier IV, Lamberts RD, et al. Randomized clinical trial of brief eclectic psychotherapy for police officers with posttraumatic stress disorder. J Trauma Stress. 2000 Apr;13(2):333-47. doi: 10.1023/A:1007793803627. PMID: 10838679..

Treatment Description: Participants monitored by a nonassessor psychologist
Trauma Detail (Study level): occupational events
Citation: Gersons BP, Carlier IV, Lamberts RD, et al. Randomized clinical trial of brief eclectic psychotherapy for police officers with posttraumatic stress disorder. J Trauma Stress. 2000 Apr;13(2):333-47. doi: 10.1023/A:1007793803627. PMID: 10838679..

Treatment Description: Treatment delivered using manual; elements included: psychoeducation, breathing retraining, imaginal exposure with processing or discussion of the content during session, and in vivo exposure.
Trauma Detail (Study level): natural or manmade disaster, accidents, rape/sexual assault, community/school violence, illness/medical procedure, combat-related, terrorism/political violence/forced displacement
Citation: Ghafoori B, Hansen MC, Garibay E, et al. Feasibility of training frontline therapists in prolonged exposure: a randomized controlled pilot study of treatment of complex trauma in diverse victims of crime and violence. J Nerv Ment Dis. 2017 Apr;205(4):283-93. doi: 10.1097/NMD.0000000000000659. PMID: 28157725.

Treatment Description: Treatment delivered using manual; content shared directed by client with therapist offering support with respect to trauma related memories; elements included: psychoeducation, breathing retraining, reviewing daily difficulties as a manifestation of PTSD related to trauma (without directive imaginal exposure).
Trauma Detail (Study level): natural or manmade disaster, accidents, rape/sexual assault, community/school violence, illness/medical procedure, combat-related, terrorism/political violence/forced displacement
Citation: Ghafoori B, Hansen MC, Garibay E, et al. Feasibility of training frontline therapists in prolonged exposure: a randomized controlled pilot study of treatment of complex trauma in diverse victims of crime and violence. J Nerv Ment Dis. 2017 Apr;205(4):283-93. doi: 10.1097/NMD.0000000000000659. PMID: 28157725.

Treatment Description: Bathysmed protocol with sessions including dive theory, psychoeducation, breathing techniques, mental preparation, and a meditative scuba dive. 10-day program, with 10 dives over 6 days plus an optional night dive .
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: 186 dives completed out of 187 total, so 1 subject did not completed one dive; intervention completion not defined in study, using participant completing all dives since that is data provided
Psychotherapy Sessions Completed Detail: Mean dives per participant; Of 187 planned dives [10 per person + one optional], 186 completed
Citation: Gibert L, Coulange M, Reynier JC, et al. Comparing meditative scuba diving versus multisport activities to improve post-traumatic stress disorder symptoms: a pilot, randomized controlled clinical trial. Eur J Psychotraumatol. 2022 Feb 7;13(1):2031590. doi: 10.1080/20008198.2022.2031590. PMID: 35145610.

Treatment Description: Multisport program including two hours of physical activity per day (e.g. sailing, surfing, canoeing, hiking and snorkelling); 10 days.
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: All subjects completed all sessions
Psychotherapy Sessions Completed Detail: All subjects completed all sessions (total 10 sessions)
Citation: Gibert L, Coulange M, Reynier JC, et al. Comparing meditative scuba diving versus multisport activities to improve post-traumatic stress disorder symptoms: a pilot, randomized controlled clinical trial. Eur J Psychotraumatol. 2022 Feb 7;13(1):2031590. doi: 10.1080/20008198.2022.2031590. PMID: 35145610.

Treatment Description: Combine aerobic and resistance exercise with yoga poses presented within a framework of mindfulness principles based on the Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction and Mindful Breathing principles
Citation: Goldstein LA, Mehling WE, Metzler TJ, et al. Veterans group exercise: a randomized pilot trial of an integrative exercise program for veterans with posttraumatic stress. J Affect Disord. 2018 Feb;227:345-52. doi: 10.1016/j.jad.2017.11.002. PMID: 29145076.

Treatment Description: Participants could participate in Integrative Exercise after 12 weeks of waiting period
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: completed waitlist: 84.61%
Citation: Goldstein LA, Mehling WE, Metzler TJ, et al. Veterans group exercise: a randomized pilot trial of an integrative exercise program for veterans with posttraumatic stress. J Affect Disord. 2018 Feb;227:345-52. doi: 10.1016/j.jad.2017.11.002. PMID: 29145076.

Treatment Description: Antiprogestogen
Dose: 600 mg
Citation: Golier JA, Caramanica K, Demaria R, et al. A pilot study of mifepristone in combat-related PTSD. Depress Res Treat. 2012;2012:393251. doi: 10.1155/2012/393251. PMID: 22611490.

Treatment Description: Matched placebo
Citation: Golier JA, Caramanica K, Demaria R, et al. A pilot study of mifepristone in combat-related PTSD. Depress Res Treat. 2012;2012:393251. doi: 10.1155/2012/393251. PMID: 22611490.

Treatment Description: Oral mifepristone
Dose: 600 mg (two 300 mg tablets)
Participant Adherence Definition: Treatment adherence ≥85% (≥12 of 14 pills taken), based on returned pill counts
Trauma Detail (Study level): Combat-related; Other ("military trauma" not further specified)
Citation: Golier JA, Li X, Bizien M, et al. Efficacy and Safety of Mifepristone in the Treatment of Male US Veterans With Posttraumatic Stress Disorder: A Phase 2a Randomized Clinical Trial. JAMA Netw Open. 2023 05 01;6(5):e2310223. doi: 10.1001/jamanetworkopen.2023.10223. PMID: 37159200.

Arm N Randomized Detail: 40 initially randomized, 1 randomized in error and excluded from efficacy analyses
Treatment Description: Matched oral placebo
Dose: Dose NA (two tablets)
Participant Adherence Definition: Treatment adherence ≥85% (≥12 of 14 pills taken), based on returned pill counts
Participants Adhered Percent Detail: of n=39 (excludes one participant randomized in error who took 1 dose)
Trauma Detail (Study level): Combat-related; Other ("military trauma" not further specified)
Citation: Golier JA, Li X, Bizien M, et al. Efficacy and Safety of Mifepristone in the Treatment of Male US Veterans With Posttraumatic Stress Disorder: A Phase 2a Randomized Clinical Trial. JAMA Netw Open. 2023 05 01;6(5):e2310223. doi: 10.1001/jamanetworkopen.2023.10223. PMID: 37159200.

Treatment Description: Brief, non-traumatizing trauma-focused CBT in which a consolidated trauma memory is reactivated using a brief narrative, then patients are presented with healthy dissociative distancing experiences and exercises to modify the perceptual structure of the memory
Trauma Detail (Study level): MST, combat-related, rape/sexual assault, accidents, community/school violence, terrorism/political violence/forced displacement, other (not specified)
Citation: Gray R, Budden-Potts D, Bourke F. Reconsolidation of traumatic memories for PTSD: a randomized controlled trial of 74 male veterans. Psychother Res. 2019 29(5): 621-639. DOI: 10.1080/10503307.2017.1408973

Trauma Detail (Study level): MST, combat-related, rape/sexual assault, accidents, community/school violence, terrorism/political violence/forced displacement, other (not specified)
Citation: Gray R, Budden-Potts D, Bourke F. Reconsolidation of traumatic memories for PTSD: a randomized controlled trial of 74 male veterans. Psychother Res. 2019 29(5): 621-639. DOI: 10.1080/10503307.2017.1408973

Treatment Description: A brief manualized treatment generally targeting current-month intrusive symptoms and heightened arousal
Treatment Duration Detail: Total of 3 sessions, "typically completed in 3 weeks"
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: not further defined
Trauma Detail (Study level): MST, Other (not specified)
Citation: Gray RM, Budden-Potts D, Schwall RJ, et al. An open-label, randomized controlled trial of the reconsolidation of traumatic memories protocol (RTM) in military women. Psychol Trauma. 2021 Sep;13(6):641-51. doi: 10.1037/tra0000986. PMID: 33211519.

Treatment Description: No direct intervention or contact from researchers received during 5-week period
Trauma Detail (Study level): MST, Other (not specified)
Citation: Gray RM, Budden-Potts D, Schwall RJ, et al. An open-label, randomized controlled trial of the reconsolidation of traumatic memories protocol (RTM) in military women. Psychol Trauma. 2021 Sep;13(6):641-51. doi: 10.1037/tra0000986. PMID: 33211519.

Treatment Description: Supervised community-based exercise training for older veterans; integrates cognitive behavioral strategies during exercise program, targeting 5 sources of self-efficacy: "(1) self-monitoring and mastery experi- ence; (2) education of physiologic responses to exercise; (3) outcome expectations; (4) barriers to participation; and (5) modeling and social support". Includes individual exercise prescription, with one-on-one and independent exercises which emphasized "aerobic, strength, balance, and flexibility exercises. Modalities included body weight, free weight, cables, and exercise bands; treadmills and stationary bikes were used for aerobic training".
Psychotherapy Sessions Completed Detail: 82% (range 23 to 100%) (of participants who attended at least one session)
Citation: Hall KS, Morey MC, Bosworth HB, et al. Pilot randomized controlled trial of exercise training for older veterans with PTSD. J Behav Med. 2019 Jul 1doi: 10.1007/s10865-019-00073-w. PMID: 31264055.

Treatment Description: Continued usual care in VA clinics.
Citation: Hall KS, Morey MC, Bosworth HB, et al. Pilot randomized controlled trial of exercise training for older veterans with PTSD. J Behav Med. 2019 Jul 1doi: 10.1007/s10865-019-00073-w. PMID: 31264055.

Treatment Description:
Pranayama plus TF-CBT
Pranayama: 3 rounds lasting 5-10 minutes at the beginning of each TF-CBT session, described as a combination of mindful breathing and breath-holding techniques 
TF-CBT: following standard guideline for remainder of session (40-45 minutes), "stabilization techniques included trauma education, progressive muscle relaxation, self-control and affect-control methods, imagination, and self-care/resource development and were followed by standard confrontation techniques"
Completed Treatment Definition: completed intervention; able to perform pranayama
Citation: Haller H, Mitzinger D, Cramer H. The integration of yoga breathing techniques in cognitive behavioral therapy for post-traumatic stress disorder: A pragmatic randomized controlled trial. Front Psychiatr. 2023;14:1101046. doi: 10.3389/fpsyt.2023.1101046. PMID: 37139325.

Treatment Description: Standard guideline TF-CBT for full session; "stabilization techniques included trauma education, progressive muscle relaxation, self-control and affect-control methods, imagination, and self-care/resource development and were followed by standard confrontation techniques"
Citation: Haller H, Mitzinger D, Cramer H. The integration of yoga breathing techniques in cognitive behavioral therapy for post-traumatic stress disorder: A pragmatic randomized controlled trial. Front Psychiatr. 2023;14:1101046. doi: 10.3389/fpsyt.2023.1101046. PMID: 37139325.

Treatment Description: Anticonvulsant
Dose: Started at 750 mg/day "in divided doses", increased by 250 mg every 3 to 4 days, titrated until positive clinical response or desired trough level (50 to 125 mcg/mL); mean daily dose range 500 to 1500 mg
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, MST
Citation: Hamner MB, Faldowski RA, Robert S, et al. A preliminary controlled trial of divalproex in posttraumatic stress disorder. Ann Clin Psychiatry. 2009 Apr-Jun;21(2):89-94. PMID: 19439158.

Treatment Description: Placebo
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, MST
Citation: Hamner MB, Faldowski RA, Robert S, et al. A preliminary controlled trial of divalproex in posttraumatic stress disorder. Ann Clin Psychiatry. 2009 Apr-Jun;21(2):89-94. PMID: 19439158.

Treatment Description: Ziprasidone augmentation to sertraline or paroxetine (open-label sertraline or paroxetine during phase 1 of study; see comments for phase 1 details).
Dose: 120 to 160 mg total daily dose, as tolerated
Dose at Study End Point Detail: all individuals reached targeted dosing range
Citation: Hamner MB, Hernandez-Tejada MA, Zuschlag ZD, et al. Ziprasidone augmentation of SSRI antidepressants in posttraumatic stress disorder: a randomized, placebo-controlled pilot study of augmentation therapy. J Clin Psychopharmacol. 2019 Mar/Apr;39(2):153-7. doi: 10.1097/JCP.0000000000001000. PMID: 30640209.

Treatment Description: Placebo augmentation to sertraline or paroxetine (open-label sertraline or paroxetine during phase 1 of study; see comments for phase 1 details).
Dose: Comparable dosing to ziprasidone 120 to 160 mg
Dose at Study End Point Detail: all individuals reached targeted dosing range
Citation: Hamner MB, Hernandez-Tejada MA, Zuschlag ZD, et al. Ziprasidone augmentation of SSRI antidepressants in posttraumatic stress disorder: a randomized, placebo-controlled pilot study of augmentation therapy. J Clin Psychopharmacol. 2019 Mar/Apr;39(2):153-7. doi: 10.1097/JCP.0000000000001000. PMID: 30640209.

Treatment Description: Injection of ropivacaine (a local anesthetic) at right C5 or C6 vertebra into the stellate ganglion - sympathetic nerve tissue of the neck.
Dose: 5 mL of 0.5% ropivacaine
Frequency: Once or twice, depending on response
Treatment Duration Detail: single injection, second injection after 3 months if needed
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: Reports in flow diagram as "received allocated intervention" (100% of participants); 2nd injection was allowed only for participants still meeting PTSD criteria, but unclear if all of these did receive 2nd injection, and no other information for treatment completion
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, other (noncombat unspecified)
Citation: Hanling SR, Hickey A, Lesnik I, et al. Stellate Ganglion Block for the treatment of posttraumatic stress disorder: a randomized, double-blind, controlled trial. Reg Anesth Pain Med. 2016 Jul-Aug;41(4):494-500. doi: 10.1097/aap.0000000000000402. PMID: 27187898.

Treatment Description: Normal saline injected in soft tissues superficial to the anterior tubercle of C6
Dose: 5 mL
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: Reports in flow diagram as "received allocated intervention" (100% of participants); participants were allowed to crossover after sham intervention and asssessment and reports those who had 1st and 2nd active injections
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, other (noncombat unspecified)
Citation: Hanling SR, Hickey A, Lesnik I, et al. Stellate Ganglion Block for the treatment of posttraumatic stress disorder: a randomized, double-blind, controlled trial. Reg Anesth Pain Med. 2016 Jul-Aug;41(4):494-500. doi: 10.1097/aap.0000000000000402. PMID: 27187898.

Standardized Treatment Name: Imagery Rehearsal Training (IRT) + Cognitive Behavioral Therapy for Insomnia (CBT-I)
Treatment Description:
IR combined with CBT-I as manualized treatment; participants completed standard daily sleep diaries.



CBT-I "included psychoeducation about sleep and post-traumatic sleep problems and the following elements of standard CBT-I: grounding, aimed at reducing arousal and/or disso- citation after waking from nightmares (session 1), progressive muscle relaxation and discussion of the relationship between daily stressors, sleep, and nightmares (session 2), sleep hygiene and setting a regular sleep schedule (session 3), stimulus control (session 4), reduction of cognitive hyperarousal (session 5), and relapse prevention (session 6)"; did not include intentional sleep restriction.



IR was incorporated in sessions 2-4 with identification and rescripting of a recurrent nightmare.
Citation: Harb GC, Cook JM, Phelps AJ, et al. Randomized controlled trial of imagery rehearsal for posttraumatic nightmares in combat veterans. J Clin Sleep Med. 2019 May 15;15(5):757-67. doi: 10.5664/jcsm.7770. PMID: 31053215.

Treatment Description: CBT-I: manualized therapy; "included psychoeducation about sleep and post-traumatic sleep problems and the following elements of standard CBT-I: grounding, aimed at reducing arousal and/or disso- citation after waking from nightmares (session 1), progressive muscle relaxation and discussion of the relationship between daily stressors, sleep, and nightmares (session 2), sleep hygiene and setting a regular sleep schedule (session 3), stimulus control (session 4), reduction of cognitive hyperarousal (session 5), and relapse prevention (session 6)"; CBT-I did not include intentional sleep restriction, discussion of nightmare content, and did not teach any imagery rescripting techniques. Participants completed standard daily sleep diaries.
Citation: Harb GC, Cook JM, Phelps AJ, et al. Randomized controlled trial of imagery rehearsal for posttraumatic nightmares in combat veterans. J Clin Sleep Med. 2019 May 15;15(5):757-67. doi: 10.5664/jcsm.7770. PMID: 31053215.

Treatment Description: Manualized, spiritually integrated, group counseling intervention designed to facilitate resolution of spiritual distress
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, rape/sexual assault, accidents, illness/medical procedure, community/school violence, other (adverse childhood experiences, not specified)
Citation: Harris JI, Usset T, Voecks C, et al. Spiritually integrated care for PTSD: a randomized controlled trial of "Building Spiritual Strength". Psychiatry Res. 2018 Jun 20;267:420-8. doi: 10.1016/j.psychres.2018.06.045. PMID: 29980120.

Treatment Description: Provides support and addresses participants' current problems but does not directly focus on the person's trauma-related memories or facilitate resolution of participants' spiritual distress
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, rape/sexual assault, accidents, illness/medical procedure, community/school violence, other (adverse childhood experiences, not specified)
Citation: Harris JI, Usset T, Voecks C, et al. Spiritually integrated care for PTSD: a randomized controlled trial of "Building Spiritual Strength". Psychiatry Res. 2018 Jun 20;267:420-8. doi: 10.1016/j.psychres.2018.06.045. PMID: 29980120.

Treatment Name: Cognitive Behavioral Social Rhythm Group Therapy
Standardized Treatment Name: Cognitive Behavioral Social Rhythm Group Therapy
Treatment Description: Manualized, structured group therapy based on social rhythm model of mood disruption. Attempts to  increase the frequency and consistency of daily, habitual behaviors including social interactions and sleep, increase ambient light exposure, and challenge unhelpful thoughts that impede behavioral goals. No discussion of past events.
Citation: Haynes PL, Burger SB, Kelly M, et al. Cognitive behavioral social rhythm group therapy versus present centered group therapy for veterans with posttraumatic stress disorder and major depressive disorder: a randomized controlled pilot trial. J Affect Disord. 2020 Dec 1;277:800-9. doi: 10.1016/j.jad.2020.09.009. PMID: 33065820.

Treatment Description: Manualized, unstructured group therapy based on group process model; focuses on current relationships, behaviors and feelings resulting from past trauma; included relaxation training and sleep hygeine rules. No discussion of past events.
Citation: Haynes PL, Burger SB, Kelly M, et al. Cognitive behavioral social rhythm group therapy versus present centered group therapy for veterans with posttraumatic stress disorder and major depressive disorder: a randomized controlled pilot trial. J Affect Disord. 2020 Dec 1;277:800-9. doi: 10.1016/j.jad.2020.09.009. PMID: 33065820.

Treatment Description: According to manual by Schauer et al. (2005), participant constructs a detailed chronological account of his/her biography. The therapist provides empathic understanding, active listening, congruency, and unconditional positive regard for the participant. The participant is encouraged to relive the emotions while narrating, and therapist links the experiences to episodic facts and contrasts the time and place of the memory with those of the present
Frequency: NR (mean 9.82 [SD 3.55] days between sessions for overall study population)
Treatment Duration Detail: 10 sessions total, lasting mean 13 weeks for overall study population
Citation: Hensel-Dittmann D, Schauer M, Ruf M, et al. Treatment of traumatized victims of war and torture: a randomized controlled comparison of narrative exposure therapy and stress inoculation training. Psychother Psychosom. 2011 Oct;80(6):345-52. doi: 10.1159/000327253. PMID: 21829046.

Treatment Description: Modified version includes breathing techniques, relaxation training, cognitive restructuring, thought stopping, guided self-dialogue, covert modeling, and role play
Frequency: NR (mean 9.82 [SD 3.55] days between sessions for overall study population)
Treatment Duration Detail: 10 sessions total, lasting mean 13 weeks for overall study population
Citation: Hensel-Dittmann D, Schauer M, Ruf M, et al. Treatment of traumatized victims of war and torture: a randomized controlled comparison of narrative exposure therapy and stress inoculation training. Psychother Psychosom. 2011 Oct;80(6):345-52. doi: 10.1159/000327253. PMID: 21829046.

Treatment Description: Partial agonist at the NMDA receptor-associated glycine site; also used as broad spectrum antibiotic. Cross-over design with 2 weeks of washout between treatment periods.
Dose: 25 mg
Trauma Detail (Study level): accidents, terrorism/political violence/forced displacement, other (physical abuse)
Citation: Heresco-Levy U, Kremer I, Javitt DC, et al. Pilot-controlled trial of D-cycloserine for the treatment of post-traumatic stress disorder. Int J Neuropsychopharmacol. 2002 Dec;5(4):301-7. doi: 10.1017/S1461145702003061. PMID: 12466030.

Treatment Description: Matched placebo. Cross-over design with 2 weeks of washout between treatment periods.
Trauma Detail (Study level): accidents, terrorism/political violence/forced displacement, other (physical abuse)
Citation: Heresco-Levy U, Kremer I, Javitt DC, et al. Pilot-controlled trial of D-cycloserine for the treatment of post-traumatic stress disorder. Int J Neuropsychopharmacol. 2002 Dec;5(4):301-7. doi: 10.1017/S1461145702003061. PMID: 12466030.

Treatment Description: NMDA glutamate receptor agonist; cross-over design with 3 week washout period.
Dose: 30 mg/kg total daily dose; titration: initiated at 10 mg/kg, increased after 1 week to 20 mg/kg and after 2 weeks to 30 mg/kg
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, accidents, terrorism/political violence/forced displacement, other (not specified)
Citation: Heresco-Levy U, Vass A, Bloch B, et al. Pilot controlled trial of D-serine for the treatment of post-traumatic stress disorder. Int J Neuropsychopharmacol. 2009 Oct;12(9):1275-82. doi: 10.1017/S1461145709000339. PMID: 19366490.

Treatment Description: Placebo in capsule identical to active treatment with same dose escalation schedule; cross-over design with 3 week washout period.
Dose: 30 mg/kg D-serine equivalent total daily dose; titration: initiated at 10 mg/kg, increased after 1 week to 20 mg/kg and after 2 weeks to 30 mg/kg
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, accidents, terrorism/political violence/forced displacement, other (not specified)
Citation: Heresco-Levy U, Vass A, Bloch B, et al. Pilot controlled trial of D-serine for the treatment of post-traumatic stress disorder. Int J Neuropsychopharmacol. 2009 Oct;12(9):1275-82. doi: 10.1017/S1461145709000339. PMID: 19366490.

Treatment Description: Glutamate-inhibiting anticonvulsant with antidepressant properties; flexible dosing to achieve maximal response
Dose: 50 to 500 mg; flexible dosing; titration: 25 mg for 2 weeks, 50 mg for 2 weeks, 100 mg for 1 week, then increased in 100-mg increments every 1 to 2 weeks with maximum dose of 500 mg; taper over last 2 weeks with 50% reduction each week
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, rape/sexual assault, other (abduction)
Citation: Hertzberg MA, Butterfield MI, Feldman ME, et al. A preliminary study of lamotrigine for the treatment of posttraumatic stress disorder. Biol psychiatry. 1999 May 1;45(9):1226-9. PMID: 10331117.

Treatment Description: Placebo
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, rape/sexual assault, other (abduction)
Citation: Hertzberg MA, Butterfield MI, Feldman ME, et al. A preliminary study of lamotrigine for the treatment of posttraumatic stress disorder. Biol psychiatry. 1999 May 1;45(9):1226-9. PMID: 10331117.

Treatment Description: SSRI; flexible dosing with titration to maximal response or dose-limiting side effects
Dose: 10 to 60 mg; titration: 10 mg for 1 week, then 20 mg for 2 weeks, then increased weekly in 10-mg increments with maximum daily dose of 60 mg
Citation: Hertzberg MA, Feldman ME, Beckham JC, et al. Lack of efficacy for fluoxetine in PTSD: a placebo controlled trial in combat veterans. Ann Clin Psychiatry. 2000 Jun;12(2):101-5. doi: 10.1023/A:1009076231175. PMID: 10907802.

Treatment Description: Placebo
Citation: Hertzberg MA, Feldman ME, Beckham JC, et al. Lack of efficacy for fluoxetine in PTSD: a placebo controlled trial in combat veterans. Ann Clin Psychiatry. 2000 Jun;12(2):101-5. doi: 10.1023/A:1009076231175. PMID: 10907802.

Arm N Randomized Detail: 41 attended at least one session and were analyzed
Treatment Description: Manualized individual therapy; cognitive behavioral "integrated treatment that addresses PTSD symptoms in the context of substance abuse."
Citation: Hien DA, Cohen LR, Miele GM, et al. Promising treatments for women with comorbid PTSD and substance use disorders. Am J Psychiatry. 2004 Aug;161(8):1426-32. doi: 10.1176/appi.ajp.161.8.1426. PMID: 15285969.

Arm N Randomized Detail: 34 completed at least one session and were randomized
Treatment Description: Manualized individual therapy addressing substance abuse; "does not directly address trauma-related symptoms."
Citation: Hien DA, Cohen LR, Miele GM, et al. Promising treatments for women with comorbid PTSD and substance use disorders. Am J Psychiatry. 2004 Aug;161(8):1426-32. doi: 10.1176/appi.ajp.161.8.1426. PMID: 15285969.

Treatment Description: Group therapy sessions following set structure; abbreviated to 12 sessions (full Seeking Safety treatment protocol is 25 sessions), each with a different topic; included topics: "safety, taking back power from PTSD, when substances are in control, honesty, setting boundaries in relationships, compassion, healing from anger, cre- ating meaning, integrating the split self, taking good care of oneself, red and green flags, and detaching from emotional pain (grounding)." All participants also had TAU for substance abuse at a community-based substance abuse treatment program which did not include trauma-focused treatments.
Completed Treatment Definition: completed at least 6 treatment sessions ("at least minimal exposure")
Trauma Detail (Study level): child physical abuse, child sexual abuse, rape/sexual assault, community/school violence, accidents, illness/medical procedure, other ("exposed to violent death")
Citation: Hien DA, Wells EA, Jiang H, et al. Multisite randomized trial of behavioral interventions for women with co-occurring PTSD and substance use disorders. J Consult Clin Psychol. 2009 Aug;77(4):607-19. doi: 10.1037/a0016227. PMID: 19634955.

Treatment Description: Group format with all sessions following the same format; intervention is "psychoeducational, manualized health curriculum focused on topics such as understanding the female body, human sexual behavior, pregnancy and childbirth, sexually trans- mitted diseases, HIV, and AIDS"; no "explicit focus or psychoeducation specific to substance abuse or trauma". All participants also had TAU for substance abuse at a community-based substance abuse treatment program which did not include trauma-focused treatments.
Completed Treatment Definition: completed at least 6 treatment sessions ("at least minimal exposure")
Trauma Detail (Study level): child physical abuse, child sexual abuse, rape/sexual assault, community/school violence, accidents, illness/medical procedure, other ("exposed to violent death")
Citation: Hien DA, Wells EA, Jiang H, et al. Multisite randomized trial of behavioral interventions for women with co-occurring PTSD and substance use disorders. J Consult Clin Psychol. 2009 Aug;77(4):607-19. doi: 10.1037/a0016227. PMID: 19634955.

Treatment Description: Manualized treatment adapted for 3 sessions; intervention that fuses emotional processing, testimony, and expressive writing by helping people construct detailed narratives of their life stories with a focus on their traumatic experiences.
Trauma Detail (Study level): terrorism/political violence/forced displacement, rape/sexual assault, combat-related
Citation: Hijazi AM, Lumley MA, Ziadni MS, et al. Brief narrative exposure therapy for posttraumatic stress in Iraqi refugees: a preliminary randomized clinical trial. J Trauma Stress. 2014 Jun;27(3):314-22. doi: 10.1002/jts.21922. PMID: 24866253.

Treatment Description: Waitlist
Trauma Detail (Study level): terrorism/political violence/forced displacement, rape/sexual assault, combat-related
Citation: Hijazi AM, Lumley MA, Ziadni MS, et al. Brief narrative exposure therapy for posttraumatic stress in Iraqi refugees: a preliminary randomized clinical trial. J Trauma Stress. 2014 Jun;27(3):314-22. doi: 10.1002/jts.21922. PMID: 24866253.

Treatment Description: Inpatient treatment, including EMDR, psychotherapy groups, physiotherapy, occupational and art therapy
Citation: Himmerich H, Willmund GD, Zimmermann P, et al. Serum concentrations of TNF-alpha and its soluble receptors during psychotherapy in German soldiers suffering from combat-related PTSD. Psychiatr. 2016;28(3):293-8. PMID: 27658839.

Treatment Description: Outpatient management, including suppportive psychotherapy but not including EMDR
Citation: Himmerich H, Willmund GD, Zimmermann P, et al. Serum concentrations of TNF-alpha and its soluble receptors during psychotherapy in German soldiers suffering from combat-related PTSD. Psychiatr. 2016;28(3):293-8. PMID: 27658839.

Standardized Treatment Name: Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) without a trauma focus
Treatment Description: Manualized treatment according to Hinton et al. (2005) that includes muscle relaxation, guided imagery and mindfulness training, yoga-like stretching linked to self images of flexibility, cognitive restructuring, exercises used to teach emotional distancing and switching, and interceptive exposure
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: Study reports all randomized patients completed the study and no missing data (no attrition from measurement), but does not provide information specifically for treatment completion.
Citation: Hinton DE, Hofmann SG, Pollack MH, et al. Mechanisms of efficacy of CBT for Cambodian refugees with PTSD: improvement in emotion regulation and orthostatic blood pressure response. CNS Neurosci Ther. 2009 Fall;15(3):255-63. doi: 10.1111/j.1755-5949.2009.00100.x. PMID: 19691545.

Hinton DE, Hofmann SG, Pollack MH, et al. Mechanisms of efficacy of CBT for Cambodian refugees with PTSD: improvement in emotion regulation and orthostatic blood pressure response. CNS Neurosci Ther. 2009 Fall;15(3):255-63. doi: 10.1111/j.1755-5949.2009.00100.x. PMID: 19691545.

Standardized Treatment Name: Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) without a trauma focus
Treatment Description: Manualized group CBT with treatment culturally adapted for Latino patients.
Citation: Hinton DE, Hofmann SG, Rivera E, et al. Culturally adapted CBT (CA-CBT) for Latino women with treatment-resistant PTSD: a pilot study comparing CA-CBT to applied muscle relaxation. Behav Res Ther. 2011 Apr;49(4):275-80. doi: 10.1016/j.brat.2011.01.005. PMID: 21333272.

Treatment Description: Manualized treatment; includes: psychoeducation about PTSD, anxiety, and panic; how those disorders produce somatic symptoms; how treatment can reduce anxiety and improve those disorders.
Citation: Hinton DE, Hofmann SG, Rivera E, et al. Culturally adapted CBT (CA-CBT) for Latino women with treatment-resistant PTSD: a pilot study comparing CA-CBT to applied muscle relaxation. Behav Res Ther. 2011 Apr;49(4):275-80. doi: 10.1016/j.brat.2011.01.005. PMID: 21333272.

Treatment Description: Brexpiprazole (atypical antipsychotic) + sertraline (SSRI), each with flexible dosing. Screening/washout period of 3-14 days then 1-week placebo run-in period, followed by 9 weeks active treatment including titration over 2-3 weeks (endpoint at week 10 for analysis), then 2 weeks follow-up (trial duration 12 weeks total).
Dose:
Brexpiprazole 1 to 3 mg/day + sertraline 100 to 200 mg/day. Titration over 2 to 3 weeks. Decreases allowed through Week 6 for each drug (to minimum 1 mg/day brexpiprazole and 100 mg/day sertraline). Participants who required a dose increase/decrease had the doses changed for both drugs.
Brexpiprazole titration: Week 1, 0.5 mg/day; Week 2, 1 mg/day; Week 3, 2 mg/day; Week 4 stay at 2, increase to 3, or decrease to 1 mg/day.
Sertraline titration: Week 1, 50 mg/day; Week 2, 100 mg/day; Week 3, 150 mg/day; Week 4, stay at 150, increase to 200, or decrease to 100 mg/day.
Treatment Duration Detail: Treatment period 9 weeks, from week 1 to week 10 endpoint (considered end of treatment for trial). See study comments and publication for additional information.
Dose at Study End Point Detail: Mean dose at each participant's last visit (reported for all 80 treated, though some did not complete 12 weeks' treatment)
Trauma Detail (Study level): Combat-related; Other (not specified)
Citation: Hobart M, Chang D, Hefting N, et al. Brexpiprazole in Combination With Sertraline and as Monotherapy in Posttraumatic Stress Disorder: A Full-Factorial Randomized Clinical Trial. J Clin Psychiatry. 2025 Feb 19;86(1):19. doi: 10.4088/JCP.24m15577. PMID: 40009045.

Treatment Description: Brexpiprazole (atypical antipsychotic) with flexible dosing + placebo for sertraline. Screening/washout period of 3-14 days then 1-week placebo run-in period,  followed by 9 weeks active treatment including titration over 2-3 weeks (endpoint at week 10 for analysis), then 2 weeks follow-up (trial duration 12 weeks total). Matching placebo.
Dose:
Brexpiprazole 1 to 3 mg/day + placebo matching sertraline capsules.
Titration over 2 to 3 weeks. Decreases allowed through Week 6 (to minimum 1 mg/day).
Brexpiprazole titration: Week 1, 0.5 mg/day; Week 2, 1 mg/day; Week 3, 2 mg/day; Week 4 stay at 2, increase to 3, or decrease to 1 mg/day.
Treatment Duration Detail: Treatment period 9 weeks, from week 1 to week 10 endpoint (considered end of treatment for trial). See study comments and publication for additional information.
Dose at Study End Point Detail: Mean dose at each participant's last visit (reported for all 75 treated, though some did not complete 12 weeks' treatment)
Trauma Detail (Study level): Combat-related; Other (not specified)
Citation: Hobart M, Chang D, Hefting N, et al. Brexpiprazole in Combination With Sertraline and as Monotherapy in Posttraumatic Stress Disorder: A Full-Factorial Randomized Clinical Trial. J Clin Psychiatry. 2025 Feb 19;86(1):19. doi: 10.4088/JCP.24m15577. PMID: 40009045.

Treatment Description: Sertraline (SSRI) with flexible dosing + placebo for brexpiprazole. Screening/washout period of 3-14 days then 1-week placebo run-in period,  followed by 9 weeks active treatment including titration over 2-3 weeks (endpoint at week 10 for analysis), then 2 weeks follow-up (trial duration 12 weeks total). Matching placebo.
Dose:
Sertraline 100 to 200 mg/day + placebo matching brexpiprazole tablets. Titration over 2 to 3 weeks. Decreases allowed through Week 6 (to minimum 100 mg/day)
Sertraline titration: Week 1, 50 mg/day; Week 2, 100 mg/day; Week 3, 150 mg/day; Week 4, stay at 150, increase to 200, or decrease to 100 mg/day.
Treatment Duration Detail: Treatment period 9 weeks, from week 1 to week 10 endpoint (considered end of treatment for trial). See study comments and publication for additional information.
Dose at Study End Point Detail: Mean dose at each participant's last visit (reported for all 79 treated, though some did not complete 12 weeks' treatment)
Trauma Detail (Study level): Combat-related; Other (not specified)
Citation: Hobart M, Chang D, Hefting N, et al. Brexpiprazole in Combination With Sertraline and as Monotherapy in Posttraumatic Stress Disorder: A Full-Factorial Randomized Clinical Trial. J Clin Psychiatry. 2025 Feb 19;86(1):19. doi: 10.4088/JCP.24m15577. PMID: 40009045.

Treatment Description: Placebos for brexpiprazole and sertraline. Screening/washout period of 3-14 days then 1-week placebo run-in period, followed by 9 weeks active treatment including titration over 2-3 weeks (endpoint at week 10 for analysis), then 2 weeks follow-up (trial duration 12 weeks total). Matching placebos to both active medications.
Dose: Placebos matching brexpiprazole tablets and sertraline capsules.
Treatment Duration Detail: Treatment period 9 weeks, from week 1 to week 10 endpoint (considered end of treatment for trial). See study comments and publication for additional information.
Trauma Detail (Study level): Combat-related; Other (not specified)
Citation: Hobart M, Chang D, Hefting N, et al. Brexpiprazole in Combination With Sertraline and as Monotherapy in Posttraumatic Stress Disorder: A Full-Factorial Randomized Clinical Trial. J Clin Psychiatry. 2025 Feb 19;86(1):19. doi: 10.4088/JCP.24m15577. PMID: 40009045.

Treatment Description: Manualized trauma-focused therapy following manual for PE using imagery exposure (Foa et al., 2007) adapted for inpatient setting; treatment included treatment rationale and psychoeducation, constructing exposure hierarchy, and imagery exposure (both entire memory and hot spots procedure).
Completed Treatment Definition: did not drop out and received therapy according to protocol
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, rape/sexual assault, accidents, community/school violence
Citation: Hoffart A, Øktedalen T, Langkaas TF, et al. Alliance and outcome in varying imagery procedures for PTSD: a study of within-person processes. J Couns Psychol. 2013 Oct;60(4):471-82. doi: 10.1037/a0033604. PMID: 23957768.

Treatment Description: Manualized trauma-focused therapy following manual for PE using imagery rescripting (Smucker, 2005) adapted for inpatient setting; treatment included treatment rationale and psychoeducation, and 3 continuous phases of imagery rescripting: imagery reliving of the traumatic event, imagining current self entering the scene at the hot spot and bringing the situation to a solution, and imagining an interaction between the current self and the traumatized self back then.
Completed Treatment Definition: did not drop out and received therapy according to protocol
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, rape/sexual assault, accidents, community/school violence
Citation: Hoffart A, Øktedalen T, Langkaas TF, et al. Alliance and outcome in varying imagery procedures for PTSD: a study of within-person processes. J Couns Psychol. 2013 Oct;60(4):471-82. doi: 10.1037/a0033604. PMID: 23957768.

Treatment Description: Breathing and relaxation technique presented at beginning of each session. EMDR consists of therapist-guided psychotherapy designed to help shift negative thoughts and bodily distress to desired positive thoughts through sensory stimulations with rhythmic quality and left-right alternating character
Trauma Detail (Study level): accidents, community/school violence
Citation: Hogberg G, Pagani M, Sundin O, et al. On treatment with eye movement desensitization and reprocessing of chronic post-traumatic stress disorder in public transportation workers--a randomized controlled trial. Nord J Psychiatry. 2007;61(1):54-61. doi:  10.1080/08039480601129408. PMID: 17365790.

Trauma Detail (Study level): accidents, community/school violence
Citation: Hogberg G, Pagani M, Sundin O, et al. On treatment with eye movement desensitization and reprocessing of chronic post-traumatic stress disorder in public transportation workers--a randomized controlled trial. Nord J Psychiatry. 2007;61(1):54-61. doi:  10.1080/08039480601129408. PMID: 17365790.

Treatment Description:
Solid needles were placed into rationally



chosen points in subcutaneous tissue or muscle for a given period of time with manipulation. Sessions comprised of 15 to 20 minute interview; 2 to 5 minute pulse and tongue evaluation; 25 to 40 minute needle insertion, manipulation and retention; 2 minute ear-seed placement.
Citation: Hollifield M, Sinclair-Lian N, Warner TD, et al. Acupuncture for posttraumatic stress disorder: a randomized controlled pilot trial. J Nerv Ment Dis. 2007 Jun;195(6):504-13. doi: 10.1097/NMD.0b013e31803044f8. PMID: 17568299.

Treatment Description: Integrates 4 modalities that have direct and theoretical evidence of efficacy: psychoeducation, behavioral activation, activity planning, cognitive restructuring, imagery rehearsal, exposure and desensitization
Citation: Hollifield M, Sinclair-Lian N, Warner TD, et al. Acupuncture for posttraumatic stress disorder: a randomized controlled pilot trial. J Nerv Ment Dis. 2007 Jun;195(6):504-13. doi: 10.1097/NMD.0b013e31803044f8. PMID: 17568299.

Hollifield M, Sinclair-Lian N, Warner TD, et al. Acupuncture for posttraumatic stress disorder: a randomized controlled pilot trial. J Nerv Ment Dis. 2007 Jun;195(6):504-13. doi: 10.1097/NMD.0b013e31803044f8. PMID: 17568299.

Treatment Description: Acupuncture following traditional Chinese medicine protocols; standard point prescription and up to 3 discretionary points with electric stimulation during needle retention (across 2-point pairs at mixed freqency of 2/100 Hz).
Completed Treatment Percent Detail:
Completed all 24 sessions: 36.17%
Completed ≥19 sessions: 70.21%
Trauma Detail (Study level): Combat-related; MST; Accidents; Other ("another violence or loss event")
Citation: Hollifield M, Hsiao AF, Smith T, et al. Acupuncture for combat-related posttraumatic stress disorder: a randomized clinical trial. JAMA Psychiatry. 2024 Feb 21;21:21. doi: 10.1001/jamapsychiatry.2023.5651. PMID: 38381417.

Arm N Randomized Detail: 46 randomized, 45 analyzed (n=1 withdrawn due to COVID-19 and excluded from analysis)
Treatment Description: Sham acupuncture, differentiated by location (2 cm lateral or medial to reference points), superficial insertion, and sham electrostimulator (blinking light without current). Matched in time, frequency, and duration to verum acupuncture intervention.
Completed Treatment Percent Detail:
Completed all 24 sessions: 21.74%
Completed ≥19 sessions: 58.70%
Trauma Detail (Study level): Combat-related; MST; Accidents; Other ("another violence or loss event")
Citation: Hollifield M, Hsiao AF, Smith T, et al. Acupuncture for combat-related posttraumatic stress disorder: a randomized clinical trial. JAMA Psychiatry. 2024 Feb 21;21:21. doi: 10.1001/jamapsychiatry.2023.5651. PMID: 38381417.

Treatment Name: Outward Bound Experience adjunctive with TAU
Treatment Description:
TAU replaced by Outward Bound Experience for 1 week; remainder of TAU was not altered.







Outward Bound Experience: adventure experience comprised of: small group exercises focused on cooperation and trust; challenges that emphasize perseverance, self-reliance, and teamwork;  reflection with individual time for solitude, journal writing, and "solo" experiences; experiential tasks such as ropes course, hiking, rock climbing; group discussions functioning as debriefings of feeling and experiences, but without specific "group therapy" sessions or focus on war-trauma issues. 







TAU: specialized inpatient PTSD treatment program using multidisciplinary team approach, but differing by location. Location A: psychosocial emphasis with stress reduction treatment focus; treatment involves ongoing process group with up to 7 module groups on aspects of trauma coping; no psychopharmaceutical treatment is allowed. Location T: significant emphasis on processing war-related trauma issues in group setting and veteran involvement in therapeutic milieu (such as peer counseling); incorporates psychopharmaceutical treatments
Treatment Duration Detail: Outward Bound Experience 1 week; overall inpatient treatment 11 to 14 weeks
Citation: Hyer L, Boyd S, Scurfield R, et al. Effects of Outward Bound experience as an adjunct to inpatient PTSD treatment of war veterans. J Clin Psychol. 1996 May;52(3):263-78. doi: 10.1002/(SICI)1097-4679(199605)52:3<263::AID-JCLP3>3.0.CO;2-T. PMID: 8835688.

Treatment Description: TAU: specialized inpatient PTSD treatment program using multidisciplinary team approach, but differing by location. Location A: psychosocial emphasis with stress reduction treatment focus; treatment involves ongoing process group with up to 7 module groups on aspects of trauma coping; no psychopharmaceutical treatment is allowed. Location T: significant emphasis on processing war-related trauma issues in group setting and veteran involvement in therapeutic milieu (such as peer counseling); incorporates psychopharmaceutical treatments

Treatment Description: Direct transcranial magnetic stimulation after script-driven imagery of the traumatic experience immediately followed by a script-driven imagery of a neutral event
Dose: 20 Hz trains of 2 seconds each with 20 seconds inter-train interval for 42 trains, 1680 pulses total
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, other (not specified)
Citation: Isserles M, Shalev AY, Roth Y, et al. Effectiveness of deep transcranial magnetic stimulation combined with a brief exposure procedure in post-traumatic stress disorder--a pilot study. Brain Stimul. 2013 May;6(3):377-83. doi: 10.1016/j.brs.2012.07.008. PMID: 22921765.

Treatment Description: DTMS after script-driven imagery of a positive experience immediately followed by a script-driven imagery of a neutral event
Dose: 20 Hz trains of 2 seconds each with 20 seconds inter-train interval for 42 trains, 1680 pulses total
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, other (not specified)
Citation: Isserles M, Shalev AY, Roth Y, et al. Effectiveness of deep transcranial magnetic stimulation combined with a brief exposure procedure in post-traumatic stress disorder--a pilot study. Brain Stimul. 2013 May;6(3):377-83. doi: 10.1016/j.brs.2012.07.008. PMID: 22921765.

Treatment Description: DTMS after script-driven imagery of a positive experience immediately followed by a script-driven imagery of a neutral event.

Dose:
18 Hz, 2-second trains, 20-second intertrain

intervals, with 80 trains at 100% of leg resting motor threshold

Treatment Description: Sham TMS

Trauma Detail (Study level): Other ("Childhood trauma"), Other (not specified)
