Treatment Description:
Manualized CPT without a trauma account, increasing standard 12 sessions to maximum 16 sessions.
TAU could include pharmacotherapy, clinical monitoring, psychoeducation, and supportive counseling, all commonly used for treating patient with PTSD in Japanese medical settings.
Treatment Duration Detail: 12 to 16 weekly sessions; median treatment duration 88.9 (IQR 84.0-101.5) days
Trauma Detail (Study level): Accidents; Illness/medical procedure; Natural or manmade disasters; Rape/sexual assault;  Community/school violence; Other (severe human suffering; sudden violent death; any other very stressful event or experience)
Citation: Ito M, Katayanagi A, Miyamae M, et al. Cognitive Processing Therapy for Posttraumatic Stress Disorder in Japan: A Randomized Clinical Trial. JAMA Netw Open. 2025 Feb 03;8(2):e2458059. doi: 10.1001/jamanetworkopen.2024.58059. PMID: 39908018.

Treatment Description: Waitlist participants received CPT following 17 week post-treatment assessment (during follow-up). TAU throughout study period, which could include pharmacotherapy, clinical monitoring, psychoeducation, and supportive counseling, all commonly used for treating patient with PTSD in Japanese medical settings.
Trauma Detail (Study level): Accidents; Illness/medical procedure; Natural or manmade disasters; Rape/sexual assault;  Community/school violence; Other (severe human suffering; sudden violent death; any other very stressful event or experience)
Citation: Ito M, Katayanagi A, Miyamae M, et al. Cognitive Processing Therapy for Posttraumatic Stress Disorder in Japan: A Randomized Clinical Trial. JAMA Netw Open. 2025 Feb 03;8(2):e2458059. doi: 10.1001/jamanetworkopen.2024.58059. PMID: 39908018.

Treatment Description: Guided internet-delivered CBT for PTSD: 8 text-based modules including validated components of "psychoeducation, anxiety coping skills training, exposure, and cognitive restructuring".
Trauma Detail (Study level): intimate partner violence, accidents, illness/medical procedure, combat-related, natural or manmade disasters, community/school violence, other (torture, multiple stressors)
Citation: Ivarsson D, Blom M, Hesser H, et al. Guided internet-delivered cognitive behavior therapy for post-traumatic stress disorder: a randomized controlled trial. Internet Interv. 2014 March;1(1):33-40. doi: 10.1016/j.invent.2014.03.002.

Treatment Description: Minimal support, delayed treatment control; non-passive condition comprised of voluntary participation in internet-delivered weekly sets of general questions regarding well-being, stress, and sleep. Treatment with guided internet-delivered CBT for PTSD offered after collection of post-treatment measures.
Trauma Detail (Study level): intimate partner violence, accidents, illness/medical procedure, combat-related, natural or manmade disasters, community/school violence, other (torture, multiple stressors)
Citation: Ivarsson D, Blom M, Hesser H, et al. Guided internet-delivered cognitive behavior therapy for post-traumatic stress disorder: a randomized controlled trial. Internet Interv. 2014 March;1(1):33-40. doi: 10.1016/j.invent.2014.03.002.

Treatment Description: Combined NET with IPT. First treatment session consists of psychoeducation. NET consists of the therapist recording participant's story in writing while seeking to reactivate the associated thoughts and emotions and raise the participant's awareness of his/her concomitant bodily responses. The IPT portion targets symptoms of depression and grief related to the losses and to raise awareness about major current problems
Completed Treatment Definition: Did not drop out of therapy
Completed Treatment Percent Detail:
n=1 dropped out of therapy, text states participants completed the treatment within 10 weeks, and "The number of dropouts from therapy was low, with only 
1 orphan in each group discontinuing therapy."
Trauma Detail (Study level): rape/sexual assault, terrorism/political violence/forced displacement
Citation: Jacob N, Neuner F, Maedl A, et al. Dissemination of psychotherapy for trauma spectrum disorders in postconflict settings: a randomized controlled trial in Rwanda. Psychother Psychosom. 2014 Nov;83(6):354-63. doi: 10.1159/000365114. PMID: 25323203.

Trauma Detail (Study level): rape/sexual assault, terrorism/political violence/forced displacement
Citation: Jacob N, Neuner F, Maedl A, et al. Dissemination of psychotherapy for trauma spectrum disorders in postconflict settings: a randomized controlled trial in Rwanda. Psychother Psychosom. 2014 Nov;83(6):354-63. doi: 10.1159/000365114. PMID: 25323203.

Treatment Description: Reading of Persian-language poetry. Poems selected for each participant "according to the emotional situation of a person… poems were selected based on the connection, language, poet narration, motivation and perceptible concepts for better understanding". "Poems were read two or three times, and patients were asked to talk about the specific concepts and semantics, communication with the poem, verse or theme. Then, they select a new arbitrary poem from the booklet. Then the sound, sensation, tone, topic and the body language were surveyed."
Treatment Duration Detail: Four 45 min sessions over a week, timing not otherwise described
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: No loss to follow-up, but no information on treatment attendance or completion
Citation: Jahanpour F, Armoon B, Mozafari N, et al. The comparison of the effect of poetry therapy on anxiety and post-traumatic stress disorders in patients with myocardial infarction. J Poet Ther. 2019 Dec;32(4):214-22. doi: 10.1080/08893675.2019.1639884.

Treatment Description: No intervention
Citation: Jahanpour F, Armoon B, Mozafari N, et al. The comparison of the effect of poetry therapy on anxiety and post-traumatic stress disorders in patients with myocardial infarction. J Poet Ther. 2019 Dec;32(4):214-22. doi: 10.1080/08893675.2019.1639884.

Standardized Treatment Name: Skills Training in Affect and Interpersonal Regulation (STAIR)
Treatment Description: Five 60-min appointments during which emotion regulation and interpersonal skills, or “tools,” were flexibly selected following a strengths-based approach whereby the skills selected were those that a client already used and was effective in implementing
Citation: Jain S, Ortigo K, Gimeno J, Baldor DA, Weiss BJ, Cloitre M. A Randomized Controlled Trial of Brief Skills Training in Affective and Interpersonal Regulation (STAIR) for Veterans in Primary Care. J Trauma Stress. 2020 Aug;33(4):401-409. doi: 10.1002/jts.22523. Epub 2020 Jun 7. PMID: 32506563.

Treatment Description: Identifying the primary presenting problem (i.e., PTSD symptoms or depression). For depression, TAU consisted of referral to the PCMHI psychologist for brief psychotherapy to target depression or, if applicable, referral to the PCMHI psychiatrist for a medication evaluation. For PTSD symptoms, TAU involved referral to specialty mental health care (i.e., PTSD clinics).
Citation: Jain S, Ortigo K, Gimeno J, Baldor DA, Weiss BJ, Cloitre M. A Randomized Controlled Trial of Brief Skills Training in Affective and Interpersonal Regulation (STAIR) for Veterans in Primary Care. J Trauma Stress. 2020 Aug;33(4):401-409. doi: 10.1002/jts.22523. Epub 2020 Jun 7. PMID: 32506563.

Treatment Description: Standard CPT without trauma narrative; included education about PTSD symptoms and treatment, a brief "Impact Statement" and identification of distorted thoughts ("stuck points"), learning connection between thoughts and feelings, and challenging distorted thoughts and stuck points.
Citation: Jak AJ, Jurick S, Crocker LD, et al. SMART-CPT for veterans with comorbid post-traumatic stress disorder and history of traumatic brain injury: a randomised controlled trial. J Neurol Neurosurg Psychiatry. 2019 Mar;90(3):333-41. doi: 10.1136/jnnp-2018-319315. PMID: 30554135.

Standardized Treatment Name: Cognitive Processing Therapy (CPT) adapted for traumatic brain injury (TBI)
Treatment Description: A hybrid treatment with adapted CPT components plus elements from CogSMART; adaptations were focused on TBI and cognitive complaints including psychoeducation and compensatory strategies.
Citation: Jak AJ, Jurick S, Crocker LD, et al. SMART-CPT for veterans with comorbid post-traumatic stress disorder and history of traumatic brain injury: a randomised controlled trial. J Neurol Neurosurg Psychiatry. 2019 Mar;90(3):333-41. doi: 10.1136/jnnp-2018-319315. PMID: 30554135.

Arm N Randomized Detail: Enrolled until 10 completed (4 dropped out)
Standardized Treatment Name: Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) without a trauma focus
Treatment Description: CBT featuring education about symptoms, exposure to somatic sensations associated with PTSD, yoga-like stretching and meditation, treatmetn of somatic sensations and anxiety-type psychopathalogical processes, anger reduction, and sleep improvement; cultural adaptation included addressing cultural stigma about trauma, using non-stigmatizing local expressions, and relying on culturally appropriate metaphors, analogies, and references, and a special emphasis on somatic and sensorial experiencing.
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: Study continued to enroll participants until n=10 had completed treatment
Citation: Jalal B, Kruger Q, Hinton DE. Culturally adapted CBT (CA-CBT) for traumatised indigenous South Africans (Sepedi): a randomised pilot trial comparing CA-CBT to applied muscle relaxation. Intervention 2020;18:61-5

Arm N Randomized Detail: Enrolled until 10 completed (6 dropped out)
Treatment Description: Manualized muscle relaxation therapy; not culturally adapted
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: Study continued to enroll participants until n=10 had completed treatment
Citation: Jalal B, Kruger Q, Hinton DE. Culturally adapted CBT (CA-CBT) for traumatised indigenous South Africans (Sepedi): a randomised pilot trial comparing CA-CBT to applied muscle relaxation. Intervention 2020;18:61-5

Treatment Description: Modified Shapiro protocol for EMDR with 8 phases: history-taking and planning; introducing procedures; assessment; desensitization, addressing disturbing emotions and eliciting insights; integration of cognitive reorganisation; body scan; closure with debriefing; and reevaluation
Trauma Detail (Study level): Child physical abuse; Child sexual abuse; Child other abuse
Citation: Jamshidi F, Rajabi S, Dehghani Y. How to heal their psychological wounds? Effectiveness of EMDR therapy on post-traumatic stress symptoms, mind-wandering and suicidal ideation in Iranian child abuse victims. Counselling & Psychotherapy Research. 2021 Jun;21(2):412-21. doi: 10.1002/capr.12339.

Treatment Description: Waitlist, not further described
Trauma Detail (Study level): Child physical abuse; Child sexual abuse; Child other abuse
Citation: Jamshidi F, Rajabi S, Dehghani Y. How to heal their psychological wounds? Effectiveness of EMDR therapy on post-traumatic stress symptoms, mind-wandering and suicidal ideation in Iranian child abuse victims. Counselling & Psychotherapy Research. 2021 Jun;21(2):412-21. doi: 10.1002/capr.12339.

Treatment Description: EMDR Protocol for Recent Critical Incidents and Ongoing Traumatic Stress. Three-pronged approach addressing past, present, and future. Manualized treatment with eight phases: 1) Patient history (brief description of trauma), 2) Preparation (including butterfly hug as an alternative to EMDR, and postdisaster self-soothing strategies), 3) Assessment (patient reviews adverse experience from before it began through present into future, identifying disturbing memories), 4) Desensitization (reviewing disturbing memories simultaneously with EMDR or butterfly hug), 5) Global installation (developing a positive cognition applied to the whole adverse experience), 6) Body scan, 7) Self-soothing, and 8) Standard procedures (not described).
Treatment Duration Detail: Intensive therapy, two sessions in one day
Completed Treatment Definition: Did not drop out of treatment
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: No dropouts during study period
Trauma Detail (Study level): traumas experienced as first responders (e.g. witnessing deaths; witnessing victims of child physical abuse, rape/sexual assault, intimate partner violence, accidents, pregnancy loss, community/school violence, and natural or manmade disasters (fire); threat of own death in a fire)
Citation: Jarero I, Schnaider S, Givaudan M. Randomized controlled trial: Provision of EMDR protocol for recent critical incidents and ongoing traumatic stress to first responders. Journal of EMDR Practice and Research. 2019;13(2):100-10. doi: 10.1891/1933-3196.13.2.100.

Treatment Description: No treatment during study, received treatment after study.
Trauma Detail (Study level): traumas experienced as first responders (e.g. witnessing deaths; witnessing victims of child physical abuse, rape/sexual assault, intimate partner violence, accidents, pregnancy loss, community/school violence, and natural or manmade disasters (fire); threat of own death in a fire)
Citation: Jarero I, Schnaider S, Givaudan M. Randomized controlled trial: Provision of EMDR protocol for recent critical incidents and ongoing traumatic stress to first responders. Journal of EMDR Practice and Research. 2019;13(2):100-10. doi: 10.1891/1933-3196.13.2.100.

Treatment Description: Treatment included 1 history-taking session and 2 EMDR sessions. Therapist instructs the participant to visualize a picture of the traumatic scene and concentrate on previously identified negative statement associated with the trauma. Then the participant simultaneously focus on  the physical sensation of anxiety and visually track therapist's finger as it moves rapidly back-and-forth, inducing saccadic eye movement. Saccades were elicited continuously until subjective units of distress reached 0.
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: Study reports participants completing the study, unclear if this is also treatment completion rate.
Citation: Jensen JA. An investigation of Eye Movement Desensitization Reprocessing (EMD/R) as a treatment for posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) symptoms of Vietnam combat veterans. Behav Ther. 1994 Spring;25(2):311-25. doi: 10.1016/S0005-7894(05)80290-4.

Treatment Description: Participants informed of their group assignment and given a list of local alternative treatment sites
Citation: Jensen JA. An investigation of Eye Movement Desensitization Reprocessing (EMD/R) as a treatment for posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) symptoms of Vietnam combat veterans. Behav Ther. 1994 Spring;25(2):311-25. doi: 10.1016/S0005-7894(05)80290-4.

Treatment Description: Hour-long music from MusiCure series played through speakers around special pillow
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: n=1 dropped out during study; "All participants in the intervention group reported listening to the music every night during the 3 week intervention period", so using treatment completion = did not drop out
Citation: Jespersen KV, Vuust P. The effect of relaxation music listening on sleep quality in traumatized refugees: a pilot study. J Music Ther. 2012;49(2):205-29.  PMID: 26753218.

Treatment Description: Same ergonomic pillow as treatment group without music
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: n=3 dropped out during study, no other part of treatment adherence described, treatment completion = did not drop out
Citation: Jespersen KV, Vuust P. The effect of relaxation music listening on sleep quality in traumatized refugees: a pilot study. J Music Ther. 2012;49(2):205-29.  PMID: 26753218.

Arm N Randomized Detail: n=20 randomized (assuming 1:1:1 randomization resulted in 20:20:20 groups from n=60 randomized); 1 participant excluded for stroke progression
Treatment Description:
rTMS (20 minutes): Immediately after brief exposure, using MagPro instrument with "8" shaped coil placed parallel to scalp, stimulation to right dorsolateral prefrontal cortex. Intensity 90% of motor threshold, frequency 1 Hz; 20 seconds stimulation per minute with 40-second intervals between.

Brief exposure (3 minutes): patients recorded audio scripts describing 3 experiences: positive emotional events, neutral emotional events, and stroke events. During sessions patients in 30-second intervals first listened to stroke event script, then imagined the event, then listened to neutral script, then imagined that event.
Dose: 1 Hz for 20 minutes
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: n=2 withdrew during treatment, all other dropouts lost to follow-up
Citation: Jiang C, Li Z, Wang J, et al. Effectiveness of repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation combined with a brief exposure procedure for post-stroke posttraumatic stress disorder. Journal of affective disorders. 2023;326:89-95. doi: 10.1016/j.jad.2023.01.096. PMID: 36717030.

Arm N Randomized Detail: n=20 randomized (assuming 1:1:1 randomization resulted in 20:20:20 groups from n=60 randomized); 2 participants excluded for stroke progression
Treatment Description: MagPro instrument with "8" shaped coil placed parallel to scalp, stimulation to right dorsolateral prefrontal cortex. Intensity 90% of motor threshold, frequency 1 Hz; 20 seconds stimulation per minute with 40-second intervals between.
Dose: 1 Hz for 20 minutes
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: n=2 withdrew during treatment, all other dropouts lost to follow-up
Citation: Jiang C, Li Z, Wang J, et al. Effectiveness of repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation combined with a brief exposure procedure for post-stroke posttraumatic stress disorder. Journal of affective disorders. 2023;326:89-95. doi: 10.1016/j.jad.2023.01.096. PMID: 36717030.

Treatment Description:
Sham rTMS (20 minutes): Immediately after sham exposure, using MagPro instrument with "8" shaped coil placed perpendicular to scalp, "resulting in invalid stimulation"

Sham brief exposure (3 minutes): patients recorded audio scripts describing 3 experiences: positive emotional events, neutral emotional events, and stroke events. During sessions patients in 30-second intervals first listened to positive emotional event script, then imagined the event, then listened to neutral script, then imagined that event.
Session Length:
sham rTMS: 20 minutes

sham brief exposure: 3 minutes
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: n=1 withdrew during treatment, all other dropouts lost to follow-up
Citation: Jiang C, Li Z, Wang J, et al. Effectiveness of repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation combined with a brief exposure procedure for post-stroke posttraumatic stress disorder. Journal of affective disorders. 2023;326:89-95. doi: 10.1016/j.jad.2023.01.096. PMID: 36717030.

Treatment Description: Comprehensive yoga style which incorporates traditional elements of yoga practice including postures and physical exercises, breathing techniques, meditation, cultivation of mind-body awareness, and deep relaxation. The general class structure was active warm-up and loosening exercises, yoga postures and exercises, deep supine relaxation, yoga breathing techniques, meditation, and discussion of the physical, psychological, and philosophical principles of yoga; daily home practice of 15 minutes. The program integrated guidelines for trauma sensitive yoga.
Trauma Detail (Study level): rape/sexual assault, child sexual abuse, intimate partner violence, terrorism/political violence/forced displacement, illness/medical procedure, accidents, other (emotional abuse, systemic discrimination, compassion fatigue)
Citation: Jindani FA, Turner N, Khalsa SBS. A yoga intervention for posttraumatic stress: a preliminary randomized control trial. Evid Based Complement Alternat Med. 2015;2015:351746. doi: 10.1155/2015/351746. PMID: 26366179.

Trauma Detail (Study level): rape/sexual assault, child sexual abuse, intimate partner violence, terrorism/political violence/forced displacement, illness/medical procedure, accidents, other (emotional abuse, systemic discrimination, compassion fatigue)
Citation: Jindani FA, Turner N, Khalsa SBS. A yoga intervention for posttraumatic stress: a preliminary randomized control trial. Evid Based Complement Alternat Med. 2015;2015:351746. doi: 10.1155/2015/351746. PMID: 26366179.

Treatment Name: Helping to Overcome PTSD through Empowerment
Standardized Treatment Name: Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) without a trauma focus
Treatment Description: Participants provided with an "empowerment toolbox" that includes an exhaustive list of positive coping strategies regarding safety and empowerment, managing symptoms, and improving relationships. Core modules included engagement and goal setting, psychoeducation about abuse and PTSD, safety planning, establishing trust, cognitive restructuring, managing triggers, self-soothing, establishing boundaries, anger management, and establishing long-term support. Participants who left shelter prior to completing 12 sessions were referred to treatment in community
Citation: Johnson DM, Zlotnick C, Perez SK. Cognitive behavioral treatment of PTSD in residents of battered women's shelters: results of a randomized clinical trial. J Consult Clin Psychol. 2011 Aug;79(4):542-51. doi: 10.1037/a0023822. PMID: 21787052.

Treatment Description: Provided referrals to treatment in community
Citation: Johnson DM, Zlotnick C, Perez SK. Cognitive behavioral treatment of PTSD in residents of battered women's shelters: results of a randomized clinical trial. J Consult Clin Psychol. 2011 Aug;79(4):542-51. doi: 10.1037/a0023822. PMID: 21787052.

Treatment Name: Helping to Overcome PTSD through Empowerment
Standardized Treatment Name: Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) without a trauma focus
Treatment Description: Short-term, present-centered, cognitive behavioral treatment designed for women in IPV shelters. Focuses on safety, self-care, and empowerment rather than recall and processing of trauma-related memories. Intervention begins in shelter and continues after residents leave shelter.
Frequency: At least weekly in shelter, at least bi-weekly post-shelter
Treatment Duration Detail: up to 16 sessions total; up to 10 sessions over 10 weeks while in shelter, with remainder in the 3 months post-shelter; monthly booster sessions in shelter if stay >10 weeks
Citation: Johnson DM, Zlotnick C, Hoffman L, et al. A randomized controlled trial comparing HOPE treatment and present-centered therapy in women residing in shelter with PTSD from intimate partner violence. Psychol Women Q. 2020 Dec;44(4):539-53. doi: 10.1177/0361684320953120

Treatment Description: Problem-focused, supportive therapy used as an attention-matched control condition. PCT+ is a version of PCT adapted for IPV victims to include safety planning. Intervention begins in shelter and continues after residents leave shelter.
Frequency: At least weekly in shelter, at least bi-weekly post-shelter
Treatment Duration Detail: up to 16 sessions total; up to 10 sessions over 10 weeks while in shelter, with remainder in the 3 months post-shelter; monthly booster sessions in shelter if stay >10 weeks
Citation: Johnson DM, Zlotnick C, Hoffman L, et al. A randomized controlled trial comparing HOPE treatment and present-centered therapy in women residing in shelter with PTSD from intimate partner violence. Psychol Women Q. 2020 Dec;44(4):539-53. doi: 10.1177/0361684320953120

Treatment Description: Therapy comprised of one treatment session and one booster session. Participants instructed to research skin cell rebuilding to see that dermal cells in trauma-related body region have been rebuilt completely since last contact with perpetrator. Then therapist confronts patient with her own ideas on contamination, and develop an idiosyncratic imagery representing the process of skin or cell renewal.
Session Length: Treatment session 90 minutes, booster session 50 minutes
Treatment Duration Detail: treatment session was one week after pre-treatment assessment; booster session administered one week after the treatment session
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: no patient dropped out of treatment, n=2 were nonstarters; treatment completion at t2 (5 weeks after study intake)
Citation: Jung K, Steil R. A randomized controlled trial on cognitive restructuring and imagery modification to reduce the feeling of being contaminated in adult survivors of childhood sexual abuse suffering from posttraumatic stress disorder. Psychother Psychosom. 2013 Jun;82(4):213-20. doi: 10.1159/000348450. PMID: 23712073.

Jung K, Steil R. A randomized controlled trial on cognitive restructuring and imagery modification to reduce the feeling of being contaminated in adult survivors of childhood sexual abuse suffering from posttraumatic stress disorder. Psychother Psychosom. 2013 Jun;82(4):213-20. doi: 10.1159/000348450. PMID: 23712073.

Treatment Description: NAC: total 2.7 g/day NAC adjunctive to TAU. Drug initially supplied as effervescent tablets, later as capsules. TAU not further described.
Dose: 900 mg
Citation: Kanaan RA, Oliver G, Dharan A, et al. A multi-centre, double-blind, 12-week, randomized, placebo-controlled trial of adjunctive N-Acetylcysteine for treatment-resistant PTSD. Psychiatry Res. 2023 Sep;327:115398. doi: 10.1016/j.psychres.2023.115398. PMID: 37540942.

Arm N Randomized Detail: 53 randomized, 1 later excluded who did not meet CAPS criteria (protocol violation)
Treatment Description: Placebo: adjunctive to TAU. Initially supplied as effervescent tablets matching NAC tablets. Placebo formulation after switch to NAC capsules not described. "Placebo containers were specially treated with microgram levels of NAC dust to mask its characteristic smell." TAU not further described.
Dose: Matched placebo
Citation: Kanaan RA, Oliver G, Dharan A, et al. A multi-centre, double-blind, 12-week, randomized, placebo-controlled trial of adjunctive N-Acetylcysteine for treatment-resistant PTSD. Psychiatry Res. 2023 Sep;327:115398. doi: 10.1016/j.psychres.2023.115398. PMID: 37540942.

Treatment Description: Glucose isomer that "can affect the function of several neurotransmitters including serotonin;" given in powder form, patients instructed to take in juice or tea.
Dose: 6 grams (2 teaspoons)
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, accidents, community/school violence, other (not specified)
Citation: Kaplan Z, Amir M, Swartz M, et al. Inositol treatment of post-traumatic stress disorder. Anxiety. 1996;2(1):51-2. doi: 10.1002/(SICI)1522-7154(1996)2:1<51::AID-ANXI8>3.0.CO;2-G. PMID: 9160600.

Treatment Description:
Glucose; in powder form of similar taste and texture to inositol; patients



instructed to take two teaspoons twice a day in juice or tea (12 grams/day).
Dose: 12 grams
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, accidents, community/school violence, other (not specified)
Citation: Kaplan Z, Amir M, Swartz M, et al. Inositol treatment of post-traumatic stress disorder. Anxiety. 1996;2(1):51-2. doi: 10.1002/(SICI)1522-7154(1996)2:1<51::AID-ANXI8>3.0.CO;2-G. PMID: 9160600.

Treatment Description: Therapist lightly stimulate endpoints of traditional acupuncture meridians on the face, upper body, and hands, while patients focus on the traumatic event
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: Study reports as attrition, unclear if attrition from measurement or from treatment; number is same for 'dropout' and 'failed to attend post-assessment'
Trauma Detail (Study level): accidents, community/school violence, other (not specified)
Citation: Karatzias A, Power KG, Brown KW, et al. A controlled comparison of the effectiveness and efficiency of two psychological therapies for posttraumatic stress disorder: Eye Movement Desensitization and Reprocessing vs. Emotional Freedom Techniques. J. Nerv. Ment. Dis. 2011 Jun;199(6):372-8. doi: 10.1097/NMD.0b013e31821cd262. PMID: 21629014.

Treatment Description: According to manual by Shapiro (2001, 2002) in which therapist utilizes bilateral stimulation while participant's attention is directed toward the traumatic event until Subjective Unit of Discomfort Scale reaches 0
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: Study reports as attrition, unclear if attrition from measurement or from treatment; number is same for 'dropout' and 'failed to attend post-assessment'
Trauma Detail (Study level): accidents, community/school violence, other (not specified)
Citation: Karatzias A, Power KG, Brown KW, et al. A controlled comparison of the effectiveness and efficiency of two psychological therapies for posttraumatic stress disorder: Eye Movement Desensitization and Reprocessing vs. Emotional Freedom Techniques. J. Nerv. Ment. Dis. 2011 Jun;199(6):372-8. doi: 10.1097/NMD.0b013e31821cd262. PMID: 21629014.

Treatment Description: Eight-phase treatment protocol which includes components of affect management, psychoeducation, assessment of distressing memory components, bilateral stimulation to reach Subjective Units of Discomfort Scale score of 0 and Validity of Cognition Scale score of 7, and re-evaluation. The bilateral stimulation included standard light bar, tactile and auditory stimulus in order to accommodate the participants' disabilities.
Completed Treatment Definition: Attended 4 or more of the 8 EMDR sessions
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: no other information on treatment completion, only assessment/study completion
Citation: Karatzias T, Brown M, Taggart L, et al. A mixed-methods, randomized controlled feasibility trial of Eye Movement Desensitization and Reprocessing (EMDR) plus Standard Care (SC) versus SC alone for DSM-5 Posttraumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) in adults with intellectual disabilities. J Appl Res Intellect Disabil. 2019 Jul;32(4):806-18. doi: 10.1111/jar.12570. PMID: 30714684.

Treatment Description: Continuation of participants' usual psychological, psychiatric and medical care
Citation: Karatzias T, Brown M, Taggart L, et al. A mixed-methods, randomized controlled feasibility trial of Eye Movement Desensitization and Reprocessing (EMDR) plus Standard Care (SC) versus SC alone for DSM-5 Posttraumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) in adults with intellectual disabilities. J Appl Res Intellect Disabil. 2019 Jul;32(4):806-18. doi: 10.1111/jar.12570. PMID: 30714684.

Treatment Name: Enhanced Skills Training in Affective and Interpersonal Regulation (STAIR)
Standardized Treatment Name: Skills Training in Affect and Interpersonal Regulation (STAIR)
Treatment Description:
Enhanced STAIR; modular intervention guided by measurement-based assessment of symptoms, with a formulation session plus 4 modules each addressing the different symptom clusters of CPTSD. Four modules focused on 1) affective dysregulation (6 sessions), 2) disturbances in relationships (6 sessions), 3) negative self-concept (5 sessions), and 4) PTSD (7 sessions). "The PTSD module focuses on emotional processing of trauma memories through verbal narration and cognitive reappraisal and targets reexperiencing, avoidance, and hyperarousal symptoms."
Participants assessed at end of each module with ITQ, continued to next module if not CPTSD diagnosis free; if diagnosis free then offered post-treatment assessment.
Treatment Duration Detail: post-treatment = week 25; participants could complete treatment early if diagnosis free at end of given module
Completed Treatment Definition: Completing all 4 modules (80% or more of treatment)
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: Treatment dropout defined as leaving treatment before all 4 modules completed (80% of treatment)
Trauma Detail (Study level): Combat-related; Other ("assault with a weapon", "fire or explosion", "sudden violent death", "exposure to a war zone", "any other very stressful event or experience")
Citation: Karatzias T, Shevlin M, Cloitre M, Busuttil W, Graham K, Hendrikx L, Hyland P, Biscoe N, Murphy D. Enhanced Skills Training in Affective and Interpersonal Regulation versus Treatment as Usual for ICD-11 Complex PTSD: A Pilot Randomised Controlled Trial (The RESTORE Trial). Psychother Psychosom. 2024;93(3):203-215. doi: 10.1159/000538428. Epub 2024 Apr 30. PMID: 38688242; PMCID: PMC11152001.

Treatment Description: Mental health assessment followed by a treatment package including psychoeducation, symptom management, and/or active monitoring. Interventions received: most (82%) received individual or group therapy (one participant received EMDR, no other participants received trauma-focused therapy), or active monitoring (but no active intervention; 18%).
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: Treatment dropout defined as leaving  before 24 weeks of treatment had been completed.
Trauma Detail (Study level): Combat-related; Other ("assault with a weapon", "fire or explosion", "sudden violent death", "exposure to a war zone", "any other very stressful event or experience")
Citation: Karatzias T, Shevlin M, Cloitre M, Busuttil W, Graham K, Hendrikx L, Hyland P, Biscoe N, Murphy D. Enhanced Skills Training in Affective and Interpersonal Regulation versus Treatment as Usual for ICD-11 Complex PTSD: A Pilot Randomised Controlled Trial (The RESTORE Trial). Psychother Psychosom. 2024;93(3):203-215. doi: 10.1159/000538428. Epub 2024 Apr 30. PMID: 38688242; PMCID: PMC11152001.

Treatment Description: MAOI; 2-week placebo run-in, responders excluded; titrated to maximum 3 tablets (150 mg) based on physician's judgment of best dose
Dose: 50 to 150 mg (total daily dose); titration: initiated at 50 mg/day, maximum daily dose of 150 mg
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, rape/sexual assault, accidents, community/school violence, other (not specified)
Citation: Katz RJ, Lott MH, Arbus P, et al. Pharmacotherapy of post-traumatic stress disorder with a novel psychotropic. Anxiety. 1994;1(4):169-74.  PMID: 9160569.

Treatment Description: After single-blind 2-week placebo run-in, responders excluded; double-blind phase started with one tablet/day identical to active treatment, titrated to maximum 3 tablets based on physician's judgment of best dose
Dose at Study End Point Detail: Modal dose = 2 tablets
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, rape/sexual assault, accidents, community/school violence, other (not specified)
Citation: Katz RJ, Lott MH, Arbus P, et al. Pharmacotherapy of post-traumatic stress disorder with a novel psychotropic. Anxiety. 1994;1(4):169-74.  PMID: 9160569.

Treatment Description: Integrative treatment focusing on underlying causes or patterns of unfulfilling or abusive relationships rather than specific events. Practiced in 3 steps: 1) identifying patterns, 2) cognitive shifts and holistic reappraisals, and 3) reprocessing using imagery. Treatment included 2 to 4 reprocessing procedures.
Trauma Detail (Study level): MST, rape/sexual assault, child sexual abuse, intimate partner violence
Citation: Katz LS, Douglas S, Zaleski K, et al. Comparing holographic reprocessing and prolonged exposure for women veterans with sexual trauma: a pilot randomized trial. J Contemp Psychother. 2014 Mar;44(1):9-19. doi: 10.1007/s10879-013-9248-6.

Treatment Description: Therapy followed protocol by Foa et al. 2007; PE uses in vivo and imaginal exposure to enable patients to "confront their fears and anxieties, repair a fragmented narrative, and desensitize to memories of trauma."
Trauma Detail (Study level): MST, rape/sexual assault, child sexual abuse, intimate partner violence
Citation: Katz LS, Douglas S, Zaleski K, et al. Comparing holographic reprocessing and prolonged exposure for women veterans with sexual trauma: a pilot randomized trial. J Contemp Psychother. 2014 Mar;44(1):9-19. doi: 10.1007/s10879-013-9248-6.

Treatment Description: Treatment followed Rogerian supportive therapy and focuses on providing support and discussing and understanding here-and-now issues that are generated by patients; treatment included supportive listening, relaxation training, and problem solving.
Trauma Detail (Study level): MST, rape/sexual assault, child sexual abuse, intimate partner violence
Citation: Katz LS, Douglas S, Zaleski K, et al. Comparing holographic reprocessing and prolonged exposure for women veterans with sexual trauma: a pilot randomized trial. J Contemp Psychother. 2014 Mar;44(1):9-19. doi: 10.1007/s10879-013-9248-6.

Treatment Description: Treatment following therapy manual; included relaxation therapy, flooding, integration of new information or emotions evoked from imagery just presented, and intersession homework; primary focus of therapy is gradual presentation of stimulus and response of traumatic memory in the context of a supportive clinical relationship.
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: no information reported on treatment completion, no drop outs (from assessment or treatment) reported
Citation: Keane TM, Fairbank JA, Caddell JM, et al. Implosive (flooding) therapy reduces symptoms of PTSD in Vietnam combat veterans. Behav Ther. 1989 Spring;20(2):245-60. doi: 10.1016/S0005-7894(89)80072-3.

Treatment Description: Waitlist participants were not prohibited from obtaining or continuing psychiatric treatment during the waiting period.
Citation: Keane TM, Fairbank JA, Caddell JM, et al. Implosive (flooding) therapy reduces symptoms of PTSD in Vietnam combat veterans. Behav Ther. 1989 Spring;20(2):245-60. doi: 10.1016/S0005-7894(89)80072-3.

Treatment Description: Mindfulness-based stress reduction following format developed by Kabat-Zinn, including mindfulness exercises, attentional skills, daily meditation and yoga
Session Length:
2.5 hours weekly plus



7 hours on 1 Saturday
Citation: Kearney DJ, McDermott K, Malte C, et al. Effects of participation in a mindfulness program for veterans with posttraumatic stress disorder: a randomized controlled pilot study. J Clin Psychol. 2013 Jan;69(1):14-27. doi: 10.1002/jclp.21911. PMID: 22930491.

Treatment Description: Usual care without intervention from the study team
Citation: Kearney DJ, McDermott K, Malte C, et al. Effects of participation in a mindfulness program for veterans with posttraumatic stress disorder: a randomized controlled pilot study. J Clin Psychol. 2013 Jan;69(1):14-27. doi: 10.1002/jclp.21911. PMID: 22930491.

Treatment Description:
MBSR: Group course with "instruction on mindfulness meditation practices, including body scan meditation, breathing meditation, gentle yoga, walking meditation, and loving-kindness meditation", between-session home practice meditation using audio CD, and other homework.



TAU: continuation of "treatment as usual without intervention from the study team"
Citation: Kearney DJ, Simpson TL, Malte CA, et al. Mindfulness-based stress reduction in addition to usual care is associated with improvements in pain, fatigue, and cognitive failures among veterans with Gulf War illness. Am J Med. 2016 Feb;129(2):204-14. doi: 10.1016/j.amjmed.2015.09.015. PMID: 26519614.

Treatment Description: Continuation of "treatment as usual without intervention from the study team".
Citation: Kearney DJ, Simpson TL, Malte CA, et al. Mindfulness-based stress reduction in addition to usual care is associated with improvements in pain, fatigue, and cognitive failures among veterans with Gulf War illness. Am J Med. 2016 Feb;129(2):204-14. doi: 10.1016/j.amjmed.2015.09.015. PMID: 26519614.

Treatment Description: Group meditation sessions focused on mindfulness and loving kindness meditation, homework consisted of 30 minutes of meditation 6 days per week using compact discs and informal loving-kindness meditation practices.
Completed Treatment Definition: Completing half or more of sessions
Trauma Detail (Study level): Combat-related, Rape/sexual assault, Community/school violence, Accidents, Other (sudden death; other unspecified)
Citation: Kearney DJ, Malte CA, Storms M, et al. Loving-kindness meditation vs cognitive processing therapy for posttraumatic stress disorder among veterans: a randomized clinical trial. JAMA Netw Open. 2021 Apr 1;4(4):e216604. doi: 10.1001/jamanetworkopen.2021.6604. PMID: 33861329.

Treatment Description: Cognitive only, does not include writing a trauma narrative; based on manual for CPT and combines cognitive restructuring with emotional processing of trauma-related content. Homework consisted of worksheets and exercises for 30 minutes 6 days a week plus writing an impact statement at start and end of treatment.
Completed Treatment Definition: Completing half or more of sessions
Trauma Detail (Study level): Combat-related, Rape/sexual assault, Community/school violence, Accidents, Other (sudden death; other unspecified)
Citation: Kearney DJ, Malte CA, Storms M, et al. Loving-kindness meditation vs cognitive processing therapy for posttraumatic stress disorder among veterans: a randomized clinical trial. JAMA Netw Open. 2021 Apr 1;4(4):e216604. doi: 10.1001/jamanetworkopen.2021.6604. PMID: 33861329.

Arm N Randomized Detail: n=32 randomized, n=29 with post-treatment assessment analyzed
Treatment Description: Deep brain reorienting, sessions conducted over videoconferencing due to COVID-19 pandemic. DBR is a psychotherapy approach that targets the ordered neurophysiological sequence that is thought to have ocurred in response to a traumatic event and which persists when triggered. Sessions structured using Orienting-Tension-(Shock)-Affect sequence by: indentifying the target; orienting to the present; orienting to the traumatic event; tension (identify and respond); shock (with therapist guidance in response); affect (identify and process with therapist support); closure of session (address residual tension, reflect on new perspective).
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: "Attrition was minimal with one participant not completing treatment" (completed: 31/32)
Trauma Detail (Study level): Child physical abuse; Child sexual abuse; Child other abuse; Rape/sexual assault; Illness/medical procedure;  Community/school violence; Other ("Work-related", "Adult - Interpersonal")
Citation: Kearney BE, Corrigan FM, Frewen PA, et al. A randomized controlled trial of Deep Brain Reorienting: a neuroscientifically guided treatment for post-traumatic stress disorder. Eur J Psychotraumatol. 2023;14(2) doi: 10.1080/20008066.2023.2240691. PMID: 37581275.

Arm N Randomized Detail: n=27 randomized, n=25 with post-treatment assessment analyzed
Treatment Description: Waitlist
Trauma Detail (Study level): Child physical abuse; Child sexual abuse; Child other abuse; Rape/sexual assault; Illness/medical procedure;  Community/school violence; Other ("Work-related", "Adult - Interpersonal")
Citation: Kearney BE, Corrigan FM, Frewen PA, et al. A randomized controlled trial of Deep Brain Reorienting: a neuroscientifically guided treatment for post-traumatic stress disorder. Eur J Psychotraumatol. 2023;14(2) doi: 10.1080/20008066.2023.2240691. PMID: 37581275.

Standardized Treatment Name: Integrated Motivational Enhancement Therapy (MET) + Prolonged Exposure (PE)
Treatment Description: Integrated MET and PE, in which all sessions included components of both therapies. MET: "evidence-based, structured adaptation of motivational interviewing that encourages change through the structured assessment and feedback of SUD behaviors". PE: "evidence-based psychotherapy for PTSD that includes in vivo (exposure to trauma-related safe situations, objects, or people that cause distress and are avoided) and imaginal (revisiting and processing of the trauma memory) exposure".
Citation: Kehle-Forbes SM, Chen S, Polusny MA, et al. A randomized controlled trial evaluating integrated versus phased application of evidence-based psychotherapies for military veterans with comorbid PTSD and substance use disorders. Drug Alcohol Depend. 2019 Dec 1;205:107647. doi: 10.1016/j.drugalcdep.2019.107647. PMID: 31675546.

Standardized Treatment Name: Phased Motivational Enhancement Therapy (MET) + Prolonged Exposure (PE)
Treatment Description: Phased MET and PE. Sessions 1-4: MET content (plus health education content to balance time with integrated MET plus PE arm); sessions 5-16: PE (12 session course) with "brief SUD-check in at the beginning of each treatment session" (issues raised were addressed as needed using MET framework). MET: "evidence-based, structured adaptation of motivational interviewing that encourages change through the structured assessment and feedback of SUD behaviors". PE: "evidence-based psychotherapy for PTSD that includes in vivo (exposure to trauma-related safe situations, objects, or people that cause distress and are avoided) and imaginal (revisiting and processing of the trauma memory) exposure".
Citation: Kehle-Forbes SM, Chen S, Polusny MA, et al. A randomized controlled trial evaluating integrated versus phased application of evidence-based psychotherapies for military veterans with comorbid PTSD and substance use disorders. Drug Alcohol Depend. 2019 Dec 1;205:107647. doi: 10.1016/j.drugalcdep.2019.107647. PMID: 31675546.

Treatment Description: Trauma-focused Hatha style yoga
Citation: Kelly U, Haywood T, Segell E, et al. Trauma-sensitive yoga for post-traumatic stress disorder in women veterans who experienced military sexual trauma: interim results from a randomized controlled trial. J Altern Complement Med. 2021 Mar;27(S1):S45-S59. doi: 10.1089/acm.2020.0417. PMID: 33788599.

Treatment Description: Manualized trauma-focused psychotherapy
Citation: Kelly U, Haywood T, Segell E, et al. Trauma-sensitive yoga for post-traumatic stress disorder in women veterans who experienced military sexual trauma: interim results from a randomized controlled trial. J Altern Complement Med. 2021 Mar;27(S1):S45-S59. doi: 10.1089/acm.2020.0417. PMID: 33788599.

Treatment Description: Manualized intervention fostering resilience resources (e.g., awareness of positive emotions; social connectedness) that individuals are encouraged to draw on in later sessions when they revisit traumatic episodes or experience PTSD symptoms. Week 1 = introduction to concept of resilience; weeks 2-3 = attention to bodily sensations as sources of vitality and engagement; weeks 4-7 = building positive emotional experiences and social bonds; weeks 8-10 = revisiting stressors and traumas while tapping into positive emotional resources and social bonds developed in earlier sessions; weeks 11-12 = developing a plan to sustain change.
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: reports "received allocated intervention" and "discontinued intervention and lost to posttest" in flow diagram, no other information on treatment completion rates
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, child physical abuse, child other abuse, rape/sexual assault, accidents, community/school violence
Citation: Kent M, Davis MC, Stark SL, et al. A resilience-oriented treatment for posttraumatic stress disorder: results of a preliminary randomized clinical trial. J Trauma Stress. 2011 Oct;24(5):591-5. doi: 10.1002/jts.20685. PMID: 21898603.

Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, child physical abuse, child other abuse, rape/sexual assault, accidents, community/school violence
Citation: Kent M, Davis MC, Stark SL, et al. A resilience-oriented treatment for posttraumatic stress disorder: results of a preliminary randomized clinical trial. J Trauma Stress. 2011 Oct;24(5):591-5. doi: 10.1002/jts.20685. PMID: 21898603.

Standardized Treatment Name: Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) without a trauma focus
Treatment Description: CBT protocol recommended by Mueser et al (2008) and Cohen, Mannarino, Kliethermes, & Murray (2012), with 8 modules: Introduction; Crisis Plan Review; Psychoeducation (Core symptoms of PTSD); Breathing retraining; Pyschoeducation (associated symptoms of PTSD); Cognitive restructuring (common styles of thinking); Cognitive restructuring (5 steps of cognitive restructuring); Generalization Training and Termination.
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: reports number randomized to intervention only; there was no missing data and does not report on drop outs, but does not provide any information on treatment completion
Citation: Khan A, Ullah F, Abid O, et al. Efficacy of cognitive behavioral therapy in post-traumatic stress disorder among spinal cord injury patients: a randomized controlled pilot study. J Evid Based Psychother. 2021 Sep;21(2):143-62. doi: 10.24193/jebp.2021.2.16.

Treatment Description: Usual services and medical care, including supportive counseling and pharmacotherapy; no psychotherapeutic treatment of PTSD symptoms
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: reports number randomized to intervention only; there was no missing data and does not report on drop outs, but does not provide any information on treatment completion

Treatment Description: Eight-stage EMDR protocolized treatment adapted for PTSD. Number of sessions determined by therapist, considering severity of PTSD symptoms (CAPS score ≤40 routine number of sessions, CAPS ≥80 required additional sessions until condition improved), assessment, patient feedback and clinical judgment (therapist determined optimal number of sessions), and literature guidelines.
Treatment Duration Detail: Number of sessions determined by therapist; length and frequency of sessions NR
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: "all 80 patients finished therapy"
Trauma Detail (Study level): Accidents; Community/school violence; Other ("witnessed death"; NR)
Citation: Khan A, Madihie AB, Ullah F, Abid O, Awan KH. A comparative exploration of eye movement desensitisation and reprocessing versus cognitive behavioural therapy for post‐traumatic stress disorder in Pakistan: Insights from a full‐fledged randomised controlled trial. Counselling and Psychotherapy Research. 2025 Mar;25(1):e12870.

Number of sessions determined by therapist, considering severity of PTSD symptoms (CAPS score ≤40 routine number of sessions, CAPS ≥80 required additional sessions until condition improved), assessment, patient feedback and clinical judgment (therapist determined optimal number of sessions), and literature guidelines.

Treatment Description: Intervention involves imaginal exposure where participants were asked to recall the traumatic event while focusing on physiological sensations, thoughts, and emotions while engaging in clinician-directed eye movements. Second phase is imagery rescripting where participant is instructed to visualize their traumatic scene and imagine changing the imagery and sensory components of the scene to anything they choose
Trauma Detail (Study level): MST, combat-related, community/school violence
Citation: Kip KE, Rosenzweig L, Hernandez DF, et al. Randomized controlled trial of Accelerated Resolution Therapy (ART) for symptoms of combat-related post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD). Mil Med. 2013 Dec;178(12):1298-309. doi: 10.7205/MILMED-D-13-00298. PMID: 24306011.

Treatment Description: Fitness or career assessment and planning
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: received allocation (attention control, no crossover)

Interapy consists of writing activities that include self-confrontation with traumatic event, cognitive restructuring, and social sharing. Therapists provided individually written feedback and instructions on writing assignments

Treatment Description:
Suvorexant: dual orexin receptor antagonist, administered 30 minutes before going to bed (10 mg for first session, 20 mg for second session).

Written narrative exposure: 30 minutes writing about index trauma with facilitator, with periodic reporting of level of distress (SUDS); sessions at 9pm and 8am for each visit, paired with suvorexant at bedtime.
Dose: 10 mg at visit 4 and 20 mg at visit 5 if the visit 1 dose was tolerated
Treatment Duration Detail: Received medication at visit 4 and visit 5, one week apart, with final followup one week later at visit 6
Trauma Detail (Study level): Child sexual abuse; Rape/sexual assault; Intimate partner violence; Community/school violence; Other ("sudden violent death of someone close"; "sudden accidental death of someone close", not specified)
Citation: Kobayashi I, Mellman TA, Cannon A, et al. Blocking the orexin system following therapeutic exposure promoted between session habituation, but not PTSD symptom reduction. J Psychiatr Res. 2021 Dec 14;145:222-9. doi: 10.1016/j.jpsychires.2021.12.027. PMID: 34933185.

Treatment Description:
Placebo administered 30 minutes before going to bed.

Written narrative exposure: 30 minutes writing about index trauma with facilitator, with periodic reporting of level of distress (SUDS); sessions at 9pm and 8am for each visit, paired with placebo at bedtime.

Treatment Name: Skills-Training of Affect Regulation-A Culture-sensitive Approach
Standardized Treatment Name: Skills Training in Affect and Interpersonal Regulation (STAIR)
Treatment Description: A manualized group treatment of refugees aiming to improve emotional understanding, clarity, and expression on the one hand and adaptive emotion regulation on the other hand; consists of 4 modules: training of emotional clarity; training of specific emotion regulation strategies; management of specific emotions; consolidation.
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: Did not drop out of treatment

Treatment Description: Narrative exposure therapy adapted for Forensic Offender Rehabilitation (FORNET) with revision specifically for the group of former combatants in Democratic Republic of Congo. Sessions include constructing a lifeline with traumatic events, perpetrated acts, and positive events listed chronologically; discussing role change from soldier to civilian; psychoeducation including anger recognition, emotion regulation, and behavior change to abstain from violence; a buddy system for peer support; and deconstruction of recent experiences of perpetrating or avoiding violence. Both individual and group sessions included.
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: participant flow diagram, receipt of intervention reported separate from follow-up assessment
Trauma Detail (Study level): Combat-related; Other (not specified)
Citation: Koebach A, Carleial S, Elbert T, et al. Treating trauma and aggression with narrative exposure therapy in former child and adult soldiers: A randomized controlled trial in Eastern DR Congo. J Consult Clin Psychol. 2021 Mar;89(3):143-55. doi: 10.1037/ccp0000632. PMID: 33829803.

Treatment Description: Treatment as usual with clients receiving services from non-governmental organizations where they had been recruited. Services available depending on the organization, which could include occupational training, empathic listening, problem-solving, and practical support.
Completed Treatment Definition: Received TAU according to the protocol of each NGO
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: participant flow diagram; text notes n=157 clients came for at least one follow-up assessment, of those 62% had met with someone, only n=6 met with the NGO
Trauma Detail (Study level): Combat-related; Other (not specified)
Citation: Koebach A, Carleial S, Elbert T, et al. Treating trauma and aggression with narrative exposure therapy in former child and adult soldiers: A randomized controlled trial in Eastern DR Congo. J Consult Clin Psychol. 2021 Mar;89(3):143-55. doi: 10.1037/ccp0000632. PMID: 33829803.

Routine care counseling: 8 group sessions covering routine infant care.

CBT for PTSD: NR

Treatment Description: MAO-I antidepressant; dose titrated to achieve ≥85% platelet MAO inhibition with blood tested at week 2 and one week following any dosage changes, unless limited by side effects
Dose: 15 to 75 mg; titration: initiated at 15 mg, increased to target maximum dose of 60 to 75 mg with ≥85% platelet MAO inhibition
Citation: Kosten TR, Frank JB, Dan E, et al. Pharmacotherapy for posttraumatic stress disorder using phenelzine or imipramine. J Nerv Ment Dis. 1991;179(6):366-70. PMID: 2051152.

Treatment Description: TCA; dose titrated to attain blood levels >150 ng/ml after a week on stable dose, with blood tested at week 2 and one week following any dosage changes, unless limited by side effects
Dose: 50 to 300 mg; titration: 50 mg initial dose increased to achieve blood levels >150 ng/ml after 1 week of stable dosing, with maximum dose of 300 mg
Citation: Kosten TR, Frank JB, Dan E, et al. Pharmacotherapy for posttraumatic stress disorder using phenelzine or imipramine. J Nerv Ment Dis. 1991;179(6):366-70. PMID: 2051152.

Treatment Description: Placebo pills; dose (number of pills) adjusted by nonblind physician monitoring blood levels in other intervention arms

Standardized Treatment Name: Cognitive Processing Therapy (CPT) + Transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS)
Treatment Description:
TMS coil positioned over the right dorsolateral prefrontal cortex.







CPT according to Resick and Schnicke (1992), a trauma-focused therapy that elicit memories of traumatic events and directly confronting conflicts and maladaptive beliefs associated with the memories
Dose: 1-Hz at 110% motor threshold, 1800 pulses per treatment
Citation: Kozel FA, Motes MA, Didehbani N, et al. Repetitive TMS to augment cognitive processing therapy in combat veterans of recent conflicts with PTSD: a randomized clinical trial. J Affect Disord. 2018 Mar 15;229:506-14. doi: 10.1016/j.jad.2017.12.046. PMID: 29351885.

Treatment Description: Sham TMS coil positioned over the right dorsolateral prefrontal cortex. CPT according to Resick and Schnicke (1992), a trauma-focused therapy that elicit memories of traumatic events and directly confronting conflicts and maladaptive beliefs associated with the memories

Treatment Description: rTMS positioned over the dorsolateral prefrontal cortex; stimulus was 1 Hz frequency, continuous for 40 minutes with total of 2400 pulses per session and total pulses over all sessions (including taper) was 86,400. Treatment outcomes were assessed at the end of 6 weeks of rTMS (30 sessions); there was an additional 3-week taper period with 6 sessions (3 in week 1, 2 in week 2, and 1 in week 3).
Dose: Dose: 1 Hz continuous

Treatment Description: rTMS positioned over the dorsolateral prefrontal cortex; stimulus was 10 Hz frequency, 4 seconds on and 36 seconds off for 40 minutes with total of 2400 pulses per session and total pulses over all sessions (including taper) was 86,400. Treatment outcomes were assessed at the end of 6 weeks of rTMS (30 sessions); there was an additional 3-week taper period with 6 sessions (3 in week 1, 2 in week 2, and 1 in week 3).

Treatment Description: Second-generation antipsychotic; augmentation of antidepressants with or without psychotherapy; titrated over 4 weeks, with further optional 1 mg increase determined by treating investigators (blinded to study medication status).

Treatment Description: Matching tablets. Initiated at 1 tablet orally at bedtime and increased by 1 tablet per week to a dose of 3 tablets at bedtime. After participants received study medication for 4 weeks, investigators who were blinded to study medication status and were treating patients had the option of further increasing the dose by 1 tablet.

Treatment Description: Each trial began with a fixation cross that appeared in the center of the computer screen for 500 millisecond The fixation cross then disappeared and was replaced by a word pair consisting of one threat and one neutral word, presented vertically in the center of the screen for 500 millisecond, with one word directly above the other. The words then disappeared and a probe (either the letter ‘E’ or the letter ‘F’) appeared in the location of one of the two words. Participants were instructed to decide whether the probe replacing the word was an ‘E’ or an ‘F’ and press the corresponding mouse button (left mouse button for ‘E’ and right mouse button for ‘F’). The letter probe remained on the screen until the participant responded. Response latencies for each participant to identify the probe were recorded from the time the probe was presented to the time participants responded. Following each response, there was a 500 millisecond interval where participants saw a blank screen before the next trial began with a fixation cross. Each session consisted of 384 trials: 48 pre-session, 288 training or control sessions, and 48 post-sessions.
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: Study reports drop out, but unclear if attrition from measurement only or also attrition from treatment
Citation: Kuckertz JM, Amir N, Boffa JW, et al. The effectiveness of an attention bias modification program as an adjunctive treatment for post-traumatic stress disorder. Behav Res Ther. 2014 Dec;63:25-35. doi: 10.1016/j.brat.2014.09.002. PMID: 25277496.

Treatment Description: Identical to the Attention Bias Modification procedure with the exception that the probe replaced the threat and neutral words with equal frequency.
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: Study reports drop out, but unclear if attrition from measurement only or also attrition from treatment
Citation: Kuckertz JM, Amir N, Boffa JW, et al. The effectiveness of an attention bias modification program as an adjunctive treatment for post-traumatic stress disorder. Behav Res Ther. 2014 Dec;63:25-35. doi: 10.1016/j.brat.2014.09.002. PMID: 25277496.
