Treatment Description: Computerized working memory training, including increasingly difficult trials (1-back, 2-back, 3-back, and 4-back); training involves constant updating of information stored in working memory and shifting between visual and auditory stimuli; task utilizes 8 different faces and 8 different negative words; there were 4 trial types: face change, no word change; no face change, word change; no face change, no word change; face change, word change; sessions consisted of 20 blocks of 20 + n trials, each block lasting about 1 minute.
Citation: Larsen SE, Lotfi S, Bennett KP, et al. A pilot randomized trial of a dual n-back emotional working memory training program for veterans with elevated PTSD symptoms. Psychiatry Res. 2019b May;275:261-8. doi: 10.1016/j.psychres.2019.02.015. PMID: 30939398.

Treatment Description: Computerized working memory training, including only 1-back trials (without increasing difficulty); training involves constant updating of information stored in working memory and shifting between visual and auditory stimuli; task utilizes 8 different faces and 8 different negative words; there were 4 trial types: face change, no word change; no face change, word change; no face change, no word change; face change, word change; sessions consisted of 20 blocks of 20 + n trials, each block lasting about 1 minute.
Citation: Larsen SE, Lotfi S, Bennett KP, et al. A pilot randomized trial of a dual n-back emotional working memory training program for veterans with elevated PTSD symptoms. Psychiatry Res. 2019b May;275:261-8. doi: 10.1016/j.psychres.2019.02.015. PMID: 30939398.

Treatment Name: Culturally adapted trauma-focused CBT-based guided self-help
Treatment Description: Self-help facilitated by research assistants (psychologists) using a culturally sensitive self-help manual for victims of trauma (BASID Ki Kahani). The manual focuses on psychoeducation, symptom management, graded exposure, cognitive restructuring, behavioural activation, problem-solving, improving relationships and communication skills; includes stories of victims of trauma and examples from local folklore and Islamic religion. Each session included 15-20 minute overview of the content of the corresponding chapter in the manual.
Psychotherapy Sessions Completed Detail: 20 attended 9 sessions, 3 attended 6 to 9 sessions, and 2 attended 3 to 6 sessions
Citation: Latif M, Husain MI, Gul M, et al. Culturally adapted trauma-focused CBT-based guided self-help (CatCBT GSH) for female victims of domestic violence in Pakistan: feasibility randomized controlled trial. Behav. 2021 Jan;49(1):50-61. doi: 10.1017/S1352465820000685. PMID: 32993831

Treatment Description: Shelter residents in waitlist control group not routinely offered psychological treatment.
Citation: Latif M, Husain MI, Gul M, et al. Culturally adapted trauma-focused CBT-based guided self-help (CatCBT GSH) for female victims of domestic violence in Pakistan: feasibility randomized controlled trial. Behav. 2021 Jan;49(1):50-61. doi: 10.1017/S1352465820000685. PMID: 32993831

Treatment Description: ABM using a face-based variant of the dot-probe task. Training protocol consisting of 160 trials per session (120 angry-neutral and 40 neutral-neutral trials). Training was contingent on the bias measured at pre-treatment for all threat-neutral trials -- for those showing bias toward the threat the target appeared at neutral-face location, and for those showing bias away from the threat the target appeared at the threat-face location.
Citation: Lazarov A, Suarez-Jimenez B, Abend R, et al. Bias-contingent attention bias modification and attention control training in treatment of PTSD: a randomized control trial. Psychol Med. 2018 2019-02-01;49(14):2432-40. doi: 10.1017/s0033291718003367. PMID: 30415648.

Treatment Description: ACT using a face-based variant of the dot-probe task. Training protocol consisting of 160 trials per session (120 angry-neutral and 40 neutral-neutral trials). The threat-face location, probe location, and probe type were fully counter-balanced with no contingency between face valence and probe location.
Citation: Lazarov A, Suarez-Jimenez B, Abend R, et al. Bias-contingent attention bias modification and attention control training in treatment of PTSD: a randomized control trial. Psychol Med. 2018 2019-02-01;49(14):2432-40. doi: 10.1017/s0033291718003367. PMID: 30415648.

Treatment Description: Based on Foa 1991 but reduced sessions by excluding session containing thought stopping and condensing content of first three sessions into two. Sessions included assessment, controlled breathing, education, prolonged exposure, and coping skills.
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, rape/sexual assault, accidents, other (murder)
Citation: Lee CW, Gavriel H, Drummond PD, et al. Treatment of PTSD: stress inoculation training with prolonged exposure compared to EMDR. J Clin Psychol. 2002 Sep;58(9):1071-89. doi: 10.1002/jclp.10039. PMID: 12209866.

Treatment Description: Full standard 8-phase intervention as described in Shapiro 1995. Included preparation, target memory and desensitization, debriefing, and re-evaluation.
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, rape/sexual assault, accidents, other (murder)
Citation: Lee CW, Gavriel H, Drummond PD, et al. Treatment of PTSD: stress inoculation training with prolonged exposure compared to EMDR. J Clin Psychol. 2002 Sep;58(9):1071-89. doi: 10.1002/jclp.10039. PMID: 12209866.

Treatment Description: Neurofeedback self-regulating training using ProComp2, 2-Channel EEG System. Neurofeedback normalizes dysregulated brain activity via EEG monitoring and audio or visual signals. EEG components are recorded and fed to participants during the procedure so that the subject is aware of changes in brainwaves and the effect of training. Study used alpha-theta brainwave neurofeedback to maintain a relaxed state by strengthening alpha and theta waves and suppressing beta waves. Participants also received "Mentalizing the Rooms of the Mind" (a psychotherapy technique) before and after each neurofeedback session.
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: Reports "received allocated intervention" (n=11, 100%) and "discontinued intervention" (n=0); also reports lost to follow-up (n=1)
Trauma Detail (Study level): Intimate partner violence; Accidents; Community/school violence
Citation: Leem J, Cheong MJ, Lee H, et al. Effectiveness, cost-utility, and safety of neurofeedback self-regulating training in patients with post-traumatic stress disorder: a randomized controlled trial. Healthcare (Basel). 2021 Oct 11;9(10):1351. doi: 10.3390/healthcare9101351. PMID: 34683031.

Treatment Description: Participants visited hospital four times (at screening and during weeks 1, 4, and 8) for assesment without neurofeedback training, and week 12 for follow-up. Usual treatment allowed during this period.
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: Reports study dropout/loss to followup (n=0), withdrawal (n=2), and "received allocated intervention" (n=11)
Trauma Detail (Study level): Intimate partner violence; Accidents; Community/school violence
Citation: Leem J, Cheong MJ, Lee H, et al. Effectiveness, cost-utility, and safety of neurofeedback self-regulating training in patients with post-traumatic stress disorder: a randomized controlled trial. Healthcare (Basel). 2021 Oct 11;9(10):1351. doi: 10.3390/healthcare9101351. PMID: 34683031.

Treatment Name: DElivery of Self Training and Education for Stressful Situations
Treatment Description: Online coach-assisted cognitive behavioral intervention tailored for women Veterans. Participants were asked to log into the website twice a week for 8 weeks and complete homework assignments; coach called participants once a week and monitored participants' progress on website. Intervention sessions included: coping skills; cognitive strategies to identify and challenge thoughts; in vivo exposures; writing about stressful daily life events; writing about a traumatic experience; relapse prevention.
Treatment Duration Detail: 8 total weeks, could be completed over 12 weeks
Trauma Detail (Study level): MST, Combat-related, Child physical abuse, Child sexual abuse, Rape/sexual assault, Community/school violence, Other ("other military", "other" not specified)
Citation: Lehavot K, Millard SP, Thomas RM, Yantsides K, Upham M, Beckman K, Hamilton AB, Sadler A, Litz B, Simpson T. A randomized trial of an online, coach-assisted self-management PTSD intervention tailored for women veterans. J Consult Clin Psychol. 2021 Feb;89(2):134-142. doi: 10.1037/ccp0000556. PMID: 33705169; PMCID: PMC8238393.

Treatment Description: Weekly calls from study coach to assess safety and symptoms while providing general support; no CBT strategies used.
Treatment Duration Detail: 9 scheduled calls in 8 weeks, could be extended up to 12 weeks
Trauma Detail (Study level): MST, Combat-related, Child physical abuse, Child sexual abuse, Rape/sexual assault, Community/school violence, Other ("other military", "other" not specified)
Citation: Lehavot K, Millard SP, Thomas RM, Yantsides K, Upham M, Beckman K, Hamilton AB, Sadler A, Litz B, Simpson T. A randomized trial of an online, coach-assisted self-management PTSD intervention tailored for women veterans. J Consult Clin Psychol. 2021 Feb;89(2):134-142. doi: 10.1037/ccp0000556. PMID: 33705169; PMCID: PMC8238393.

Treatment Description: Oral hydrocortisone given 30 minutes before final eight sessions of PE, which include imaginal exposure. PE includes 12 total sessions, with exposure to trauma memories (imaginal) and avoided trauma cues (in vivo).
Dose: 30 mg
Treatment Duration Detail:
Hydrocortisone: one dose given 30 minutes before each of the last 8 (of 12)  PE sessions

PE: total 12 sessions
Completed Treatment Definition: "Completed treatment", fewer than 12 sessions considered completion if considered recovered based on self report and clinician assessment
Trauma Detail (Study level): "deployment-related"
Citation: Lehrner A, Hildebrandt T, Bierer LM, et al. A randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial of hydrocortisone augmentation of prolonged exposure for PTSD in U.S. combat veterans. Behav Res Ther. 2021 Sep;144:103924. doi: 10.1016/j.brat.2021.103924. PMID: 34298438.

Treatment Description: Oral placebo given 30 minutes before final eight sessions of PE, which include imaginal exposure. PE includes 12 total sessions, with exposure to trauma memories (imaginal) and avoided trauma cues (in vivo).
Treatment Duration Detail:
Placebo: one dose given 30 minutes before each of the last 8 (of 12)  PE sessions

PE: total 12 sessions
Completed Treatment Definition: "Completed treatment", fewer than 12 sessions considered completion if considered recovered based on self report and clinician assessment
Trauma Detail (Study level): "deployment-related"
Citation: Lehrner A, Hildebrandt T, Bierer LM, et al. A randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial of hydrocortisone augmentation of prolonged exposure for PTSD in U.S. combat veterans. Behav Res Ther. 2021 Sep;144:103924. doi: 10.1016/j.brat.2021.103924. PMID: 34298438.

Treatment Description: Standardized individual treatment following manual, based on trauma-focused CBT and incorporating components of testimonial therapy. "Session one is dedicated to psychoeducation and treatment planning. In session two, the therapist and the participant create a visual timeline of traumatic and supporting experiences and select the events for exposure. Sessions three to ten are dedicated to imaginal exposure. The last session allows for receiving the documented narration, focusing on the future and saying goodbye."
Trauma Detail (Study level): intimate partner violence, terrorism/political violence/forced displacement, other (unspecified child abuse, persecution)
Citation: Lely JCG, Knipscheer JW, Moerbeek M, et al. Randomised controlled trial comparing narrative exposure therapy with present-centred therapy for older patients with post-traumatic stress disorder. Br J Psychiatry. 2019 Jun;214(6):369-77. doi: 10.1192/bjp.2019.59. PMID: 30957736.

Treatment Description: Individual, non-trauma-focused therapy following PCT protocol; includes psychoeducation and homework, "targeting current maladaptive relational patterns by including problem-solving techniques, and helps patients to focus on the ‘here and now’."
Trauma Detail (Study level): intimate partner violence, terrorism/political violence/forced displacement, other (unspecified child abuse, persecution)
Citation: Lely JCG, Knipscheer JW, Moerbeek M, et al. Randomised controlled trial comparing narrative exposure therapy with present-centred therapy for older patients with post-traumatic stress disorder. Br J Psychiatry. 2019 Jun;214(6):369-77. doi: 10.1192/bjp.2019.59. PMID: 30957736.

Treatment Description: One-Hz rTMS with 2,250 pulses over 37.5 minutes, targeting the right dorsolateral prefrontal cortex (DLPFC) using Magstim Super Rapid2 model 3910-00 device
Dose: Intensity: 1 Hz for 37.5 minutes
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: "double-blind phase completers analyzed" in flow diagram (double-blind phase is 2 weeks of daily treatments, 10 total), participants randomized minus discontinued intervention
Trauma Detail (Study level): Rape/sexual assault; Other (exposure to actual or threatened death or serious injury, and witnessing such incidents)
Citation: Leong K, Chan P, Ong L, et al. A aandomized sham-controlled trial of 1-Hz and 10-Hz repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (rTMS) of the right dorsolateral prefrontal cortex in civilian post-traumatic stress disorder. Can J Psychiatry. 2020 Nov;65(11):770-8. doi: 10.1177/0706743720923064. PMID: 32379487.

Treatment Description: 10-Hz rTMS with 3,000 pulses over 37.5 minutes, targeting the right DLPFC using Magstim Super Rapid2 model 3910-00 device
Dose: Intensity: 10 Hz for 37.5 minutes
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: "double-blind phase completers analyzed" in flow diagram (double-blind phase is 2 weeks of daily treatments, 10 total), participants randomized minus discontinued intervention
Trauma Detail (Study level): Rape/sexual assault; Other (exposure to actual or threatened death or serious injury, and witnessing such incidents)
Citation: Leong K, Chan P, Ong L, et al. A aandomized sham-controlled trial of 1-Hz and 10-Hz repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (rTMS) of the right dorsolateral prefrontal cortex in civilian post-traumatic stress disorder. Can J Psychiatry. 2020 Nov;65(11):770-8. doi: 10.1177/0706743720923064. PMID: 32379487.

Treatment Description: Sham rTMS with either 1-Hz or 10-Hz sham stimulation using a Magstim D70 model 3950-00 device, identical in appearance and producing a similar sound and vibration as the active coil, targeting the right DLPFC
Dose: Intensity: Sham 1 or 10 Hz for 37.5 minutes
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: "double-blind phase completers analyzed" in flow diagram (double-blind phase is 2 weeks of daily treatments, 10 total), participants randomized minus discontinued intervention
Trauma Detail (Study level): Rape/sexual assault; Other (exposure to actual or threatened death or serious injury, and witnessing such incidents)
Citation: Leong K, Chan P, Ong L, et al. A aandomized sham-controlled trial of 1-Hz and 10-Hz repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (rTMS) of the right dorsolateral prefrontal cortex in civilian post-traumatic stress disorder. Can J Psychiatry. 2020 Nov;65(11):770-8. doi: 10.1177/0706743720923064. PMID: 32379487.

Treatment Description: Interactive online program and therapist guidance. Online program consisted of 8 modules covering psychoeducation, grounding, relaxation and anxiety management, behavioral reactivation, imaginal and in-vivo exposure, cognitive therapy, and relapse prevention. Therapist guidance (face-to-face or telephone) for support, monitoring, motivation, and problem-solving; brief check-ins between appointments.
Session Length: Session length: therapist 30 minutes (initial appointment 1 hour)
Frequency: Therapist guidance every 2 weeks, brief check-in weekly
Trauma Detail (Study level): accidents, illness/medical procedure, rape/sexual assault, terrorism/political violence/forced displacement, community/school violence
Citation: Lewis CE, Farewell D, Groves V, et al. Internet-based guided self-help for posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD): randomized controlled trial. Depress Anxiety. 2017 Jun;34(6):555-65. doi: 10.1002/da.22645. PMID: 28557299.

Treatment Description: Waiting period during which there was no therapist contact
Trauma Detail (Study level): accidents, illness/medical procedure, rape/sexual assault, terrorism/political violence/forced displacement, community/school violence
Citation: Lewis CE, Farewell D, Groves V, et al. Internet-based guided self-help for posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD): randomized controlled trial. Depress Anxiety. 2017 Jun;34(6):555-65. doi: 10.1002/da.22645. PMID: 28557299.

Treatment Description: SSRI, fixed-dose
Dose: 135 mg
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, other (chemical burn)
Citation: Li W, Ma YB, Yang Q, et al. Effect and safety of sertraline for treat posttraumatic stress disorder: a multicenter randomised controlled study. Int. J. Psychiatry Clin. Pract. 2017 Jun;21(2):151-5. doi: 10.1080/13651501.2017.1291838. PMID: 28266242.

Treatment Description: Placebo matched to sertraline (3 tablets)
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, other (chemical burn)
Citation: Li W, Ma YB, Yang Q, et al. Effect and safety of sertraline for treat posttraumatic stress disorder: a multicenter randomised controlled study. Int. J. Psychiatry Clin. Pract. 2017 Jun;21(2):151-5. doi: 10.1080/13651501.2017.1291838. PMID: 28266242.

Treatment Description: Schema therapy adapted for Malaysian context. "Schema therapy is an integrative psychotherapy which combines different aspects of cognitive-behavioural, experiential, interpersonal and psychoanalytic therapies."  Developed as treatment for borderline personality disorder. Begins with gentle approaches and progresses to confrontational approaches depending on patient's readiness. Features include a strong emphasis on the therapeutic relationship, a focus on experiential techniques, and schema theory with "early maladaptive schema" and "schema modes" ("predominant emotional states and coping responses that occur when trauma is triggered"). Therapy for this trial was adapted for Malaysian context, by incorporating art therapy, dream work, and psychodynamic techiques.
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: No dropouts during study period
Trauma Detail (Study level): Rape/sexual assault; Other ("childhood trauma", "relational trauma", "work-related trauma", "school-related trauma")
Citation: Lian AEZ, Chooi W-T, Bono SA. The development and the effectiveness of schema therapy on eMalaysian female young adults who experienced continuous trauma and post-traumatic stress disorder. European Journal of Trauma & Dissociation Vol 8(3), 2024, ArtID 100427. 2024 Sep;8(3). doi: 10.1016/j.ejtd.2024.100427.

Treatment Description: CBT with a focus on PTSD symptoms such as "replacing maladaptive trauma-related cognitions and trauma-related behaviours with more adaptive cognitions and behaviours". Incorporates "psychoeducation, relaxation skills, cognitive coping strategies such as cognitive restructuring, and exposure therapy".
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: 1 dropout during study period
Trauma Detail (Study level): Rape/sexual assault; Other ("childhood trauma", "relational trauma", "work-related trauma", "school-related trauma")
Citation: Lian AEZ, Chooi W-T, Bono SA. The development and the effectiveness of schema therapy on eMalaysian female young adults who experienced continuous trauma and post-traumatic stress disorder. European Journal of Trauma & Dissociation Vol 8(3), 2024, ArtID 100427. 2024 Sep;8(3). doi: 10.1016/j.ejtd.2024.100427.

Treatment Description: Following manual by Gersons et al. 2004, includes psychoeducation, imaginal exposure, writing tasks and memorabilia, meaning and integration, and farewell ritual
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, rape/sexual assault, accidents, community/school violence, natural or manmade disasters, other (unspecified)
Citation: Lindauer RJ, Gersons BP, van Meijel EP, et al. Effects of brief eclectic psychotherapy in patients with posttraumatic stress disorder: randomized clinical trial. Journal of traumatic stress. 2005 Jun;18(3):205-12. doi: 10.1002/jts.20029. PMID: 16281214.

Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, rape/sexual assault, accidents, community/school violence, natural or manmade disasters, other (unspecified)
Citation: Lindauer RJ, Gersons BP, van Meijel EP, et al. Effects of brief eclectic psychotherapy in patients with posttraumatic stress disorder: randomized clinical trial. Journal of traumatic stress. 2005 Jun;18(3):205-12. doi: 10.1002/jts.20029. PMID: 16281214.

Treatment Description: Anticonvulsant
Dose: 25 to 100 mg (total daily dose 50 to 200 mg); titration: initiated at 25 mg twice a day and increased weekly by 50 mg/day as tolerated with maximum dose of 200 mg/day
Citation: Lindley SE, Carlson EB, Hill K. A randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial of augmentation topiramate for chronic combat-related posttraumatic stress disorder. J Clin Psychopharmacol. 2007 Dec;27(6):677-81. doi: 10.1097/jcp.0b013e31815a43ee. PMID: 18004136..

Treatment Description: Placebo
Citation: Lindley SE, Carlson EB, Hill K. A randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial of augmentation topiramate for chronic combat-related posttraumatic stress disorder. J Clin Psychopharmacol. 2007 Dec;27(6):677-81. doi: 10.1097/jcp.0b013e31815a43ee. PMID: 18004136..

Treatment Description: Online interactive program providing psychoeducation, distress management strategies, healthy coping skills, and cognitive behavioral techniques through video, written description of skills, and written examples modeling the skills
Completed Treatment Definition: completed baseline online questionnaires and logged in to assigned program at least once
Trauma Detail (Study level): child sexual abuse, child physical abuse, rape/sexual assault, intimate partner violence
Citation: Littleton HL, Grills AE, Kline KD, et al. The From Survivor to Thriver program: RCT of an online therapist-facilitated program for rape-related PTSD. J Anxiety Disord. 2016 Oct;43:41-51. doi: 10.1016/j.janxdis.2016.07.010. PMID: 27513363.

Treatment Description: Written information providing same psychoeducation, distress management strategies, and healthy coping skills as From Survivor to Thriver program
Completed Treatment Definition: completed baseline online questionnaires and logged in to assigned program at least once
Trauma Detail (Study level): child sexual abuse, child physical abuse, rape/sexual assault, intimate partner violence
Citation: Littleton HL, Grills AE, Kline KD, et al. The From Survivor to Thriver program: RCT of an online therapist-facilitated program for rape-related PTSD. J Anxiety Disord. 2016 Oct;43:41-51. doi: 10.1016/j.janxdis.2016.07.010. PMID: 27513363.

Treatment Description: Internet-based CBT teaching coping strategies through a series of homework assignments. Specific components were: self-monitoring of situations that triggered trauma-related distress; make hierarchy of triggers; stress management strategies; graduated self-guided in vivo exposure; online trauma writing sessions; review of progess, relapse prevention education.
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: Unclear, study reports n=45 randomized and "33 completed treatment" but doesn't give numbers by arm (overall treatment completion rate 73.33%); table 1 has "for completer study group" in title but reports data for n=45 randomized
Trauma Detail (Study level): Combat-related; Terrorism/political violence/forced displacement
Citation: Litz BT, Engel CC, Bryant RA, Papa A. A randomized, controlled proof-of-concept trial of an internet-based, therapist-assisted self-management treatment for posttraumatic stress disorder. Am J Psychiatry. 2007 Nov;164(11):1676-83. doi: 10.1176/appi.ajp.2007.06122057. PMID: 17974932.

Treatment Description: Internet-based supportive counseling asking participants to self-monitor non-trauma-related concerns and write about them; psychoeducation materials available but there was no skills training or prescriptions for proactive action; could request phone call from therapist, and therapist checked in by phone periodically; therapists were supportive and nondirective, focusing on non-trauma-related current concerns.
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: Unclear, study reports n=45 randomized and "33 completed treatment" but doesn't give numbers by arm (overall treatment completion rate 73.33%); table 1 has "for completer study group" in title but reports data for n=45 randomized
Trauma Detail (Study level): Combat-related; Terrorism/political violence/forced displacement
Citation: Litz BT, Engel CC, Bryant RA, Papa A. A randomized, controlled proof-of-concept trial of an internet-based, therapist-assisted self-management treatment for posttraumatic stress disorder. Am J Psychiatry. 2007 Nov;164(11):1676-83. doi: 10.1176/appi.ajp.2007.06122057. PMID: 17974932.

Treatment Description: Partial NMDA receptor agonist, given 50 minutes before exposure therapy in sessions 2 through 5. Patients in both treatment arms received therapy; 4 of 6 total sessions included 50 minutes of imaginal exposure focused on most distressing war trauma memory.
Dose:
Session length: 60 to 90 minutes







Dose: 50 mg
Treatment Duration Detail:
Psychotherapy: 6 sessions total
D-cycloserine: 4 doses total, at sessions 2 through 5
Citation: Litz BT, Salters-Pedneault K, Steenkamp MM, et al. A randomized placebo-controlled trial of D-cycloserine and exposure therapy for posttraumatic stress disorder. J Psychiatr Res. 2012;46(9):1184-90. doi: 10.1016/j.jpsychires.2012.05.006. PMID: 22694905.

Treatment Description: Placebo pill given 50 minutes before exposure therapy. Patients in both treatment arms received therapy; of 6 total sessions, four included 50-minute imaginal exposure focused on most distressing war trauma memory.
Dose:
Session length: 60 to 90 minutes







Dose: NA
Frequency:
Psychotherapy: 6 sessions, interval NR







Placebo: 4 doses, sessions 2 through 5
Treatment Duration Detail:
Psychotherapy: 6 sessions total
Placebo: 4 doses total, at sessions 2 through 5
Citation: Litz BT, Salters-Pedneault K, Steenkamp MM, et al. A randomized placebo-controlled trial of D-cycloserine and exposure therapy for posttraumatic stress disorder. J Psychiatr Res. 2012;46(9):1184-90. doi: 10.1016/j.jpsychires.2012.05.006. PMID: 22694905.

Treatment Description: Manualized trauma-focused psychotherapy that targets danger-loss- and moral injury-related trauma using different experiental strategies. Expanded number of treatments for this study from 6 sessions to 8 sessions to equilibrate treatment hours for both interventions
Treatment Duration Detail: expanded treatment duration so that treatment hours were equivalent for both groups (Adaptive Disclosure designed to be 6 sessions)
Completed Treatment Definition: Did not drop out of treatment (did not miss last treatment session)
Psychotherapy Sessions Completed Detail: "Patients in the AD arm attended a mean of 75% of the eight sessions"
Citation: Litz BT, Rusowicz-Orazem L, Doros G, Grunthal B, Gray M, Nash W, Lang AJ. Adaptive disclosure, a combat-specific PTSD treatment, versus cognitive-processing therapy, in deployed marines and sailors: A randomized controlled non-inferiority trial. Psychiatry Res. 2021 Mar;297:113761. doi: 10.1016/j.psychres.2021.113761. Epub 2021 Jan 24. PMID: 33540206.

Treatment Description: Trauma-focused cognitive therapy, omitting written trauma narrative in CPT
Completed Treatment Definition: Did not drop out of treatment (did not miss last treatment session)
Psychotherapy Sessions Completed Detail: "patients in the CPT-C arm attended a mean of 71% of the twelve sessions"
Citation: Litz BT, Rusowicz-Orazem L, Doros G, Grunthal B, Gray M, Nash W, Lang AJ. Adaptive disclosure, a combat-specific PTSD treatment, versus cognitive-processing therapy, in deployed marines and sailors: A randomized controlled non-inferiority trial. Psychiatry Res. 2021 Mar;297:113761. doi: 10.1016/j.psychres.2021.113761. Epub 2021 Jan 24. PMID: 33540206.

Treatment Description: Manualized treatment focusing on addressing traumatic loss and moral injury. Modifications for enhanced version of adaptive disclosure included: a "compassion history assessment", letter-writing as a change agent, loving-kindness meditation and mindfulness training, using a personlized recovery/rehabilitation approach, and a "Healing & Repair Plan" for activities outside of therapy (e.g. self-care and in vivo exposure).
Completed Treatment Definition: Completed all 12 sessions within 16 weeks or early completer (therapist assessed)
Completed Treatment Percent Detail:
Completed 12 sessions: 62.92%
Completed ≥8 sessions: 75.28%
Citation: Litz BT, Yeterian J, Berke D, et al. A controlled trial of adaptive disclosure-enhanced to improve functioning and treat posttraumatic stress disorder. J Consult Clin Psychol. 2024 Mar;92(3):150-64. doi: 10.1037/ccp0000873. PMID: 38358703.

Treatment Description: Manualized therapy including empathic reflective listening, discussion of patient's life stressors and issues, and homework using adpative responses to stressors. Discussion of traumatic events not allowed.
Completed Treatment Definition: Completed all 12 sessions within 16 weeks or early completer (therapist assessed)
Completed Treatment Percent Detail:
Completed 12 sessions: 58.82%
Completing ≥8 sessions: 71.76%
Citation: Litz BT, Yeterian J, Berke D, et al. A controlled trial of adaptive disclosure-enhanced to improve functioning and treat posttraumatic stress disorder. J Consult Clin Psychol. 2024 Mar;92(3):150-64. doi: 10.1037/ccp0000873. PMID: 38358703.

Treatment Description: Participant used videoconference equipment at a community-based outpatient clinic and the therapist was located at another VA site. CPT followed manual used by the VA (for CPT-C or cognitive-only version) which doesn't include written account of the trauma. "Per protocol, participants were educated about PTSD symptoms, cognitive theory, and treatment goals; wrote about how traumatic experiences have influenced thoughts and beliefs about themselves, others, and the world; identified problematic thoughts (‘stuck points’) related to the traumatic event; learned how these thoughts influence emotions; and learned to challenge distorted thoughts and identify more balanced alternative thoughts."
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, rape/sexual assault, accidents, community/school violence, other (unspecified type of child abuse, "unexpected death", "others")
Citation: Liu L, Thorp SR, Moreno L, et al. Videoconferencing psychotherapy for veterans with PTSD: results from a randomized controlled non-inferiority trial. J Telemed Telecare. 2019 Jun 19doi: 10.1177/1357633X19853947. PMID: 31216210.

Treatment Description: In-person CPT; therapy followed manual used by the VA (for CPT-C or cognitive-only version) which doesn't include written account of the trauma. "Per protocol, participants were educated about PTSD symptoms, cognitive theory, and treatment goals; wrote about how traumatic experiences have influenced thoughts and beliefs about themselves, others, and the world; identified problematic thoughts (‘stuck points’) related to the traumatic event; learned how these thoughts influence emotions; and learned to challenge distorted thoughts and identify more balanced alternative thoughts."
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, rape/sexual assault, accidents, community/school violence, other (unspecified type of child abuse, "unexpected death", "others")
Citation: Liu L, Thorp SR, Moreno L, et al. Videoconferencing psychotherapy for veterans with PTSD: results from a randomized controlled non-inferiority trial. J Telemed Telecare. 2019 Jun 19doi: 10.1177/1357633X19853947. PMID: 31216210.

Treatment Description: Corticosteroid; placebo first week, 10 mg hydrocortisone second week, placebo third week, 30 mg hydrocortisone fourth week
Dose: 10 mg
Treatment Duration Detail: each dose taken for 1 week, followed by placebo for 1 week
Trauma Detail (Study level): child sexual abuse, rape/sexual assault, child physical abuse, child other abuse
Citation: Ludascher P, Schmahl C, Feldmann RE, Jr., et al. No evidence for differential dose effects of hydrocortisone on intrusive memories in female patients with complex post-traumatic stress disorder--a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, crossover study. J Psychopharmacol. 2015 Oct;29(10):1077-84. doi: 10.1177/0269881115592339. PMID: 26152322.

Treatment Description: Corticosteroid; 30 mg hydrocortisone first week, placebo second week, 10 mg hydrocortisone third week, placebo fourth week
Dose: 30 mg
Treatment Duration Detail: each dose taken for 1 week, followed by placebo for 1 week
Trauma Detail (Study level): child sexual abuse, rape/sexual assault, child physical abuse, child other abuse
Citation: Ludascher P, Schmahl C, Feldmann RE, Jr., et al. No evidence for differential dose effects of hydrocortisone on intrusive memories in female patients with complex post-traumatic stress disorder--a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, crossover study. J Psychopharmacol. 2015 Oct;29(10):1077-84. doi: 10.1177/0269881115592339. PMID: 26152322.

Trauma Detail (Study level): child sexual abuse, rape/sexual assault, child physical abuse, child other abuse
Citation: Ludascher P, Schmahl C, Feldmann RE, Jr., et al. No evidence for differential dose effects of hydrocortisone on intrusive memories in female patients with complex post-traumatic stress disorder--a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, crossover study. J Psychopharmacol. 2015 Oct;29(10):1077-84. doi: 10.1177/0269881115592339. PMID: 26152322.

Treatment Description: Cognitive-behavioral intervention incorporating self-forgiveness, existential, gestalt, and relational theories to reduce mental health symptoms and functional impairment associated with killing in a war.
Completed Treatment Definition: Full participation in all content outlined in 6 sessions, completion of all between-session assignments, and completion of outcome measures
Citation: Maguen S, Burkman KM, Madden E, et al. Impact of killing in war: a randomized, controlled pilot trial. J Clin Psychol. 2017 Sep;73(9):997-1012. doi: 10.1002/jclp.22471. PMID: 28294318.

Treatment Description: While on waitlist could engage in TAU, including medication management, brief case management visits, and supportive group psychotherapy. Participants were prohibited from enrolling in individual psychotherapy or cognitive-behaviorally based group psychotherapy.
Citation: Maguen S, Burkman KM, Madden E, et al. Impact of killing in war: a randomized, controlled pilot trial. J Clin Psychol. 2017 Sep;73(9):997-1012. doi: 10.1002/jclp.22471. PMID: 28294318.

Treatment Description: Beta-adrenergic receptor antagonist
Dose: 1 mg/kg
Trauma Detail (Study level): accidents, rape/sexual assault, combat-related, community/school violence, other (non-specified)
Citation: Mahabir M, Ashbaugh AR, Saumier D, et al. Propranolol's impact on cognitive performance in post-traumatic stress disorder. J Affect Disord. 2016 Mar 1;192:98-103. doi: 10.1016/j.jad.2015.11.051. PMID: 26707354.

Treatment Description: Placebo
Trauma Detail (Study level): accidents, rape/sexual assault, combat-related, community/school violence, other (non-specified)
Citation: Mahabir M, Ashbaugh AR, Saumier D, et al. Propranolol's impact on cognitive performance in post-traumatic stress disorder. J Affect Disord. 2016 Mar 1;192:98-103. doi: 10.1016/j.jad.2015.11.051. PMID: 26707354.

Treatment Description: CPT provided over video teleconference
Trauma Detail (Study level): MST, combat-related, community/school violence
Citation: Maieritsch KP, Smith TL, Hessinger JD, et al. Randomized controlled equivalence trial comparing videoconference and in person delivery of cognitive processing therapy for PTSD. J Telemed Telecare. 2016 Jun;22(4):238-43. doi: 10.1177/1357633x15596109. PMID: 26231819.

Treatment Description: In-person sessions
Trauma Detail (Study level): MST, combat-related, community/school violence
Citation: Maieritsch KP, Smith TL, Hessinger JD, et al. Randomized controlled equivalence trial comparing videoconference and in person delivery of cognitive processing therapy for PTSD. J Telemed Telecare. 2016 Jun;22(4):238-43. doi: 10.1177/1357633x15596109. PMID: 26231819.

Treatment Description: Citalopram: SSRI; baclofen: GABA-B agonist
Dose:
Citalopram: 60 mg; titrated from 10 mg to 60 mg







Baclofen: 40 mg; started at 10 mg titrated up to 40 mg
Citation: Manteghi AA, Hebrani P, Mortezania M, et al. Baclofen add-on to citalopram in treatment of posttraumatic stress disorder. J Clin Psychopharmacol. 2014 Apr;34(2):240-3. doi: 10.1097/jcp.0000000000000089. PMID: 24525635.

Treatment Description: SSRI plus placebo
Dose: 10 mg/day titrated up to 60 mg/day
Frequency: Once daily citalopram and three time a day for placebo
Citation: Manteghi AA, Hebrani P, Mortezania M, et al. Baclofen add-on to citalopram in treatment of posttraumatic stress disorder. J Clin Psychopharmacol. 2014 Apr;34(2):240-3. doi: 10.1097/jcp.0000000000000089. PMID: 24525635.

Treatment Description: Individual psychotherapy according to Shapiro (1995), includes history taking and treatment planning, assessment of target trauma, desensitization of the targeted trauma, installation of positive cognition, body scan to identify residual disturbing body sensations or affect, and EMDR closure. Treatment was offered until individual no long met DSM-III-R criteria for PTSD or study ended. Participants also received TAU, including medication visits and group therapy.
Trauma Detail (Study level): rape/sexual assault, accidents, illness/medical procedure, community/school violence, natural or manmade disaster
Citation: Marcus SV, Marquis P, Sakai CE. Controlled study of treatment of PTSD using EMDR in an HMO setting. Psychotherapy (Chic). 1997;34(3):307-15. doi: 10.1037/h0087791.

Treatment Description: All individuals received either individual psychotherapy (cognitive, psychodynamic, or behavior), medication, and/or group therapy (treated as provider preferred)
Session Length:
Individual therapy: 50 minutes







Medication visits: 30 to 45 minutes







Group therapy: 90 minutes
Trauma Detail (Study level): rape/sexual assault, accidents, illness/medical procedure, community/school violence, natural or manmade disaster
Citation: Marcus SV, Marquis P, Sakai CE. Controlled study of treatment of PTSD using EMDR in an HMO setting. Psychotherapy (Chic). 1997;34(3):307-15. doi: 10.1037/h0087791.

Standardized Treatment Name: Cognitive Behavioral Therapy for Insomnia (CBT-I) + Imagery Rehearsal Training (IRT)
Treatment Description: Treatment includes CBT-I following Morin & Epsie 2003 protocol, imaginal rehearsal of new dream, and stimulus control following Bootzin & Epstine 2000.
Citation: Margolies SO, Rybarczyk B, Vrana SR, et al. Efficacy of a cognitive-behavioral treatment for insomnia and nightmares in Afghanistan and Iraq veterans with PTSD. Journal of Clinical Psychology. 2013 Oct;69(10):1026-42. doi: 10.1002/jclp.21970. PMID: 23629959.

Margolies SO, Rybarczyk B, Vrana SR, et al. Efficacy of a cognitive-behavioral treatment for insomnia and nightmares in Afghanistan and Iraq veterans with PTSD. Journal of Clinical Psychology. 2013 Oct;69(10):1026-42. doi: 10.1002/jclp.21970. PMID: 23629959.

Treatment Description: Patients narrate an increasingly detailed trauma narrative (imaginal exposure) and confront trauma reminders (in vivo exposure) to extinguish fear responses
Frequency: Weekly for 7 weeks, then 3 sessions over next 7 weeks
Trauma Detail (Study level): rape/sexual assault, other (child abuse unspecified, interpersonal, not specified)
Citation: Markowitz JC, Petkova E, Neria Y, et al. Is exposure necessary? A randomized clinical trial of interpersonal psychotherapy for PTSD. Am J Psychiatry. 2015 May;172(5):430-40. doi: 10.1176/appi.ajp.2014.14070908. PMID: 25677355.

Treatment Description: Addresses not trauma but its interpersonal aftermath, and assigns no homework. The first half of Interpersonal Psychotherapy emphasized affective attunement, recognizing, naming, and expressing one’s feelings in non-trauma-related interpersonal situations; the remainder addressed typical Interpersonal Psychotherapy problem areas (e.g., role disputes, transitions) not trauma but its interpersonal aftermath, and assigns no homework. The first half of Interpersonal Psychotherapy emphasized affective attunement, recognizing, naming, and expressing one’s feelings in non-trauma-related interpersonal situations; the remainder addressed typical Interpersonal Psychotherapy problem areas (e.g., role disputes, transitions)
Trauma Detail (Study level): rape/sexual assault, other (child abuse unspecified, interpersonal, not specified)
Citation: Markowitz JC, Petkova E, Neria Y, et al. Is exposure necessary? A randomized clinical trial of interpersonal psychotherapy for PTSD. Am J Psychiatry. 2015 May;172(5):430-40. doi: 10.1176/appi.ajp.2014.14070908. PMID: 25677355.

Treatment Description: Highly scripted, induces progressive muscle and mental relaxation
Session Length: 90 minutes for weekly session, 30 minutes for final session
Frequency: Weekly for 7 weeks, then 3 sessions over next 7 weeks
Trauma Detail (Study level): rape/sexual assault, other (child abuse unspecified, interpersonal, not specified)
Citation: Markowitz JC, Petkova E, Neria Y, et al. Is exposure necessary? A randomized clinical trial of interpersonal psychotherapy for PTSD. Am J Psychiatry. 2015 May;172(5):430-40. doi: 10.1176/appi.ajp.2014.14070908. PMID: 25677355.

Treatment Description: Sessions 1-5: Patients asked to talk in first-person and present-tense about their experience; then rewind and 'hold' on memory of trauma until distress reduced. Homework involved listening to parts of their audiotaped description for 1 hour daily, noting peak distress before, during, and after listening sessions in diary. Sessions 6-10: Prolonged live exposure to stimuli; exposure repeated and accompanied by therapist. Homework involved live exposure for 1 hour daily, recording distress levels in diaries.
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, rape/sexual assault, accidents, community/school violence, terrorism/political violence/forced displacement
Citation: Marks I, Lovell K, Noshirvani H, et al. Treatment of posttraumatic stress disorder by exposure and/or cognitive restructuring: a controlled study. Arch Gen Psychiatry. 1998 Apr;55(4):317-25.  PMID: 9554427.

Treatment Description: Patients taught to identify dysfunctional thoughts, develop rational alternatives, and re-appraise beliefs about themselves, their trauma, and the world. Homework involved use of daily thought records.
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, rape/sexual assault, accidents, community/school violence, terrorism/political violence/forced displacement
Citation: Marks I, Lovell K, Noshirvani H, et al. Treatment of posttraumatic stress disorder by exposure and/or cognitive restructuring: a controlled study. Arch Gen Psychiatry. 1998 Apr;55(4):317-25.  PMID: 9554427.

Treatment Description: First half of sessions involved imaginal exposure, then cognitive restructuring; second half of sessions involved in vivo exposure, then cognitive restructuring (45 minutes of exposure therapy, followed by 15 minute break, followed by 45 minutes of cognitive restructuring therapy). Homework involved one hour of daily exposure and cognitive tasks.
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, rape/sexual assault, accidents, community/school violence, terrorism/political violence/forced displacement
Citation: Marks I, Lovell K, Noshirvani H, et al. Treatment of posttraumatic stress disorder by exposure and/or cognitive restructuring: a controlled study. Arch Gen Psychiatry. 1998 Apr;55(4):317-25.  PMID: 9554427.

Treatment Description: Patients taught to relax. Homework involved listening to relaxation tape daily and to record anxiety in daily diary.
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, rape/sexual assault, accidents, community/school violence, terrorism/political violence/forced displacement
Citation: Marks I, Lovell K, Noshirvani H, et al. Treatment of posttraumatic stress disorder by exposure and/or cognitive restructuring: a controlled study. Arch Gen Psychiatry. 1998 Apr;55(4):317-25.  PMID: 9554427.

Treatment Description: SSRI; started at 20 mg/day, received 30 mg/day during week 2, 40 mg/day from start of week 3; followed 1-week placebo run-in to assess compliance
Dose: 40 mg; titration: 20 mg/day for 1 week, then 30 mg/day for 1 week, then 40 mg/day for remainder
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, rape/sexual assault, accidents, community/school violence, other (serious injury, witnessing injury or death)
Citation: Marshall RD, Beebe KL, Oldham M, et al. Efficacy and safety of paroxetine treatment for chronic PTSD: a fixed-dose, placebo-controlled study. Am J Psychiatry. 2001;158(12):1982-8. doi: 10.1176/appi.ajp.158.12.1982. PMID: 11729013.

Treatment Description: SSRI, fixed-dose; followed 1-week placebo run-in to assess compliance
Dose: 20 mg
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, rape/sexual assault, accidents, community/school violence, other (serious injury, witnessing injury or death)
Citation: Marshall RD, Beebe KL, Oldham M, et al. Efficacy and safety of paroxetine treatment for chronic PTSD: a fixed-dose, placebo-controlled study. Am J Psychiatry. 2001;158(12):1982-8. doi: 10.1176/appi.ajp.158.12.1982. PMID: 11729013.

Treatment Description: 1-week placebo run-in to assess compliance, followed by placebo treatment after randomization
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, rape/sexual assault, accidents, community/school violence, other (serious injury, witnessing injury or death)
Citation: Marshall RD, Beebe KL, Oldham M, et al. Efficacy and safety of paroxetine treatment for chronic PTSD: a fixed-dose, placebo-controlled study. Am J Psychiatry. 2001;158(12):1982-8. doi: 10.1176/appi.ajp.158.12.1982. PMID: 11729013.

Treatment Description: SSRI, initiated at 10 mg daily. If patients remained symptomatic, dosage was increased to 20 mg for weeks 2 and 3, 40mg daily for weeks 4–6, and 60 mg daily for weeks 7–10 as tolerated. Followed 1-week single-blind placebo run-in period, with responders excluded from the study.
Dose: 10 mg titrated to maximum 60 mg
Trauma Detail (Study level): rape/sexual assault, accidents, community/school violence, other (witnessing events, fire)
Citation: Marshall RD, Lewis-Fernández R, Blanco C, et al. A controlled trial of paroxetine for chronic PTSD, dissociation, and interpersonal problems in mostly minority adults. Depress Anxiety. 2007;24(2):77-84. doi: 10.1002/da.20176. PMID: 16892419.

Treatment Description: Placebo
Trauma Detail (Study level): rape/sexual assault, accidents, community/school violence, other (witnessing events, fire)
Citation: Marshall RD, Lewis-Fernández R, Blanco C, et al. A controlled trial of paroxetine for chronic PTSD, dissociation, and interpersonal problems in mostly minority adults. Depress Anxiety. 2007;24(2):77-84. doi: 10.1002/da.20176. PMID: 16892419.

Treatment Description: SSRI antidepressant; dose could be increased in 20-mg increments at each of 3 titration points based on predefined response criteria
Dose: Initiated at 20 mg, titrated to maximum 80 mg
Participant Adherence Definition: Determined by direct questioning and medication counts; noncompliant if missed >4 consecutive days, >10 total days, or if ratio of capsules taken to those prescribed was <0.8 or >1.2
Participants Adhered Percent Detail: 97%-100% at all timepoints for each group
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, other ("victim of war or witness of war event," "witness of another person's death")
Citation: Martenyi F, Brown EB, Zhang H, et al. Fluoxetine versus placebo in posttraumatic stress disorder. J Clin Psychiatry. 2002;63(3):199-206.  PMID: 11926718

Treatment Description: Placebo
Participant Adherence Definition: Determined by direct questioning and medication counts; noncompliant if missed >4 consecutive days, >10 total days, or if ratio of capsules taken to those prescribed was <0.8 or >1.2
Participants Adhered Percent Detail: 97%-100% at all timepoints for each group
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, other ("victim of war or witness of war event," "witness of another person's death")
Citation: Martenyi F, Brown EB, Zhang H, et al. Fluoxetine versus placebo in posttraumatic stress disorder. J Clin Psychiatry. 2002;63(3):199-206.  PMID: 11926718

Treatment Description: SSRI, fixed-dose (no titration) 20 mg
Dose: 20 mg
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, rape/sexual assault, intimate partner violence, accidents, other (incest, witnessed a death)
Citation: Martenyi F, Brown EB, Caldwell CD. Failed efficacy of fluoxetine in the treatment of posttraumatic stress disorder: results of a fixed-dose, placebo-controlled study. J Clin Psychopharmacol. 2007;27(2):166-70. doi: 10.1097/JCP.0b013e31803308ce. PMID: 17414240.

Treatment Description: SSRI, initiated at 20 mg and increased to 40 mg after 2 weeks
Dose: 40 mg; titration: initiated at 20 mg, titrated to 40 mg
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, rape/sexual assault, intimate partner violence, accidents, other (incest, witnessed a death)
Citation: Martenyi F, Brown EB, Caldwell CD. Failed efficacy of fluoxetine in the treatment of posttraumatic stress disorder: results of a fixed-dose, placebo-controlled study. J Clin Psychopharmacol. 2007;27(2):166-70. doi: 10.1097/JCP.0b013e31803308ce. PMID: 17414240.

Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, rape/sexual assault, intimate partner violence, accidents, other (incest, witnessed a death)
Citation: Martenyi F, Brown EB, Caldwell CD. Failed efficacy of fluoxetine in the treatment of posttraumatic stress disorder: results of a fixed-dose, placebo-controlled study. J Clin Psychopharmacol. 2007;27(2):166-70. doi: 10.1097/JCP.0b013e31803308ce. PMID: 17414240.

Treatment Description: Investigational neurokinin-1 receptor antagonist, fixed-dose; followed 2-week placebo lead-in
Dose: 5 mg
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, rape/sexual assault, accidents, community/school violence, other (unexpected death)
Citation: Mathew SJ, Vythilingam M, Murrough JW, et al. A selective neurokinin-1 receptor antagonist in chronic PTSD: a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, proof-of-concept trial. Eur. Neuropsychopharmacol. 2011;21(3):221-9. doi: 10.1016/j.euroneuro.2010.11.012. PMID: 21194898.

Treatment Description: Placebo capsules identical to active drug; double-blind period followed 2-week placebo lead-in
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, rape/sexual assault, accidents, community/school violence, other (unexpected death)
Citation: Mathew SJ, Vythilingam M, Murrough JW, et al. A selective neurokinin-1 receptor antagonist in chronic PTSD: a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, proof-of-concept trial. Eur. Neuropsychopharmacol. 2011;21(3):221-9. doi: 10.1016/j.euroneuro.2010.11.012. PMID: 21194898.

Treatment Description: Used "Standard VSDT protocol". Patient identifies "laughter point" based on a person or a memory and "trauma point" based on a traumatic memory, and locates these points in space at two locations around a circle. Therapist then redirects patient's attention from the trauma point to the laughter point while saying "Whoosh!" This displacement process is repeated three times and includes a sequence of instructions to blink, tightly close eyes, and exhale deeply.
Treatment Duration Detail: 7 appointments after screening: one for preparation, 6 for treatment
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: only reports rate for early completion (all trauma targets treated in fewer than 6 sessions; 33.3%), no other information on treatment completion; flow diagram only reports "received allocated intervention" (78.95%, 15/19)
Psychotherapy Sessions Completed Detail: Early completer = all trauma targets treated in fewer than 6 sessions: 33.3%
Citation: Matthijssen S, Brouwers TC, de Jongh A. Visual Schema Displacement Therapy versus Eye Movement Desensitization and Reprocessing therapy versus waitlist in the treatment of post-traumatic stress disorder: results of a randomized clinical trial. Front Psychiatry. 2024;15(1377108). doi: 10.3389/fpsyt.2024.1377108. PMID: 38651013.

Treatment Description: Follows EMDR standard protocol, excluding stabilization/emotion regulation techniques. Not further described.
Treatment Duration Detail: 7 appointments after screening: one for preparation, 6 for treatment
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: only reports rate for early completion (all trauma targets treated in fewer than 6 sessions; 41.2%), no other information on treatment completion; flow diagram only reports "received allocated intervention" (89.47%, 17/19)
Psychotherapy Sessions Completed Detail: Early completer = all trauma targets treated in fewer than 6 sessions: 41.2%
Citation: Matthijssen S, Brouwers TC, de Jongh A. Visual Schema Displacement Therapy versus Eye Movement Desensitization and Reprocessing therapy versus waitlist in the treatment of post-traumatic stress disorder: results of a randomized clinical trial. Front Psychiatry. 2024;15(1377108). doi: 10.3389/fpsyt.2024.1377108. PMID: 38651013.

Treatment Description: Waiting period covered same 6-week "treatment" period and 12-week follow-up period as active treatment groups
Citation: Matthijssen S, Brouwers TC, de Jongh A. Visual Schema Displacement Therapy versus Eye Movement Desensitization and Reprocessing therapy versus waitlist in the treatment of post-traumatic stress disorder: results of a randomized clinical trial. Front Psychiatry. 2024;15(1377108). doi: 10.3389/fpsyt.2024.1377108. PMID: 38651013.

Treatment Description: Group therapy following manual; sessions are directed toward teaching how to retrieve specific memories rather than over general memories, based on cue words of negative, positive, and neutral emotion levels; group interactions involved sharing examples and asking questions; homework assignments involved cue words and were reviewed at each session.
Trauma Detail (Study level): rape/sexual assault, child sexual abuse, child physical abuse, accidents, community/school violence, other (military-related, not specified)
Citation: Maxwell K, Callahan JL, Holtz P, et al. Comparative study of group treatments for posttraumatic stress disorder. Psychotherapy (Chic). 2016 Dec;53(4):433-45. doi: 10.1037/pst0000032. PMID: 26390014.

Treatment Description: Group therapy following manual by Resick et al. 2010; group members write down, in great detail, their experience of their traumatic event, and refer back to this direct account throughout treatment; sessions involved psychoeducation, writing and sharing an impact statement, discussing the meaning of their trauma, Socratic questioning of "stuck points", reading full trauma account, challenging assumptions and problematic beliefs, and behavioral assignments.
Trauma Detail (Study level): rape/sexual assault, child sexual abuse, child physical abuse, accidents, community/school violence, other (military-related, not specified)
Citation: Maxwell K, Callahan JL, Holtz P, et al. Comparative study of group treatments for posttraumatic stress disorder. Psychotherapy (Chic). 2016 Dec;53(4):433-45. doi: 10.1037/pst0000032. PMID: 26390014.

Treatment Description: Dose increased on Day 3 and Weeks 2 through 6. Treatment directed at nightmares thought to contribute to suicidality.
Dose: Prazosin initiated at 1 mg and titrated up to a maximum dose of 20 mg for men and 10 mg for women
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, other (not specified)
Citation: McCall WV, Pillai A, Case D, et al. A pilot, randomized clinical trial of bedtime doses of prazosin versus placebo in suicidal posttraumatic stress disorder patients with nightmares. J Clin Psychopharmacol. 2018 Dec;38(6):618-21. doi: 10.1097/JCP.0000000000000968. PMID: 30335633.

Treatment Description: Placebo identical to prazosin
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, other (not specified)
Citation: McCall WV, Pillai A, Case D, et al. A pilot, randomized clinical trial of bedtime doses of prazosin versus placebo in suicidal posttraumatic stress disorder patients with nightmares. J Clin Psychopharmacol. 2018 Dec;38(6):618-21. doi: 10.1097/JCP.0000000000000968. PMID: 30335633.

Treatment Description: Manualized, modified version of treatment developed by Foa et al., 1999; primary components of prolonged exposure, in vivo exposure, and cognitive restructuring; additional components included psychoeducation, breathing retraining, and homework.
Citation: McDonagh A, Friedman MJ, McHugo GJ, et al. Randomized trial of cognitive-behavioral therapy for chronic posttraumatic stress disorder in adult female survivors of childhood sexual abuse. J Consult Clin Psychol. 2005 Jun;73(3):515-24. doi: 10.1037/0022-006X.73.3.515. PMID: 15982149.

Treatment Description: Manualized, collaborative therapeutic intervention with focus on here-and-now problem-solving; main elements include psychoeducation, training in problem solving, and journal writing.
Citation: McDonagh A, Friedman MJ, McHugo GJ, et al. Randomized trial of cognitive-behavioral therapy for chronic posttraumatic stress disorder in adult female survivors of childhood sexual abuse. J Consult Clin Psychol. 2005 Jun;73(3):515-24. doi: 10.1037/0022-006X.73.3.515. PMID: 15982149.

Treatment Description: Waitlist; participants were contacted after randomization and encouraged to seek additional phone contact as needed during waiting period and were offered help seeking treatment as usual in the community (none requested such help).
Citation: McDonagh A, Friedman MJ, McHugo GJ, et al. Randomized trial of cognitive-behavioral therapy for chronic posttraumatic stress disorder in adult female survivors of childhood sexual abuse. J Consult Clin Psychol. 2005 Jun;73(3):515-24. doi: 10.1037/0022-006X.73.3.515. PMID: 15982149.

Standardized Treatment Name: Smoking cessation integrated into PTSD TAU
Treatment Description: Tobacco cessation counseling and optional  cessation medication integrated into participant's ongoing PTSD treatment. Tobacco cessation counseling delivered in individual sessions using treatment manual; core sessions included "tobacco use education, behavioral skills for quitting smoking, setting a quit date..., and relapse prevention"; follow-up visits and booster sessions in which clinicians "assessed tobacco use, reinforced abstinence and relapse prevention, and re-applied cessation treatment to continued smokers." Cessation medication following algorithm for "standard prescribing practices for nicotine replacement therapy, bupropion, and varenicline".
Treatment Duration Detail:
patients completed the initial course of smoking cessation treatment within 3 months of randomization
≥8 total sessions [5 core sessions + 3 follow-up sessions + as needed booster sessions]
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: reports by number of smoking cessation sessions received (Table 3 of publication): 0, 10.1%; 1-2, 7.1%; 3-5, 14.8%; 6-8, 20.9%; >8, 47.1%
Trauma Detail (Study level): "related to military service"
Citation: McFall ME, Saxon AJ, Malte CA, et al. Integrating tobacco cessation into mental health care for posttraumatic stress disorder: a randomized controlled trial. JAMA. 2010 Dec 8;304(22):2485-93. doi: 10.1001/jama.2010.1769. PMID: 21139110.

Standardized Treatment Name: PTSD TAU + referral to smoking cessation clinic
Treatment Description: Specialized cessation clinic (VA standard of care) that following smoking cessation practice guidelines; "provided treatment within 6 weeks of referral, prescribed cessation medications directly or through patients' primary care provider", and provided cessation treatment sessions.
Treatment Duration Detail: patients completed the initial course of smoking cessation treatment within 3 months of randomization
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: reports by number of smoking cessation sessions received (Table 3 of publication): 0, 32.6%; 1-2, 32.2%; 3-5, 24.2%; 6-8, 5.8%; >8, 5.2%
Trauma Detail (Study level): "related to military service"
Citation: McFall ME, Saxon AJ, Malte CA, et al. Integrating tobacco cessation into mental health care for posttraumatic stress disorder: a randomized controlled trial. JAMA. 2010 Dec 8;304(22):2485-93. doi: 10.1001/jama.2010.1769. PMID: 21139110.

Treatment Description: Cogntive behavioral therapy focused exclusively on headache and stress; used behavioral interventions, stress management, and cognitive therapy.
Treatment Duration Detail: 8 weekly or bi-weekly sessions, 4-8 weeks total
Citation: McGeary DD, Resick PA, Penzien DB, et al. Cognitive behavioral therapy for veterans with comorbid posttraumatic headache and posttraumatic stress disorder symptoms: a randomized clinical trial. JAMA Neurol. 2022;79(8):746-57. doi: 10.1001/jamaneurol.2022.1567. PMID: 35759281.

Treatment Description: Manualized PTSD intervention; emphasized cognitive therapy and focused on PTSD only.
Treatment Duration Detail: Erronously reported as 12-hour sessions over 6 weeks
Citation: McGeary DD, Resick PA, Penzien DB, et al. Cognitive behavioral therapy for veterans with comorbid posttraumatic headache and posttraumatic stress disorder symptoms: a randomized clinical trial. JAMA Neurol. 2022;79(8):746-57. doi: 10.1001/jamaneurol.2022.1567. PMID: 35759281.

Treatment Description: VA standard of care for mTBI; multidisciplinary treatment including pharmacotherapy, pain management, physical therapy, and complementary and integrative health treatments
Citation: McGeary DD, Resick PA, Penzien DB, et al. Cognitive behavioral therapy for veterans with comorbid posttraumatic headache and posttraumatic stress disorder symptoms: a randomized clinical trial. JAMA Neurol. 2022;79(8):746-57. doi: 10.1001/jamaneurol.2022.1567. PMID: 35759281.

Treatment Description:
Integrated CBT: manualized individual therapy for PTSD and SUD, crisis/relapse prevention, breathing retraining, PTSD symptom education, PTSD associated symptoms, cognitive restructuring, generalization training



Standard care: intensive outpatient program or methadone maintenance
Trauma Detail (Study level): child physical abuse, child sexual abuse, rape/sexual assault, community/school violence, accidents
Citation: McGovern MP, Lambert-Harris C, Alterman AI, et al. A randomized controlled trial comparing integrated cognitive behavioral therapy versus individual addiction counseling for co-occurring substance use and posttraumatic stress disorders. J Dual Diagn. 2011 Jan 1;7(4):207-27. doi: 10.1080/15504263.2011.620425. PMID: 22383864.

Treatment Description:
Individual addiction counseling: manual guided therapy targeting substance use only, "designed to be integrated into an addiction treatment or methadone maintenance programs"; consists of 5 modules: treatment initiation; early abstinence; maintaining abstinence; recovery; termination.



Standard care: intensive outpatient program or methadone maintenance
Trauma Detail (Study level): child physical abuse, child sexual abuse, rape/sexual assault, community/school violence, accidents
Citation: McGovern MP, Lambert-Harris C, Alterman AI, et al. A randomized controlled trial comparing integrated cognitive behavioral therapy versus individual addiction counseling for co-occurring substance use and posttraumatic stress disorders. J Dual Diagn. 2011 Jan 1;7(4):207-27. doi: 10.1080/15504263.2011.620425. PMID: 22383864.

Treatment Description:
Integrated CBT: manualized individual therapy for PTSD and SUD; 3 main components are: education, mindful relaxation, and flexible thinking.



Standard care: intensive outpatient program, includes individual and group therapy and medication management
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: Study reports on assessment completion only, no information on treatment completion; treatment completers described in secondary publication (Meier, 2015) but sum of N completed and N drop out for each group is more than reported N randomized in any of the publications (reports completers n=62, dropouts n=29)

Individual addiction counseling: manual guided individual therapy focused only on substance use and recovery (doesn't directly address PTSD); modules included: treatment initiation, early abstinence, maintaining abstinence, and recovery; adaptation of "individual drug counseling (IDC) from the NIDA Cocaine Collaborative Study and Twelve-Step facilitation (TSF) from the NIAAA Project Match".

Treatment Description: Standard care: intensive outpatient program, includes individual and group therapy and medication management

Treatment Description: High-intensity interval-based cycle exercise training; 30-second high intensity cycling ergometer bouts followed by a 1-minute active recovery interval for first 2 weeks, followed by increase to 10 60-second bouts. All sessions started with a 3-minute warm-up and ended with a 2-minute cool down. Participants did not talk with research staff or listen to music during exercise.
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: treatment completion = "received allocated intervention" are those allocated minus did not receive allocated intervention
Trauma Detail (Study level): Rape/sexual assault; Accidents; Community/school violence; Other ("child abuse" not further specified, "other")
Citation: McGranahan MJ, O'Connor PJ. Effect of high-intensity interval training exercise on sleep quality in women with probable post-traumatic stress disorder: A pilot randomized controlled trial. Sleep Med. 2025 May;129:245-256. doi: 10.1016/j.sleep.2025.02.029. Epub 2025 Feb 21. PMID: 40056660.

Treatment Description: Target memories selected and saccadic eye movements used to desensitize, substituting positive for negative beliefs and eliminating negative body sensations

Treatment Description: Included initial trauma interview and breathing retraining; in vivo exposure homework; and imaginal exposure during treatment sessions

Treatment Description: Manualized treatment; initial sessions focused on rationale for therapy, meditation and attentional control with autonomic control using biofeedback (J&J Engineering Biofeedback system), skill practice during trauma recall, and discussion of PTSD symptoms; remaining sessions focused on exposure using virtual reality simulation with three-dimensional visual scenarios and relevant sounds, and cognitive restructuring conducted at the end of each session.
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: Study reports "all participants participated in treatment"; also reports all in VR-GET completed post-treatment assessment, but separate from treatment
Citation: McLay RN, Wood DP, Webb-Murphy JA, et al. A randomized, controlled trial of virtual reality-graded exposure therapy for post-traumatic stress disorder in active duty service members with combat-related post-traumatic stress disorder. Cyberpsychol Behav Soc Netw. 2011 Apr;14(4):223-9. doi: 10.1089/cyber.2011.0003. PMID: 21332375.

Treatment Description: TAU included any of the regular services available at the Naval Medical Center San Diego and Naval Hospital Camp Pendleton, including PTSD treatment with medication and/or therapy (individual and/or group).

Treatment Description: In vivo exposure using virtual reality with computer-simulation and head-mounted display with optional vibration and smells; this exposure combined with participant recounting traumatic experience wile confronting simulated aspects of that trauma in virtual reality with increasing intensity throughout therapy; homework for confronting real life stresses in vivo; cognitive reframing, discussion, and symptom monitoring at each session.
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: Study reports attrition from measurement; performed analysis of treatment completers (completed at least 8 sessions) but data not provided
Citation: McLay RN, Baird A, Webb-Murphy J, et al. A randomized, head-to-head study of virtual reality exposuretherapy for posttraumatic stress disorder. Cyberpsychol Behav Soc Netw. 2017 Apr;20(4):218-24. doi: 10.1089/cyber.2016.0554. PMID: 28394217.

Treatment Description: Exposure therapy following the same protocol as virtual reality exposure therapy but without virtual reality headset or other immersive technology; instead still images were viewed on standard computer screen for participant to focus on during in-session exposure.
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: Study reports attrition from measurement; performed analysis of treatment completers (completed at least 8 sessions) but data not provided
Citation: McLay RN, Baird A, Webb-Murphy J, et al. A randomized, head-to-head study of virtual reality exposuretherapy for posttraumatic stress disorder. Cyberpsychol Behav Soc Netw. 2017 Apr;20(4):218-24. doi: 10.1089/cyber.2016.0554. PMID: 28394217.

Treatment Description: A 10-session self-guided online program that follows the prolonged exposure protocol, with therapist faciitation through asynchronous feedback after each session and scheduled phone calls.
Trauma Detail (Study level): Inclusion required exposure to a Criterion A combat-related traumatic event but index trauma could be non-combat-related

A non-trauma focused manualized therapy designed to help patients disclose and problem solve current life problems that may or may not

Treatment Name: Renew smartphone application without coaching support
Treatment Description: Smartphone application focusing on exposure therapy and social support for users to self-manage PTSD symptoms; includes 2 primary exposure components: process (imaginal exposure) and approach (guided in vivo exposure); also includes psychoeducation, self-care, and a support function allowing users to invite support persons to a support team in the application.

Number of points: median (IQR) 155 (50-140)

Treatment Description:
Variable-length written exposure therapy delivered online with peer coach support. WET adapted to "(a) delivery through an online program, (b) typing the trauma narrative instead of writing it by hand, (c) the use of peer coaches rather than therapists, and (d) variable length treatment between four and eight sessions", exposure was related to participant's worst (index) traumatic event. Treatment included 30-minute self-guided exposure sessions with participant typing their narrative into the program and reported SUDS before and after the exercise, and a brief (5-15 minute) online chat with a peer coach before and after each session and coaches reviewed the narrative prior to the next session. Sessions could be completed at any time during a 10-week window, with participants encouraged to complete multiple sessions per week (up to 1 session per day). If the participant's PCL-5 score was 21 or lower, the next session was the final session.
Due to limited availability of peer coaches midway through the study, a change was made allowing participants to skip the the presession and/or postsession chat with peer coach and were provided text instructional information and reminders; this was nonpersonalized and based on session number rather than individualized based on the narrative.
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: of randomized sample
Psychotherapy Sessions Completed Detail:
NR by group
overall randomized sample: 2.46 (SD 3.26)
participants who initiated treatment (n=62): 4.92 (SD 3.02)
Citation: McLean CP, Malek N, Straud CL. A pilot randomized controlled trial of online written exposure therapy delivered by peer coaches to veterans with posttraumatic stress disorder. J Trauma Stress. 2024 Feb 13. doi: 10.1002/jts.23020. Epub ahead of print. PMID: 38348490.

Treatment Description: Variable-length verbal exposure therapy delivered online with peer coach support. Treatment the same as for Arm A (WET) but with trauma narrative through self-guided verbal recounting, which was converted to a written account through text to type software for the peer coach to review.

Treatment Description:
Interpersonal Psychotherapy delivered by non-specialist therapists; IPT "helps patients improve social functioning and manage interpersonal crises characterized as grief, role dispute, or role transition, by building social skills and gathering social support"



Treatment as usual: HIV clinic services and providers available as needed; "TAU resources for HIV+GBV+ women included informal counseling and HIV treatment adherence counseling, medical professionals, community elders, church leaders, police [e.g., GBV legal issues], and pro bono legal aid." No explicit, evidence-based mental health treatment was provided.
Citation: Meffert SM, Neylan TC, McCulloch CE, et al. Arm N Randomized Detail: n=206 randomized, n=184 completed baseline interview
Treatment Description: Care manager provided active patient education and engagement using NIMH PTSD brochures and motivational interviewing and community resource support and facilitated continuity of care via ≥ 15 phone or in-person contacts (an initial in-person visit in conjunction with a scheduled primary care medical visit and up to 14 additional follow-up contacts by phone or in-person, over 1 year). Also, Primary Care Clinician education about trauma, PTSD and evidence-based psychopharmacology, including 2-hour training onsite and 2 booster training sessions via Webcast; laminated medication guide; patients provided with NIMH brochure
Completed Treatment Percent Detail:

Treatment Description: Collaborative care including regular contacts with a care manager (2 in-person and 6 by phone), patient education on PTSD, motivational interviewing to boost self-efficacy and coping, and linking to community resources. Model adapted from the Violence and Stress Assessment (ViStA) study for use with African American patients in Federally Qualified Health Centers, using a community workgroup to improve cultural sensitivity. Program includes integrated behavioral health. Also included all elements of Enhanced Usual Care.

treatment completion not defined; does report study/assessment completion (n=16). Completed initial in-person visit with care manager: 78.95% (15/19)

Treatment Description: Self-directed online tool (web or mobile app) addressing PTSD symptoms. Translated into Arabic with culturally-relevant pictures. Participants chose how much to use the program and which tools to use.

Standardized Treatment Name: Concurrent Treatment for PTSD and Substance Use Disorder Using Prolonged Exposure (COPE)
Treatment Description:
COPE: modified version of Concurrent Treatment of PTSD and Cocaine Dependence. "The version of COPE used in present study represents an integration of existing evidence-based manualized CBT interventions for PTSD and substance dependence... Treatment components include motivational enhancement and CBT for substance use (sessions 1-4 and throughout); psychoeducation relating to both disorders and their interaction (sessions 1-4); in vivo exposure (sessions 5-12); imaginal exposure (sessions 6-12); and cognitive therapy for PTSD (sessions 8-12). The final session (session 13) is dedicated to providing a review of the treatment, devising an after-care plan, and termination of therapy."



Usual Treatment: participants could engage in usual treatment for substance dependence "currently available in the community, including outpatient counseling, inpatient or outpatient detoxification, residential rehabilitation, and pharmacotherapies (e.g.,, methadone, buprenorphine, buprenorphine plus naloxone, naltrexone)."
Treatment Duration Detail: Intended to be delivered in 13 weekly sessions, but actual treatment duration ranged from 0 to 271 days (median 71 days)
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, child sexual abuse, rape/sexual assault, accidents, community/school violence, natural or manmade disasters, terrorism/political violence/forced displacement, other (not specified)
Citation: Mills KL, Teesson M, Back SE, et al. Integrated exposure-based therapy for co-occurring posttraumatic stress disorder and substance dependence: a randomized controlled trial. JAMA. 2012 Aug 15;308(7):690-9. doi: 10.1001/jama.2012.9071. PMID: 22893166..

Treatment Description:
3,4-methylenedioxymethamphetamine (MDMA) + therapy following the MDMA-assisted therapy treatment manual. Therapy was 



inner-directed and designed to invite inquiry and to facilitate therapeutic effect by providing support for approaching difficult material. Three experimental sessions with MDMA, overnight stay after each with first integration session the following morning and 2 more integration sessions over the following 3 to 4 weeks.
Dose: Single divided dose of 80 to 180mg
Session Length:
Experimental sessions: 8 hours



Integration sessions: 90 minutes
Frequency:
Experimental sessions: 3 sessions approximately 4 weeks apart



Integration sessions: 9 sessions, approximately 1 week apart
Treatment Duration Detail: 3 experimental sessions with MDMA and 9 integration sessions
Trauma Detail (Study level): Combat-related; Other ("developmental trauma", "multiple trauma")
Citation: Mitchell JM, Bogenschutz M, Lilienstein A, et al. MDMA-assisted therapy for severe PTSD: a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled phase 3 study. Nat Med. 2021 Jun;27(6):1025-33. doi: 10.1038/s41591-021-01336-3. PMID: 33972795.

Treatment Description: Psychotherapy with concomitant placebo (lactose) administration: 2 psychotherapy sessions with placebo administration, 11 non-drug psychotherapy sessions with option of additional integration sessions as needed.
Dose:
Dose: NA







Psychotherapy: 90 minutes







Placebo-assisted psychotherapy sessions: 8 to 10 hours with overnight stay
