Treatment Description: MDMA, a psychoactive compound scheduled in the U.S. as a drug of abuse (ecstasy), and also used as an adjunct to psychotherapy. Patients received both MDMA-assisted "non-directive or client-directed" therapy sessions, following a treatment manual with a male or female co-therapy team, and additional non-drug therapy sessions. Treatment sessions of (double blind stage): 3 preparatory sessions with co-therapy team; 2 MDMA experimental sessions about one month (3-5 weeks) apart, each experimental session included an overnight stay with an integration session the next morning, daily phone contact for the following week, and 2 more integration psychotherapy sessions (approximately weekly).
Dose:
Session length: MDMA sessions 8 hours, nondrug (preparatory) sessions 90 minutes

Dose: 125 mg (followed 1.5 to 2 hours later by an optional supplemental dose of half the initial dose)
Treatment Duration Detail: primary endpoint was 1 month after 2nd MDMA session; treatment duration entered as approximation (3-5 weeks between experimental session 1 and 2, plus 1 week for phone contact and 2 weeks for integration sessions)
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: assessment prior to crossover
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, other (firefighter/police officer)
Citation: Mithoefer MC, Mithoefer AT, Feduccia AA, et al. 3,4-methylenedioxymethamphetamine (MDMA)-assisted psychotherapy for post-traumatic stress disorder in military veterans, firefighters, and police officers: a randomised, double-blind, dose-response, phase 2 clinical trial. Lancet Psychiatry. 2018 Jun;5(6):486-97. doi: 10.1016/S2215-0366(18)30135-4. PMID: 29728331.

Treatment Description: Drug dose titrated upward by 25-50 mg increments weekly over 8 weeks to maximum tolerated dose or "until complete or near-complete efficacy achieved" or maximum allowed dose reached, then maintained for 4 more weeks. Preceded by washout phase (up to 30 days) for protocol-prohibited medications if indicated.
Dose:
25 to 400 mg/day
titration: started at 25 mg/day, increased by 25 to 50 mg increments weekly over up to 8 weeks based on efficacy and tolerability; maximum dose 400 mg/day
Treatment Duration Detail:
12 weeks total
titration: ≤8 weeks maintenance: ≥4 weeks (remainder of duration)
Dose at Study End Point Detail: Median 100 mg/day, range 25 to 400 mg/day
Citation: Monga V, Petty F, Padala K, et al. Topiramate monotherapy for civilian posttraumatic stress disorder: a controlled pilot study. Prim Care Companion CNS Disord. 2023 Oct 19;25(5):19. doi: 10.4088/PCC.23m03555. PMID: 37857291.

Treatment Description: Includes 3 phases that include both in- and out-of-session exercises. Phase I: establishing rationale for therapy and relationship safety. Phase 2: Avoidance. Phase 3: Influence of trauma on relationship trust, control, emotional closeness, and physical intimacy
Frequency: Twice weekly for phases 1 and 2, weekly during phase 3.
Trauma Detail (Study level): rape/sexual assault, child sexual abuse, accidents, illness/medical procedure, combat-related, community/school violence, other (not specified)
Citation: Monson CM, Fredman SJ, Macdonald A, et al. Effect of cognitive-behavioral couple therapy for PTSD: a randomized controlled trial. JAMA. 2012 Aug 15;308(7):700-9. doi: 10.1001/jama.2012.9307. PMID: 22893167.

Treatment Description: Wait for 3 months before receiving treatment
Trauma Detail (Study level): rape/sexual assault, child sexual abuse, accidents, illness/medical procedure, combat-related, community/school violence, other (not specified)

Treatment Description: Trauma-focused therapy delivered in a couple therapy format and consisting of three phases: "(1) psychoeducation about PTSD and conflict management skills, (2) communication skills training and behavioural exposures designed to overcome avoidance, and (3) making new meaning of the trauma and addressing cognitions that maintain PTSD and/or relationship conflict via a dyadic cognitive strategy designed to increase cognitive flexibility in each partner.
Citation: Monson CM, Pukay-Martin ND, Wagner AC, Crenshaw AO, Blount TH, Schobitz RP, Dondanville KA, Young-McCaughan S, Mintz J, Riggs DS, Brundige A, Hembree EA, Litz BT, Roache JD, Yarvis JS, Peterson AL; STRONG STAR Consortium. Cognitive-behavioural conjoint therapy versus prolonged exposure for PTSD in military service members and veterans: results and lessons from a randomized controlled trial. Eur J Psychotraumatol. 2024;15(1):2330305. doi: 10.1080/20008066.2024.2330305. Epub 2024 Apr 8. PMID: 38590124; PMCID: PMC11005874.

Treatment Description: Trauma-focused therapy consisting of "imaginal exposure to specific traumatic memories and in vivo exposures designed to overcome avoidance of specific trauma reminders."
Citation: Monson CM, Pukay-Martin ND, Wagner AC, Crenshaw AO, Blount TH, Schobitz RP, Dondanville KA, Young-McCaughan S, Mintz J, Riggs DS, Brundige A, Hembree EA, Litz BT, Roache JD, Yarvis JS, Peterson AL; STRONG STAR Consortium. Treatment Description: Training group sessions following manual; aim of treatment is to enhance the specificity with which participants retrieve personal events from their autobiographical memory; uses concepts of specific vs over general memories; sessions involve training using neutral, positive, and negative cues, recall exercises and homework.
Citation: Moradi AR, Moshirpanahi S, Parhon H, et al. A pilot randomized controlled trial investigating the efficacy of Memory Specificity Training in improving symptoms of posttraumatic stress disorder. Behav Res Ther. 2014 May;56:68-74. doi: 10.1016/j.brat.2014.03.002. PMID: 24705337.

Treatment Description: No additional contact.
Citation: Moradi AR, Moshirpanahi S, Parhon H, et al. A pilot randomized controlled trial investigating the efficacy of Memory Specificity Training in improving symptoms of posttraumatic stress disorder. Behav Res Ther. 2014 May;56:68-74. doi: 10.1016/j.brat.2014.03.002. PMID: 24705337.

Treatment Description: Workbook-based program intended to improved autobiographical memory processes, by improving access to emotionally positive or benign memories and ability to move between specific and general memory. No retrieval of traumatic memories. Trains three core skills: balancing, elaboration, and flexibility.  Initial brief in-person orientation, which may be delivered by someone without mental healthcare training, followed by 8 independent sessions using a paper workbook. Participant may contact researcher with questions via text message.
Treatment Duration Detail:
8 total workbook sessions



Pre-intervention to post-intervention: mean 31.7 days
Citation: Moradi AR, Piltan M, Choobin MH, et al. Proof of concept for the autobiographical memory flexibility (MemFlex) intervention for posttraumatic stress disorder. Clin Psychol Sci. 2021 Jul;9(4):686-98. doi: 10.1177/2167702620982576. PMID: 34354873.

Treatment Description: Initial in-person meeting, then no contact until follow-up assessments; same number of face-to-face appointments as MemFlex intervention. Received MemFlex intervention after 3-month follow-up.
Treatment Duration Detail:
For overall sample:
Pre-intervention to post-intervention: mean 31.7 days (range = 28–36); post-intervention to follow-up: mean 92.4 days (range = 84–103)
Citation: Moradi AR, Piltan M, Choobin MH, et al. Proof of concept for the autobiographical memory flexibility (MemFlex) intervention for posttraumatic stress disorder. Clin Psychol Sci. 2021 Jul;9(4):686-98. doi: 10.1177/2167702620982576. PMID: 34354873.

Treatment Description: In-home-in-person individual PE; includes psychoeducation, breathing retraining, imaginal and in vivo exposure. Number of sessions dependent on treatment response - early responders "could graduate before attending 15 sessions if they completed six or seven sessions of PE and had PCL‐5 scores <21 for two consecutive sessions" or PCL-5 score <30 (cutoff score for PCL-5 revised during study).
Citation: Morland L, Mackintosh MA, Glassman L, et al. Home-based delivery of variable length prolonged exposure therapy: a comparison of clinical efficacy between service modalities. 2019 Dec 24. doi: 10.1002/da.22979. PMID: 31872563.

Treatment Description: Brief version of manualized conjoint CBT protocol, conducted in VA office setting. Original protocol included 15 sessions in 3 phases. Brief version includes phases 1 and 2 (7 sessions) plus an eighth session corresponding to the final session in the original protocol. Phase 1 includes psychoeducation on PTSD and relationships, anger, and conflict management. Phase 2 builds communication skills and emotional intimacy, and also includes cognitive challenging of trauma-related thoughts.
Completed Treatment Definition: Seven of eight sessions considered "meaningful dose"
Citation: Morland LA, Knopp KC, Khalifian CE, et al. A randomized trial of brief couple therapy for PTSD and relationship satisfaction. J Consult Clin Psychol. 2022 May;90(5):392-404. doi: 10.1037/ccp0000731. PMID: 35604746.

Treatment Description: Brief version of manualized conjoint CBT protocol, conducted remotely. Original version included 15 sessions in 3 phases. Phase 1 includes psychoeducation on PTSD and relationships, anger, and conflict management. Phase 2 builds communication skills and emotional intimacy, and also includes cognitive challenging of trauma-related thoughts.
Completed Treatment Definition: Seven of eight sessions considered "meaningful dose"

Treatment Description:
C-METTA is an intervention combining cognitive techniques and loving-kindness meditation. In-person treatments for 6 weeks (treatment phase) followed by a 4-week self-guided practice phase.
Treatment phase: Inital sessions include psychoeducation on trauma-related guilt and shame, and Socratic questioning to restructure guilt/shame cognitions. Later sessions combine cognitive techniques with loving-kindness meditation, directed towards oneself, a specific "benefactor" in the patient's life, and towards all human beings. Up to 2 additional 50-minute sessions were allowed "to address severe comorbid symptoms and problems" at therapist discretion. Audiotapes provided for home practice.
Pracice phase: Participants were asked to continue self-guided meditation for 4 weeks after the in-person intervention was complete.
Treatment Duration Detail: 6 weekly in-person sessions (treatment phase) followed by 4 weeks of self-guided home meditation (practice phase)
Completed Treatment Definition: Attended all 6 treatment sessions and completed the 4-week practice phase
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: No
Psychotherapy Sessions Completed Detail: all participants completed the 6 sessions in treatment phase, "half of the patients received additional sessions" (overall mean number of sessions NR)
Trauma Detail (Study level): Child physical abuse; Child sexual abuse; Rape/sexual assault;  Community/school violence; Other (not specified)
Citation: Muller-Engelmann M, Bahnemann L, Kummerle S. The effects of a combination of cognitive interventions and loving-kindness meditations (C-METTA) on guilt, shame and PTSD symptoms: results from a pilot randomized controlled trial. Eur J Psychotraumatol. 2024;15(1):2308439. doi: 10.1080/20008066.2024.2308439. PMID: 38323870.

Treatment Description: Waitlist
Trauma Detail (Study level): Child physical abuse; Child sexual abuse; Rape/sexual assault;  Community/school violence; Other (not specified)

Treatment Description: Trauma-focused individual therapy; sessions included: psychoeducation about trauma and related symptoms, treatment rationale and description, breathing retraining, in vivo exposure, imaginal exposure, and discussion/processing, as well as in vivo homework assignments between sessions.
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: reports study/assessment completion only, no information on treatment completion
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, terrorism/political violence
Citation: Nacasch N, Foa EB, Huppert JD, et al. Prolonged exposure therapy for combat- and terror-related posttraumatic stress disorder: a randomized control comparison with treatment as usual. J Clin Psychiatry. 2011 Sep;72(9):1174-80. doi: 10.4088/JCP.09m05682blu. PMID: 21208581.

Treatment Description: Usual treatment with nondirective, psychodynamically oriented therapy and/or medication and counseling; therapy delivered by the same therapists as the PE intervention and was not focused on the traumatic event.
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: reports study/assessment completion only, no information on treatment completion
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, terrorism/political violence
Citation: Nacasch N, Foa EB, Huppert JD, et al. Prolonged exposure therapy for combat- and terror-related posttraumatic stress disorder: a randomized control comparison with treatment as usual. J Clin Psychiatry. 2011 Sep;72(9):1174-80. doi: 10.4088/JCP.09m05682blu. PMID: 21208581.

Treatment Description: Short-duration PE therapy according to treatment manual for PE (Foa et al., 2007), with imaginal exposure portion limited to 20 minutes of a 60-minute session. The first 2 sessions (pre-randomization) included treatment rationale, information gathering about trauma history, most disturbing trauma, breathing retraining, construction of in vivo exposure hierarchy and homework assignments. Remaining sessions (postrandomization) included homework review, imaginal exposure for 20 minutes followed by processing, and assignment of in vivo exposure homework.
Session Length:
Session length: 60 minutes



Imaginal exposure portion: 20 minutes
Completed Treatment Definition: Supervisor and therapist agreed that the patient's self-reported symptoms of PTSD remained low and stable (minimum 10, maximum 15 sessions)
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, rape/sexual assault, child sexual abuse, community/school violence, terrorism/political violence/forced displacement, accidents
Citation: Nacasch N, Huppert JD, Su Y-J, et al. Are 60-minute prolonged exposure sessions with 20-minute imaginal exposure to traumatic memories sufficient to successfully treat PTSD? A randomized nonininferiority clinical trial. Behav Ther. 2015 May;46(3):328-41. doi: 10.1016/j.beth.2014.12.002. PMID: 25892169.

Treatment Description: Long-duration (typical) PE therapy according to treatment manual for PE (Foa et al., 2007), with imaginal exposure portion of 40 minutes and a 90-minute session. The first 2 sessions (prerandomization) included treatment rationale, information gathering about trauma history, most disturbing trauma, breathing retraining, construction of in vivo exposure hierarchy and homework assignments. Remaining sessions (postrandomization) included homework review, imaginal exposure for 40 minutes followed by processing, and assignment of in vivo exposure homework.
Session Length:
Session length: 90 minutes



Imaginal exposure portion: 40 minutes
Completed Treatment Definition: Supervisor and therapist agreed that the patient's self-reported symptoms of PTSD remained low and stable (minimum 10, maximum 15 sessions)
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, rape/sexual assault, child sexual abuse, community/school violence, terrorism/political violence/forced displacement, accidents
Citation: Nacasch N, Huppert JD, Su Y-J, et al. Are 60-minute prolonged exposure sessions with 20-minute imaginal exposure to traumatic memories sufficient to successfully treat PTSD? A randomized nonininferiority clinical trial. Behav Ther. 2015 May;46(3):328-41. doi: 10.1016/j.beth.2014.12.002. PMID: 25892169.

Treatment Description: Individual, past-focused cognitive-behavioral therapy for PTSD/SUD; covered 17 topics relevant to both PTSD and SUD. Both interventions included "a check-in, inspirational quotation, handouts, and check-out"; participants also allowed to "attend nonstudy therapies and supports including 12-step self-help groups, except for current PTSD or PTSD/SUD evidence-based therapy models."
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: reports study/assessment completion only; treatment attendance reported for overall arm (67% of available CC sessions attended), and a note that one participant attended no sessions (intervention arm of this participant not provided)
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, rape/sexual assault, other (NR)
Citation: Najavits LM, Krinsley K, Waring ME, et al. A randomized controlled trial for veterans with PTSD and substance use disorder: creating change versus seeking safety. Subst Use Misuse. 2018 Sep 19;53(11):1788-800. doi: 10.1080/10826084.2018.1432653. PMID: 29461920.

Treatment Description: Individual, present-focused cognitive-behavioral therapy for PTSD/SUD; 17 of the 25 topics in Seeking Safety were used in order to keep dose of therapy the same between interventions (the 17 topics were same for all participants). Both interventions included "a check-in, inspirational quotation, handouts, and check-out"; participants also allowed to "attend nonstudy therapies and supports including 12-step self-help groups, except for current PTSD or PTSD/SUD evidence-based therapy models."
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: reports study/assessment completion only; treatment attendance reported for overall arm (68% of available SS sessions attended), and a note that one participant attended no sessions (intervention arm of this participant not provided)
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, rape/sexual assault, other (NR)
Citation: Najavits LM, Krinsley K, Waring ME, et al. A randomized controlled trial for veterans with PTSD and substance use disorder: creating change versus seeking safety. Subst Use Misuse. 2018 Sep 19;53(11):1788-800. doi: 10.1080/10826084.2018.1432653. PMID: 29461920.

Treatment Description: Low-frequency rTMS to the right prefrontal cortex

Completed Treatment Percent Detail: publication reports for study completers only, dropouts were before or during treatment period (all in active arm) so appears study completers also completed treatment
Trauma Detail (Study level): intimate partner violence, accidents, community/school violence
Citation: Nam D-H, Pae C-U, Chae J-H. Low-frequency, repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation for the treatment of patients with posttraumatic stress disorder: a double-blind, sham-controlled study. Clin Psychopharmacol Neurosci. 2013 Aug;11(2):96-102. doi: 10.9758/cpn.2013.11.2.96. PMID: 24023554.

Treatment Description: Identical rTMS treatment except lateral wing of coil raised 90 degrees off the head, with edge of medial wing of the coil still touching scalp.

Trauma Detail (Study level): intimate partner violence, accidents, community/school violence
Citation: Nam D-H, Pae C-U, Chae J-H. Low-frequency, repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation for the treatment of patients with posttraumatic stress disorder: a double-blind, sham-controlled study. Clin Psychopharmacol Neurosci. 2013 Aug;11(2):96-102. doi: 10.9758/cpn.2013.11.2.96. PMID: 24023554.

Treatment Description:
TAU + mandala coloring
Mandala coloring: group sessions following group therapy. A 1-hour training lecture on art-making was given prior to intervention, covering mandala designs and instructions on coloring. For mandala sessions, participants were provided identical sets of uncolored mandala designs and crayons to color one mandala per session.
TAU: group therapy as routine care in which psychologist taught self-care, stress and emotion management, and exercises such as muscle relaxation, slow breathing, and body scanning.
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: no information on treatment completion, only reports participants "received allocated intervention"(n=42)
Citation: Nasiri MA, Sajadi SA, Farsi Z, Heidarieh M. The Effects of Mandala Coloring and Free Coloring on Mindfulness and the Score of Posttraumatic Stress Disorder in Veterans: A Randomized Controlled Trial. Holist Nurs Pract. 2024 Aug 5. doi: 10.1097/HNP.0000000000000680. Epub ahead of print. PMID: 39102487.

Treatment Description:
TAU + free coloring
Free coloring: group sessions following group therapy. No training lectuire given. Participants were  provided blank paper and crayons to color freely for each session.
TAU: group therapy as routine care in which psychologist taught self-care, stress and emotion management, and exercises such as muscle relaxation, slow breathing, and body scanning.
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: no information on treatment completion, only reports participants "received allocated intervention"(n=42)
Citation: Nasiri MA, Sajadi SA, Farsi Z, Heidarieh M. The Effects of Mandala Coloring and Free Coloring on Mindfulness and the Score of Posttraumatic Stress Disorder in Veterans: A Randomized Controlled Trial. Holist Nurs Pract. 2024 Aug 5. doi: 10.1097/HNP.0000000000000680. Epub ahead of print. PMID: 39102487.

Treatment Description: Second-generation antipsychotic augmentation; all patients also continued baseline antidepressant treatment for PTSD. Following a 2-week placebo lead-in, aripiprazole 5 mg/day taken for 2 weeks, 5 to 10 mg/day for 2 weeks, 5 to 15 mg/day for 2 weeks, and finally 5 to 20 mg/day taken for 2 weeks.
Dose: Initiated at 5 mg, titrated to maximum 20 mg
Citation: Naylor JC, Kilts JD, Bradford DW, et al. A pilot randomized placebo-controlled trial of adjunctive aripiprazole for chronic PTSD in US military veterans resistant to antidepressant treatment. Int. Clin Psychopharmacol. 2015;30(3):167-74. doi: 10.1097/YIC.0000000000000061. PMID: 25647451.

Treatment Description: Augmentation with placebo capsules identical to active drug; all patients also continued baseline antidepressant treatment for PTSD. Double-blind treatment followed a 2-week placebo lead-in.
Citation: Naylor JC, Kilts JD, Bradford DW, et al. A pilot randomized placebo-controlled trial of adjunctive aripiprazole for chronic PTSD in US military veterans resistant to antidepressant treatment. Int. Clin Psychopharmacol. 2015;30(3):167-74. doi: 10.1097/YIC.0000000000000061. PMID: 25647451.

Treatment Description: Carried out according to manual by Schauer et al. (2005). Participants construct a chronological account of his own biography. Then the counselor discussed traumatic experiences with focus on current emotional, physiological, cognitive, and behavioral reactions to the experience until habituation of the emotional reactions
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: Study reports 4% "dropped out of NET treatment" in abstract; study results show n=4 (3.6%) refused or dropped out of treatment, describes remainder as treatment completers
Citation: Neuner F, Onyut PL, Ertl V, et al. Treatment of posttraumatic stress disorder by trained lay counselors in an African refugee settlement: a randomized controlled trial. J Consult Clin Psychol. 2008 Aug;76(4):686-94. doi: 10.1037/0022-006X.76.4.686. PMID: 18665696.

Treatment Description: Counselors address psychological and social needs expressed by the participant by relating current problems to past traumatic experiences. Counselors can use narrative exposure of traumatic events as part of therapy, but is not required
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: Study reports n=22 did not complete therapy, describes remainder as treatment completers
Citation: Neuner F, Onyut PL, Ertl V, et al. Treatment of posttraumatic stress disorder by trained lay counselors in an African refugee settlement: a randomized controlled trial. J Consult Clin Psychol. 2008 Aug;76(4):686-94. doi: 10.1037/0022-006X.76.4.686. PMID: 18665696.

Neuner F, Onyut PL, Ertl V, et al. Treatment of posttraumatic stress disorder by trained lay counselors in an African refugee settlement: a randomized controlled trial. J Consult Clin Psychol. 2008 Aug;76(4):686-94. doi: 10.1037/0022-006X.76.4.686. PMID: 18665696.

Treatment Description: Intervention according to manual by Schauer et al. (2005) containing psychoeducation and participants narrating their biography
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: Study reports n=2 dropped out, neither completed NET, flow diagram shows only these 2 as discontinued intervention
Citation: Neuner F, Kurreck S, Ruf M, et al. Can asylum-seekers with posttraumatic stress disorder be successfully treated? A randomized controlled pilot study. Cogn Behav Ther. 2010;39(2):81-91. doi: 10.1080/16506070903121042. PMID: 19816834.

Treatment Description: Participants encouraged to continue their current treatment or were referred to institutions of public mental health care
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: no set treatment (TAU), study states "except for one patient, all patients in the TAU condition received treatment"
Citation: Neuner F, Kurreck S, Ruf M, et al. Can asylum-seekers with posttraumatic stress disorder be successfully treated? A randomized controlled pilot study. Cogn Behav Ther. 2010;39(2):81-91. doi: 10.1080/16506070903121042. PMID: 19816834.

Treatment Description: Centrally acting alpha-2 receptor agonist
Dose: 0.5 mg at week 1, titrated by 0.5 mg per week up to 1 to 3 mg
Citation: Neylan TC, Lenoci M, Samuelson KW, et al. No improvement of posttraumatic stress disorder symptoms with guanfacine treatment. Am J Psychiatry. 2006 Dec;163(12):2186-8. doi: 10.1176/appi.ajp.163.12.2186. PMID: 17151174.

Treatment Description: Placebo
Citation: Neylan TC, Lenoci M, Samuelson KW, et al. No improvement of posttraumatic stress disorder symptoms with guanfacine treatment. Am J Psychiatry. 2006 Dec;163(12):2186-8. doi: 10.1176/appi.ajp.163.12.2186. PMID: 17151174.

Treatment Description: Neurofeedback training; participants down-regulated alpha amplitude (8–12 Hz) using real-time EEG feedback signal from the midline parietal cortex (Pz- electrode). Incorporated  interactive gaming with visual and auditory cues indicating when participants were suppressing alpha amplitude.
Trauma Detail (Study level): Rape/sexual assault; Community/school violence; Other (first responder occupational trauma, military occupational trauma)
Citation: Nicholson AA, Ros T, Densmore M, et al. A randomized, controlled trial of alpha-rhythm EEG neurofeedback in posttraumatic stress disorder: a preliminary investigation showing evidence of decreased PTSD symptoms and restored default mode and salience network connectivity using fMRI. Neuroimage Clin. 2020;28:102490. doi: 10.1016/j.nicl.2020.102490. PMID: 33395981.

Treatment Description: Participants given the same instructions as experimental group, but received sham NFB signal (replayed feedback signal from a successful participant in the experimental group).
Trauma Detail (Study level): Rape/sexual assault; Community/school violence; Other (first responder occupational trauma, military occupational trauma)
Citation: Nicholson AA, Ros T, Densmore M, et al. A randomized, controlled trial of alpha-rhythm EEG neurofeedback in posttraumatic stress disorder: a preliminary investigation showing evidence of decreased PTSD symptoms and restored default mode and salience network connectivity using fMRI. Neuroimage Clin. 2020;28:102490. doi: 10.1016/j.nicl.2020.102490. PMID: 33395981.

Treatment Description: Sitting meditation with eyes closed to quiet thoughts; PTSD symptoms not specifically addressed. Meditation technique taught in 5 sessions on consecutive days in a group format with lectures and some one-on-one instruction. Seven group maintenance sessions taught over the rest of the 3-month period. Home practice of two 20-minute daily sessions encouraged.
Frequency: Daily for 5 days then on average every 11 days ("gradually spaced")
Trauma Detail (Study level): MST; Combat-related; Illness/medical procedure; Natural or manmade disasters; Other (life-threatening or serious injury; life-threatening illness)
Citation: Nidich S, Mills PJ, Rainforth M, et al. Non-trauma-focused meditation versus exposure therapy in veterans with post-traumatic stress disorder: a randomised controlled trial. Lancet Psychiatry. 2018 Dec;5(12):975-86. doi: 10.1016/S2215-0366(18)30384-5. PMID: 30449712.

Treatment Description: Trauma-focused behavioural treatment with graduated exposure to imaginal and in-vivo trauma experiences delivered Individually. Homework involved listening to imaginal and engaging in in-vivo exposures.
Trauma Detail (Study level): MST; Combat-related; Illness/medical procedure; Natural or manmade disasters; Other (life-threatening or serious injury; life-threatening illness)
Citation: Nidich S, Mills PJ, Rainforth M, et al. Non-trauma-focused meditation versus exposure therapy in veterans with post-traumatic stress disorder: a randomised controlled trial. Lancet Psychiatry. 2018 Dec;5(12):975-86. doi: 10.1016/S2215-0366(18)30384-5. PMID: 30449712.

Treatment Description: Health education specific to PTSD veterans, including symptoms, negative coping behaviors, and healthy lifestyle. Group sessions fostered social support and personal expression
Trauma Detail (Study level): MST; Combat-related; Illness/medical procedure; Natural or manmade disasters; Other (life-threatening or serious injury; life-threatening illness)
Citation: Nidich S, Mills PJ, Rainforth M, et al. Non-trauma-focused meditation versus exposure therapy in veterans with post-traumatic stress disorder: a randomised controlled trial. Lancet Psychiatry. 2018 Dec;5(12):975-86. doi: 10.1016/S2215-0366(18)30384-5. PMID: 30449712.

Treatment Description: Psychoeducation, imaginal exposure, cognitive restructuring and writing assignments
Trauma Detail (Study level): rape/sexual assault, accidents, natural or manmade disasters, community/school violence, other (war-related)
Citation: Nijdam MJ, Gersons BP, Reitsma JB, et al. Brief eclectic psychotherapy v. Eye Movement Desensitization and Reprocessing therapy for post-traumatic stress disorder: randomised controlled trial. Br J Psychiatry. 2012 Mar;200(3):224-31. doi: 10.1192/bjp.bp.111.099234. PMID: 22322458.

Treatment Description: During EMDR therapy, the most distressing images of the traumatic event are identified and processed consecutively. After the patient has focused on an image with the corresponding negative cognition, the most distressing emotion and the bodily location of the emotion, the patient is continuously asked to follow the therapist’s finger making saccadic movements in alternation with the patient’s own associations.
Trauma Detail (Study level): rape/sexual assault, accidents, natural or manmade disasters, community/school violence, other (war-related)
Citation: Nijdam MJ, Gersons BP, Reitsma JB, et al. Brief eclectic psychotherapy v. Eye Movement Desensitization and Reprocessing therapy for post-traumatic stress disorder: randomised controlled trial. Br J Psychiatry. 2012 Mar;200(3):224-31. doi: 10.1192/bjp.bp.111.099234. PMID: 22322458.

Treatment Description: 2 in-person sessions and 6 phone sessions; participants given Mindfulness Handbook which covered mindfulness topics: defining mindfulness, noticing sensations, noticing thoughts and emotions, beginners' mind, choice, patience, and continuing to practice; in-person sessions included mindfulness exercises; participants instructed to practice with guided mindfulness exercises on provided CD and track practice.
Session Length: Session length: 45-minute in-person sessions and 20-minute phone sessions
Participant Adherence Definition: Self-reported proportion of assigned readings completed and the amount of unguided practice
Citation: Niles BL, Klunk-Gillis J, Ryngala DJ, et al. Comparing mindfulness and psychoeducation treatments for combat-related PTSD using a telehealth approach. Psychol Trauma. 2012 Sep;4(5):538-47. doi: 10.1037/a0026161

Treatment Description: 2 in-person sessions and 6 telephone sessions; participants given PTSD Education Handbook complementing treatment and providing education on issues of trust, safety, self-care, relationships and trauma, coping and healing, change, and moving forward; treatment focused on educating participants on how PTSD may affect their lives, and encouraged reflection and gave suggestions on positive coping without specific coping techniques (no relaxation exercises or behavioral activation).
Session Length: Session length: 45-minute in-person sessions and 20-minute phone sessions
Participant Adherence Definition: Self-reported proportion of assigned readings completed
Citation: Niles BL, Klunk-Gillis J, Ryngala DJ, et al. Comparing mindfulness and psychoeducation treatments for combat-related PTSD using a telehealth approach. Psychol Trauma. 2012 Sep;4(5):538-47. doi: 10.1037/a0026161

Arm N Randomized Detail: 234 completed baseline assessment and analyzed
Treatment Description: Mobile app to administer attention-bias modification remotely, using words selected as highly threatening for individual participants. Two words presented on screen for each trial, one neutral and one threatening. Probe letter ("E" or "F")  then appears in the location of the neutral word, and participant asked to select corresponding letter at the bottom of the screen, thus directing attention away from threatening and towards neutral word stimulus. 90 trials/session. Less-threatening words used in first week, more-threatening words in second week.
Trauma Detail (Study level): Child physical abuse; Child sexual abuse; Rape/sexual assault; Accidents; Community/school violence; Natural or manmade disasters; Other ("military" not further specified, "sudden death", "sudden move/loss of possessions", "sudden abandonment", "other" not further specified)
Citation: Niles AN, Woolley JD, Tripp P, et al. Randomized controlled trial testing mobile-based attention-bias modification for posttraumatic stress using personalized word stimuli. Clin Psychol Sci. 2020 Jul;8(4):756-72. doi: 10.1177/2167702620902119. PMID: 34414018.

Arm N Randomized Detail: 219 completed baseline assessment and analyzed
Treatment Description: Mobile app to administer attention-bias modification remotely, using the same set of threat words for all participants.Two words presented on screen for each trial, one neutral and one threatening. Probe letter ("E" or "F")  then appears in the location of the neutral word, and participant asked to select corresponding letter at the bottom of the screen, thus directing attention away from threatening and towards neutral word stimulus. 90 trials/session.
Trauma Detail (Study level): Child physical abuse; Child sexual abuse; Rape/sexual assault; Accidents; Community/school violence; Natural or manmade disasters; Other ("military" not further specified, "sudden death", "sudden move/loss of possessions", "sudden abandonment", "other" not further specified)
Citation: Niles AN, Woolley JD, Tripp P, et al. Randomized controlled trial testing mobile-based attention-bias modification for posttraumatic stress using personalized word stimuli. Clin Psychol Sci. 2020 Jul;8(4):756-72. doi: 10.1177/2167702620902119. PMID: 34414018.

Arm N Randomized Detail: 236 completed baseline assessment and analyzed
Treatment Description: Mobile app presenting two neutral words for each trial. Probe letter ("E" or "F")  then appears in the location of one of the neutral words, and participant asked to select corresponding letter at the bottom of the screen. 90 trials/session.
Trauma Detail (Study level): Child physical abuse; Child sexual abuse; Rape/sexual assault; Accidents; Community/school violence; Natural or manmade disasters; Other ("military" not further specified, "sudden death", "sudden move/loss of possessions", "sudden abandonment", "other" not further specified)
Citation: Niles AN, Woolley JD, Tripp P, et al. Randomized controlled trial testing mobile-based attention-bias modification for posttraumatic stress using personalized word stimuli. Clin Psychol Sci. 2020 Jul;8(4):756-72. doi: 10.1177/2167702620902119. PMID: 34414018.

Treatment Description: Treatment followed the alpha/theta protocol by El-Hage, Quide, Radua & Olff (2013) where participants relax with eyes closed. Participants asked to recall positive memory to increase cerebral theta waves. Feedback consisted of audio of river waves representing alpha waves and ocean waves representing theta waves
Citation: Noohi S, Miraghaie AM, Arabi A, et al. Effectiveness of neuro-feedback treatment with alpha/theta method on PTSD symptoms and their executing function. Biomed Res. 2017;28(5):2019-27.
Noohi S, Miraghaie AM, Arabi A, et al. Effectiveness of neuro-feedback treatment with alpha/theta method on PTSD symptoms and their executing function. Biomed Res. 2017;28(5):2019-27.

Treatment Description:
Basic body awareness therapy: manualized physical exercise with "slow, guided movements while standing, sitting and lying down, aiming at normalising and improving balance, muscle tension, free breathing and awareness." Participants also encouraged to do exercises as homework.



TAU: interdisciplinary treatmen with medical doctor and psychologist; medical doctor focused on pharmacological treatment as needed and psychoeducation; psychologist followed manual for treatment - "individual flexible CBT with elements of acceptance and commitment therapy, stress management and mindfulness."
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, rape/sexual assault, terrorism/political violence/forced dsplacement, other ("violence from relatives")
Citation: Nordbrandt MS, Sonne C, Mortensen EL, et al. Trauma-affected refugees treated with basic body awareness therapy or mixed physical activity as augmentation to treatment as usual-a pragmatic randomised controlled trial. PLoS One. 2020;10:846. doi: 10.1371/journal.pone.0230300. PMID: 32163509.

Treatment Description:
Mixed physical activity: followed manual; "bsic exercises focusing on improving strength, endurance, balance and coordination, using simple tools such as water bottles, bicycle, resistance bands, grocery bags etc." (tools selected which would allow participants to practice exercises at home). Participants also encouraged to do exercises as homework.



TAU: interdisciplinary treatmen with medical doctor and psychologist; medical doctor focused on pharmacological treatment as needed and psychoeducation; psychologist followed manual for treatment - "individual flexible CBT with elements of acceptance and commitment therapy, stress management and mindfulness."
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, rape/sexual assault, terrorism/political violence/forced dsplacement, other ("violence from relatives")
Citation: Nordbrandt MS, Sonne C, Mortensen EL, et al. Trauma-affected refugees treated with basic body awareness therapy or mixed physical activity as augmentation to treatment as usual-a pragmatic randomised controlled trial. PLoS One. 2020;10:846. doi: 10.1371/journal.pone.0230300. PMID: 32163509.

Treatment Description: Interdisciplinary treatmen with medical doctor and psychologist; medical doctor focused on pharmacological treatment as needed and psychoeducation; psychologist followed manual for treatment - "individual flexible CBT with elements of acceptance and commitment therapy, stress management and mindfulness."
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, rape/sexual assault, terrorism/political violence/forced dsplacement, other ("violence from relatives")
Citation: Nordbrandt MS, Sonne C, Mortensen EL, et al. Trauma-affected refugees treated with basic body awareness therapy or mixed physical activity as augmentation to treatment as usual-a pragmatic randomised controlled trial. PLoS One. 2020;10:846. doi: 10.1371/journal.pone.0230300. PMID: 32163509.

Treatment Name: Concurrent Treatment for PTSD and Substance Use Disorder Prolonged Exposure (COPE)
Standardized Treatment Name: Concurrent Treatment for PTSD and Substance Use Disorder Using Prolonged Exposure (COPE)
Treatment Description: Integrated prolonged exposure with cognitive behavioral relapse prevention skills for SUD, includes in vivo and imaginal exposure; 12 sessions with option of up to 16 sessions if participant and therapist agreed that treatment goals not yet met; encouraged to attend 1-2 sessions per week but allowed up to 6 months to complete.
Treatment Duration Detail: 12-16 sessions, up to 6 months to complete
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, rape/sexual assault, accidents, community/school violence, natural or manmade disasters, illness/medical procedure
Citation: Norman SB, Trim R, Haller M, et al. Efficacy of integrated exposure therapy vs integrated coping skills therapy for comorbid posttraumatic stress disorder and alcohol use disorder: a randomized clinical trial. JAMA Psychiatry. 2019 Apr 24;76(8):791-9. doi: 10.1001/jamapsychiatry.2019.0638. PMID: 31017639.

Treatment Description: Present-focused therapy teaching cognitive behavioral and interpersonal techniques and case management with 24 modules, each module includes safe coping skills; trauma discussed in context of its current affect on patient; 12 sessions with option of up to 16 sessions if participant and therapist agreed that treatment goals not yet met; encouraged to attend 1-2 sessions per week but allowed up to 6 months to complete.
Treatment Duration Detail: 12-16 sessions, up to 6 months to complete
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, rape/sexual assault, accidents, community/school violence, natural or manmade disasters, illness/medical procedure
Citation: Norman SB, Trim R, Haller M, et al. Efficacy of integrated exposure therapy vs integrated coping skills therapy for comorbid posttraumatic stress disorder and alcohol use disorder: a randomized clinical trial. JAMA Psychiatry. 2019 Apr 24;76(8):791-9. doi: 10.1001/jamapsychiatry.2019.0638. PMID: 31017639.

Treatment Description: Cognitive-behavioral psychotherapy targeting non-adaptive guilt and shame and moral injury associated with deployment trauma in veterans. Helps patients reevaluate their role in the trauma and re‐engage in adaptive ways to express values other than through guilt. One additional off-protocol session allowed.
Treatment Duration Detail: 6 protocol sessions; allowed on additional off protocol session during treatment
Psychotherapy Sessions Completed Detail: 16.2% of participants had an off-protocol session
Trauma Detail (Study level): Combat-related; Rape/sexual assault;  Accidents; Illness/medical procedure; Community/school violence; Natural or manmade disasters; Other (life-threatening injury)
Citation: Norman SB, Capone C, Panza KE, et al. A clinical trial comparing trauma-informed guilt reduction therapy (TrIGR), a brief intervention for trauma-related guilt, to supportive care therapy. Depress Anxiety. 2022 Apr;39(4):262-73. doi: 10.1002/da.23244. PMID: 35075738.

Treatment Description: Adapted from present-centered therapy, omitting problem-solving and daily diary. Patients guide session content. First session includes psychoeducation about trauma-related guilt; patients may choose to discuss guilt and trauma in subsequent sessions. One additional off-protocol session allowed.
Treatment Duration Detail: 6 protocol sessions; allowed on additional off protocol session during treatment
Psychotherapy Sessions Completed Detail: 1.4% of participants had an off-protocol session
Trauma Detail (Study level): Combat-related; Rape/sexual assault;  Accidents; Illness/medical procedure; Community/school violence; Natural or manmade disasters; Other (life-threatening injury)
Citation: Norman SB, Capone C, Panza KE, et al. A clinical trial comparing trauma-informed guilt reduction therapy (TrIGR), a brief intervention for trauma-related guilt, to supportive care therapy. Depress Anxiety. 2022 Apr;39(4):262-73. doi: 10.1002/da.23244. PMID: 35075738.

Treatment Description: Traditional Japanese-Chinese herbal formula containing a mixture of 7 dried herbs each registered in the Pharmacopoeia of Japan version 15
Dose: 2.5 grams (contains 1.17 grams herb extract)
Citation: Numata T, GunFan S, Takayama S, et al. Treatment of posttraumatic stress disorder using the traditional Japanese herbal medicine saikokeishikankyoto: a randomized, observer-blinded, controlled trial in survivors of the great East Japan earthquake and tsunami. Evid Based Complement Alternat Med. 2014;2014:683293. doi: 10.1155/2014/683293. PMID: 24790634.

Treatment Description: "control"
Citation: Numata T, GunFan S, Takayama S, et al. Treatment of posttraumatic stress disorder using the traditional Japanese herbal medicine saikokeishikankyoto: a randomized, observer-blinded, controlled trial in survivors of the great East Japan earthquake and tsunami. Evid Based Complement Alternat Med. 2014;2014:683293. doi: 10.1155/2014/683293. PMID: 24790634.

Treatment Description: MDMA is a psychoactive compound [Schedule 1 in the U.S. as a drug of abuse (ecstasy]). MDMA was given as an adjunct to psychotherapy. Patients received MDMA-assisted psychotherapy, music therapy and "body work" (e.g. hand-holding) with 2 therapists present over an 8-hour period, followed by non-drug therapy sessions the following day, and at one- and two-weeks post MDMA treatment.
Dose:
Session length: MDMA sessions 8 hours, NR for non-drug sessions







Dose: 187.5 mg (125 mg followed 2.5 hours later by 62.5 mg)
Frequency: Interval between MDMA sessions NR; one non-drug session the morning after each MDMA-assisted session, followed by 2 non-drug sessions one week apart
Treatment Duration Detail: Interval between MDMA sessions NR; MDMA sessions followed by 2 non-drug sessions one week apart
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: Study reports "received allocated intervention" and dropout/withdrew after first MDMA session separately
Trauma Detail (Study level): child sexual abuse, rape/sexual assault, accidents, illness/medical procedure
Citation: Oehen P, Traber R, Widmer V, et al. A randomized, controlled pilot study of MDMA (±3,4-Methylenedioxymethamphetamine)-assisted psychotherapy for treatment of resistant, chronic post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD). J Psychopharmacol. 2013 Jan;27(1):40-52. doi: 10.1177/0269881112464827. PMID: 23118021.

Treatment Description: Low-dose MDMA used as an "active placebo" to maintain blinding "since MDMA's effects can be easily discerned by both subjects and investigators." Chosen dose expected "to produce minimal, but detectable subjective effects," but no significant therapeutic effect. Low-dose MDMA was given as an adjunct to psychotherapy. Patients received low-dose MDMA-assisted psychotherapy, music therapy and "body work" (e.g. hand-holding) with 2 therapists present over an 8-hour period, followed by non-drug therapy sessions the following day, and at one- and two-weeks post MDMA treatment.
Dose:
Session length: MDMA sessions 8 hours, NR for non-drug sessions







Dose: 37.5 mg (25 mg followed 2.5 hours later by 12.5 mg)
Frequency: Interval between MDMA sessions NR; one non-drug session the morning after each MDMA-assisted session, followed by 2 non-drug sessions one week apart
Treatment Duration Detail: Interval between MDMA sessions NR; MDMA sessions followed by 2 non-drug sessions one week apart
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: Study reports "received allocated intervention" and dropout/withdrew after first MDMA session separately
Trauma Detail (Study level): child sexual abuse, rape/sexual assault, accidents, illness/medical procedure
Citation: Oehen P, Traber R, Widmer V, et al. A randomized, controlled pilot study of MDMA (±3,4-Methylenedioxymethamphetamine)-assisted psychotherapy for treatment of resistant, chronic post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD). J Psychopharmacol. 2013 Jan;27(1):40-52. doi: 10.1177/0269881112464827. PMID: 23118021.

Treatment Description: SSRI; flexible dosing, single dose in the morning; if no response at week 8, dose increased from 20 to 40 mg
Dose: Initiated at 20 mg, could be increased to 40 mg
Citation: Önder E, Tural Ü, Aker AT. A comparative study of fluoxetine, moclobemide, and tianeptine in the treatment of posttraumatic stress disorder following an earthquake. Eur Psychiatry. 2006 Apr;21(3):174-9. doi: 10.1016/j.eurpsy.2005.03.007. PMID: 15964747.

Treatment Description: MAOI Antidepressant; flexible dosing, daily dose divided between 8 am and 8 pm; if no response at week 8, increased from 450 mg to 900 mg
Dose: Initiated at 450 mg, could be increased to 900 mg
Citation: Önder E, Tural Ü, Aker AT. A comparative study of fluoxetine, moclobemide, and tianeptine in the treatment of posttraumatic stress disorder following an earthquake. Eur Psychiatry. 2006 Apr;21(3):174-9. doi: 10.1016/j.eurpsy.2005.03.007. PMID: 15964747.

Treatment Description: Atypical antidepressant; flexible dosing, daily dose divided between 8 am, 4 pm, and 11 pm; if no response at 8 weeks, increased from 37.5 to 50 mg
Dose: Initiated at 37.5 mg, could be increased to 50 mg
Citation: Önder E, Tural Ü, Aker AT. A comparative study of fluoxetine, moclobemide, and tianeptine in the treatment of posttraumatic stress disorder following an earthquake. Eur Psychiatry. 2006 Apr;21(3):174-9. doi: 10.1016/j.eurpsy.2005.03.007. PMID: 15964747.

Treatment Description:
Manualized treatment; PE is a form of cognitive behavioural therapy involving psychoeducation about PTSD, imaginal



exposure (repeatedly recounting most disturbing traumatic memories) and exposure in vivo.
Completed Treatment Definition: Patients completed all sessions or had PCL-5 score <16 for three consecutive weeks
Trauma Detail (Study level): Child physical abuse; Child sexual abuse; Community/school violence; Other (sexual abuse in adulthood)
Citation: Oprel DAC, Hoeboer CM, Schoorl M, et al. Effect of prolonged exposure, intensified prolonged exposure and STAIR+prolonged exposure in patients with PTSD related to childhood abuse: a randomized controlled trial. Eur J Psychotraumatol. 2021;12(1) doi: 10.1080/20008198.2020.1851511. PMID: 34630934.

Treatment Description: iPE was implemented similarly to the PE condition, except for the time format of the sessions; started with 3 sessions per week for 4 weeks (12 sessions total) followed by 2 sessions after one and 2 months.
Frequency: 3 sessions per week for 4 weeks, then one per month for 2 months
Completed Treatment Definition: Patients completed all sessions or had PCL-5 score <16 for three consecutive weeks
Trauma Detail (Study level): Child physical abuse; Child sexual abuse; Community/school violence; Other (sexual abuse in adulthood)
Citation: Oprel DAC, Hoeboer CM, Schoorl M, et al. Effect of prolonged exposure, intensified prolonged exposure and STAIR+prolonged exposure in patients with PTSD related to childhood abuse: a randomized controlled trial. Eur J Psychotraumatol. 2021;12(1) doi: 10.1080/20008198.2020.1851511. PMID: 34630934.

Treatment Name: Skills training in affective and interpersonal regulation + prolonged exposure
Standardized Treatment Name: Skills Training in Affect and Interpersonal Regulation (STAIR) followed by Prolonged Exposure (PE)
Treatment Description:
Manualized phase-based treatment of STAIR followed by PE. STAIR is a skill training programme with 4 sessions focused on improving emotion regulation skills followed by 4 sessions focused on developing interpersonal skills. PE was implemented similar to the PE



condition.
Completed Treatment Definition: Patients completed all sessions or had PCL-5 score <16 for three consecutive weeks
Trauma Detail (Study level): Child physical abuse; Child sexual abuse; Community/school violence; Other (sexual abuse in adulthood)
Citation: Oprel DAC, Hoeboer CM, Schoorl M, et al. Effect of prolonged exposure, intensified prolonged exposure and STAIR+prolonged exposure in patients with PTSD related to childhood abuse: a randomized controlled trial. Eur J Psychotraumatol. 2021;12(1) doi: 10.1080/20008198.2020.1851511. PMID: 34630934.

Treatment Description: Psychoeducation in the first session, then treatment proceeds with "lifeline" exercise where patient chronologically narrates her life using stones to mark traumatic events and flowers to mark joyful events. Therapists also provided consultation on safety issues and current violence.
Treatment Duration Detail: 10-12 sessions; "Each therapy period lasted between 3 and 6 months, due to various cancellations and interruptions"
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: "received intervention" in flow diagram, text describes as completers (other participants described as "did not begin or complete the treatment")
Citation: Orang T, Ayoughi S, Moran JK, et al. The efficacy of narrative exposure therapy in a sample of Iranian women exposed to ongoing intimate partner violence-a randomized controlled trial. Clin Psychol Psychother. 2018 Nov;25(6):827-41. doi: 10.1002/cpp.2318. PMID: 30079583.

Treatment Description: Psychoeducation and supportive counseling individually tailored to each patient, including life skill training, cognitive-behavioral techniques, acceptance and commitment therapy, improvement of self-knowledge, and involvement of violent husbands as needed.
Treatment Duration Detail: 10-12 sessions; "Each therapy period lasted between 3 and 6 months, due to various cancellations and interruptions"
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: "received intervention" in flow diagram, text describes as completers (other participants described as "did not begin or complete the treatment")
Citation: Orang T, Ayoughi S, Moran JK, et al. The efficacy of narrative exposure therapy in a sample of Iranian women exposed to ongoing intimate partner violence-a randomized controlled trial. Clin Psychol Psychother. 2018 Nov;25(6):827-41. doi: 10.1002/cpp.2318. PMID: 30079583.

Treatment Description: Manualized therapy developed for use with psychedelics; followed patients' process with no agenda or solutions offered. Three preparatory sessions followed by two eight-hour MDMA sessions (with overnight observation), each drug session followed by three non-drug integrative sessions over one month and daily phone contact for a week.
Dose: Dose: 125 mg + 62.5 mg available supplemental dose
Session Length: Preparatory sessions: 90 minutes; MDMA sessions: 8 hours; Integrative sessions: NR
Frequency: Preparatory sessions: interval NR; MDMA sessions: one month apart; Integrative sessions: ~10 days apart
Treatment Duration Detail: approximate duration based on 1 month between MDMA sessions and 1 month of integrative sessions after last MDMA session
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: participant flow diagram: 1 treatment discontinuation (12/13 did not discontinue); does not appear to include open-label sessions
Trauma Detail (Study level): Combat-related; Child physical abuse; Child sexual abuse; Accidents; Community/school violence; Other (ritual abuse, witnessing a crime)
Citation: Ot'alora GM, Grigsby J, Poulter B, et al. 3,4-methylenedioxymethamphetamine-assisted psychotherapy for treatment of chronic posttraumatic stress disorder: a randomized phase 2 controlled trial. J Psychopharmacol. 2018 Dec;32(12):1295-307. doi: 10.1177/0269881118806297. PMID: 30371148.

Treatment Description: Initiated at 1 mg/day, increase weekly by up to 1 mg/day to target dose of 4 to 6 mg/day
Dose: 4 to 6 mg total daily dose
Trauma Detail (Study level): rape/sexual assault, intimate partner violence, child physical abuse, community/school violence, other (violent death of a loved one)
Citation: Padala PR, Madison J, Monnahan M, et al. Risperidone monotherapy for post-traumatic stress disorder related to sexual assault and domestic abuse in women. Int Clin Psychopharmacol. 2006 Sep;21(5):275-80. PMID: 16877898.

Treatment Description: SSRI; patients visited every 2 weeks by a psychiatrist who adjusted dose based on response and adverse effects
Dose: Initiated at 50 mg, titrated to maximum 200 mg

Dose: 900 mg
Participants Adhered Percent Detail: 0 participants excluded from mITT population due to nonadherence

Treatment Description: Patients were exposed to anxiety-provoking trauma-related images and situations until habituated to each.
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: Reports number who dropped out of exposure therapy (n=1), remainder described as "completed the study", however N randomized to each arm NR (only overall, n=20 randomized)
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, rape/sexual assault, accidents, community/school violence, terrorism/political violence/forced displacement, other (exposure to toxic substance)
Citation: Paunovic N, Öst L-G. Cognitive-behavior therapy vs exposure therapy in the treatment of PTSD in refugees. Behav Res Ther. 2001 Oct;39(10):1183-97. doi: 10.1016/S0005-7967(00)00093-0. PMID: 11579988.

Treatment Description: Flexible combination of exposure, cognitive therapy, and controlled breathing.
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: Reports number who dropped out of CBT (n=3), remainder described as "completed the study", however N randomized to each arm NR (only overall, n=20 randomized)

Treatment Name: PE + financial incentives + TAU for OUD
Standardized Treatment Name: Prolonged Exposure (PE) + financial incentive + Treatment as usual (TAU) for substance use
Treatment Description:
PE: included breathing exercises, in vivo and imaginal exposures; modified for co-occurring PTSD and OUD clinical population by reducing sessions to 60 minutes and including psychoeducation about the association between PTSD and opioid use disorder
Financial incentives contingent on session attendance (maximum $920 for attending all sessions).
TAU: All participants continued medication for OUD with methadone or buprenorphine
Dose:
At baseline:
Buprenorphine, mean (SD) mg/day (N=5): 13.2 (5.0)
Methadone, mean (SD) mg/day (N=5): 112.0 (44.4)
Completed Treatment Definition: Completed at least 8 sessions of PE
Trauma Detail (Study level): Combat-related; Rape/sexual assault; Accidents; Community/school violence; Other ("witnessed or learned about injury or death"; "other" not further described)
Citation: Peck K, Badger G, Cole R, et al. Prolonged exposure therapy for PTSD in individuals with opioid use disorder: a randomized pilot study. Addict Behav. 2023;143 doi: 10.1016/j.addbeh.2023.107688. PMID: 36989699.

Treatment Name: PE + financial incentives + TAU medication for OUD
Treatment Description:
PE: included education about PTSD and its relationship to OUD, breathing exercises to manage arousal, and both in-vivo and imaginal exposures. PE modified for OUD participants by decreasing session length to 60 minutes, adding education about association between PTSD and OUD and weekly check-ins about about substance use, and providing therapy in person or via telemedicine. Participants were not required to abstain from non-prescribed substances.
Financial incentives: contingent on therapy session attendance (but not on substance use abstinence), maximum value $920.
TAU medication for OUD: continued medication treatment for OUD (methadone, buprenorphine) from current provider.
Dose at Study End Point Detail:
Baseline medication
buprenorphine: 61.1%; mean daily dose 11.6 (SD 5.7) mg
methadone: 38.9%; mean daily dose 90.4 (SD 43.9) mg
Trauma Detail (Study level): Accidents; Community/ school violence; Natural or manmade disasters; Rape/sexual assault; Other (witnessed or learned about injury or death)
Citation: Peck KR, Giannini J, Badger GJ, et al. A novel prolonged exposure therapy protocol for improving therapy session attendance and PTSD symptoms among adults receiving buprenorphine or methadone treatment. Drug Alcohol Depend. 2025 Jan 01;266:112507. doi: 10.1016/j.drugalcdep.2024.112507. PMID: 39642783.

Treatment Description: EMDR follows protocol according to Shapiro (2005), which involves participant isolating a visual representation of a traumatic memory, holding the memory, negative statement, evoked emotion, and area of body where the emotion is experienced while visually follow clinician's fingers for a set of 25 eye movements. All participants also received standard treatment for addiction, including clinical interviews, baclofen administration, anxiolytics/antidepressants administration, heroin substitution therapy, medications for PTSD treatment, and psychoeducation
Frequency: Three sessions in first month, followed by monthly sessions
Trauma Detail (Study level): other (sexual abuse, physical abuse or physical threatening or negligence, emotional abuse)
Citation: Perez-Dandieu B, Tapia G. Treating trauma in addiction with EMDR: a pilot study. J Psychoactive Drugs. 2014 Oct-Dec;46(4):303-9. doi: 10.1080/02791072.2014.921744. PMID: 25188700.

Treatment Description: Clinical interviews, baclofen administration, anxiolytics/antidepressants administration, heroin substitution therapy, medications for PTSD treatment, and psychoeducation
Trauma Detail (Study level): other (sexual abuse, physical abuse or physical threatening or negligence, emotional abuse)
Citation: Perez-Dandieu B, Tapia G. Treating trauma in addiction with EMDR: a pilot study. J Psychoactive Drugs. 2014 Oct-Dec;46(4):303-9. doi: 10.1080/02791072.2014.921744. PMID: 25188700.

Treatment Description: Compressed 3-week PE protocol, including psychoeducation about trauma, diaphragmatic breathing, in vivo exposure, imaginal exposure, and processing of the trauma, with 8 treatment augmentations: team-based treatment, completing homework in clinic, brief therapist feedback, enhanced social support, processing top 3 traumas using graduated imaginal exposure, brief review of all traumas, and posttreatment booster sessions.
Session Length: "full day", 90 minute PE sessions plus treatment augmentations
Completed Treatment Definition: Completing all 15 sessions, or ≥12 sessions with ≥10-point reduction in PCL-5 and participant-therapist agreement to terminate treatment
Citation: Peterson AL, Blount TH, Foa EB, et al. Massed vs intensive outpatient prolonged exposure for combat-related posttraumatic stress disorder: a randomized clinical trial. JAMA Netw Open. 2023;6(1):e2249422. doi: 10.1001/jamanetworkopen.2022.49422. PMID: 36602803.

Treatment Description: Compressed 3-week PE protocol, including psychoeducation about trauma, diaphragmatic breathing, in vivo exposure, imaginal exposure, and processing of the trauma.
Completed Treatment Definition: Completing all 15 sessions, or ≥12 sessions with ≥10-point reduction in PCL-5 and participant-therapist agreement to terminate treatment
Citation: Peterson AL, Blount TH, Foa EB, et al. Massed vs intensive outpatient prolonged exposure for combat-related posttraumatic stress disorder: a randomized clinical trial. JAMA Netw Open. 2023;6(1):e2249422. doi: 10.1001/jamanetworkopen.2022.49422. PMID: 36602803.

Treatment Description: Paroxetine: SSRI; naltrexone: opioid antagonist
Dose:
Paroxetine initiated at 10 mg, titrated over 2 weeks to 40 mg







Naltrexone initiated at 25 mg for 1 day then 50 mg for rest of treatment
Citation: Petrakis IL, Ralevski E, Desai N, et al. Noradrenergic vs serotonergic antidepressant with or without naltrexone for veterans with PTSD and comorbid alcohol dependence. Neuropsychopharmacology. 2012 Mar;37(4):996-1004. doi: 10.1038/npp.2011.283. PMID: 22089316.

Treatment Description: SSRI

Dose: Initiated at 2 mg, titrated over 2 weeks up to 16 mg

Treatment Description: Zonisamide: anticonvulsant dose titrated upwards over 6 weeks to maximum of 400 mg, tapered down for 2 weeks after study completed at week 12. CPT: All patients received up to 12 sessions of CPT standardized to address alcohol use.
Dose: Dose: zonisamide initiated at 100 mg/day, titrated every 2 weeks by 100 mg to maximum 400 mg/day, maintained from week 6 to week 12
Participants Adhered Percent Detail: compliance monitored by pill count, adherence not defined
Psychotherapy Sessions Completed Detail: Unclear if mean number of sessions for each arm or overall sample. States no difference between groups.
Dose at Study End Point Detail: Reported for overall sample; mean maximum dose 327.8 (SD 101.7) mg/day; 66.6% reached maximum dose
Citation: Petrakis I, Ralevski E, Arias AJ, et al. Zonisamide as an adjunctive treatment to cognitive processing therapy for veterans with posttraumatic stress disorder and comorbid alcohol use disorder: a pilot study. Am J Addict. 2020 11;29(6):515-24. doi: 10.1111/ajad.13061. PMID: 32462773

Treatment Description: Placebo: identical appearance and administration to zonisamide. CPT: All patients received up to 12 sessions of CPT standardized to address alcohol use.
Dose: Matching placebo equivalent dose

Psychotherapy Sessions Completed Detail: Unclear if mean number of sessions for each arm or overall sample. States no difference between groups.

Treatment Description: Standard manualized CPT protocol without written component. Goals include accepting reality of event, challenging dysfunctional thoughts, and establishing realistic beliefs. Uses Socratic questioning to challenge distorted cognitions. All participants also received buprenorphine for OUD.
Completed Treatment Definition: Completed ≥7 therapy sessions within 12 weeks and PCL-5 at either Week 8 or 12
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: 3 completed all visits, 7 more completed ≥7 and 8- or 12-week assessment
Trauma Detail (Study level): Combat-related; Rape/sexual assault; Accidents; Community/school violence; Other (witnessing severe injury or death)
Citation: Petrakis IL, Meshberg-Cohen S, Nich C, et al. Cognitive processing therapy (CPT) versus individual drug counseling (IDC) for PTSD for veterans with opioid use disorder maintained on buprenorphine. Am J Addict. 2024. doi: 10.1111/ajad.13557. PMID: 38624259.

Treatment Description: Manualized drug counseling supporting abstinence through behavior changes like avoiding triggers, establishing life structure, and engaging in healthy behaviors. All participants also received buprenorphine for OUD.
Completed Treatment Definition: Completed ≥7 therapy sessions within 12 weeks and PCL-5 at either Week 8 or 12
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: 6 completed all visits, 4 more completed ≥7 and 8- or 12-week assessment
Trauma Detail (Study level): Combat-related; Rape/sexual assault; Accidents; Community/school violence; Other (witnessing severe injury or death)
Citation: Petrakis IL, Meshberg-Cohen S, Nich C, et al. Cognitive processing therapy (CPT) versus individual drug counseling (IDC) for PTSD for veterans with opioid use disorder maintained on buprenorphine. Am J Addict. 2024. doi: 10.1111/ajad.13557. PMID: 38624259.

Treatment Description: Intermittent theta-burst transcranial magnetic stimulation to right dorsolateral prefrontal cortex at 80% motor threshold (1800 pulses, 9.5 minutes) using a Magstim Rapid 2+1 system.
Dose: Dose: 1800 pulses at 80% of active motor threshold
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, rape/sexual assault, accidents, illness/medical procedure, community/school violence, natural or manmade disasters, terrorism/political violence/forced displacement, other (unspecified childhood trauma, "serious injury, harm, or death you caused to someone else", "other very stressful event/experiences")
Citation: Philip NS, Barredo J, Aiken E, et al. Theta-burst transcranial magnetic stimulation for posttraumatic stress disorder. Am J Psychiatry. 2019 Jun 24;176(11):939-48. doi: 10.1176/appi.ajp.2019.18101160. PMID: 31230462.

Treatment Name: Sham intermittent theta-burst transcranial magnetic stimulation
Treatment Description: Sham treatment; used separate coils for sham stimulation using a Magstim Rapid 2+1 system.
Dose: Dose: NR (sham treatment)
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, rape/sexual assault, accidents, illness/medical procedure, community/school violence, natural or manmade disasters, terrorism/political violence/forced displacement, other (unspecified childhood trauma, "serious injury, harm, or death you caused to someone else", "other very stressful event/experiences")
Citation: Philip NS, Barredo J, Aiken E, et al. Theta-burst transcranial magnetic stimulation for posttraumatic stress disorder. Am J Psychiatry. 2019 Jun 24;176(11):939-48. doi: 10.1176/appi.ajp.2019.18101160. PMID: 31230462.

Treatment Description: Active synchronized TMS for 4 weeks. Optional unblinded synchronized TMS for another 4 weeks, delivered on a separate device from the one used for blinded stimulation.
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: publication doesn't report on study dropout, no information on TMS completion
Citation: Philip NS, Aiken EE, Kelley ME, et al. Synchronized transcranial magnetic stimulation for posttraumatic stress disorder and comorbid major depression. Brain Stimul. 2019 Sep-Oct;12(5):1335-7. doi: 10.1016/j.brs.2019.06.010. PMID: 31204205.

Treatment Description: Sham synchronized TMS was identical to active synchronized TMS except it did not use rotating magnets. Sham stimulation followed by optional unblinded synchronized TMS for another 4 weeks, delivered on a separate device from the one used for blinded stimulation.
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: publication doesn't report on study dropout, no information on TMS completion
Citation: Philip NS, Aiken EE, Kelley ME, et al. Synchronized transcranial magnetic stimulation for posttraumatic stress disorder and comorbid major depression. Brain Stimul. 2019 Sep-Oct;12(5):1335-7. doi: 10.1016/j.brs.2019.06.010. PMID: 31204205.

Standardized Treatment Name: Cognitive Behavioral Therapy for Insomnia (CBT-I) + Cognitive Processing Therapy (CPT)
Treatment Description:
CBT-i followed by CPT

CBT-i: standardized, multicomponent CBT intervention; components included: stimulus control therapy including establishment of a prebedtime routine; sleep psychoeducation; sleep restriction therapy; sleep hygeine; cognitive therapy; and self management/relapse prevention. Daily sleep diaries (started 1 week prior to first session, continued throughout intervention)

CPT: standard structured 12-session protocol; included psychoeducation, cognitive therapy, written trauma accounts, identifying and challenging beliefs, impact statement.
Treatment Duration Detail:
CBT-i: 4 total sessions

CPT: total 12 weekly sessions
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: Reports number completing measurement/assessment only, no information for treatment completion specifically

Treatment Description:
Waitlist followed by CPT.

Waitlist period: participants completed daily sleep diaries (started 1 week prior to first session, continued throughout waitlist period), and received 4 weekly phone calls from the clinical coordinator (limited to brief check ins and reminders).

CPT: standard structured 12-session protocol; included psychoeducation, cognitive therapy, written trauma accounts, identifying and challenging beliefs, impact statement.
Treatment Duration Detail:
WL: 4 week waiting period

CPT: total 12 weekly sessions
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: Reports number completing measurement/assessment only, no information for treatment completion specifically
Citation: Pigeon WR, Crean HF, Cerulli C, et al. A randomized clinical trial of cognitive-behavioral therapy for insomnia to augment posttraumatic stress disorder treatment in survivors of interpersonal violence. Psychother Psychosom. 2022 Jan;91(1):50-62. doi: 10.1159/000517862. PMID: 34265777.

Treatment Description: CBT following model developed by Foa et al (1995) that included imaginal and in vivo exposure, psychoeducation, and anxiety management. A device measures breathing frequency and provides immediate feedback (sound) when breathing frequency is outside preprogrammed frequency
Treatment Duration Detail: flexible number of sessions until subjective units of distress‚ ≤30
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: all participants attended all sessions
Trauma Detail (Study level): accidents, other (sexual or physical abuse)
Citation: Polak AR, Witteveen AB, Denys D, et al. Breathing biofeedback as an adjunct to exposure in cognitive behavioral therapy hastens the reduction of PTSD symptoms: a pilot study. Appl Psychophysiol Biofeedback. 2015 Mar;40(1):25-31. doi: 10.1007/s10484-015-9268-y. PMID: 25750106.

Treatment Description: CBT following model developed by Foa et al (1995) that included imaginal and in vivo exposure, psychoeducation, and anxiety management
Treatment Duration Detail: flexible number of sessions until subjective units of distress‚ ≤30

Treatment Description: Program teaches participants to attend to the present moment (immediate emotional and physical states) in a nonjudgmental and accepting way. Sessions include didactic training and formal practice in 3 meditation techniques: body scan, sitting meditation, and mindful yoga. Intervention modified to include PTSD psychoeducation.
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, rape/sexual assault, illness/medical procedure, community/school violence, natural or manmade disaster, other (not specified)
Citation: Polusny MA, Erbes CR, Thuras P, et al. Mindfulness-based stress reduction for posttraumatic stress disorder among veterans: a randomized clinical trial. JAMA. 2015 Aug 4;314(5):456-65. doi: 10.1001/jama.2015.8361. PMID: 26241597.

Treatment Description: Therapy focuses on current life problems as manifestations of PTSD. Therapists are nondirective and encourage patients to provide each other with support, problem solving, and validation
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, rape/sexual assault, illness/medical procedure, community/school violence, natural or manmade disaster, other (not specified)

Treatment Description: Brief Primary Care–Based Mindfulness Training. Instruction includes sitting & moving meditations, body scan, yoga stretching, and group processing of class experiences. At-home practice encouraged.
Treatment Duration Detail: 4 weekly classes, plus 2 one-on-one brief meetings with class peer cofacilitators (one prior to start of group classes, and one after the 4 classes ended)

Treatment Name: Primary care treatment integrating motivation and exposure (PC-TIME)
Standardized Treatment Name: Primary Care Treatment Integrating Motivation and Exposure (PC-TIME)
Treatment Description: Primary care-based integrated treatment for co-occurring PTSD and harmful alcohol use combining motivational interviewing and prolonged exposure.
Treatment Duration Detail: 5 sessions, 1-2 additional sessions could be added based on patient need
Citation: Possemato K, Mastroleo NR, Balderrama-Durbin C, King P, Davis A, Borsari B, Rauch SAM. Treatment Description: Patient's attention is directed to an external stimulus while they simultaneously concentrate on an identified source of emotional disturbance. External stimuli used included bilateral saccadic eye movements or alternating hand taps. When distress had sufficiently reduced on the part of the patient negative belief statements were replaced by preferred belief statements and saccadic eye movements or hand taps
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: reports only "completion" and drop-out from assessment, does not provide information specifically for treatment dropout/completion
Trauma Detail (Study level): accidents, rape/sexual assault, community/school violence, other (traumatic death, not specified)
Citation: Power K, McGoldrick T, Brown K, et al. A controlled comparison of Eye Movement Desensitization and Reprocessing versus exposure plus cognitive restructuring versus waiting list in the treatment of post-traumatic stress disorder. Clin Psychol Psychother. 2002 Sep/Oct;9(5):299-318. doi: 10.1002/cpp.341.

Treatment Description: Imaginal exposure sessions which were audio-taped. Therapists facilitated this process by prompting, questioning and encouraging. Patients were provided with audio-tape copies and asked to listen to the recording at least once per day as homework.
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: reports only "completion" and drop-out from assessment, does not provide information specifically for treatment dropout/completion

Treatment Description: Participants completed a 30-minute bout of moderate-intensity treadmill exercise (70% of age-predicted HRmax) immediately prior to each PE session. PE was manualized treatment program including education about trauma; breathing retraining: prolonged and repeated imaginal exposure to the trauma memories; prolonged and repeated in vivo exposure to safe situations; assignment of homework; and monitoring compliance of homework assignments.
Citation: Powers MB, Medina JL, Burns S, et al. Exercise augmentation of exposure therapy for PTSD: rationale and pilot efficacy data. Cogn Behav Ther. 2015;44(4):314-27. doi: 10.1080/16506073.2015.1012740. PMID: 25706090.

Treatment Description: PE was manualized treatment program including education about trauma; breathing retraining: prolonged and repeated imaginal exposure to the trauma memories; prolonged and repeated in vivo exposure to safe situations; assignment of homework; and monitoring compliance of homework assignments.

Treatment Name: CBT for insomnia (CBT-I) + imagery rehearsal therapy (IRT) for nightmares
Standardized Treatment Name: Cognitive Behavioral Therapy for Insomnia (CBT-I) + Imagery Rehearsal Training (IRT)
Treatment Description: Group sessions including both CBT-I and IRT. CBT-I included psychoeducation, sleep efficiency training, stimulus control, relaxation training, and sleep hygiene. IRT followed a protocol with minimal exposure to nightmare content and included grounding strategies to reduce arousal after nightmares; imagery exercises; challenging nightmare identities; and nightmare identification, rescripting, and rescript rehearsal. Participants asked to complete a daily sleep diary. Individual catch-up sessions offered as needed, following the same structure and content as the group sessions.
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: Full dose of intervention not further defined (number of sessions not stated)
Citation: Prguda E, Evans J, McLeay S, et al. Posttraumatic sleep disturbances in veterans: a pilot randomized controlled trial of cognitive behavioral therapy for insomnia and imagery rehearsal therapy. J Clin Psychol. 2023 Nov;79(11):2493-514. doi: 10.1002/jclp.23561. PMID: 37392411.

Treatment Description: Group sessions of CBT-I; included psychoeducation, sleep efficiency training, stimulus control, relaxation training, and sleep hygiene. Citation: Prguda E, Evans J, McLeay S, et al. Posttraumatic sleep disturbances in veterans: a pilot randomized controlled trial of cognitive behavioral therapy for insomnia and imagery rehearsal therapy. J Clin Psychol. 2023 Nov;79(11):2493-514. doi: 10.1002/jclp.23561. PMID: 37392411.

Treatment Description: Manualized psychotherapy modified for PTSD, addressing the effect of trauma on interpersonal function: "focus is to help the individual understand emotions to regain safety and trust in interpersonal relationships and to mobilize social supports."

Citation: Proenca CR, Markowitz JC, Coimbra BM, et al. Dose: 50 to 200 mg

Treatment Description: Satyananda yoga includes postures, breathing techniques, deep relaxation, and meditation. Supportive therapy provided by trained psychologist and follows mandatory ordinary assistance protocol designed by Agencia Colombiana para la Reintegracion for reintegrating individuals

Supportive therapy: once monthly

Citation: Quinones N, Maquet YG, Velez DM, et al. Efficacy of a Satyananda yoga intervention for reintegrating adults diagnosed with posttraumatic stress disorder. Int J Yoga Therap. 2015;25(1):89-99. doi: 10.17761/1531-2054-25.1.89. PMID: 26667292.

Treatment Description: Wait list for yoga with monthly appointment with a trained psychologist following the mandatory ordinary assistance protocol designed by Agencia Colombiana para la Reintegracion for reintegrating individuals.
