Standardized Treatment Name: Skills Training in Affect and Interpersonal Regulation (STAIR)
Treatment Description: Treatment followed STAIR manual; first 4 sessions focused on emotion regulation; last 4 sessions on trauma-related interpersonal schemas, maladaptive schemas, assertiveness, flexibility, and comnpassion. Each session includes psychoeducation, skill demonstration and practice, and homework exercises.
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: did not discontinue intervention, participant flow diagram
Trauma Detail (Study level): Child physical abuse; Child sexual abuse
Citation: Raabe S, Ehring T, Marquenie L, et al. Imagery rescripting as a stand-alone treatment for posttraumatic stress disorder related to childhood abuse: a randomized controlled trial. J Behav Ther Exp Psychiatry. 2022;77:101769. doi: 10.1016/j.jbtep.2022.101769. PMID: 36113906.

Treatment Description: First session is used to compose list of traumatic situations and pilot imagery rescripting with non-traumatic material; sessions 2-16, imagery rescripting is applied to process trauma memories. "procedure consists of 3 phases: in Phase 1, patients are asked to imagine a traumatic childhood experience as vividly as possible from the child's perspective, with their eyes closed. As soon as strong trauma-related emotions are triggered, therapist and patient move to the next phase. In Phase 2, patients enter the image as an adult who witnesses the situation, and are prompted to intervene and do whatever they think is necessary. This is followed by Phase 3, in which patients imagine the scene again as a child, and experience the adult's intervention developed in Phase 2 from the child's perspective. Patients can then ask for additional interventions until the child feels safe and is satisfied with the intervention."
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: did not discontinue intervention, participant flow diagram
Psychotherapy Sessions Completed Detail: Mean 13 sessions but not reported separately for group A (received ImRs after STAIR) and group B (ImRs only) (stated as not significantly different between conditions)
Trauma Detail (Study level): Child physical abuse; Child sexual abuse
Citation: Raabe S, Ehring T, Marquenie L, et al. Imagery rescripting as a stand-alone treatment for posttraumatic stress disorder related to childhood abuse: a randomized controlled trial. J Behav Ther Exp Psychiatry. 2022;77:101769. doi: 10.1016/j.jbtep.2022.101769. PMID: 36113906.

Treatment Description: No contact with therapist during waitlist period.
Trauma Detail (Study level): Child physical abuse; Child sexual abuse
Citation: Raabe S, Ehring T, Marquenie L, et al. Imagery rescripting as a stand-alone treatment for posttraumatic stress disorder related to childhood abuse: a randomized controlled trial. J Behav Ther Exp Psychiatry. 2022;77:101769. doi: 10.1016/j.jbtep.2022.101769. PMID: 36113906.

Treatment Description: Two right-sided SGB treatments, with ropivicaine injected into ganglion site at level of C6 anterior tubercle, performed at 0 and 2 weeks with outcomes measured at 8 weeks
Dose: 7 to 10 mL of 0.5% ropivacaine
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: injections at study week 0 and 2, flow diagram reports "in study through week-2 visit", data entered is participants completed baseline visit and in study through week-2 visit and completed week-2 visit
Citation: Rae Olmsted KL, Bartoszek M, Mulvaney S, et al. Effect of stellate ganglion block treatment on posttraumatic stress disorder symptoms: a randomized clinical trial. JAMA Psychiatry. 2020 Feb 1;77(2):130-8. doi: 10.1001/jamapsychiatry.2019.3474. PMID: 31693083.

Treatment Description: Two sham right-sided SGB treatments, with normal saline injected into musculature anterolateral to the anterior tubercle of C6, performed at 0 and 2 weeks with outcomes measured at 8 weeks
Dose: 1 to 2 mL of normal saline
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: injections at study week 0 and 2, flow diagram reports "in study through week-2 visit", data entered is participants completed baseline visit and in study through week-2 visit and completed week-2 visit
Citation: Rae Olmsted KL, Bartoszek M, Mulvaney S, et al. Effect of stellate ganglion block treatment on posttraumatic stress disorder symptoms: a randomized clinical trial. JAMA Psychiatry. 2020 Feb 1;77(2):130-8. doi: 10.1001/jamapsychiatry.2019.3474. PMID: 31693083.

Treatment Description: Memantine added to patient's existing PTSD regimen. Dose increased over 3 weeks as tolerated.
Dose:
20 mg maintenance dose
Initial dose 5 mg, increased by 5 mg each week up to 20 mg, adjusted based on tolerability
Citation: Rajabi F, Fozveh F, Maracy MR. The effect of add-on memantine in new onset combat-related posttraumatic stress disorder core symptoms: a pilot study. Iranian Journal of Psychiatry. 2023 Jul;18(3):266-74. doi: 10.18502/ijps.v18i3.13003. PMID: 37575607.

Arm N Randomized Detail: 57 total randomized, NR by arm; 21 in arm A after post-randomization exclusions
Treatment Description: One session of Modified Lifespan Integration, a manualized procedure to identify and visualize episodic "memory cues" chronologically from time of trauma to present, with the goal of converting trauma to a past episode rather than current threat ("trauma clearing").
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: single session, "received allocated intervention" = completed treatment
Citation: Rajan G, Wachtler C, Lee S, et al. A one-session treatment of PTSD after single sexual assault trauma. A pilot study of the WONSA MLI project: a randomized controlled trial. J Interpers Violence. 2020 doi: 10.1177/0886260520965973. PMID: 33084475

Arm N Randomized Detail: 57 total randomized, NR by arm; 17 in arm B after post-randomization exclusions
Treatment Description: Waitlist control: attention control in the form of the same initial doctor visit as the intervention arm, at which they were clinically assessed and given information about the treatment. Asked to prepare a memory cue list 1 to 2 days before intervention, which was offered after the second outcome measurement at time point 2 (25 ± 6 days after baseline).
Citation: Rajan G, Wachtler C, Lee S, et al. A one-session treatment of PTSD after single sexual assault trauma. A pilot study of the WONSA MLI project: a randomized controlled trial. J Interpers Violence. 2020 doi: 10.1177/0886260520965973. PMID: 33084475

Treatment Description: Alpha-1 adrenergic receptor antagonist; titrated for up to 6 weeks based on response and tolerability, with a lower morning dose and higher bedtime dose, and separate titration schedules for men and women with lower doses for women
Dose: Initiated at 1 mg for both men and women, titrated to maximum 25 mg for men and 12 mg for women
Frequency: Daily (divided into smaller morning and larger bedtime doses)
Dose at Study End Point Mean: Bedtime dose 15.6 mg for men and 7.0 mg for women. Midmorning dose 4.0 mg for men and 1.7 mg for women.
Dose at Study End Point Standard deviati: Bedtime dose (6.0) mg for men and (3.5) mg for women. Midmorning dose (1.4) mg for men and (0.5) mg for women.
Citation: Raskind MA, Peterson K, Williams T, et al. A trial of prazosin for combat trauma PTSD with nightmares in active-duty soldiers returned from Iraq and Afghanistan. Am J Psychiatry. 2013 Sep;170(9):1003-10. doi: 10.1176/appi.ajp.2013.12081133. PMID: 23846759.

Treatment Description: Capsules indistinguishable from the 3 active drug capsules (1 mg, 2 mg, 5 mg); titration period for both placebo and active arms
Dose at Study End Point Mean: Bedtime dose 18.8 mg for men and 10.0 mg for women. Midmorning dose 4.8 mg for men and 2.0 mg for women.
Dose at Study End Point Standard deviati: Bedtime dose (3.3) mg for men and (0.0) mg for women. Midmorning dose (0.8) mg for men and (0.0) mg for women.
Citation: Raskind MA, Peterson K, Williams T, et al. A trial of prazosin for combat trauma PTSD with nightmares in active-duty soldiers returned from Iraq and Afghanistan. Am J Psychiatry. 2013 Sep;170(9):1003-10. doi: 10.1176/appi.ajp.2013.12081133. PMID: 23846759.

Treatment Description: Alpha-1 adrenergic receptor antagonist; titrated based on response and tolerability, with a lower morning dose and higher bedtime dose, and separate titration schedules for men and women with lower doses for women. After the first 10 weeks, other pharmacologic therapies (except prazosin, trazodone, or psychostimulants) or psychotherapeutic treatments could be added, discontinued, or modified by treating clinicians.
Dose: Initiated at 1 mg for both men and women, titrated to maximum 20 mg for men and 12 mg for women
Frequency: Daily (divided into smaller morning and larger bedtime doses)
Citation: Raskind MA, Peskind ER, Chow B, et al. Trial of prazosin for post-traumatic stress disorder in military veterans. N Engl J Med. 2018 Feb 8;378(6):507-17. doi: 10.1056/NEJMoa1507598. PMID: 29414272.

Treatment Description: Capsules identical to the 3 active drug capsules (1 mg, 2 mg, 5 mg); titration period for both placebo and active arms. After the first 10 weeks, other pharmacologic therapies (except prazosin, trazodone, or psychostimulants) or psychotherapeutic treatments could be added, discontinued, or modified by treating clinicians.
Citation: Raskind MA, Peskind ER, Chow B, et al. Trial of prazosin for post-traumatic stress disorder in military veterans. N Engl J Med. 2018 Feb 8;378(6):507-17. doi: 10.1056/NEJMoa1507598. PMID: 29414272.

Treatment Description: Investigational anxiolytic and anticonvulsant; biweekly dose escalations by 200 mg twice daily, based on tolerability
Dose: Initiated at 200 mg, titrated to maximum 600 mg
Participant Adherence Definition: counted returned supplies; and compared plasma trough levels of ganaxolone to predicted therapeutic levels (≥20 ng/mL)
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, child physical abuse, child sexual abuse, child other abuse
Citation: Rasmusson AM, Marx CE, Jain S, et al. A randomized controlled trial of ganaxolone in posttraumatic stress disorder. Psychopharmacology (Berl). 2017;234(15):2245-57. doi: 10.1007/s00213-017-4649-y. PMID: 28667510.

Treatment Description: Gelatin capsules identical to those containing ganaxolone
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, child physical abuse, child sexual abuse, child other abuse
Citation: Rasmusson AM, Marx CE, Jain S, et al. A randomized controlled trial of ganaxolone in posttraumatic stress disorder. Psychopharmacology (Berl). 2017;234(15):2245-57. doi: 10.1007/s00213-017-4649-y. PMID: 28667510.

Treatment Description: Manualized therapy including psychoeducation, imaginal exposure, in vivo exposure, and emotional processing.
Citation: Rauch SAM, King AP, Abelson JL, et al. Biological and symptom changes in posttraumatic stress disorder treatment: a randomized clinical trial. Depress Anxiety. 2015 Mar;32(3):204-12. doi: 10.1002/da.22331. PMID: 25639570.

Treatment Description: Therapy following the Shea manual (Schnurr 2007), with psychoeducation (2 sessions) and discussion of current experience of PTSD symptoms and coping (remaining sessions).
Citation: Rauch SAM, King AP, Abelson JL, et al. Biological and symptom changes in posttraumatic stress disorder treatment: a randomized clinical trial. Depress Anxiety. 2015 Mar;32(3):204-12. doi: 10.1002/da.22331. PMID: 25639570.

Treatment Description: Prolonged exposure therapy sessions included psychoeducation, imaginal exposure to traumatic memories, discussion, and in vivo exposure homework. Sertraline titrated with last dose increase at 10 weeks.
Dose: Dose: sertraline adjusted between 50 and 200 mg
Frequency: Psychotherapy: 13 sessions over 24 weeks; Sertraline: daily
Participant Adherence Definition: completing all 13 sessions and taking sertraline at week 24
Participants Adhered Percent Detail: defined for both interventions together
Citation: Rauch SAM, Kim HM, Powell C, et al. Efficacy of prolonged exposure therapy, sertraline hydrochloride, and their combination among combat veterans with posttraumatic stress disorder: a randomized clinical trial. JAMA Psychiatry. 2019 Feb 1;76(2):117-26. doi: 10.1001/jamapsychiatry.2018.3412. PMID: 30516797.

Treatment Description: Prolonged exposure therapy sessions included psychoeducation, imaginal exposure to traumatic memories, discussion, and in vivo exposure homework. Placebo titrated with last dose increase at 10 weeks.
Frequency: Psychotherapy: 13 sessions over 24 weeks; Placebo: daily
Participant Adherence Definition: completing all 13 sessions and taking sertraline at week 24
Participants Adhered Percent Detail: defined for both interventions together
Citation: Rauch SAM, Kim HM, Powell C, et al. Efficacy of prolonged exposure therapy, sertraline hydrochloride, and their combination among combat veterans with posttraumatic stress disorder: a randomized clinical trial. JAMA Psychiatry. 2019 Feb 1;76(2):117-26. doi: 10.1001/jamapsychiatry.2018.3412. PMID: 30516797.

Treatment Description: Sertraline titrated with last dose increase at 10 weeks. Enhanced medication management ending at week 12 provided to balance time, psychoeducation, and clinician support compared with PE therapy groups
Dose: 50 to 100 mg
Citation: Rauch SAM, Kim HM, Powell C, et al. Efficacy of prolonged exposure therapy, sertraline hydrochloride, and their combination among combat veterans with posttraumatic stress disorder: a randomized clinical trial. JAMA Psychiatry. 2019 Feb 1;76(2):117-26. doi: 10.1001/jamapsychiatry.2018.3412. PMID: 30516797.

Treatment Description: Therapist provided trauma-related stimuli in a gradual manner through a virtual reality environment. Participants were asked to give a Subjective Units of Distress Scale every 5 minutes and to scan their body to report levels of tension.
Citation: Ready DJ, Gerardi RJ, Backscheider AG, et al. Comparing virtual reality exposure therapy to present-centered therapy with 11 U.S. Vietnam veterans with PTSD. Cyberpsychol Behav Soc Netw. 2010 Feb;13(1):49-54.  PMID: 20528293.

Treatment Description: Supportive therapy involving psychoeducation, teaching problem-solving techniques, and helping participants through a focus on problems occurring in their lives
Citation: Ready DJ, Gerardi RJ, Backscheider AG, et al. Comparing virtual reality exposure therapy to present-centered therapy with 11 U.S. Vietnam veterans with PTSD. Cyberpsychol Behav Soc Netw. 2010 Feb;13(1):49-54.  PMID: 20528293.

Treatment Description: Treatment involves creation of group cohesion, improving coping skills, imaginal and in vivo exposure exercises, and guided imagery exercise
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: "completed" in participant flow diagram, n=4 dropped out during treatment
Citation: Ready DJ, Mascaro N, Wattenberg MS, et al. A controlled study of group-based exposure therapy with Vietnam-era veterans. J Loss Trauma. 2018;23(6):439-57. doi: 10.1080/15325024.2018.1485268.

Treatment Description: Sessions focus on current problems related to PTSD symptoms and problem-solving
Frequency: Twice weekly; Booster session once every 3 weeks
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: "completed" in participant flow diagram, n=4 dropped out during treatment
Citation: Ready DJ, Mascaro N, Wattenberg MS, et al. A controlled study of group-based exposure therapy with Vietnam-era veterans. J Loss Trauma. 2018;23(6):439-57. doi: 10.1080/15325024.2018.1485268.

Treatment Description: Each session included healing touch using two protocols: biofield treatment, and amygdala treatment. Participants also received standard of care during both phases.
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: "1 subject dropped over the course of treatment"
Citation: Reeve K, et al. Examining the impact of a Healing Touch intervention to reduce posttraumatic stress disorder symptoms in combat veterans. Psychological Trauma: Theory, Research, Practice, and Policy. 2020. doi: 10.1037/tra0000591.

Treatment Description: Medication and psychotherapy delivered by the subjects regular practitioners and a variety of other interventions, such as relaxation training, meditation, archery, or yoga.
Citation: Reeve K, et al. Examining the impact of a Healing Touch intervention to reduce posttraumatic stress disorder symptoms in combat veterans. Psychological Trauma: Theory, Research, Practice, and Policy. 2020. doi: 10.1037/tra0000591.

Treatment Description: Intervention follow PE treatment protocol according to Foa et al. (2007) with traumatic memory shown through virtual reality headset. While wearing headset, patient verbally describe the events.
Citation: Reger GM, Koenen-Woods P, Zetocha K, et al. Randomized controlled trial of prolonged exposure using imaginal exposure vs. virtual reality exposure in active duty soldiers with deployment-related posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD). J Consult Clin. Psychol. 2016 Nov;84(11):946-59. doi: 10.1037/ccp0000134. PMID: 27606699.

Treatment Description: Manualized intervention according to Foa et al. (2007), includes psychoeducation, breathing retraining, repeated and prolonged imaginal exposure to traumatic memory, cognitive and emotional processing of traumatic material, and in vivo exposure to safe but feared situations
Citation: Reger GM, Koenen-Woods P, Zetocha K, et al. Randomized controlled trial of prolonged exposure using imaginal exposure vs. virtual reality exposure in active duty soldiers with deployment-related posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD). J Consult Clin. Psychol. 2016 Nov;84(11):946-59. doi: 10.1037/ccp0000134. PMID: 27606699.

Reger GM, Koenen-Woods P, Zetocha K, et al. Randomized controlled trial of prolonged exposure using imaginal exposure vs. virtual reality exposure in active duty soldiers with deployment-related posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD). J Consult Clin. Psychol. 2016 Nov;84(11):946-59. doi: 10.1037/ccp0000134. PMID: 27606699.

Treatment Description: Atypical antipsychotic
Dose: 0.5 mg for 3 days, then 1 mg/day after 3 days, then increase weekly by up to 1 mg/day to 4 mg/day.  Could increase to maximum of 8 mg/day after week 5
Frequency: Daily at bedtime initially, then could be 2 or 3 times daily
Dose at Study End Point Mean: overall 1.41 mg, mean 2.05 mg at week 8
Trauma Detail (Study level): child physical abuse, child sexual abuse, child other abuse
Citation: Reich DB, Winternitz S, Hennen J, et al. A preliminary study of risperidone in the treatment of posttraumatic stress disorder related to childhood abuse in women. J Clin Psychiatry. 2004 Dec;65(12):1601-6. PMID: 15641864.

Treatment Description: Placebo
Frequency: Once daily at bedtime initially, then up to 2 or 3 times daily
Trauma Detail (Study level): child physical abuse, child sexual abuse, child other abuse
Citation: Reich DB, Winternitz S, Hennen J, et al. A preliminary study of risperidone in the treatment of posttraumatic stress disorder related to childhood abuse in women. J Clin Psychiatry. 2004 Dec;65(12):1601-6. PMID: 15641864.

Treatment Description: Group yoga sessions comprised of centering and breathing exercises, body warm-ups, physical poses, breath work, moving meditation, and relaxation; participants asked to practice yoga for 15 minutes daily.
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: completed stage 1 (randomization through post assessment), "completed" in table 1
Citation: Reinhardt KM, Noggle Taylor JJ, Johnston J, et al. Kripalu yoga for military veterans With PTSD: a randomized trial. J Clin Psychol. 2018 Jan;74(1):93-108. doi: 10.1002/jclp.22483. PMID: 28524358.

Treatment Description: No treatment; participants completed assessments as a group (except CAPS, completed individually).
Citation: Reinhardt KM, Noggle Taylor JJ, Johnston J, et al. Kripalu yoga for military veterans With PTSD: a randomized trial. J Clin Psychol. 2018 Jan;74(1):93-108. doi: 10.1002/jclp.22483. PMID: 28524358.

Treatment Description: Manualized therapy including cognitive therapy and exposure in the form of writing and reading about the traumatic event
Session Length: 60 minutes for initial session, all others 90 minutes
Trauma Detail (Study level): child sexual abuse, rape/sexual assault
Citation: Resick PA, Nishith P, Weaver TL, et al. A comparison of cognitive-processing therapy with prolonged exposure and a waiting condition for the treatment of chronic posttraumatic stress disorder in female rape victims. J Consult Clin Psychol. 2002 Aug;70(4):867-79.  PMID: 12182270.

Treatment Description: Includes education-rationale, breathing retraining, behavioral exposures, and imaginal exposures
Session Length: 60 minutes for initial session, all others 90 minutes
Trauma Detail (Study level): child sexual abuse, rape/sexual assault
Citation: Resick PA, Nishith P, Weaver TL, et al. A comparison of cognitive-processing therapy with prolonged exposure and a waiting condition for the treatment of chronic posttraumatic stress disorder in female rape victims. J Consult Clin Psychol. 2002 Aug;70(4):867-79.  PMID: 12182270.

Treatment Description: Participants were encouraged to call therapist for client-centered telephone counseling
Trauma Detail (Study level): child sexual abuse, rape/sexual assault
Citation: Resick PA, Nishith P, Weaver TL, et al. A comparison of cognitive-processing therapy with prolonged exposure and a waiting condition for the treatment of chronic posttraumatic stress disorder in female rape victims. J Consult Clin Psychol. 2002 Aug;70(4):867-79.  PMID: 12182270.

Treatment Description: Manualized therapy that teaches skill of recognizing and challenging dysfunctional cognitions
Trauma Detail (Study level): child physical abuse, child sexual abuse, rape/sexual assault, intimate partner violence
Citation: Resick PA, Galovski TE, Uhlmansiek MOB, et al. A randomized clinical trial to dismantle components of cognitive processing therapy for posttraumatic stress disorder in female victims of interpersonal violence. J Consult Clin Psychol. 2008 Apr;76(2):243-58. doi: 10.1037/0022-006X.76.2.243. PMID: 18377121.

Treatment Description: Exposure-focused component of CPT where patients wrote about index event and discussed emotional response regarding event, but did not include cognitive therapy or challenge to client's dysfunctional statements
Session Length: 60 minutes for initial 2 sessions, 2 hours for remaining sessions
Frequency: Twice weekly for first week, then weekly
Trauma Detail (Study level): child physical abuse, child sexual abuse, rape/sexual assault, intimate partner violence
Citation: Resick PA, Galovski TE, Uhlmansiek MOB, et al. A randomized clinical trial to dismantle components of cognitive processing therapy for posttraumatic stress disorder in female victims of interpersonal violence. J Consult Clin Psychol. 2008 Apr;76(2):243-58. doi: 10.1037/0022-006X.76.2.243. PMID: 18377121.

Treatment Description: Identical to manualized CPT but without written account component
Trauma Detail (Study level): child physical abuse, child sexual abuse, rape/sexual assault, intimate partner violence
Citation: Resick PA, Galovski TE, Uhlmansiek MOB, et al. A randomized clinical trial to dismantle components of cognitive processing therapy for posttraumatic stress disorder in female victims of interpersonal violence. J Consult Clin Psychol. 2008 Apr;76(2):243-58. doi: 10.1037/0022-006X.76.2.243. PMID: 18377121.

Treatment Description: Trauma-focused cognitive therapy where patients learn to label events, thoughts, and subsequent emptions while therapist uses Socratic questioning to help patients examine the facts and context, and develop new, more balanced thinking about traumatic events
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, child sexual abuse
Citation: Resick PA, Wachen JS, Mintz J, et al. A randomized clinical trial of group cognitive processing therapy compared with group present-centered therapy for PTSD among active duty military personnel. J Consult Clin Psychol. 2015 Dec;83(6):1058-68. doi: 10.1037/ccp0000016. PMID: 25939018.

Treatment Description: Therapists help patients manage current symptoms through problem solving, directing discussion of trauma back to present time
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, child sexual abuse
Citation: Resick PA, Wachen JS, Mintz J, et al. A randomized clinical trial of group cognitive processing therapy compared with group present-centered therapy for PTSD among active duty military personnel. J Consult Clin Psychol. 2015 Dec;83(6):1058-68. doi: 10.1037/ccp0000016. PMID: 25939018.

Treatment Description: Trauma-focused cognitive therapy in groups of 8 to 10 participants; cognitive-only version following manual developed for military and veterans and incorporating special considerations for military population; one individual meeting with therapist prior to treatment to review trauma history; therapy aim to teach patients to recognize and challenge dysfunctional cognitions (stuck points) about the traumatic event(s) and current thoughts about themselves, others, and the world. Participants who missed 4 sessions were dropped from group treatment.
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, rape/sexual assault, accidents, community/school violence, other (noncombat death)
Citation: Resick PA, Wachen JS, Dondanville KA, et al. Effect of group vs individual cognitive processing therapy in active-duty military seeking treatment for posttraumatic stress disorder: a randomized clinical trial. JAMA Psychiatry. 2017 Jan;74(1):28-36.  PMID: 27893032.

Treatment Description: Individual trauma-focused cognitive therapy; cognitive-only version following manual developed for military and veterans and incorporating special considerations for military population; therapy aim to teach patients to recognize and challenge dysfunctional cognitions (stuck points) about the traumatic event(s) and current thoughts about themselves, others, and the world. Participants who couldn't complete treatment in 3 months for reasons other than military assignments had treatment ended.
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, rape/sexual assault, accidents, community/school violence, other (noncombat death)
Citation: Resick PA, Wachen JS, Dondanville KA, et al. Effect of group vs individual cognitive processing therapy in active-duty military seeking treatment for posttraumatic stress disorder: a randomized clinical trial. JAMA Psychiatry. 2017 Jan;74(1):28-36.  PMID: 27893032.

Treatment Description: App based on principles of Acceptance and Commitment Therapy, including engaging with the present moment, clarifying values, and committing to a value-based life. Daily audio-guided mindfulness exercises, weekly videos and reflections. Weekly calls from research team to address technical issues.
Treatment Duration Detail: "Participants were advised to practice at least one daily audio-guided mindfulness meditation"
Citation: Reyes AT, Fudolig M, Sharma M, et al. Testing the effectiveness of a mindfulness- and acceptance-based smartphone app for nurses traumatized by the COVID-19 pandemic: a pilot study. Issues Ment Health Nurs. 2024 Oct;45(10):1034-45. doi: 10.1080/01612840.2024.2385571. PMID: 39173125.

Treatment Description: No intervention; offered mindfulness app after 10-week followup
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: completed the control procedures 100%
Citation: Reyes AT, Fudolig M, Sharma M, et al. Testing the effectiveness of a mindfulness- and acceptance-based smartphone app for nurses traumatized by the COVID-19 pandemic: a pilot study. Issues Ment Health Nurs. 2024 Oct;45(10):1034-45. doi: 10.1080/01612840.2024.2385571. PMID: 39173125.

Treatment Name: Imaginal exposure followed by live exposure
Treatment Description: Imaginal exposure involved patients reliving their traumatic memories until anxiety is reduced. Live exposure involved patients re-entering trauma-related situations that they had been avoiding.
Treatment Duration Detail: 4 sessions each of imaginal and live exposure
Trauma Detail (Study level): rape/sexual assault, accidents, community/school violence, natural or manmade disasters
Citation: Richards DA, Lovell K, Marks IM. Post-traumatic stress disorder: evaluation of a behavioral treatment program. J Trauma Stress. 1994 Oct;7(4):669-80. doi: 10.1007/BF02103014. PMID: 7820356.

Treatment Name: Live exposure followed by imaginal exposure
Treatment Description: Imaginal exposure involved patients reliving their traumatic memories until anxiety is reduced. Live exposure involved patients re-entering trauma-related situations that they had been avoiding.
Treatment Duration Detail: 4 sessions each of imaginal and live exposure
Trauma Detail (Study level): rape/sexual assault, accidents, community/school violence, natural or manmade disasters
Citation: Richards DA, Lovell K, Marks IM. Post-traumatic stress disorder: evaluation of a behavioral treatment program. J Trauma Stress. 1994 Oct;7(4):669-80. doi: 10.1007/BF02103014. PMID: 7820356.

Arm N Randomized Detail: 114 initially randomized, n=3 excluded for no longer meeting inclusion criteria; 97 received intervention
Treatment Description: Veteran paired with service dog trained to perform five PTSD-specific tasks: turning on a light in a dark room, entering and sweeping the perimeter of a room, retrieving an object at handler's request, blocking a person approaching from the front, and blocking a person approaching from behind
Treatment Duration Detail: 18 months' follow-up after paired with dog
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: n=97 received a service dog, of those, n=9 discontinued the intervention before completing 18 months of follow-up = 88 received a dog and did not discontinue
Citation: Richerson JT, Wagner TH, Abrams T, et al. Therapeutic and economic benefits of service dogs versus emotional support dogs for veterans with PTSD. Psychiatr Serv. 2023:appips20220138. doi: 10.1176/appi.ps.20220138. PMID: 36718602.

Arm N Randomized Detail: 113 initially randomized, n=11 excluded for no longer meeting inclusion criteria; 84 received intervention
Treatment Description: Veteran paired with companion dog not trained in PTSD-specific tasks
Treatment Duration Detail: 18 months' follow-up after paired with dog
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: n=84 received a support dog, of those, n=9 discontinued the intervention before completing 18 months of follow-up = 65 received a dog and did not discontinue
Citation: Richerson JT, Wagner TH, Abrams T, et al. Therapeutic and economic benefits of service dogs versus emotional support dogs for veterans with PTSD. Psychiatr Serv. 2023:appips20220138. doi: 10.1176/appi.ps.20220138. PMID: 36718602.

Treatment Description: Individual + group therapy sessions; adapted version expanded group component to "maximize the focus on behaviour change away from ongoing perpetration of violence within the community, and to increase the emphasis on peer support". Individual sessions involved construction of lifeline, exploration of traumatic events (act of perpetrated violence). Group sessions "aimed to develop skills and motivation to avoid perpetrating violence within the community" and group members encouraged to support each other and introduced a 'buddy system'.
Session Length: Individual sessions: 90 to 120 minutes; Group sessions: 60 to 90 minutes
Frequency: Individual sessions: weekly; Group sessions: weekly
Completed Treatment Definition: attended all individual and group therapy sessions (6 sessions each)
Citation: Robjant K, Koebach A, Schmitt S, et al. The treatment of posttraumatic stress symptoms and aggression in female former child soldiers using adapted Narrative Exposure therapy - a RCT in Eastern Democratic Republic of Congo. Behav Res Ther. 2019 Dec;123:103482. doi: 10.1016/j.brat.2019.103482. PMID: 31639529.

Treatment Description: Services available through NGO, including: "occupational training courses, empathic listening and basic counselling, problem solving and practical support, provided whenever needed"; participant was visited at home if more than a week from last drop in.
Citation: Robjant K, Koebach A, Schmitt S, et al. The treatment of posttraumatic stress symptoms and aggression in female former child soldiers using adapted Narrative Exposure therapy - a RCT in Eastern Democratic Republic of Congo. Behav Res Ther. 2019 Dec;123:103482. doi: 10.1016/j.brat.2019.103482. PMID: 31639529.

Arm N Randomized Detail: 3 in first study period
Treatment Description: Extended-release alpha-1 noradrenergic antagonist with 15 to 19 hour half-life; initiated at 4 mg/day and increased by 4 mg every 4 days to final dose of 16 mg/day
Dose: Initiated at 4 mg, titrated to 16 mg
Citation: Rodgman C, Verrico CD, Holst M, et al. Doxazosin XL reduces symptoms of posttraumatic stress disorder in veterans with PTSD: a pilot clinical trial. J Clin Psychiatry. 2016 May;77(5):e561-5. doi: 10.4088/JCP.14m09681. PMID: 27249080.

Arm N Randomized Detail: 5 in first study period
Treatment Description: Placebo capsules identical to active treatment, dose increased over study period
Citation: Rodgman C, Verrico CD, Holst M, et al. Doxazosin XL reduces symptoms of posttraumatic stress disorder in veterans with PTSD: a pilot clinical trial. J Clin Psychiatry. 2016 May;77(5):e561-5. doi: 10.4088/JCP.14m09681. PMID: 27249080.

Treatment Description: Intervention follow method as described by Shapiro (1995). Subjects asked to concentrate on a visual image, the negative statement, and the sensation while tracking the therapist's finger back and forth. When subjects report minimal distress, they were asked to concentrate on the visual image and positive cognition during eye movements.
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: sample is participants who completed posttreatment assessment, part of an ongoing study; this is a single session intervention, but posttreatment assessment was 1 week after the session; no further information on treatment completion provided
Citation: Rogers S, Silver SM, Goss J, et al. A single session, group study of exposure and Eye Movement Desensitization and Reprocessing in treating posttraumatic stress disorder among Vietnam War veterans: preliminary data. J Anxiety Disord. 1999 Jan-Apr;13(1-2):119-30. doi: 10.1016/S0887-6185(98)00043-7. PMID: 10225504.

Treatment Description: Intervention based on explosion procedure described in Lyons and Keane (1989). Subjects were guided in a progress muscle relaxation exercise, then visualized the experience while paying attention to sensory, cognitive, and emotional cues. The scene was repeated with relaxation.
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: sample is participants who completed posttreatment assessment, part of an ongoing study; this is a single session intervention, but posttreatment assessment was 1 week after the session; no further information on treatment completion provided
Citation: Rogers S, Silver SM, Goss J, et al. A single session, group study of exposure and Eye Movement Desensitization and Reprocessing in treating posttraumatic stress disorder among Vietnam War veterans: preliminary data. J Anxiety Disord. 1999 Jan-Apr;13(1-2):119-30. doi: 10.1016/S0887-6185(98)00043-7. PMID: 10225504.

Treatment Description:
Resistance training and pedometer-based walking program. Resistance training included one supervised exercise session and two home-based unsupervised exercise sessions per week.







Participants also received usual care which could include psychotherapy, pharmaceutical interventions, and group therapy.
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: study reports mean attendance (58% of sessions) but not number of participants attending sessions; completion of assessments also reported
Trauma Detail (Study level): other (trauma experienced through occupation, not specified)
Citation: Rosenbaum S, Sherrington C, Tiedemann A. Exercise augmentation compared with usual care for post-traumatic stress disorder: a randomized controlled trial. Acta Psychiatr Scand. 2015 May;131(5):350-9. doi: 10.1111/acps.12371. PMID: 25443996.

Treatment Description: Usual care which could include psychotherapy, pharmaceutical interventions, and group therapy.
Trauma Detail (Study level): other (trauma experienced through occupation, not specified)
Citation: Rosenbaum S, Sherrington C, Tiedemann A. Exercise augmentation compared with usual care for post-traumatic stress disorder: a randomized controlled trial. Acta Psychiatr Scand. 2015 May;131(5):350-9. doi: 10.1111/acps.12371. PMID: 25443996.

Treatment Description: Individual sessions following treatment manual; patient imagines a scene that represents the entire trauma, focusing on sensations of anxiety while rehearsing words that match the picture and simultaneously follows therapist's finger moving back and forth until anxiety is decreased; patient then follows same procedure while rehearsing new, preferred belief, until the new statement feels true to the patient. The first session was comprised of information gathering, without EMDR.
Completed Treatment Definition: Did not drop out of treatment
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: reports study/assessment completion and drop out; completed treatment = did not drop out; n=1 drop out after baseline assessment
Citation: Rothbaum BO. A controlled study of Eye Movement Desensitization and Reprocessing in the treatment of posttraumatic stress disordered sexual assault victims. Bull Menninger Clin. 1997 Summer;61(3):317-34.  PMID: 9260344.

Completed Treatment Definition: Did not drop out of treatment
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: reports study/assessment completion and drop out; n=2 drop out from wait list
Citation: Rothbaum BO. A controlled study of Eye Movement Desensitization and Reprocessing in the treatment of posttraumatic stress disordered sexual assault victims. Bull Menninger Clin. 1997 Summer;61(3):317-34.  PMID: 9260344.

Treatment Description: Patient imagines a scene representing the worst part of the trauma, focuses on sensations of distress and rehearses negative thoughts, simultaneously following therapist's fingers back and forth at least 20 times each repetition until distress drops to 0 or 1 (measured 0 to 10 on subjective units of discomfort scale); patient then rehearses new, preferred belief while tracking therapist's finger until new statement feels true to the participant; uses cognitive interweaves to accomplish cognitive work. First two sessions for education and treatment planning; remaining 7 sessions were EMDR treatment.
Citation: Rothbaum BO, Astin MC, Marsteller F. Prolonged exposure versus Eye Movement Desensitization and Reprocessing (EMDR) for PTSD rape victims. J Trauma Stress. 2005 Dec;18(6):607-16. doi: 10.1002/jts.20069. PMID: 16382428.

Treatment Description: Patients instructed to imaging assault scene and describe aloud while anxiety levels are monitored, repeating the process for 45 to 60 minutes, followed by discussion of patient's reaction; patients instructed to listen to recording of narrative at least once a day and assigned homework. Two sessions for treatment planning including construction of a hierarchy of avoided situations for in vivo exposure homework; 7 sessions of imaginative exposure.
Citation: Rothbaum BO, Astin MC, Marsteller F. Prolonged exposure versus Eye Movement Desensitization and Reprocessing (EMDR) for PTSD rape victims. J Trauma Stress. 2005 Dec;18(6):607-16. doi: 10.1002/jts.20069. PMID: 16382428.

Treatment Description: Waitlist after pretreatment assessment, then randomly assigned to PE or EMDR after posttreatment assessment.
Citation: Rothbaum BO, Astin MC, Marsteller F. Prolonged exposure versus Eye Movement Desensitization and Reprocessing (EMDR) for PTSD rape victims. J Trauma Stress. 2005 Dec;18(6):607-16. doi: 10.1002/jts.20069. PMID: 16382428.

Treatment Description: SSRI antidepressant and prolonged exposure therapy comprised of psychoeducation, breathing retraining, in vivo exposure, prolonged imaginal exposure, and homework.
Dose:
Sertraline dose: 25 to 200 mg, previously titrated to maximum dose tolerated in Phase I







PE session length: 90 to 120 minutes
Frequency:
Sertraline: daily







PE: Twice a week
Completed Treatment Definition: Did not drop out of treatment
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: "completed" in participant flow diagram; did not drop out of treatment
Participant Adherence Definition: Sertraline: compliance as number of tablets taken divided by number of tablets that should have been taken, using medication dispensing data and unused medication returns (average % compliance with regimen)
Participants Adhered Percent Detail: Average % compliance with regimen 7.1% (SD 7.99) at Week 10 and 97.1% (SD 5.86) at Week 15 endpoint for both sertraline groups (% of patients being 100% adherent NR)
Dose at Study End Point Mean: 173.1 mg at Week 10 and 173.5 mg at Week 15 (average for both sertraline groups)
Dose at Study End Point Standard deviati: (44.26) mg at Week 10 and (42.82) mg at Week 15 (average for both sertraline groups)
Trauma Detail (Study level): child sexual abuse, child physical abuse, accidents, combat-related, other (death [not combat-related] of another person)
Citation: Rothbaum BO, Cahill SP, Foa EB, et al. Augmentation of sertraline with prolonged exposure in the treatment of posttraumatic stress disorder. J Trauma Stress. 2006 Oct;19(5):625-38. doi: 10.1002/jts.20170. PMID: 17075912.

Treatment Description: SSRI antidepressant, continuation of medication following 10 weeks of open-label treatment with flexible dosing titrated over first 5 weeks.
Dose: Dose: 25 to 200 mg, previously titrated to maximum dose tolerated prior to randomization

Treatment Description: Augmentation of an SSRI antidepressant (sertraline) with an atypical antipsychotic; all participants treated with sertraline in phase 1, and non-responders randomized to augmentation with risperidone or placebo; dose increased weekly by 0.5 mg/day as tolerated to maximum 2 mg/day, or 3 mg/day "on a case-by-case basis." Sertraline continued through phase 2, mean dose at endpoint 147 mg for risperidone arm.
Dose: Initiated at 0.5 mg, titrated to maximum of 2 or 3 mg
Trauma Detail (Study level): rape/sexual assault, intimate partner violence, accidents, community/school violence, other (stalking, break-in, witnessed killing or suicide attempt)
Citation: Rothbaum BO, Killeen TK, Davidson JRT, et al. Placebo-controlled trial of risperidone augmentation for selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor-resistant civilian posttraumatic stress disorder. J. Clin. Psychiatry. 2008;69(4):520-5. doi: 10.4088/JCP.v69n0402. PMID: 18278987.

Treatment Description: Augmentation of an SSRI antidepressant (sertraline) with placebo matching risperidone; all participants treated with sertraline in phase 1, and non-responders randomized to augmentation with risperidone or placebo; sertraline continued through phase 2.
Trauma Detail (Study level): rape/sexual assault, intimate partner violence, accidents, community/school violence, other (stalking, break-in, witnessed killing or suicide attempt)
Citation: Rothbaum BO, Killeen TK, Davidson JRT, et al. Placebo-controlled trial of risperidone augmentation for selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor-resistant civilian posttraumatic stress disorder. J. Clin. Psychiatry. 2008;69(4):520-5. doi: 10.4088/JCP.v69n0402. PMID: 18278987.

Treatment Description:
Virtual reality exposure: sessions comprised of exposure to subject's most traumatic memories using computer-generated virtual Iraq or Afghanistan environments with simulated field/combat situations and trigger stimuli (auditory, visual, olfactory, and tactile), manipulated by the therapist with attempt to match patient-described stimuli followed by experience processing, integration, and associations. This therapy differed from typical exposure therapy in that there was no homework assigned. 







D-cycloserine: NMDA glutamate receptor partial agonist
Dose:
Drug dose: 50 mg (30 minutes prior to session)







Sessions: 90 minutes (30 minutes prior to exposure for medication and assessments including startle responses and cortisol sampling). 30 to 45 minutes continuous exposure, until anxiety level decreases, 15 to 20 minutes processing time. One introductory session without medication or exposure was given.
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: participant flow diagram lists as "Post/Completed Treatment", this is same Ns as for "completed postttreatment" follow-up (using those Ns for treatment completion)
Citation: Rothbaum BO, Price M, Jovanovic T, et al. A randomized, double-blind evaluation of D-cycloserine or alprazolam combined with virtual reality exposure therapy for posttraumatic stress disorder in Iraq and Afghanistan War veterans. Am J Psychiatry. 2014 Jun;171(6):640-8. doi: 10.1176/appi.ajp.2014.13121625. PMID: 24743802.

Treatment Description:
Propranolol: centrally acting β1- and β2-noradrenergic receptor blocker given 90 minutes before trauma memory reactivation sessions, intended to disrupt memory reconsolidation.



Traumatic memory reactivation: therapy included writing a trauma narrative focusing on disturbing moments and emotional details; in later sessions patient read traumatic script to therapist.
Dose: Dose: 1.67 mg/kg, given as divided dose during first session; full dose given at once at later sessions if tolerated
Completed Treatment Definition: Did not drop out during treatment period
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: "four patients (12.12%) per group dropped out between the first and seventh weeks" (treatment period), leaving n=29 completing
Trauma Detail (Study level): Combat-related; Rape/sexual assault; Accidents; Community/school violence; Terrorism/political violence/forced displacement; Other ("life threatening event", "sudden unexpected death")
Citation: Roullet P, Vaiva G, Very E, et al. Traumatic memory reactivation with or without propranolol for PTSD and comorbid MD symptoms: a randomised clinical trial. Neuropsychopharmacology. 2021 Feb 21;21:21. doi: 10.1038/s41386-021-00984-w. PMID: 33612830.

Treatment Description:
Placebo: lactose-containing placebo capsule, same size and color as active drug capsules, given 90 minutes before trauma memory reactivation sessions.



Traumatic memory reactivation: therapy included writing a trauma narrative focusing on disturbing moments and emotional details; in later sessions patient read traumatic script to therapist.
Dose: Placebo equivalent dose to proporanolol
Completed Treatment Definition: Did not drop out during treatment period
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: "four patients (12.12%) per group dropped out between the first and seventh weeks" (treatment period), leaving n=29 completing
Trauma Detail (Study level): Combat-related; Rape/sexual assault; Accidents; Community/school violence; Terrorism/political violence/forced displacement; Other ("life threatening event", "sudden unexpected death")

Treatment Name: Motion-assisted, multi-modal memory desensitization and reconsolidation, with eye movement
Standardized Treatment Name: Multi-modular motion-assisted memory desensitization and reconsolidation (3MDR)
Treatment Description: Motion-assisted, multi-modal memory desensitization and reconsolidation, including eye movement component; "exposure-based 'walk and talk' cognitive therapy" delivered over 10 sessions (3 preparatory, 6 intervention, and 1 consolidation session). "Participants provided songs and pictures that they rated on impactfulness. While walking in the 3MDR virtual environment, participants started with a song to bring them back to the time of their trauma, and then traversed two hallways, actively walking toward emotionally evocative pictures that they then discussed with their therapist. Key words or feelings they expressed were superimposed over the picture, then read aloud, whereupon EM + participants recited numbers flashing on a ball crisscrossing the picture. These procedures were repeated for multiple pictures per session. A song to return the participant to present day closed each session."
Trauma Detail (Study level): Combat-related; Other ("sexual traumas"; not specified)
Citation: Roy MJ, Bellini P, Kruger SE, et al. Randomized controlled trial of motion-assisted exposure therapy for posttraumatic stress disorder after mild traumatic brain injury, with and without an eye movement task. Front Virtual Real. 2022;3 doi: 10.3389/frvir.2022.1005774.

Treatment Name: Motion-assisted, multi-modal memory desensitization and reconsolidation, without eye movement
Standardized Treatment Name: Multi-modular motion-assisted memory desensitization and reconsolidation (3MDR) minus eye movement
Treatment Description: Motion-assisted, multi-modal memory desensitization and reconsolidation, with no eye movement component; "exposure-based 'walk and talk' cognitive therapy" delivered over 10 sessions (3 preparatory, 6 intervention, and 1 consolidation session). "Participants provided songs and pictures that they rated on impactfulness. While walking in the 3MDR virtual environment, participants started with a song to bring them back to the time of their trauma, and then traversed two hallways, actively walking toward emotionally evocative pictures that they then discussed with their therapist. Key words or feelings they expressed were superimposed over the picture, then read aloud" The no EM participants continued to look at their image for another 30 seconds. "These procedures were repeated for multiple pictures per session. A song to return the participant to present day closed each session."
Trauma Detail (Study level): Combat-related; Other ("sexual traumas"; not specified)
Citation: Roy MJ, Bellini P, Kruger SE, et al. Randomized controlled trial of motion-assisted exposure therapy for posttraumatic stress disorder after mild traumatic brain injury, with and without an eye movement task. Front Virtual Real. 2022;3 doi: 10.3389/frvir.2022.1005774.

Treatment Description: Modification of the Bonny Method of Guided Imagery and Music for group format and trauma treatment; includes guided relaxation, music listening, and expressive arts. Delivered in 12 weekly 2.5-hour sessions.
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: 52% (11/21) attended all 12 sessions
Trauma Detail (Study level): Child physical abuse; Child sexual abuse; Child other abuse; Rape/sexual assault; Community/school violence; Other (adult psychological abuse)
Citation: Rudstam G, Elofsson UOE, Söndergaard HP, et al. Trauma-focused group music and imagery with women suffering from PTSD/Complex PTSD: A randomized controlled study. Eur. J. Trauma Dissociation. 2022;6(3) doi: 10.1016/j.ejtd.2022.100277.

Treatment Description: Waitlist
Trauma Detail (Study level): Child physical abuse; Child sexual abuse; Child other abuse; Rape/sexual assault; Community/school violence; Other (adult psychological abuse)
Citation: Rudstam G, Elofsson UOE, Söndergaard HP, et al. Trauma-focused group music and imagery with women suffering from PTSD/Complex PTSD: A randomized controlled study. Eur. J. Trauma Dissociation. 2022;6(3) doi: 10.1016/j.ejtd.2022.100277.

Treatment Description: Three mindfulness-based and guided imagery techniques (breathing exercise, inner safe space, and body scan); exercises provided as audio files to participant mobile phone. These had been translated to common languages used by refugees for the study setting (English, French, Turkish, Arabic, Farsi, Serbian). Participants also had 2 meetings with a member of the study team, which included psychoeducation about PTSD and its symptoms, introduction and practice of stablization techniques.
Treatment Duration Detail: Individual meetings at start of treatment and at 2 weeks
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: ad lib use, treatment completion not defined; publication provides self-reported use of exercises (5 participants did not use at all, 2 used between 1 and 10 times, and 5 participants used more than 10 times during study period)
Psychotherapy Sessions Completed Detail: reported use of exercises: mean 8.25 (SD 11.04, range 0-30) times
Citation: Rzepka I, Zehetmair C, Nagy E, Friederich HC, Nikendei C. Implementing a stabilizing intervention for traumatized refugees in temporary accommodations in South-West Germany - a randomized controlled pilot trial. Front Psychiatry. 2024 Oct 31;15:1453957. doi: 10.3389/fpsyt.2024.1453957. PMID: 39544372; PMCID: PMC11560747.

Treatment Description: Waitlist
Citation: Rzepka I, Zehetmair C, Nagy E, Friederich HC, Nikendei C. Implementing a stabilizing intervention for traumatized refugees in temporary accommodations in South-West Germany - a randomized controlled pilot trial. Front Psychiatry. 2024 Oct 31;15:1453957. doi: 10.3389/fpsyt.2024.1453957. PMID: 39544372; PMCID: PMC11560747.

Treatment Name: Exposure with eyes fixated and moving
Treatment Description: Exposure with eyes moving while fixated on therapist's moving hand; treatment followed EMDR manual by Solomon and Shapiro, except for variation in stimulation (eye movement); treatment focuses on  distressing trauma-related images, beliefs, and bodily sensations; therapy ended when PTSD diagnostic criteria no longer met, or 3 sessions without subjective symptom reduction, with maximum of 8 sessions.
Trauma Detail (Study level): accidents, natural or manmade disasters, community/school violence, other (sexual trauma)
Citation: Sack M, Zehl S, Otti A, et al. A comparison of dual attention, eye movements, and exposure only during Eye Movement Desensitization and Reprocessing for posttraumatic stress disorder: results from a randomized clinical trial. Psychother Psychosom. 2016;85(6):357-65. doi: 10.1159/000447671. PMID: 27744424.

Treatment Name: Exposure with eyes fixated and not moving

Treatment Description: Exposure without explicit task of fixating on external focus of attention (eyes closed or eyes open and looking unfocused into the room); treatment followed EMDR manual by Solomon and Shapiro, except for variation in stimulation (eye movement); treatment focuses on distressing trauma-related images, beliefs, and bodily sensations; therapy ended when PTSD diagnostic criteria no longer met, or 3 sessions without subjective symptom reduction, with maximum of 8 sessions.

Treatment Description: Intranasal oxytocin (Syntocinon, Novartis, Brazil) administered 45 minutes before trauma-script exposure. Trauma-script stress exposure used a script of 2 minutes and did not include an imagery period.
Dose: 24 IU
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: "received allocated intervention" in flow diagram, intervention comprised of two treatment sessions, no further details
Trauma Detail (Study level): rape/sexual assault, child sexual abuse, community/school violence, accidents, natural or manmade disasters, other ("non-sexual violence by a family member")
Citation: Sack M, Spieler D, Wizelman L, et al. Treatment Description: Intranasal placebo administered 45 minutes before trauma-script exposure. Placebo spray included all ingredients as the oxytocin intranasal spray except for the oxytocin. Trauma-script stress exposure used a script of 2 minutes and did not include an imagery period.
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: "received allocated intervention" in flow diagram, intervention comprised of two treatment sessions, no further details

Arm N Randomized Detail: 58 randomized; post-randomization exclusion of 4
Treatment Description: Imagery rehearsal therapy: adaptation of manual-based CBTsessions; includes psychoeducation about sleep and dreams, cognitive restructuring, imagery education and exercises, and imagery rescripting of disturbing dream or nightmare with rehearsal of a new, non-disturbing dream. Mianserin: an oral sedating tetracyclic antidepressant (not FDA-approved; similar to mirtazapine) used to treat sleep disturbance; increased from 10 to 30 mg/day based on effectiveness and side effects. TAU: interdisciplinary treatment over 8 to 12 months including medication, physical therapy, psychoeducation (including sleep hygiene and relaxation), and manual-based CBT, provided by physician, physical therapist, and psychologist.
Dose: Mianserin initiated at 10 mg nightly, could increase "gradually" to maximum 30 mg/day
Treatment Duration Detail:
Mean total duration: 12.40 (SD 4.92) months
Drug distributed during physician visits, weekly x 6 then monthly x 4; TAU CBT given weekly x 16, imagery therapy during 6 of these sessions; TAU overall 6 to 8 months
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: "per-protocol completers of IRT were defined as participants for whom IRT methods had been used in a minimum of four sessions"
Participants Adhered Percent Detail:
Value for mITT sample entered.



Of patients with blood samples: 72% (23/NR)



Discrepancy in calculated denominators with samples for Arms A and C (total 36 + 32 ≠ 70)
Psychotherapy Sessions Completed Detail:
entered value is for imagery sessions
Imagery, number of sessions where imagery therapy used: mean 3.61 (SD 4.24)
TAU, number of sessions with psychologist: mean 13.56 (SD 6.27)
Dose at Study End Point Detail: mg/day
Trauma Detail (Study level): Combat-related; Rape/sexual assault; Terrorism/political violence/forced displacement; Other ("violence from relatives", "cranial trauma")
Citation: Sandahl H, Jennum P, Baandrup L, et al. Imagery rehearsal therapy and/or mianserin in treatment of refugees diagnosed with PTSD: results from a randomized controlled trial. J Sleep Res. 2021 Feb 02:e13276. doi: 10.1111/jsr.13276. PMID: 33529449.
