Standardized Treatment Name: Integrated cognitive behavioral therapy for PTSD and AUD
Treatment Description: Integrated exposure-based CBT for PTSD and AUD. CBT for PTSD was manualized, and incorporated exposure therapy and cognitive restructuring; integrated with CBT for AUD, a manual-guided therapy based on Project MATCH and the Combined Behavioral Intervention Manual (same as AUD portion for Alcohol support intervention). Included structured homework.
Trauma Detail (Study level): child physical abuse, child sexual abuse, rape/sexual assault, community/school violence, intimate partner violence, accidents, other ("witnessed injury/killing/mutilation", "news of someone close", "danger of losing life/other")
Citation: Sannibale C, Teesson M, Creamer MC, et al. Randomized controlled trial of cognitive behaviour therapy for comorbid post-traumatic stress disorder and alcohol use disorders. Addiction. 2013 Aug;108(8):1397-410. doi: 10.1111/add.12167. PMID: 25328957.

Standardized Treatment Name: Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) without a trauma focus
Treatment Description: CBT for AUD plus supportive counseling. CBT was based on Project MATCH and the Combined Behavioral Intervention Manual (same as AUD portion for Integrated therapy intervention). Included structured homework. Supportive counseling is present-centered, manualized therapy, and targeted AUD symptoms only in this intervention.
Trauma Detail (Study level): child physical abuse, child sexual abuse, rape/sexual assault, community/school violence, intimate partner violence, accidents, other ("witnessed injury/killing/mutilation", "news of someone close", "danger of losing life/other")
Citation: Sannibale C, Teesson M, Creamer MC, et al. Randomized controlled trial of cognitive behaviour therapy for comorbid post-traumatic stress disorder and alcohol use disorders. Addiction. 2013 Aug;108(8):1397-410. doi: 10.1111/add.12167. PMID: 25328957.

Treatment Description: Includes narrative recollection of traumatic event, relaxation exercises, psychoeducation, exposure therapy, and home assignments
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: reports study completion only; "completed the study (i.e., both clinical and MRI data acquired before and after psychotherapy)", unclear if this is also treatment completion rate
Citation: Santarnecchi E, Bossini L, Vatti G, et al. Psychological and brain connectivity changes following trauma-focused CBT and EMDR treatment in single-episode PTSD patients. Front Psychol. 2019;10:129. doi: 10.3389/fpsyg.2019.00129. PMID: 30858808.

Treatment Description: Therapy includes identification of  disturbing memories of traumatic event and focusing on these memories while following finger movements performed by therapist
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: reports study completion only; "completed the study (i.e., both clinical and MRI data acquired before and after psychotherapy)", unclear if this is also treatment completion rate
Citation: Santarnecchi E, Bossini L, Vatti G, et al. Psychological and brain connectivity changes following trauma-focused CBT and EMDR treatment in single-episode PTSD patients. Front Psychol. 2019;10:129. doi: 10.3389/fpsyg.2019.00129. PMID: 30858808.

Treatment Name: Guided prolonged exposure with wearable technology
Treatment Description: Manualized prolonged exposure therapy with guided use of wearable technology (Bio Ware), "an integrated platform that consists of a clinician dashboard, backend applications, a patient-facing mobile application, wearables, and system devices" to facilitate in vivo exposures. Clinician-guided in vivo exposure using Bio Ware system.
Completed Treatment Definition: At least 8 sessions of PE and used the Bio Ware device at least once
Trauma Detail (Study level): Accidents; Community/school violence; Rape/sexual assault; Combat-related; Illness/medical procedure; Other ("severe human suffering", "sudden violent death", "sudden accidental death")
Citation: Saraiya TC, Jarnecke AM, Rothbaum AO, et al. Technology-enhanced in vivo exposures in Prolonged Exposure for PTSD: A pilot randomized controlled trial. J Psychiatr Res. 2022;156:467-75. doi: 10.1016/j.jpsychires.2022.10.056. PMID: 36347106

Treatment Description: Manualized prolonged exposure therapy, with unguided use of wearable technology (Bio Ware), "an integrated platform that consists of a clinician dashboard, backend applications, a patient-facing mobile application, wearables, and system devices" to facilitate in vivo exposures. Participants completed assigned in vivo exposure exercises while using Bio Ware device on their own (no clinican guidance).
Completed Treatment Definition: At least 8 sessions of PE and used the Bio Ware device at least once
Trauma Detail (Study level): Accidents; Community/school violence; Rape/sexual assault; Combat-related; Illness/medical procedure; Other ("severe human suffering", "sudden violent death", "sudden accidental death")
Citation: Saraiya TC, Jarnecke AM, Rothbaum AO, et al. Technology-enhanced in vivo exposures in Prolonged Exposure for PTSD: A pilot randomized controlled trial. J Psychiatr Res. 2022;156:467-75. doi: 10.1016/j.jpsychires.2022.10.056. PMID: 36347106

Arm N Randomized Detail: 29 couples
Treatment Description: PTSD treatment and couples-based therapy by individual therapist; manual-based interventions organized within a stress inoculation therapy (SIT) framework including psychoeducation (2 sessions), emotion activation and skills training (4 sessions), and disclosure-based exposure (6 sessions); homework assignment with each session. Up to 3 additional sessions were permitted if it wasn't possible to complete the protocol within 12 sessions.
Citation: Sautter FJ, Glynn SM, Cretu JB, et al. Efficacy of structured approach therapy in reducing PTSD in returning veterans: A randomized clinical trial. Psychol Serv. 2015 Aug;12(3):199-212. doi: 10.1037/ser0000032. PMID: 26213789.

Arm N Randomized Detail: 28 couples
Treatment Description: PTSD treatment and couples-based therapy, manualized and adapted from the Support and Family Education (SAFE) program and behavioral family therapy family education sections; treatment using lectures, discussion, and written materials designed to educate about PTSD and PTSD-related conditions. Avoided skills training and other therapeutic interventions. Up to 3 additional sessions were permitted if it wasn't possible to complete the protocol within 12 sessions.
Citation: Sautter FJ, Glynn SM, Cretu JB, et al. Efficacy of structured approach therapy in reducing PTSD in returning veterans: A randomized clinical trial. Psychol Serv. 2015 Aug;12(3):199-212. doi: 10.1037/ser0000032. PMID: 26213789.

Treatment Description: SSRI antidepressant; flexible dosing based on "clinical status"
Dose: 50 to 100 mg
Citation: Saygin MZ, Sungur MZ, Sabol EU, et al. Nefazodone versus sertraline in the treatment of posttraumatic stress disorder. Klinik Psikofarmakol Bülteni. 2002 Jan;12(1):1-5.

Treatment Description: Serotonin antagonist and reuptake inhibitor; flexible dose based on "clinical status"
Dose: 200 to 400 mg
Citation: Saygin MZ, Sungur MZ, Sabol EU, et al. Nefazodone versus sertraline in the treatment of posttraumatic stress disorder. Klinik Psikofarmakol Bülteni. 2002 Jan;12(1):1-5.

Treatment Description: Manualized therapy according to Foa, Hembree, & Rothbaum (2007) that includes breathing retraining for relaxation and imaginal and in vivo exposure. Incentive was gift card or clinic fee voucher beginning at $30 for Session 1, escalating $10 per session  with maximum total amount equaling $480. If the participant missed a session, the next attended session reset earnings to $30. Participants who missed 4 consecutive weeks were withdrawn from PE therapy but remained eligible to participate in followup assessments
Completed Treatment Definition: completed 12 sessions or at least 9 sessions and demonstrated a 70% reduction on MPSS-R score
Trauma Detail (Study level): child sexual assault, child physical assault, intimate partner violence, other (unexpected death of loved one)
Citation: Schacht RL, Brooner RK, King VL, et al. Incentivizing attendance to prolonged exposure for PTSD with opioid use disorder patients: a randomized controlled trial. J Consult Clin Psychol. 2017 Jul;85(7):689-701. doi: 10.1037/ccp0000208. PMID: 28414485

Treatment Description: Manualized therapy according to Foa, Hembree, & Rothbaum (2007) that includes breathing retraining for relaxation and imaginal and in vivo exposure. Participants received $40 for completing each followup assessment
Completed Treatment Definition: completed 12 sessions or at least 9 sessions and demonstrated a 70% reduction on MPSS-R score
Trauma Detail (Study level): child sexual assault, child physical assault, intimate partner violence, other (unexpected death of loved one)
Citation: Schacht RL, Brooner RK, King VL, et al. Incentivizing attendance to prolonged exposure for PTSD with opioid use disorder patients: a randomized controlled trial. J Consult Clin Psychol. 2017 Jul;85(7):689-701. doi: 10.1037/ccp0000208. PMID: 28414485

Treatment Description:
PE: trauma-focused CBT comprised of guided exposure to traumatic memories and situations to enhance emotional processing.







Paroxetine: controlled-release; SSRI
Dose:
Session length: 90 minutes







Dose: 12.5 mg for 1 week, then 25 mg for 3 weeks, then increased as tolerated to maximum of 50 mg
Dose at Study End Point Mean: 32.2 mg (mean maximum daily dose for at least 1 week)
Citation: Schneier FR, Neria Y, Pavlicova M, et al. Combined prolonged exposure therapy and paroxetine for PTSD related to the World Trade Center attack: a randomized controlled trial. Am J Psychiatry. 2012 Jan;169(1):80-8. doi: 10.1176/appi.ajp.2011.11020321. PMID: 21908494.

Treatment Description:
PE: trauma-focused CBT comprised of guided exposure to traumatic memories and situations to enhance emotional processing.







Placebo: matching placebo tablets
Dose:
Session length: 90 minutes







Dose: matching placebo to paroxetine which was prescribed at 12.5 mg for 1 week, then 25 mg for 3 weeks, then increased as tolerated to maximum of 50 mg
Dose at Study End Point Mean: 36.8 mg (paroxetine equivalent) (mean maximum daily dose attained for at least 1 week)
Citation: Schneier FR, Neria Y, Pavlicova M, et al. Combined prolonged exposure therapy and paroxetine for PTSD related to the World Trade Center attack: a randomized controlled trial. Am J Psychiatry. 2012 Jan;169(1):80-8. doi: 10.1176/appi.ajp.2011.11020321. PMID: 21908494.

Treatment Description: Atypical antidepressant (tetracyclic, alpha-2 antagonist); mirtazapine increased after 4 weeks' treatment based on response and adverse events. All patients in both treatment arms also received the SSRI sertraline, initiated at 25 mg/day and titrated up to 200 mg/day.
Dose: 15 to 45 mg; initiated at 30 mg for 4 weeks, increased as tolerated if continued PTSD symptoms to maximum of 45 mg, decreased if needed for adverse events to minimum dose of 15 mg
Trauma Detail (Study level): rape/sexual assault, community/school violence
Citation: Schneier FR, Campeas R, Carcamo J, et al. Combined mirtazapine and SSRI treatment of PTSD: a placebo-controlled trial. Depress Anxiety. 2015 Aug;32(8):570-9. doi: 10.1002/da.22384. PMID: 26115513.

Treatment Description: Placebo capsules matching mirtazapine; all patients in both treatment arms also received the SSRI sertraline, initiated at 25 mg/day and titrated up to 200 mg/day.
Dose: 15 to 45 mg mirtazapine equivalent; initiated at 30 mg for 4 weeks, increased as tolerated if continued PTSD symptoms to maximum of 45 mg, decreased if needed for adverse events to minimum dose of 15 mg
Trauma Detail (Study level): rape/sexual assault, community/school violence
Citation: Schneier FR, Campeas R, Carcamo J, et al. Combined mirtazapine and SSRI treatment of PTSD: a placebo-controlled trial. Depress Anxiety. 2015 Aug;32(8):570-9. doi: 10.1002/da.22384. PMID: 26115513.

Treatment Description: Exposure-based treatment in a group context following manualized protocol; includes psychoeducation, symptom self-management, coping resource assessment, exposure, cognitive restructuring, relapse prevention, and coping skills training, and exposure homework.
Frequency:
Active treatment: weekly







Booster sessions: monthly
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: additional data: adequate dose, defined as completed ≥80% of weekly sessions, 58.90%; completed active treatment and boosters, 65.55%
Citation: Schnurr PP, Friedman MJ, Foy DW, et al. Randomized trial of trauma-focused group therapy for posttraumatic stress disorder. Arch Gen Psychiatry. 2003 May;60(5):481-9. doi: 10.1001/archpsyc.60.5.481. PMID: 12742869.

Treatment Description: Group therapy following manualized protocol; includes psychoeducation, connection between PTSD symptoms and difficulties in relationships, problem-solving, specific individual issues, development of plans to deal with issues with interaction of group members for input and feedback, review of experience and progress.
Frequency:
Active treatment: weekly







Booster sessions: monthly
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: additional data: adequate dose, defined as completed ≥80% of weekly sessions, 61.70%; completed active treatment and boosters, 75.00%
Citation: Schnurr PP, Friedman MJ, Foy DW, et al. Randomized trial of trauma-focused group therapy for posttraumatic stress disorder. Arch Gen Psychiatry. 2003 May;60(5):481-9. doi: 10.1001/archpsyc.60.5.481. PMID: 12742869.

Treatment Description: Individual therapy delivered according to a manual; treatment included psychoeducation about common reactions to trauma; breathing retraining; imaginal exposure through prolonged (repeated) recounting of trauma memories during sessions; exposure homework, both imaginal (listen to recording of trauma recounting) and in vivo (safe situations avoided due to trauma-related fear); discussion of thoughts and feelings related to exposure exercises.
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, MST, rape/sexual assault, community/school violence, natural or manmade disasters, illness/medical procedure, accidents, other (sexual trauma, not specified)
Citation: Schnurr PP, Friedman MJ, Engel CC, et al. Cognitive behavioral therapy for posttraumatic stress disorder in women: a randomized controlled trial. JAMA. 2007 Feb 28;297(8):820-30. doi: 10.1001/jama.297.8.820. PMID: 17327524.

Treatment Description: Individual therapy delivered according to a manual, with focus on current life problems as manifestations of PTSD; included psychoeducation about PTSD and treatment rationale; review of general daily difficulties,  with therapist helping patient to identifying daily stresses and discussing in supportive, nondirective mode; reviewing accomplishments made during therapy; and making plans for the future.
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, MST, rape/sexual assault, community/school violence, natural or manmade disasters, illness/medical procedure, accidents, other (sexual trauma, not specified)
Citation: Schnurr PP, Friedman MJ, Engel CC, et al. Cognitive behavioral therapy for posttraumatic stress disorder in women: a randomized controlled trial. JAMA. 2007 Feb 28;297(8):820-30. doi: 10.1001/jama.297.8.820. PMID: 17327524.

Treatment Description: Collaborative care delivered by primary care provider and care manager (psychologist). Treatment at primary care provider's discretion and could include mental health specialty referral. Support calls by care managers until trial end or participant met response criteria (30% reduction in PCL, for those with depression also 50% reduction in PHQ-9 score); calls focused on barriers to adherence, helping to overcome barriers, and measuring treatment response.
Frequency: Support calls: weeks 1, 4, and 8, then every 4 weeks
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: Treatment completion not defined. Study assessed process of care outcomes (such as number of mental health visits, antidepressant prescriptions), and reports % of participants receiving high-fidelity, low-fidelity, or no care
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, rape/sexual assault, accidents, natural or manmade disaster, community/school violence
Citation: Schnurr PP, Friedman MJ, Oxman TE, et al. RESPECT-PTSD: re-engineering systems for the primary care treatment of PTSD, a randomized controlled trial. J Gen Intern Med. 2013 Jan;28(1):32-40. doi: 10.1007/s11606-012-2166-6. PMID: 22865017.

Treatment Description: Treatment at primary care provider's discretion and could include referral to a mental health specialist.
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, rape/sexual assault, accidents, natural or manmade disaster, community/school violence
Citation: Schnurr PP, Friedman MJ, Oxman TE, et al. RESPECT-PTSD: re-engineering systems for the primary care treatment of PTSD, a randomized controlled trial. J Gen Intern Med. 2013 Jan;28(1):32-40. doi: 10.1007/s11606-012-2166-6. PMID: 22865017.

Treatment Description: Prolonged Exposure therapy including in vivo exposure, approaching distressing trauma-related situations, places, and people, and remaining until distress is reduced; and imaginal exposure, with repeated revisiting and retelling of traumatic event in detail. Psychoeducation and breathing exercises also included. Flexible protocol, number os sessions adjusted for patient need: 12 weekly sessions planned, participants could finish in 10 or 11 sessions if PCL-5 ≤18 for 2 sessions by session 8. Two additional sessions allowed if PCL-5 ≥38 at session 12.
Treatment Duration Detail: flexible according to patient need; 10-14 sessions total (12 weekly sessions per protocol)
Completed Treatment Definition: Completion according to study protocol (10 to 14 sessions)
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: Completed standard 12 session protocol: 25.3%
Trauma Detail (Study level): MST; Combat-related; Rape/sexual assault; Accidents; Illness/medical procedure; Community/school violence; Natural or manmade disasters; Other (life threatening injury; other traumatic event not specified)
Citation: Schnurr PP, Chard KM, Ruzek JI, et al. Comparison of prolonged exposure vs cognitive processing therapy for treatment of posttraumatic stress disorder among US veterans: a randomized clinical trial. JAMA Netw Open. 2022 Jan 4;5(1):e2136921. doi: 10.1001/jamanetworkopen.2021.36921. PMID: 35044471.

Treatment Description: Cognitive Processing Therapy including briefly processing trauma by writing accounts of the event, its causes, and impacts, and sessions including dialogue and worksheets to challenge problematic beliefs. Flexible protocol, number os sessions adjusted for patient need: 12 weekly sessions planned, participants could finish in 10 or 11 sessions if PCL-5 ≤18 for 2 sessions by session 8. Two additional sessions allowed if PCL-5 ≥38 at session 12.
Treatment Duration Detail: flexible according to patient need; 10-14 sessions total (12 weekly sessions per protocol)
Completed Treatment Definition: Completion according to study protocol (10 to 14 sessions)
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: Completed standard 12 session protocol: 41.0%
Trauma Detail (Study level): MST; Combat-related; Rape/sexual assault; Accidents; Illness/medical procedure; Community/school violence; Natural or manmade disasters; Other (life threatening injury; other traumatic event not specified)
Citation: Schnurr PP, Chard KM, Ruzek JI, et al. Comparison of prolonged exposure vs cognitive processing therapy for treatment of posttraumatic stress disorder among US veterans: a randomized clinical trial. JAMA Netw Open. 2022 Jan 4;5(1):e2136921. doi: 10.1001/jamanetworkopen.2021.36921. PMID: 35044471.

Treatment Description: High intensity training sessions on an exercise bike with 5 minutes each for warm up and cool down and 20 minutes of exercise with 10 1-minute intervals exceeding 77% heart rate max interspersed with 1-minute intervals of <77% heart rate max; sessions supervised 1:1 with trained study personnel providing HR monitoring and motivation.
Completed Treatment Definition: Did not drop out during intervention
Trauma Detail (Study level): Child sexual abuse; Child physical abuse; Rape/sexual assault; Community/school violence; Combat-related; Terrorism/political violence/forced displacement; Other ("other incident")
Citation: Schoofs N, Pieper A, Meyer K, Herrmann S, Jäger A, Wülfing F, Grummt M, Wolfarth B, Ströhle A, Priebe K. High-intensity interval training in individuals with posttraumatic stress disorder: A randomized controlled pilot trial. Mental Health and Physical Activity. 2024 Feb 5:100579.

Treatment Description: Low intensity training with mobilization, stretching, and stabilization aerobic exercises with frequency and duration matched to high intensity training intervention and supervision monitoring HR (keeping <70% of HR max).
Completed Treatment Definition: Did not drop out during intervention
Trauma Detail (Study level): Child sexual abuse; Child physical abuse; Rape/sexual assault; Community/school violence; Combat-related; Terrorism/political violence/forced displacement; Other ("other incident")
Citation: Schoofs N, Pieper A, Meyer K, Herrmann S, Jäger A, Wülfing F, Grummt M, Wolfarth B, Ströhle A, Priebe K. High-intensity interval training in individuals with posttraumatic stress disorder: A randomized controlled pilot trial. Mental Health and Physical Activity. 2024 Feb 5:100579.

Treatment Description: 200 trials of the Dot-Probe test (80% neutral/trauma-related pairs; 20% neutral/neutral pairs); performed at home on a secured website.
Trauma Detail (Study level): other (childhood trauma unspecified, adult trauma unspecified)
Citation: Schoorl M, Putman P, Van Der Does W. Attentional bias modification in posttraumatic stress disorder: a randomized controlled trial. Psychother Psychosom. 2013;82(2):99-105. doi: 10.1159/000341920. PMID: 23295710

Treatment Description: 200 trials of the Dot-Probe test (no neutral/neutral pairs), probes appear behind threat and neutral equally; performed at home on a secured website.
Trauma Detail (Study level): other (childhood trauma unspecified, adult trauma unspecified)
Citation: Schoorl M, Putman P, Van Der Does W. Attentional bias modification in posttraumatic stress disorder: a randomized controlled trial. Psychother Psychosom. 2013;82(2):99-105. doi: 10.1159/000341920. PMID: 23295710

Treatment Description: Clinical HRV biofeedback training sessions using slow diaphragmatic breathing at personal resonance frequency rate established during first session using Alive Pioneer software and blood volume pulse sensor placed on earlobe. Instructed in home practice using smartphone app.
Session Length: 20 minutes HRV biofeedback training with additional time for education, assessments, review and discussion (~42 to ~85 minutes total/session)
Treatment Duration Detail: Initial session + 3 clinical sessions spaced ~1 week apart
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: Treatment completion not defined, study completion reported (88.89%, n=16); also states "Fifteen (83.33%) HRVB participants completed all aspects of the study and these participants all reported continued use of the resonance frequency breathing technique, both with and without feedback"
Participant Adherence Definition: moderate to high adherence to home practice (at least 50% completed, 245 minutes)
Participants Adhered Percent Detail: n=4 participants
Psychotherapy Sessions Completed Detail: Of n=12 with verified practice: total minutes practiced mean 263.34 (SD 202.25, range 74.21 to 792.17), total number of times device used mean 36.50 (SD 25.55, range 12 to 102)
Trauma Detail (Study level): MST; Combat-related; Natural or manmade disasters
Citation: Schuman DL, Lawrence KA, Boggero I, et al. A pilot study of a three-session heart rate variability biofeedback intervention for veterans with posttraumatic stress disorder. Appl Psychophysiol Biofeedback. 2023;48(1):51-65. doi: 10.1007/s10484-022-09565-z. PMID: 36331685.

Treatment Description: Not further described
Trauma Detail (Study level): MST; Combat-related; Natural or manmade disasters
Citation: Schuman DL, Lawrence KA, Boggero I, et al. A pilot study of a three-session heart rate variability biofeedback intervention for veterans with posttraumatic stress disorder. Appl Psychophysiol Biofeedback. 2023;48(1):51-65. doi: 10.1007/s10484-022-09565-z. PMID: 36331685.

Treatment Description: Computerized protocol for word-based probe detection, using words rated by patient as most threatening. Each session included 160 trials, 128 including one threat and one neutral word, 32 including two neutral words. Initial central fixation cross shown followed by two words above and below the fixation point. Target letter (probe) 'E' or 'F' then displayed where one of the words had been, until patient identified the target by pressing a button. Faster reaction time for probes appearing in location of threatening word indicates attention bias towards threat.
Psychotherapy Sessions Completed Detail: 100% of participants completed all 6 sessions; mean 5.7 (SD 0.94) across all groups
Trauma Detail (Study level): Combat-related; Child physical abuse; Child sexual abuse; Rape/sexual assault; Accidents; Illness/medical procedure; Community/school violence; Terrorism/political violence/forced displacement; Other (tragic death of a close relative;  repeated and extreme occupational exposure to aversive details of traumatic events)
Citation: Segal A, Pine DS, Bar-Haim Y. Personalized attention control therapy for PTSD: effectiveness and moderators of outcome in a randomized controlled trial. Psychol Med. 2022 Sep;52(12):2365-75. doi: 10.1017/S0033291720004304. PMID: 33231534.

Treatment Description: Computerized protocol for word-based probe detection, using randomly chosen threat words. Each session included 160 trials, 128 including one threat and one neutral word, 32 including two neutral words. Initial central fixation cross shown followed by two words above and below the fixation point. Target letter (probe) 'E' or 'F' then displayed where one of the words had been, until patient identified the target by pressing a button. Faster reaction time for probes appearing in location of threatening word indicates attention bias towards threat.
Trauma Detail (Study level): Combat-related; Child physical abuse; Child sexual abuse; Rape/sexual assault; Accidents; Illness/medical procedure; Community/school violence; Terrorism/political violence/forced displacement; Other (tragic death of a close relative;  repeated and extreme occupational exposure to aversive details of traumatic events)
Citation: Segal A, Pine DS, Bar-Haim Y. Personalized attention control therapy for PTSD: effectiveness and moderators of outcome in a randomized controlled trial. Psychol Med. 2022 Sep;52(12):2365-75. doi: 10.1017/S0033291720004304. PMID: 33231534.

Treatment Description: Computerized task with one neutral word presented centrally, followed by a probe also displayed centrally which the patient identified. "Does not include the essential ingredients thought to drive symptom reduction in [attention control therapy]: exposure to threat content and competition for attentional resources."
Trauma Detail (Study level): Combat-related; Child physical abuse; Child sexual abuse; Rape/sexual assault; Accidents; Illness/medical procedure; Community/school violence; Terrorism/political violence/forced displacement; Other (tragic death of a close relative;  repeated and extreme occupational exposure to aversive details of traumatic events)
Citation: Segal A, Pine DS, Bar-Haim Y. Personalized attention control therapy for PTSD: effectiveness and moderators of outcome in a randomized controlled trial. Psychol Med. 2022 Sep;52(12):2365-75. doi: 10.1017/S0033291720004304. PMID: 33231534.

Arm N Randomized Detail: n=33 randomized, 2 excluded (no longer eligible at start of treatment)
Standardized Treatment Name: Skills Training in Affect and Interpersonal Regulation (STAIR) followed by Narrative Exposure Therapy (NET)
Treatment Description:
STAIR followed by narrative therapy.
STAIR: group version provided by two therapists, "adapted from the original individual protocol by the treatment developers." Study-specific elements added: residential staff support and encourage participants to complete homework, and non-protocol individual therapy sessions added (without trauma-focused intervention).
Narrative therapy: individual exposure sessions with "imaginal reliving of trauma memories and cognitive restructuring of trauma-generated beliefs." Staff could also help with homework for narrative therapy.
Session Length:
STAIR group: 90 minutes
STAIR individual: 45 minutes
Narrative therapy: 60 minutes
Frequency:
STAIR group: NR
STAIR individual: weekly
Narrative therapy: NR
Treatment Duration Detail:
STAIR group: 12 sessions over 10 weeks 
Narrative therapy: 8 sessions over 6 weeks
Completed Treatment Definition: Did not drop out of treatment
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: n=30 started treatment, 2 dropped out during treatment (28/31 for treatment completion)
Psychotherapy Sessions Completed Detail:
Overall: NR
STAIR group: NR
STAIR individual: mean 12.0 (SD 2.9)
Narrative therapy: mean 7.1 (SD 2.1)
Trauma Detail (Study level): Child physical abuse; Child sexual abuse; Child other abuse
Citation: Sele P, Hoffart A, Cloitre M, et al. Comparing phase-based treatment, prolonged exposure, and skills-training for complex posttraumatic stress disorder: a randomized controlled trial. J Anxiety Disord. 2023 Dec;100:102786. doi: 10.1016/j.janxdis.2023.102786. PMID: 37871452.

Treatment Description: Atypical antidepressant; could be titrated upward after second visit at clinician's discretion

Completed Treatment Percent Detail: parrticipants randomized only after completion of phase I (PE intervention)
Trauma Detail (Study level): rape/sexual assault, intimate partner violence, accidents, illness/medical procedure, other (exposure to war)
Citation: Simon NM, Connor KM, Lang AJ, et al. Paroxetine CR augmentation for posttraumatic stress disorder refractory to prolonged exposure therapy. J Clin Psychiatry. 2008 Mar;69(3):400-5. PMID: 18348595.

Treatment Description: Trauma-focused CBT plus placebo; 5 additional sessions of PE augmented with addition of matched pill placebo. (Participants randomized after Phase I if SPRINT ≥6 or CGI-S ≥3 after eight 90- to 120-minute individual PE sessions over a 4- to 6-week period).
Dose:
Session length: 90 to 120 minutes







Dose: equivalent to 12.5 to 62.5 mg paroxetine controlled release; titration: flexible dose initiated at 12.5 mg titrated up to maximum dose of 62.5 mg based on efficacy and tolerability
Frequency:
Psychotherapy: once every 2 weeks







Placebo: daily
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: parrticipants randomized only after completion of phase I (PE intervention)
Dose at Study End Point Mean: 44.8 mg equivalent to paroxetine controlled release
Trauma Detail (Study level): rape/sexual assault, intimate partner violence, accidents, illness/medical procedure, other (exposure to war)
Citation: Simon NM, Connor KM, Lang AJ, et al. Paroxetine CR augmentation for posttraumatic stress disorder refractory to prolonged exposure therapy. J Clin Psychiatry. 2008 Mar;69(3):400-5. PMID: 18348595.

Treatment Description: 12-session CBT program focusing on self-monitoring and coping skills to address high-risk drinking and can address PTSD-related triggers
Treatment Duration Detail: 12 sessions could be completed in 6-20 weeks
Trauma Detail (Study level): Combat-related; Rape/sexual assault; Community/school violence; Other ("traumatic loss", "another trauma type")
Citation: Simpson TL, Kaysen DL, Fleming CB, et al. Cognitive processing therapy or relapse prevention for comorbid posttraumatic stress disorder and alcohol use disorder: a randomized clinical trial. PLoS One. 2022;17(11):e0276111. doi: 10.1371/journal.pone.0276111. PMID: 36445895.

Treatment Description: 12-session cognitive processing therapy without trauma narratives
Treatment Duration Detail: 12 sessions could be completed in 6-20 weeks
Trauma Detail (Study level): Combat-related; Rape/sexual assault; Community/school violence; Other ("traumatic loss", "another trauma type")
Citation: Simpson TL, Kaysen DL, Fleming CB, et al. Cognitive processing therapy or relapse prevention for comorbid posttraumatic stress disorder and alcohol use disorder: a randomized clinical trial. PLoS One. 2022;17(11):e0276111. doi: 10.1371/journal.pone.0276111. PMID: 36445895.

Treatment Description: Brief 15-minute weekly support/safety calls with study therapist
Trauma Detail (Study level): Combat-related; Rape/sexual assault; Community/school violence; Other ("traumatic loss", "another trauma type")
Citation: Simpson TL, Kaysen DL, Fleming CB, et al. Cognitive processing therapy or relapse prevention for comorbid posttraumatic stress disorder and alcohol use disorder: a randomized clinical trial. PLoS One. 2022;17(11):e0276111. doi: 10.1371/journal.pone.0276111. PMID: 36445895.

Treatment Description: Participants instructed to write about most traumatic/distressing experience of their lives with as much emotion and feeling as possible; in second and third sessions, could write about same or different experience.
Trauma Detail (Study level): rape/sexual assault, accidents, child sexual abuse, community/school violence, other (witness to murder)
Citation: Sloan DM, Marx BP. A closer examination of the structured written disclosure procedure. J Consult Clin Psychol. 2004 Apr;72(2):165-75. doi: 10.1037/0022-006X.72.2.165. PMID: 15065952.

Treatment Description: Participants instructed to write about how they spent their time without describing any emotion or opinions, in as much detail as possible.
Trauma Detail (Study level): rape/sexual assault, accidents, child sexual abuse, community/school violence, other (witness to murder)
Citation: Sloan DM, Marx BP. A closer examination of the structured written disclosure procedure. J Consult Clin Psychol. 2004 Apr;72(2):165-75. doi: 10.1037/0022-006X.72.2.165. PMID: 15065952.

Treatment Name: Written disclosure focused on emotional expression
Treatment Description: Participants instructed to write about most traumatic experience of their lives with as much emotion and feeling as possible; participant asked to write about the same experience at each writing session.
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: Overall 98.82%, not reported by arm
Trauma Detail (Study level): rape/sexual assault, community/school violence, accidents, other (witness to murder)
Citation: Sloan DM, Marx BP, Epstein EM, et al. Does altering the writing instructions influence outcome associated with written disclosure? Behav Ther. 2007 Jun;38(2):155-68. doi: 10.1016/j.beth.2006.06.005. PMID: 17499082.

Treatment Name: Written disclosure focused on insight and cognitive assimilation
Treatment Description: Participants instructed to write about most traumatic experience of their lives with a focus on what the event has meant to them, how the event changed their lives (both good and bad), and challenge their dissonant thoughts about the event; asked to write about the same experience at each writing session.
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: Overall 98.82%, not reported by arm
Trauma Detail (Study level): rape/sexual assault, community/school violence, accidents, other (witness to murder)
Citation: Sloan DM, Marx BP, Epstein EM, et al. Does altering the writing instructions influence outcome associated with written disclosure? Behav Ther. 2007 Jun;38(2):155-68. doi: 10.1016/j.beth.2006.06.005. PMID: 17499082.

Treatment Description: Participants instructed to write about how they spent their time without describing any emotion or opinions.
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: Overall 98.82%, not reported by arm
Trauma Detail (Study level): rape/sexual assault, community/school violence, accidents, other (witness to murder)
Citation: Sloan DM, Marx BP, Epstein EM, et al. Does altering the writing instructions influence outcome associated with written disclosure? Behav Ther. 2007 Jun;38(2):155-68. doi: 10.1016/j.beth.2006.06.005. PMID: 17499082.

Treatment Description: Procedure following Pennebaker 1997; participants were asked to write about the most traumatic experience of their lives with as much emotion and feeling as possible; asked to write about the same traumatic experience at each session.
Trauma Detail (Study level): rape/sexual assault, community/school violence, accidents, combat-related, other (witness to a murder)
Citation: Sloan DM, Marx BP, Greenberg EM. A test of written emotional disclosure as an intervention for posttraumatic stress disorder. Behav Res Ther. 2011 Apr;49(4):299-304. doi: 10.1016/j.brat.2011.02.001. PMID: 21367400.

Treatment Description: Procedure following Pennebaker 1997; participants were asked to write about how they spent their time each day without describing any emotion or opinions.
Trauma Detail (Study level): rape/sexual assault, community/school violence, accidents, combat-related, other (witness to a murder)
Citation: Sloan DM, Marx BP, Greenberg EM. A test of written emotional disclosure as an intervention for posttraumatic stress disorder. Behav Res Ther. 2011 Apr;49(4):299-304. doi: 10.1016/j.brat.2011.02.001. PMID: 21367400.

Treatment Description: Exposure through writing about the same motor vehicle accident each session. Initial session focused on describing the event in detail and delving into deepest emotions and thoughts at the time of the accident; remaining sessions focused on most distressing part of the event ("hot spot"), and how it had affected participant's life. The therapist read writing instructions and answered questions; participants were left alone in the room for the writing exercise; therapists addressed concerns at the end of the writing exercise, checked that instructions were followed, and instructed participant to allow experiencing of trauma-related memories, images, thoughts, or feelings in between sessions.
Session Length: 1 hour (first session), 40 minutes (remaining 4 sessions); writing exercises 30 minutes per session
Citation: Sloan DM, Marx BP, Bovin MJ, et al. Written exposure as an intervention for PTSD: a randomized clinical trial with motor vehicle accident survivors. Behav Res Ther. 2012 Oct;50(10):627-35. doi: 10.1016/j.brat.2012.07.001. PMID: 22863540.

Treatment Description: Participants encouraged to contact project coordinator any time if experiencing problems; contacted prior to followup assessments for reminder and to make sure they had not experienced a substantial increase in PTSD symptom severity. Participants were offered written exposure therapy after the 18-week assessment was completed.
Citation: Sloan DM, Marx BP, Bovin MJ, et al. Written exposure as an intervention for PTSD: a randomized clinical trial with motor vehicle accident survivors. Behav Res Ther. 2012 Oct;50(10):627-35. doi: 10.1016/j.brat.2012.07.001. PMID: 22863540.

Treatment Description: Patients instructed to write about a specific traumatic event, focusing on details of the event and the thoughts and feelings that occurred during the event, for 30 minutes each session; no assignments between sessions.
Completed Treatment Definition: received written exposure therapy as randomized
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, rape/sexual assault, child sexual abuse, child physical abuse, accidents, community/school violence
Citation: Sloan DM, Marx BP, Lee DJ, et al. A brief exposure-based treatment vs cognitive processing therapy for posttraumatic stress disorder: a randomized noninferiority clinical trial. JAMA Psychiatry. 2018 Mar 1;75(3):233-9. doi: 10.1001/jamapsychiatry.2017.4249. PMID: 29344631.

Treatment Description: Trauma-focused therapy; patients taught to recognize and challenge dysfunctional cognitions about their traumatic event and current thoughts about themselves, others, and the world; write 2 trauma accounts (at home) including sensory details, thoughts, and feelings associated with the trauma then read the account daily until the next session; additional between-session assignments given after each session.
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, rape/sexual assault, child sexual abuse, child physical abuse, accidents, community/school violence
Citation: Sloan DM, Marx BP, Lee DJ, et al. A brief exposure-based treatment vs cognitive processing therapy for posttraumatic stress disorder: a randomized noninferiority clinical trial. JAMA Psychiatry. 2018 Mar 1;75(3):233-9. doi: 10.1001/jamapsychiatry.2017.4249. PMID: 29344631.

Treatment Description: Group cognitive-behavioral intervention focused on trauma. Includes in vivo, written, and imaginal exposure, progressive muscle relaxation, cognitive restructuring, and behavioral activation. Between-session practice (homework) emphasized.
Trauma Detail (Study level): Combat-related; Child physical abuse; Child sexual abuse; Rape/sexual assault; Accidents; Community/school violence; Other (death or trauma to friend or loved one)
Citation: Sloan DM, Unger W, Lee DJ, et al. A randomized controlled trial of group cognitive behavioral treatment for veterans diagnosed with chronic posttraumatic stress disorder. J Trauma Stress. 2018b Dec;31(6):886-98. doi: 10.1002/jts.22338. PMID: 30499227.

Treatment Description: Core components of present-centered treatment include psychoeducation, peer support, and  peer-facilitated problem solving. No trauma-focused work or clinician instruction in skill development. Weekly home therapy assignments.
Trauma Detail (Study level): Combat-related; Child physical abuse; Child sexual abuse; Rape/sexual assault; Accidents; Community/school violence; Other (death or trauma to friend or loved one)
Citation: Sloan DM, Unger W, Lee DJ, et al. A randomized controlled trial of group cognitive behavioral treatment for veterans diagnosed with chronic posttraumatic stress disorder. J Trauma Stress. 2018b Dec;31(6):886-98. doi: 10.1002/jts.22338. PMID: 30499227.

Treatment Description: CPT: trauma-focused therapy in which patients are taught to recognize and challenge dysfunctional cognitions about their traumas and current thoughts about themselves, others, and the world. Delivered in 12 one-hour sessions held twice per week.
Citation: Sloan DM, Marx BP, Resick PA, et al. Effect of written exposure therapy vs cognitive processing therapy on increasing treatment efficiency among military service members with posttraumatic stress disorder: a randomized noninferiority trial. JAMA Netw Open. 2022 Jan 4;5(1):e2140911. doi: 10.1001/jamanetworkopen.2021.40911. PMID: 35015065.

Treatment Description: WET: psychoeducation and writing sessions in which participant writes about their trauma for 30 minutes with brief check ins by therapist after writing to determine challenges. Consisted of 5 sessions; no between-session assignments.
Session Length: 45-60 minutes (first session 60 minutes, remaining 4 sessions 45 minutes)
Citation: Sloan DM, Marx BP, Resick PA, et al. Effect of written exposure therapy vs cognitive processing therapy on increasing treatment efficiency among military service members with posttraumatic stress disorder: a randomized noninferiority trial. JAMA Netw Open. 2022 Jan 4;5(1):e2140911. doi: 10.1001/jamanetworkopen.2021.40911. PMID: 35015065.

Treatment Description: WET delivered in person or through video conferencing at participant's preference. Treatment consists of sessions during which participants write about a specific trauma event. Initial session for psychoeducation and treatment rationale; subsequent sessions included 30 minutes of writing-based imaginal exposure and therapist feedback on prior written narrative. Initial sessions include writing details of index trauma and resulting thoughts and feelings; in later sessions participants discuss effect of event on their lives. Participants had no between-treatment assignments. An additional 1-2 sessions were allowed to be added by the therapist to ensure adequate exposure to the trauma memory; there was no option to end treatment early (before session 5).
Treatment Duration Detail: 5 sessions minimum, study therapist had option for 1-2 additional sessions
Completed Treatment Definition: Did not drop out prior to completion
Trauma Detail (Study level): MST; Combat-related; Rape/sexual assault; Accidents; Community/school violence; Other (sudden violent death)
Citation: Sloan DM, Marx BP, Acierno R, et al. Written exposure therapy vs prolonged exposure therapy in the treatment of posttraumatic stress disorder: a randomized clinical trial. JAMA Psychiatry. 2023 Nov 1;80(11):1093-100. doi: 10.1001/jamapsychiatry.2023.2810. PMID: 37610727.

Treatment Description: Exposure-based treatment delivered in person or through video conferencing at participant's preference; sessions included 40 minutes of in-session imaginal exposure and between-session in vivo exposures." Imaginal exposure focuses on most distressing traumatic event; in vivo exercises require exposure to people, places and situations related to index trauma. Early completion was allowed at ≥8 sessions if participant score <33 on PCL-5 for at least 2 consecutive sessions and both therapist and participant agreed additional sessions were not necessary.
Completed Treatment Definition: Did not drop out prior to completion
Trauma Detail (Study level): MST; Combat-related; Rape/sexual assault; Accidents; Community/school violence; Other (sudden violent death)
Citation: Sloan DM, Marx BP, Acierno R, et al. Written exposure therapy vs prolonged exposure therapy in the treatment of posttraumatic stress disorder: a randomized clinical trial. JAMA Psychiatry. 2023 Nov 1;80(11):1093-100. doi: 10.1001/jamapsychiatry.2023.2810. PMID: 37610727.

Treatment Description:
Short-term, trauma-focused cognitive behavioral therapy, with the goal to "contextualize the sensory, affective, and cognitive memories of
trauma within the client’s life course"; NET protocol of this study followed Schauer, Elbert, and Neuner guidelines.
Trauma Detail (Study level): Terrorism/political violence/forced displacement; Other ("seeing the deformed body of a relative"; "witnessing or experiencing torture")
Citation: Smaik N, Simmons LA, Abdulhaq B, et al. The feasibility and preliminary efficacy of narrative exposure therapy on post-traumatic stress disorder among Syrian refugees in Jordan. Int J Nurs Sci. 2023 Oct;10(4):518-26. doi: 10.1016/j.ijnss.2023.09.007. PMID: 38020837.

Treatment Description: Waiting list participants received an educational lecture about positive child-rearing practices, but no active treatment.
Trauma Detail (Study level): Terrorism/political violence/forced displacement; Other ("seeing the deformed body of a relative"; "witnessing or experiencing torture")
Citation: Smaik N, Simmons LA, Abdulhaq B, et al. The feasibility and preliminary efficacy of narrative exposure therapy on post-traumatic stress disorder among Syrian refugees in Jordan. Int J Nurs Sci. 2023 Oct;10(4):518-26. doi: 10.1016/j.ijnss.2023.09.007. PMID: 38020837.

Treatment Description: SSRI antidepressant, initiated at 50 mg, dose increased to 100 mg after 14 days based on tolerability
Dose: Initiated at 50 mg, titrated to 100 mg
Citation: Smajkic A, Weine SM, Djuric-Bijedic Z, et al. Sertraline, paroxetine, and venlafaxine in refugee posttraumatic stress disorder with depression symptoms. J Trauma. Stress. 2001 Jul;14(3):445-52. doi: 10.1023/A:1011177420069. PMID: 11534876.

Treatment Description: SSRI antidepressant, dose maintained after 14 days if tolerated
Dose: 20 mg
Citation: Smajkic A, Weine SM, Djuric-Bijedic Z, et al. Sertraline, paroxetine, and venlafaxine in refugee posttraumatic stress disorder with depression symptoms. J Trauma. Stress. 2001 Jul;14(3):445-52. doi: 10.1023/A:1011177420069. PMID: 11534876.

Treatment Description: SNRI antidepressant, initiated at 37.5 mg, dose increased to 75 mg after 14 days based on tolerability
Dose: Initiated at 37.5 mg, titrated to 75 mg
Citation: Smajkic A, Weine SM, Djuric-Bijedic Z, et al. Sertraline, paroxetine, and venlafaxine in refugee posttraumatic stress disorder with depression symptoms. J Trauma. Stress. 2001 Jul;14(3):445-52. doi: 10.1023/A:1011177420069. PMID: 11534876.

Treatment Description: Participants write about traumatic event, it's effect on their thoughts, feelings, and sensations, and the rationality of their negative beliefs; three 20-minute writing sessions with 15-minute rest interval between sessions
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: adherence, defined as "completed the expermental manipulation"
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, rape/sexual assault
Citation: Smyth JM, Hockemeyer JR, Tulloch H. Expressive writing and post-traumatic stress disorder: effects on trauma symptoms, mood states, and cortisol reactivity. Br J Health Psychol. 2008 Feb;13(1):85-93. doi: 10.1348/135910707X250866. PMID: 18230238.

Treatment Description: Participants write about time management and their daily plans; three 20-minute writing sessions with 15-minute rest interval between sessions
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: adherence, defined as "completed the expermental manipulation"
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, rape/sexual assault
Citation: Smyth JM, Hockemeyer JR, Tulloch H. Expressive writing and post-traumatic stress disorder: effects on trauma symptoms, mood states, and cortisol reactivity. Br J Health Psychol. 2008 Feb;13(1):85-93. doi: 10.1348/135910707X250866. PMID: 18230238.

Arm N Randomized Detail: 62 randomized, 61 in ITT (one excluded for starting treatment after study completion)
Standardized Treatment Name: Eye Movement Desensitization and Reprocessing (EMDR) + Dialectical Behavior Therapy (DBT)
Treatment Description:
Concurrent EMDR + DBT, delivered by separate therapists. EMDR started after the 6th DBT group session, while patients concurrently received the rest of DBT.
EMDR following standard protocol (Shapiro), with optional supplementary EMDR techniques such as cognitive interweaves employed as deemed appropriate. Minimum 12 and maximum 18 sessions; exact number of sessions determined based on individual needs of participant collaboratively by patient and therapist.
DBT following protocol (Linehan) in both group and individual sessions. DBT started with up to 6 individual (motivational) 45-minute pre-treatment sessions, followed by 12-month program including 48 weekly group sessions and biweekly individual sessions. Group training focused on skills to enhance emotional regulation, interpersonal effectiveness, mindfulness, and distress tolerance.
Frequency:
EMDR: weekly
DBT: weekly (group) and biweekly (individual)
Treatment Duration Detail:
EMDR: 12-18 weekly sessions, concurrent with DBT
DBT: 12 months, concurrent with EMDR
Completed Treatment Definition:
EMDR: Attended ≥9 sessions (≥75% of minimum 12 sessions)
DBT: attended ≥37 group sessions (>75% of 48 sessions)
Completed Treatment Percent Detail:
Completed EMDR treatment: 39%
Completed DBT group treatment: 43%
Psychotherapy Sessions Completed Detail:
for overall sample
EMDR sessions: mean 6.8 (SD 5.9)
DBT sessions: mean 26.6 (SD 19.4)
for EMDR treatment completers
EMDR sessions: mean 13.5 (SD 3.3)
DBT sessions: mean 43.4 (SD 10.6)
Trauma Detail (Study level): Child physical abuse; Child sexual abuse; Child other abuse; Rape/sexual assault; Illness/medical procedure; Other ("physical violence" victim or witness, "sudden death" as witness, and "other" not specified)
Citation: Snoek A, Beekman ATF, Dekker J, Aarts I, van Grootheest G, Blankers M, Vriend C, van den Heuvel O, Thomaes K. A randomized controlled trial comparing the clinical efficacy and cost-effectiveness of eye movement desensitization and reprocessing (EMDR) and integrated EMDR-Dialectical Behavioural Therapy (DBT) in the treatment of patients with post-traumatic stress disorder and comorbid (Sub)clinical borderline personality disorder: study design. BMC Psychiatry. 2020 Aug 6;20(1):396. doi: 10.1186/s12888-020-02713-x. PMID: 32762677; PMCID: PMC7409691.

Treatment Description: EMDR following standard protocol (Shapiro), with optional supplementary EMDR techniques such as cognitive interweaves employed as deemed appropriate. Minimum 12 and maximum 18 sessions; exact number of sessions determined based on individual needs of participant collaboratively by patient and therapist.
Trauma Detail (Study level): Child physical abuse; Child sexual abuse; Child other abuse; Rape/sexual assault; Illness/medical procedure; Other ("physical violence" victim or witness, "sudden death" as witness, and "other" not specified)
Citation: Snoek A, Beekman ATF, Dekker J, Aarts I, van Grootheest G, Blankers M, Vriend C, van den Heuvel O, Thomaes K. A randomized controlled trial comparing the clinical efficacy and cost-effectiveness of eye movement desensitization and reprocessing (EMDR) and integrated EMDR-Dialectical Behavioural Therapy (DBT) in the treatment of patients with post-traumatic stress disorder and comorbid (Sub)clinical borderline personality disorder: study design. BMC Psychiatry. 2020 Aug 6;20(1):396. doi: 10.1186/s12888-020-02713-x. PMID: 32762677; PMCID: PMC7409691.

Arm N Randomized Detail: Cluster randomized 10 groups of participants to one of the two therapies
Treatment Description: Integrated gender-focused topics and cognitive processing therapy  into MBRP. CPT designed to bring awareness to trauma-related beliefs that include exaggerated blame toward the trauma survivor or generalizing trauma cues to safe situations. Sessions also included mindfulness practices bringing awareness to cognitons and behaviors contributing to substance use, and substance use as a way to cope with PTSD.
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: not further defined
Citation: Somohano VC, Bowen S. Trauma-Integrated Mindfulness-Based Relapse Prevention for Women with Comorbid Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder and Substance Use Disorder: A Cluster Randomized Controlled Feasibility and Acceptability Trial. J Integr Complement Med. 2022 May 31;31:31. doi: 10.1089/jicm.2021.0306. PMID: 35648046.

Arm N Randomized Detail: Cluster randomized 10 groups of participants to one of the two therapies
Treatment Description: Protocol including mindfulness practice, cognitive-behavioral methods, and psychoeducation on habit patterns associated with substance use. Includes navigating high-risk situations and supporting lifestyle wellness.
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: not further defined
Citation: Somohano VC, Bowen S. Trauma-Integrated Mindfulness-Based Relapse Prevention for Women with Comorbid Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder and Substance Use Disorder: A Cluster Randomized Controlled Feasibility and Acceptability Trial. J Integr Complement Med. 2022 May 31;31:31. doi: 10.1089/jicm.2021.0306. PMID: 35648046.

Treatment Description: SSRI with 10 sessions with psychiatrist/medical doctor for drug management and pscyhoeducation, 16 sessions with psychologist using flexible manual-based cognitive therapy with elements of trauma-focused therapy, acceptance commitment therapy, and mindfulness. Group and individual sessions with a social worker offered.
Dose:
Session length: NR







Dose: sertraline initiated at 25 to 50 mg/day, titrated weekly by 25 to 50 mg for first 6 weeks, then monthly up to 200 mg/day
Citation: Sonne C, Carlsson JM, Bech P, et al. Treatment of trauma-affected refugees with venlafaxine versus sertraline combined with psychotherapy - a randomised study. BMC Psychiatry. 2016 Nov 8;16(1):383. doi: 10.1186/s12888-016-1081-5. PMID: 27825327.

Treatment Description: SNRI with 10 sessions with psychiatrist/medical doctor for drug management and pscyho-education, 16 sessions with psychologist using flexible manual-based cognitive therapy with elements of trauma-focused therapy, acceptance commitment therapy, and mindfulness. Group and individual sessions with a social worker offered.
Dose:
Session length: NR







Dose: venlafaxine initiated at 37.5 to 75 mg/day, titrated weekly by 37.5 to 75 mg for first 6 weeks, then monthly up to maximum 375 mg/day
Completed Treatment Definition: ≥8 consecutive weeks of pharmacological compliance during the study period
Citation: Sonne C, Carlsson JM, Bech P, et al. Treatment of trauma-affected refugees with venlafaxine versus sertraline combined with psychotherapy - a randomised study. BMC Psychiatry. 2016 Nov 8;16(1):383. doi: 10.1186/s12888-016-1081-5. PMID: 27825327.

Treatment Description: Riluzole capsules,  50 mg bid for 2 weeks and then 100 mg bid unless patients PCL-S score decreased by 10 or more points
Dose: 50 mg bid for first 2 weeks, then 100 mg bid
Trauma Detail (Study level): Combat-related
Citation: Spangler PT, West JC, Dempsey CL, et al. Randomized controlled trial of riluzole augmentation for posttraumatic stress disorder: efficacy of a glutamatergic modulator for antidepressant-resistant symptoms. Treatment Description: Placebo capsules, identical to treatment capsules
Dose: Placebo
Trauma Detail (Study level): Combat-related
Citation: Spangler PT, West JC, Dempsey CL, et al. Randomized controlled trial of riluzole augmentation for posttraumatic stress disorder: efficacy of a glutamatergic modulator for antidepressant-resistant symptoms. Treatment Description: Online lessons include in vivo and imaginal exposure, cognitive restructuring, and de-arousal strategies. Also includes an online discussion forum moderated by the therapist and written resources about assertiveness skills, anger management, strategies for improving sleep, diet, exercise, and reducing drug and alcohol use
Completed Treatment Definition: Completed all lessons during treatment period
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: n=18 completed all 7 lessons within the 8 weeks of the program, another n=3 completed within 4 days of program end (not included as treatment completers in data entered), reports n=5 did not complete the program (this includes the n=3 completing after program end)
Trauma Detail (Study level): rape/sexual assault, accidents, community/school violence, other (not specified)
Citation: Spence J, Titov N, Dear BF, et al. Randomized controlled trial of internet-delivered cognitive behavioral therapy for posttraumatic stress disorder. Depress Anxiety. 2011 Jul;28(7):541-50. doi: 10.1002/da.20835. PMID: 21721073.

Treatment Description: Lessons include psychoeducation, stress management, and cognitive restructuring

Treatment Description: Norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor antidepressant, 8 mg/day fixed dose
Dose: 4 mg
Participant Adherence Definition: ensured by "direct questioning and by counting of medication capsules"
Citation: Spivak B, Strous RD, Shaked G, et al. Treatment Description: Scripted condition for coping skills training;  participants given a copy of the script, short overview statement, homework materials, and a CD recording of the script and overview; therapist also provided 4 coaching calls. Participants were taught "how trauma exposure can lead to distorted thoughts and beliefs, which in turn can lead to negative feelings and unhealthy behaviors. They were given “A-B-C” sheets and taught how to identify the antecedent..., beliefs and thoughts, and consequences" and taught 3 questions from skill set in Cognitive Processing Therapy to evaluate accuracy of thought/belief, and guided through use of ABC sheet for a recent drinking or craving episode; participants were to practice at home with ABC sheets.
Frequency: In-person session: once (single session); Coaching calls: weekly
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: received intervention (single in-person session) and started IVR monitoring
Citation: Stappenbeck CA, Luterek JA, Kaysen DL, et al. A controlled examination of two coping skills for daily alcohol use and PTSD symptom severity among dually diagnosed individuals. Behav Res Ther. 2015a Mar;66:8-17. doi: 10.1016/j.brat.2014.12.013. PMID: 25617814.

Treatment Description: Scripted condition for coping skills training;  participants given a copy of the script, short overview statement, homework materials, and a CD recording of the script and overview; therapist also provided 4 coaching calls. Participants introduced "to the idea that avoiding thoughts and feelings is often associated with more distress and poorer coping. Instead, accepting thoughts and feelings can enable one to make choices consistent with one's values rather than having one's behavior driven by distress or urges to drink.", and to "urge surfing" and mindful breathing meditation; participants identified ways they avoided or tried to change thoughts or feelings and how experiential acceptance concepts could be used.
Frequency: In-person session: once (single session); Coaching calls: weekly
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: received intervention (single in-person session) and started IVR monitoring
Citation: Stappenbeck CA, Luterek JA, Kaysen DL, et al. A controlled examination of two coping skills for daily alcohol use and PTSD symptom severity among dually diagnosed individuals. Behav Res Ther. 2015a Mar;66:8-17. doi: 10.1016/j.brat.2014.12.013. PMID: 25617814.

Treatment Description: Scripted condition for attention control condition; participants given a copy of the script, short overview statement, homework materials, and a CD recording of the script and overview; therapist also provided 4 coaching calls. Nutrition guidance as "comparable length interaction with the therapist that involved learning something germane to health but not specifically relevant to either PTSD or problematic alcohol use". Participants learned plate method of nutrition, assessed current eating habits, and how to align diet with recommendations.
Frequency: In-person session: once (single session); Coaching calls: weekly
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: received intervention (single in-person session) and started IVR monitoring
Citation: Stappenbeck CA, Luterek JA, Kaysen DL, et al. A controlled examination of two coping skills for daily alcohol use and PTSD symptom severity among dually diagnosed individuals. Behav Res Ther. 2015a Mar;66:8-17. doi: 10.1016/j.brat.2014.12.013. PMID: 25617814.

Standardized Treatment Name: Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) without a trauma focus
Treatment Description: CBT-based telephone session to identify and address beliefs about PTSD treatment
Citation: Stecker T, McHugo GJ, Xie HY, et al. RCT of a brief phone-based CBT intervention to improve PTSD treatment utilization by returning service members. Psychiatr Serv. 2014 Oct;65(10):1232-7. doi: 10.1176/appi.ps.201300433. PMID: 24933496.

Treatment Description: Received baseline assessment and followup assessments calls only.
Citation: Stecker T, McHugo GJ, Xie HY, et al. RCT of a brief phone-based CBT intervention to improve PTSD treatment utilization by returning service members. Psychiatr Serv. 2014 Oct;65(10):1232-7. doi: 10.1176/appi.ps.201300433. PMID: 24933496.

Treatment Description: Atypical antipsychotic + previously prescribed SSRI (fluoxetine, paroxetine or sertraline). Olanzapine started at 10 mg daily for 2 weeks, increased to 20 mg daily if needed and tolerated.
Dose: 10 to 20 mg; titration: 10 mg for 2 weeks, optional increase to maximum of 20 mg
Citation: Stein MB, Kline NA, Matloff JL. Adjunctive olanzapine for SSRI-resistant combat-related PTSD: a double-blind, placebo-controlled study. Am J Psychiatry. 2002 Oct;159(10):1777-9. doi: 10.1176/appi.ajp.159.10.1777. PMID: 12359687.

Treatment Description: Placebo + previously prescribed SSRI. Placebo started at 10 mg equivalent daily for 2 weeks, increased to 20 mg equivalent daily if needed and tolerated.
Dose: 10 to 20 mg equivalent; titration: 10 mg daily for 2 weeks, then optional; increase to 20 mg maximum
Citation: Stein MB, Kline NA, Matloff JL. Adjunctive olanzapine for SSRI-resistant combat-related PTSD: a double-blind, placebo-controlled study. Am J Psychiatry. 2002 Oct;159(10):1777-9. doi: 10.1176/appi.ajp.159.10.1777. PMID: 12359687.

Treatment Description: Losartan, an angiotensin type 1 receptor inhibitor, flexible dose with titration. Titration: initial dose 25 mg, increased as tolerated to 50 mg by week 2, 75 mg by week 4, and 100 mg at week 6; maintained at highest tolerated dose from week 6. Participants unable to tolerate 25 mg losartan were withdrawn from the study.
Dose: 25 to 100 mg
Participants Adhered Percent Detail: "did not differ significantly between losartan and placebo arms"
Trauma Detail (Study level): Combat-related; Other (not specified)
Citation: Stein MB, Jain S, Simon NM, et al. Randomized, placebo-controlled trial of the angiotensin receptor antagonist losartan for posttraumatic stress disorder. Biol Psychiatry. 2021 Oct 1;90(7):473-81. doi: 10.1016/j.biopsych.2021.05.012. PMID: 34275593.

Treatment Description: Placebo matched to losartan, flexible dose with titration. Placebo capsules contained lactose monohydrate powder and were identical to losartan capsules, Titration: initial dose 25 mg, increased as tolerated to 50 mg by week 2, 75 mg by week 4, and 100 mg at week 6; maintained at highest tolerated dose from week 6. Participants unable to tolerate 25 mg losartan were withdrawn from the study.
Dose: 25 to 100 mg equivalent
Participants Adhered Percent Detail: "did not differ significantly between losartan and placebo arms"
Trauma Detail (Study level): Combat-related; Other (not specified)
Citation: Stein MB, Jain S, Simon NM, et al. Randomized, placebo-controlled trial of the angiotensin receptor antagonist losartan for posttraumatic stress disorder. Biol Psychiatry. 2021 Oct 1;90(7):473-81. doi: 10.1016/j.biopsych.2021.05.012. PMID: 34275593.

Treatment Description: Internet-based cogntive behavioral therapy based on Interapy, with cognitive restructuring and social sharing. Protocol adapted to be linguistically and culturally appropriate and to fit within the format of the web portal. Treatment using structured writing assignments (letter-writing) and consisted of introduction, first phase "to reflect on automatic dysfunctional cognitions and adjust unrealistic assumptions (e.g. guilt)" (4 letters), and phase 2 social sharing "focused on a symbolic farewell letter.. to themselves or to a significant other". Writing sessions were scheduled and letters provided to counselor, who provided individual feedback and instructions for the next letter; psychoeducation was included at the beginning of each module.
Trauma Detail (Study level): Rape/sexual assault; Child sexual abuse; Other (not specified)
Citation: Stein J, Vohringer M, Wagner B, et al. Exposure versus cognitive restructuring techniques in brief internet-based cognitive behavioral treatment for Arabic-speaking people with posttraumatic stress disorder: randomized clinical trial. JMIR Ment Health. 2023 Dec 13;10:e48689. doi: 10.2196/48689. PMID: 38090792.

Treatment Description: Internet-based cogntive behavioral therapy based on Interapy, with self-confrontation and social sharing. Protocol adapted to be linguistically and culturally appropriate and to fit within the format of the web portal. Treatment using structured writing assignments (letter-writing) and consisted of introduction, first phase (self-controntation) participants wrote letters "about the traumatic event and their related thoughts, fears, and physiological reactions" (4 letters), and phase 2 social sharing "focused on a symbolic farewell letter.. to themselves or to a significant other". Writing sessions were scheduled and letters provided to counselor, who provided individual feedback and instructions for the next letter; psychoeducation was included at the beginning of each module.
Trauma Detail (Study level): Rape/sexual assault; Child sexual abuse; Other (not specified)
Citation: Stein J, Vohringer M, Wagner B, et al. Exposure versus cognitive restructuring techniques in brief internet-based cognitive behavioral treatment for Arabic-speaking people with posttraumatic stress disorder: randomized clinical trial. JMIR Ment Health. 2023 Dec 13;10:e48689. doi: 10.2196/48689. PMID: 38090792.

Treatment Description: Waiting period during which participants completed assessment measures but did not receive treatment.
Trauma Detail (Study level): Rape/sexual assault; Child sexual abuse; Other (not specified)
Citation: Stein J, Vohringer M, Wagner B, et al. Exposure versus cognitive restructuring techniques in brief internet-based cognitive behavioral treatment for Arabic-speaking people with posttraumatic stress disorder: randomized clinical trial. JMIR Ment Health. 2023 Dec 13;10:e48689. doi: 10.2196/48689. PMID: 38090792.

Treatment Description: Manualized trauma therapy aimed at strengthening resilience and coping capacities. Treatment elements include: psychoeducation; establishing a sense of safety and control; strengthening the adult ego of the patient, and focus on resource activation to enhance emotion regulation; techniques taught to patients include: imaginative techniques to distance from overwhelming traumatic emotions and intrusions; grounding techniques to help manage dissociative crises; and resource development and installation (an EMDR technique).
Trauma Detail (Study level): intimate partner violence, accidents, rape/sexual assault, combat-related, community/school violence, other (trafficking)
Citation: Steinert C, Bumke PJ, Hollekamp RL, et al. Treating post-traumatic stress disorder by resource activation in Cambodia. World Psychiatry. 2016 Jun;15(2):183-5. doi: 10.1002/wps.20303. PMID: 27265714.

Trauma Detail (Study level): intimate partner violence, accidents, rape/sexual assault, combat-related, community/school violence, other (trafficking)
Citation: Steinert C, Bumke PJ, Hollekamp RL, et al. Treating post-traumatic stress disorder by resource activation in Cambodia. World Psychiatry. 2016 Jun;15(2):183-5. doi: 10.1002/wps.20303. PMID: 27265714.

Treatment Description: Therapist assists patient construct a chronological narrative of their life stories with emphasis on traumatic experiences. Therapeutic re-exposures to traumatic experiences continue until associated fear responses decline
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: not further defined
Citation: Stenmark H, Catani C, Neuner F, et al. Treating PTSD in refugees and asylum seekers within the general health care system. A randomized controlled multicenter study. Behav Res Ther. 2013 Oct;51(10):641-7. doi: 10.1016/j.brat.2013.07.002. PMID: 23916633.

Treatment Description: Therapists can use any intervention except for steps specific to NET, such as help with sleep problems, depressive symptoms, problems related to asylum status, etc.
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: not further defined
Citation: Stenmark H, Catani C, Neuner F, et al. Treating PTSD in refugees and asylum seekers within the general health care system. A randomized controlled multicenter study. Behav Res Ther. 2013 Oct;51(10):641-7. doi: 10.1016/j.brat.2013.07.002. PMID: 23916633.

Arm N Randomized Detail: One later found ineligible and excluded
Treatment Description: Choosing and adopting a companion dog (not a service dog) from a Humane Society shelter. Participants paid for care, except veterinary care during which was provided by study during 6-month duration. Veterans attended 8 weekly obedience classes. "Participants anticipated keeping their companion indefinitely after the end of the study."
Treatment Duration Detail: Remained in study for 6 months, but non-comparative after 3 months when waitlist participants adopted dogs
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: treatment completion not defined; n=6 participants kept their dogs more than 2 weeks
Trauma Detail (Study level): MST; Combat-related; Other (not specified)
Citation: Stern SL, Finley EP, Mintz J, et al. Adopting a companion dog helps veterans with posttraumatic stress disorder in a pilot randomized trial. Society & Animals: Journal of Human-Animal Studies. 2024 Mar;32(2):196-218. doi: 10.1163/15685306-bja10089.

Treatment Description: Adopted dog after 3-month waiting period.
Trauma Detail (Study level): MST; Combat-related; Other (not specified)
Citation: Stern SL, Finley EP, Mintz J, et al. Adopting a companion dog helps veterans with posttraumatic stress disorder in a pilot randomized trial. Society & Animals: Journal of Human-Animal Studies. 2024 Mar;32(2):196-218. doi: 10.1163/15685306-bja10089.

Arm N Randomized Detail: 1 excluded from ITT analysis due to protocol violation (30 randomized initially, 29 analyzed)
Treatment Description: NET delivered over 15 sessions. Sessions 1-3  (50 minutes each, non-exposure) included psychoeducation on trauma, PTSD and the NET procedures. Sessions 4-15 (90 minutes each) involved trauma exposure via NET. In the last two sessions, patients received their narrative and short cognitive interventions, as needed, to reduce emotions of shame and guilt. Patients were also encouraged to reintegrate into and refocus on their daily routines.
Session Length: 50-90 minutes (50 minutes for non-exposure sessions, 90 minutes for exposure sessions; total 1,330 minutes individual therapy)
Frequency: 1-2 times per week (non-exposure sessions weekly, exposure sessions twice a week)
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: no definition provided
Trauma Detail (Study level): Child physical abuse; Child sexual abuse; Child other abuse; Community/school violence
Citation: Steuwe C, Berg M, Beblo T, et al. Narrative exposure therapy in patients with posttraumatic stress disorder and borderline personality disorder in a naturalistic residential setting: a randomized controlled trial. Front Psychiatry 2021 Nov 26;12:765348. doi: 10.3389/fpsyt.2021.765348. PMID: 34899426.

Arm N Randomized Detail: 1 excluded from ITT analysis due to protocol violation (30 randomized initially, 29 analyzed)
Treatment Description: DBT in individual and group sessions. DBT is a cognitive-behavioral treatment program that was developed to treat suicidal patients with BPD. DBT aims to help patients achieve the following: (1) reduction of suicidal behaviors, (2) reduction of therapy interfering behaviors, and (3) other risky or destabilizing behaviors. Standard DBT aims to achieve these goals by (1) conveying behavioral capabilities (skills), (2) motivating to apply these skills, (3) helping to generalize learned skills to the patient’s natural environment, (4) structuring the treatment environment to reinforce functional behavior, and 5) conveying therapeutic resources and motivation to effectively treat patients with BPD. Treatment consisted of weekly 50-min sessions of individual treatment (ten sessions over the 10 weeks) plus the following weekly group treatments: 180 min of skills training, 45 min of practicing mindfulness and psychoeducation on BPS as well as 60 min of patient-guided support group (ten sessions each over the 10 weeks).
Session Length: 50 minutes for individual sessions; 285 minutes for group sessions (total 500 minutes individual therapy and 2,850 minutes group therapy)
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: no definition provided
Trauma Detail (Study level): Child physical abuse; Child sexual abuse; Child other abuse; Community/school violence
Citation: Steuwe C, Berg M, Beblo T, et al. Narrative exposure therapy in patients with posttraumatic stress disorder and borderline personality disorder in a naturalistic residential setting: a randomized controlled trial. Front Psychiatry 2021 Nov 26;12:765348. doi: 10.3389/fpsyt.2021.765348. PMID: 34899426.

Treatment Description: Manualized 89-step protocol; "brief cognitive intervention with minimal and non-traumatising exposure to the original stimulus." Reactivation of traumatic memories in a setting that allows threat to appear less relevant and reduces intensity of emotional response.
Frequency: NR ("at least one mandatory sleep session between sessions")
Treatment Duration Detail: Two to four sessions over 3 to 4 weeks
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: "compliance with therapy" reported for overall sample only (60%, 95% CI 46.96 to 71.76); this does not appear to be the same as % of participants that did not discontinue intervention (n=4 discontinued), but no further details provided
Psychotherapy Sessions Completed Detail: "RTM was almost 5% short of the threshold of 70% retention"
Citation: Sturt J, Rogers R, Armour C, et al. Reconsolidation of traumatic memories protocol compared to trauma-focussed cognitive behaviour therapy for post-traumatic stress disorder in UK military veterans: a randomised controlled feasibility trial. Pilot & Feasibility Studies. 2023 Oct 13;9(1):175. doi: 10.1186/s40814-023-01396-x. PMID: 37833734.

Treatment Description: CBT focused on identifying the relevant appraisals, memory characteristics and triggers, and behavioural and cognitive strategies that maintain PTSD symptoms." Based on Ehlers and Clark congitive processing model.
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: "compliance with therapy" reported for overall sample only (60%, 95% CI 46.96 to 71.76); this does not appear to be the same as % of participants that did not discontinue intervention (n=6 discontinued), but no further details provided
Psychotherapy Sessions Completed Detail: "Fifty percent threshold for retention in TFCBT was achieved"
Citation: Sturt J, Rogers R, Armour C, et al. Reconsolidation of traumatic memories protocol compared to trauma-focussed cognitive behaviour therapy for post-traumatic stress disorder in UK military veterans: a randomised controlled feasibility trial. Pilot & Feasibility Studies. 2023 Oct 13;9(1):175. doi: 10.1186/s40814-023-01396-x. PMID: 37833734.

Arm N Randomized Detail: n=52 analyzed
Treatment Description: CBT designed for treatment of rape-related PTSD, includes education, cognitive restructuring, and writing trauma narratives
Citation: Surís A, Link-Malcolm J, Chard K, Ahn C, North C. A randomized clinical trial of cognitive processing therapy for veterans with PTSD related to military sexual trauma. J Trauma Stress. 2013 Feb;26(1):28-37. doi: 10.1002/jts.21765. Epub 2013 Jan 16. PMID: 23325750.
