Arm N Randomized Detail: n=27 analyzed; number randomized not reported by arm
Treatment Description:
Single dose paired with reactivation of a specific trauma memory.







Sirolimus also known as rapamycin; developed as an antifungal, used as an immunosuppressant; regulates dendritic protein synthesis in the amygdala and dorsal hippocampus through the systemic inhibition of the protein kinase mTOR (mammalian target of rapamycin) pathway. After administration of sirolimus, participants wrote script describing most distressing combat trauma memory (about 45 minute process), in next session (physicologic asessment) 7 days later, the participant listened to 3 recordings: standard neutral script, followed by personal combat script, then another standard neutral script (scripts approximately 30 to 40 seconds duration).
Dose: 15 mg
Session Length: Session length (session 2 when drug administered): mean 45 minutes (range 30 to 75)
Treatment Duration Detail: single session for medication and traumatic memory reactivation
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: single treatment session, all analyzed had complete data, no other dropouts reported
Citation: Surís AM, Smith JC, Powell CM, et al. Interfering with the reconsolidation of traumatic memory: sirolimus as a novel agent for treating veterans with posttraumatic stress disorder. Ann Clin Psychiatry. 2013 Feb;25(1):33-40. PMID: 23376868.

Arm N Randomized Detail: n=24 analyzed; number randomized not reported by arm
Treatment Description: Placebo. After administration, participants wrote script describing most distressing combat trauma memory (about 45 minute process), in next session (physiologic assessment) 7 days later, the participant listened to 3 recordings: standard neutral script, followed by personal combat script, then another standard neutral script (scripts approximately 30 to 40 seconds duration).
Session Length: Session length (session 2 when drug administered): mean 45 minutes (range 30 to 75)
Treatment Duration Detail: single session for medication and traumatic memory reactivation

Treatment Name: Dexamethasone + brief trauma memory reactivation task
Treatment Description: Glucocorticoid paired with brief trauma memory reactivation task; patients in each arm received four treatment sessions, receiving drug or placebo 60 minutes before therapy sessions that included writing a trauma narrative and listening to staff audio recordings of the narrative; audio recordings were 30 to 45 seconds.
Dose: 0.15 mg/kg
Completed Treatment Percent Detail:
"completed DEX" in flow chart, matches with "43 who provided
treatment completion data in the study" (15 in DEX, 28 in placebo)
Citation: Surís A, Holliday R, Adinoff B, Holder N, North CS. Facilitating Fear-Based Memory Extinction With Dexamethasone: A Randomized Controlled Trial in Male Veterans With Combat-Related PTSD. Psychiatry. 2017 Winter;80(4):399-410. doi: 10.1080/00332747.2017.1286892. PMID: 29466111.

Treatment Name: Placebo + brief trauma memory reactivation task
Treatment Description: Placebo paired with brief trauma memory reactivation task; patients in each arm received four treatment sessions, receiving drug or placebo 60 minutes before therapy sessions that included writing a trauma narrative and listening to staff audio recordings of the narrative; audio recordings were 30 to 45 seconds.
Completed Treatment Percent Detail:
"completed DEX" in flow chart, matches with "43 who provided
treatment completion data in the study" (15 in DEX, 28 in placebo)
Citation: Surís A, Holliday R, Adinoff B, Holder N, North CS. Facilitating Fear-Based Memory Extinction With Dexamethasone: A Randomized Controlled Trial in Male Veterans With Combat-Related PTSD. Psychiatry. 2017 Winter;80(4):399-410. doi: 10.1080/00332747.2017.1286892. PMID: 29466111.

Treatment Description: Followed standard EMDR protocol, but omitting installation phase (using eye movements with a positive cognition). Protocol used had the following steps: 1) client history and tratment planning; 2) preparation; 3) assessment, including identification of the target visual image of trauma and associated emotions and rating of subjective units of distress; 4) desensitization, by asking client  to focus on trauma while following therapist's finger moving left to right and back in visual field, with 24 cycles repeated several times, and rating of subjective units of distress, and body scan; 5) closure, including stabilization techniques and relaxation exercises.
Treatment Duration Detail: Minimum 4, maximum 6; ended if patient attained a Subjective Units of Distress (SUD) score of 0 or 1 at 4th or 5th session
Completed Treatment Definition: Received complete sessions of treatment (at least 4 sessions)
Trauma Detail (Study level): Rape/sexual assault; Intimate partner violence; Other (not specified)
Citation: Susanty E, Sijbrandij M, Srisayekti W, et al. The Effectiveness of Eye Movement Desensitization for Post-traumatic Stress Disorder in Indonesia: A Randomized Controlled Trial. Front Psychol. 2022;13:845520. doi: https://dx.doi.org/10.3389/fpsyg.2022.845520. PMID: 35548495.

Treatment Description: Trauma retrieval-only group followed same protocol as EMD group (arm A) but without eye movements. Identified a target visual image of trauma and associated emotions. Asked to focus on trauma, but omitted eye movement procedure.
Treatment Duration Detail: Minimum 4, maximum 6; ended if patient attained a Subjective Units of Distress (SUD) score of 0 or 1 at 4th or 5th session
Completed Treatment Definition: Received complete sessions of treatment (at least 4 sessions)
Trauma Detail (Study level): Rape/sexual assault; Intimate partner violence; Other (not specified)
Citation: Susanty E, Sijbrandij M, Srisayekti W, et al. The Effectiveness of Eye Movement Desensitization for Post-traumatic Stress Disorder in Indonesia: A Randomized Controlled Trial. Front Psychol. 2022;13:845520. doi: https://dx.doi.org/10.3389/fpsyg.2022.845520. PMID: 35548495.

Treatment Description: Patients instructed to write about a specific traumatic event, focusing on details of the event and the thoughts and feelings that occurred during the event, for 30 minutes each session; no assignments between sessions.
Citation: Talbot LS, Maguen S, Metzler TJ, et al. Cognitive behavioral therapy for insomnia in posttraumatic stress disorder: a randomized controlled trial. Sleep. 2014 Feb 1;37(3):327-41. doi: 10.5665/sleep.3408. PMID: 24497661.

Treatment Description: Monitored sleep using sleep diary and actigraphy; weekly telephone or email check-ins from study coordinator.
Citation: Talbot LS, Maguen S, Metzler TJ, et al. Cognitive behavioral therapy for insomnia in posttraumatic stress disorder: a randomized controlled trial. Sleep. 2014 Feb 1;37(3):327-41. doi: 10.5665/sleep.3408. PMID: 24497661.

Treatment Description: Alpha-1 adrenoreceptor antagonist, titrated over 10 days with 1-mg dose increases every 2 to 3 days based on response and tolerability; 3-week crossover periods separated by 1-week washout

Treatment Description: Placebo capsules indistinguishable from active drug, titrated over 10 days with 1-mg equivalent dose increases every 2 to 3 days based on response and tolerability; 3-week crossover periods separated by 1-week washout

Treatment Description: Included treatment planning and preparing patient for trauma-focused treatment (3 sessions), followed by desensitization and reprocessing (6 sessions), and evaluation; total 12 hours treatment. During desensitization and reprocessing, a focus on a traumatic image and the thoughts, sensations, feelings and memories that it elicits, is combined with an attention-demanding task such as tracking the therapist's fingers with the eyes. Followed Dutch version of EMDR protocol.
Session Length:
Treatment planning and preparation sessions: 60 minutes







EMDR sessions: 90 minutes
Completed Treatment Definition: Started treatment and no treatment dropout
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: n=1 did not start any treatment; n=6 discontinued intervention
Trauma Detail (Study level): terrorism/political violence/forced displacement, community/school violence
Citation: Ter Heide FJJ, Mooren TM, Van de Schoot R, et al. Eye Movement Desensitisation and Reprocessing therapy v. stabilisation as usual for refugees: randomised controlled trial. Br J Psychiatry. 2016 Oct;209(4):311-8. doi: 10.1192/bjp.bp.115.167775. PMID: 26892849.

Treatment Description: Non-structured stabilization treatment as usual aimed at enhancing safety, control over symptoms, and socio-psychological competencies through interventions such as emotion regulation and relational skills building, stress management, and cognitive restructuring; asked to not do trauma exposure. 12 weekly hour sessions provided.
Completed Treatment Definition: Started treatment and no treatment dropout
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: n=1 did not start any treatment; n=8 discontinued intervention
Trauma Detail (Study level): terrorism/political violence/forced displacement, community/school violence

Treatment Description: High frequency (10 Hz) rTMS to the right dorsolateral prefrontal cortex. 60 trains of 5-sec duration with 20-sec intertrain intervals, resulting in 3000 pulses per session. At enrollment patients prepare written trauma narratives, which they read throughout rTMS sessions.
Dose: Frequency 10 Hz with intensity at 110% of resting motor threshold.
Session Length: 45 minutes for procedure, 25 minutes for rTMS
Treatment Duration Detail: 8 sessions total, missed sessions added to end of treatment course
Psychotherapy Sessions Completed Detail: calculated from reported number of sessions completed by noncompleters and completers
Trauma Detail (Study level): Combat-related; Rape/sexual assault; Accidents; Illness/medical procedure; Community/school violence; Terrorism/political violence/forced displacement; Other (injury threatening survival)
Citation: Thierree S, Raulin-Briot M, Legrand M, et al. Combining trauma script exposure with rTMS to reduce symptoms of post-traumatic stress disorder: randomized controlled trial. Neuromodulation. 2021 Jun;25(4):549-57. doi: 10.1111/ner.13505. PMID: 35667770.

Treatment Description: Low frequency (1 Hz) rTMS (this frequency thought to have no effect on dorsolateral prefrontal cortex, so considered sham treatment). 60 trains of 5-sec duration with 20-sec intertrain intervals, totaling 300 pulses per session. At enrollment patients prepare written trauma narratives, which they read throughout rTMS sessions.
Dose: Frequency 1 Hz with intensity at 70% of resting motor threshold.
Session Length: 45 minutes for procedure, 25 minutes for rTMS
Treatment Duration Detail: 8 sessions total, missed sessions added to end of treatment course
Psychotherapy Sessions Completed Detail: calculated from reported number of sessions completed by noncompleters and completers

Treatment Description: Treatment following Foa et al. 2007 protocol, including breathing retraining skills, imaginal exposure, and in-vivo exposures

Treatment Description: Seeking Safety in group format (2 groups of 10 women each); manualized intervention addressing both trauma and substance abuse, and "designed to promote trauma recovery, increase coping strategies, reduce drug and alcohol use, and address mental health issues such as depression and PTSD that stem from traumatic exposure"; consists of 25 modules covering cognitive-behavioral and interpersonal skills, with group leader tailoring topics to the needs of participants.
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: Study reports drop out before post-test and between post-test and follow-up, reports completed post-test assessment but unclear if this was also treatment completion
Citation: Tripodi SJ, Mennicke AM, McCarter SA, et al. Evaluating seeking safety for women in prison: a randomized controlled trial. Res Soc Work Pract. 2019 Mar;29(3):281-90. doi: 10.1177/1049731517706550.

Treatment Description: Treatment-as-usual, available programming included residential substance abuse treatment, psychological services, mindful meditation, group intervention, and anger management.
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: Study reports drop out before post-test and between post-test and follow-up, reports completed post-test assessment but unclear if this was also treatment completion

Treatment Description: Yohimbine HCl: alpha-2 adrenergic receptor antagonist; oral dose given 1 hour prior to first imaginal exposure of PE treatment (session 3). PE: manualized trauma-focused treatment including psychoeducation, in vivo exposure, imaginal exposure, and discussion or processing of traumatic events, with homework focused on imaginal and in vivo exposures; early termination criteria: ≥1.5 standard deviation improvement from baseline on PCL-M, or total PCL-M score <30.
Completed Treatment Definition: completed the entire course of care
Citation: Tuerk PW, Wangelin BC, Powers MB, et al. Augmenting treatment efficiency in exposure therapy for PTSD: a randomized double-blind placebo-controlled trial of yohimbine HCl. Cogn. Behav. Ther. 2018 Sep;47(5):351-71. doi: 10.1080/16506073.2018.1432679. PMID: 29448886.

Treatment Description: Placebo: matching placebo given 1 hour prior to first imaginal exposure of PE treatment (session 3). Treatment Description: Brief cognitive intervention targeting the intrusive symptoms of PTSD; procedure includes minimal, nontraumatizing exposure to target trauma, providing dissociative experiences of traumatic memory with structural alterations as needed, design of nontraumatizing versions, and ending when trauma can't be evoked and narrative can be told without significant autonomic arousal. Sessions were separated by ‚â•24 hours.
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, other (not specified)

Standardized Treatment Name: Cognitive Behavioral Therapy for Insomnia (CBT-I) + Imagery Rehearsal Training (IRT)
Treatment Description: 3 sessions of CBT for insomnia followed by 3 sessions of imagery rehearsal therapy; CBT for insomnia: individually tailored behavioral regimen based on sleep restriction theory, stimulus control, sleep hygiene, and identification and restructuring of dysfunctional beliefs and attitudes regarding sleep; imagery rehearsal therapy: included education about the role of learning in nightmares, visual imagery skill building, and instruction in rescripting nightmares. Participants also used an electronic sleep diary to record subjective sleep symptoms daily (interactive program on hand-held computer).
Citation: Ulmer CS, Edinger JD, Calhoun PS. A multi-component cognitive-behavioral intervention for sleep disturbance in veterans with PTSD: a pilot study. J Clin Sleep Med. 2011 Feb 15;7(1):57-68.  PMID: 21344046.

Treatment Description: Participants also used an electronic sleep diary to record subjective sleep symptoms daily (interactive program on hand-held computer).
Citation: Ulmer CS, Edinger JD, Calhoun PS. A multi-component cognitive-behavioral intervention for sleep disturbance in veterans with PTSD: a pilot study. J Clin Sleep Med. 2011 Feb 15;7(1):57-68.  PMID: 21344046.

Treatment Description: A psychotherapeutic approach that reduces PTSD symptom-severity by systematically exposing the subject, in both imaginary and in vivo ways, to previously avoided traumatic internal and external stimuli.
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: 15.1% of participants were early completers, early completion allowed when PSS-SR ≤10 on two consecutive occasions
Trauma Detail (Study level): rape/sexual assault, child sexual abuse, child other abuse, accidents, natural or manmade disasters, other (traumatic psychosis, war, physical abuse)

Treatment Description: A psychotherapeutic approach in which memory representations of traumatic life experiences are processed in order to change dysfunctional beliefs about self or others that originated from damaging traumatic experiences.

Standardized Treatment Name: Eye Movement Desensitization and Reprocessing (EMDR) + cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) without a trauma focus
Treatment Description: EMDR followed by CBT. Two introductory sessions with psychoeducation and discussion of grief and social support (introductory session content was the same for all interventions); 3 sessions of EMDR with alternating eye movements following standard Dutch EMDR treatment protocol; 3 sessions of CBT focused on identifying, challenging, and changing negative cognitions related to the loss with use of behavioral experiments and cognitive restructuring.
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: also reports number that did not drop out between sessions 1 and 8, so infer that completion is 8 sessions
Trauma Detail (Study level): homicidally bereaved
Citation: van Denderen M, de Keijser J, Stewart R, et al. Treating complicated grief and posttraumatic stress in homicidally bereaved individuals: a randomized controlled trial. Clin Psychol Psychother. 2018 Feb 26(25):497-508. doi: 10.1002/cpp.2183. PMID: 29479767.

Treatment Description:
Group schema therapy (GST): treatment for personality disorder "aimed at identifying and meeting core emotional needs that have not been met in early life (i.e. secure attachment, autonomy, freedom to express, spontaneity and play, and realistic limits)." Supplemented with additional schema-focused psychomoter therapy (SF-PMT) sessions.
Imagery rescripting (ImRs): standalone PTSD intervention delivered individually, "aimed at changing emotional and cognitive aspects of aversive memories by changing the course of events within the traumatic memory by using imagination." Protocol based on existing manuals. Included 4 pre-treatment sessions to acquaint participants with schema concepts and make schema mode case conceptualization.
Session Length:
GST -
pre-treatment sessions: 45 minutes
regular GST sessions: 90 minutes
experiential GST block sessions: 75 min
ImRs: 75 minutes
Frequency:
GST -
pre-treatment sessions: weekly
regular GST sessions: weekly
experiential GST block sessions: NR
ImRs: weekly
Treatment Duration Detail: "40 weekly GST sessions" + 12 to 18 SF-PMT sessions in 2 to 3 blocks + 12 to 18 weekly ImRs sessions + 3 optional individual booster sessions (schema therapy, SF-PMT, or ImRs). Total duration unclear; Figure S1 shows GST, SF-PMT, and ImRs series running concurrently, but over 12 months instead of 40 weeks
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: attending at least 75% of GST sessions: 51.56%
Psychotherapy Sessions Completed Detail:
for overall sample
GST sessions: mean 33.3 (SD 18.7)
ImRs sessions: mean 9.2 (SD 6.1)
data also provided for completers and non-completers (not entered)

Treatment Name: EMDR +  targeted memory reactivation using EMDR clicks
Standardized Treatment Name: Eye Movement Desensitization and Reprocessing (EMDR) + targeted memory reactivation
Treatment Description: Single session of EMDR including standard auditory clicks. While asleep during the following night, patients received targeted memory reactivation (TMR) using the EMDR clicks as auditory cue. TMR: slow oscillation (SO) phase-targeted TMR, using modeling-based closed-loop neurostimulation (M-CLNS) of polysomnography EEG signal to time lock EMDR clicks to SO upwaves.
Treatment Duration Detail: 1 day; single EMDR session + TMR during subsequent sleep cycle
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: single session, infer that all participants completed/assessed
Citation: van der Heijden AC, van der Werf YD, van den Heuvel OA, Talamini LM, van Marle HJF. Targeted memory reactivation to augment treatment in post-traumatic stress disorder. Curr Biol. 2024 Aug 19;34(16):3735-3746.e5. doi: 10.1016/j.cub.2024.07.019. Epub 2024 Aug 7. PMID: 39116885.

Standardized Treatment Name: Eye Movement Desensitization and Reprocessing (EMDR) + sham memory reactivation
Treatment Description: Single session of EMDR including standard auditory clicks. While asleep during the following night, patients received no auditory cue (sham targeted memory reactivation [TMR]). Polysomnography EEG was marked at same time targets as in active TMR group (slow oscillation upwaves).
Treatment Duration Detail: 1 day; single EMDR session + sham TMR during subsequent sleep cycle
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: single session, infer that all participants completed/assessed
Citation: van der Heijden AC, van der Werf YD, van den Heuvel OA, Talamini LM, van Marle HJF. Targeted memory reactivation to augment treatment in post-traumatic stress disorder. Curr Biol. 2024 Aug 19;34(16):3735-3746.e5. doi: 10.1016/j.cub.2024.07.019. Epub 2024 Aug 7. PMID: 39116885.

J Clin Psychiatry. 2007 Jan;68(1):37-46. doi: 10.4088/JCP.v68n0105. PMID: 17284128.

Arm N Randomized Detail: total n=76 randomized, n=12 withdrew consent prior to treatment (Ns not given by arm), reports on and analyzed n=32
Treatment Description: Trauma-informed Hatha yoga, including breathing, postures, and meditation elements
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: did not drop out during the 10-week treatment phase
Citation: van der Kolk BA, Stone L, West J, et al. Yoga as an adjunctive treatment for posttraumatic stress disorder: a randomized controlled trial. J Clin Psychiatry. 2014 Jun;75(6):e559-65. doi: 10.4088/JCP.13m08561. PMID: 25004196.

Arm N Randomized Detail: total n=76 randomized, n=12 withdrew consent prior to treatment (Ns not given by arm), reports on and analyzed n=32
Treatment Description: Education focusing on active participation and support, and to increase self-efficacy (no discussion of trauma)
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: did not drop out during the 10-week treatment phase
Citation: van der Kolk BA, Stone L, West J, et al. Yoga as an adjunctive treatment for posttraumatic stress disorder: a randomized controlled trial. J Clin Psychiatry. 2014 Jun;75(6):e559-65. doi: 10.4088/JCP.13m08561. PMID: 25004196.

Treatment Description:
EEG training following flexible, principle-based manual; training intended to teach subjects to alter the power spectrum of specific filtered frequencies of activity; reward indicated with auditory and visual feedback (auditory tones, progress in simple computer games); adjustment of reward frequency based on rated symptoms of over-arousal and under-arousal; training time increased by 3-minute increments when subject reported positive change.







Continuation of all ongoing treatments (psychotherapeutic and pharmacological).
Dose:
Dose:



Inhibit frequencies: 2 to 6 Hz, and 22 to 36 Hz



Reward frequency: initial 10 to 13 Hz
Trauma Detail (Study level): child other abuse, rape/sexual assault, intimate partner violence, other (not specified)
Citation: Van der Kolk BA, Hodgdon HB, Gapen MA, et al. A randomized controlled study of neurofeedback for chronic PTSD. PLoS One. 2016 Dec 16;11(12):e0166752. doi: 10.1371/journal.pone.0166752. PMID: 27992435.

Treatment Description: Continuation of all ongoing treatments (psychotherapeutic and pharmacological) during waiting period, received neurofeedback intervention after completing week 12 evaluation
Trauma Detail (Study level): child other abuse, rape/sexual assault, intimate partner violence, other (not specified)
Citation: Van der Kolk BA, Hodgdon HB, Gapen MA, et al. A randomized controlled study of neurofeedback for chronic PTSD. PLoS One. 2016 Dec 16;11(12):e0166752. doi: 10.1371/journal.pone.0166752. PMID: 27992435.

Treatment Name: Multi-modular motion-assisted memory desensitization and reconsolidation (3MDR)
Standardized Treatment Name: Multi-modular motion-assisted memory desensitization and reconsolidation (3MDR)
Treatment Description: Manualized intervention combining techniques of virtual reality and EMDR. Participant walks on treadmill while viewing synchronized virtual reality environment, personalized for individual participant with images and music, and going through sequence for EMDR. Each session ended wth therapist-led discussion of experiences.
Completed Treatment Definition: Received intervention and did not discontinue
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: flow diagram, participants "received  intervention" (n=21) minus those discontinued intervention (n=1)
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, accidents, illness/medical procedure, community/school violence, terrorism/political violence/forced displacement, other ("severe human suffering", "death caused to someone else", "explosion or fire")
Citation: van Gelderen MJ, Nijdam MJ, Haagen JFG, et al. Interactive motion-assisted exposure therapy for veterans with treatment-resistant posttraumatic stress disorder: a randomized controlled trial. Psychother Psychosom. 2020 Mar 23;89(4):215-27. doi: 10.1159/000505977. PMID: 32203971.

Treatment Description: Non-trauma-focused treatment delivered by a team with psychiatrist and mental health worker; allowed "case management, medication consults, stabilizing interventions, psychoeducation, systemic interventions and cognitive behavioral therapy without trauma-focused elements such as exposure or cognitive restructuring of distorted cognitions related to traumatic events"
Completed Treatment Definition: Received intervention and did not discontinue
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: flow diagram, participants "received  intervention" (n=21) minus those discontinued intervention (n=1)
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, accidents, illness/medical procedure, community/school violence, terrorism/political violence/forced displacement, other ("severe human suffering", "death caused to someone else", "explosion or fire")
Citation: van Gelderen MJ, Nijdam MJ, Haagen JFG, et al. Interactive motion-assisted exposure therapy for veterans with treatment-resistant posttraumatic stress disorder: a randomized controlled trial. Psychother Psychosom. 2020 Mar 23;89(4):215-27. doi: 10.1159/000505977. PMID: 32203971.

Treatment Description: Software application focused on restructuring and relearning past events using photos, narrative texts, maps, and 3D virtual worlds. Participant received introductory session with trained therapist and provided with treatment manual, then autonomously followed through the 12 sessions of 3MR intervention at home with use of the treatment manual.
Trauma Detail (Study level): Child sexual abuse; Other ("war related")
Citation: van Meggelen M, Morina N, van der Heiden C, et al. A randomized controlled trial to pilot the efficacy of a computer-based intervention with elements of virtual reality and limited therapist assistance for the treatment of post-traumatic stress disorder. Front Digit Health. 2022;4:974668. doi: 10.3389/fdgth.2022.974668. PMID: 36329832.

Treatment Description: 12 sessions of a trauma-focused intervention for PTSD (imaginal exposure, eye movement desnsitization and reprocessing, or narrative exposure therapy)
Trauma Detail (Study level): Child sexual abuse; Other ("war related")

Treatment Name: Transcranial direct current stimulation + Virtual reality exposure
Standardized Treatment Name: Virtual reality exposure therapy (VRET) + Transcranial direct current stimulation (tDCS)
Treatment Description:
Simultaneous transcranial direct current stimulation and virtual reality exposure



Transcranial direct current stimulation: stimulation targeting ventromedial prefrontal cortex using neuroConn DC Stimulator Plus



Virtual reality exposure: "head-mounted display with integrated head tracking and stereo earphones presenting combat-related multisensory information". Each session included driving scenarios with presentation of warzone events.
Dose: Dose: 2 mA (transcranial direct current stimulation)
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: Infer from study text that all participants completed all sessions, "Twelve male Veterans with warzone-related PTSD… completed six VR sessions… over two weeks "
Citation: van 't Wout-Frank M, Shea MT, Larson VC, et al. Combined transcranial direct current stimulation with virtual reality exposure for posttraumatic stress disorder: feasibility and pilot results. Brain Stimul. 2019 Jan - Feb;12(1):41-3. doi: 10.1016/j.brs.2018.09.011. PMID: 30266416.

Treatment Name: Sham transcranial direct current stimulation + Virtual reality exposure
Treatment Description:
Simultaneous sham transcranial direct current stimulation and virtual reality exposure



Sham transcranial direct current stimulation: sham stimulation using neuroConn DC Stimulator Plus



Virtual reality exposure: "head-mounted display with integrated head tracking and stereo earphones presenting combat-related multisensory information". Each session included driving scenarios with presentation of warzone events.
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: Infer from study text that all participants completed all sessions, "Twelve male Veterans with warzone-related PTSD… completed six VR sessions… over two weeks "
Citation: van 't Wout-Frank M, Shea MT, Larson VC, et al. Combined transcranial direct current stimulation with virtual reality exposure for posttraumatic stress disorder: feasibility and pilot results. Brain Stimul. 2019 Jan - Feb;12(1):41-3. doi: 10.1016/j.brs.2018.09.011. PMID: 30266416.

Treatment Name: Transcranial direct current stimulation (tDCS) + warzone virtual reality
Standardized Treatment Name: Virtual reality exposure therapy (VRET) + Transcranial direct current stimulation (tDCS)
Treatment Description: tDCS delivered using NeuroConn DC-Stimulator Plus to ventromedial prefrontal cortex with 2mA current, simultaneous with VR. Bravemind VR application included "visual, auditory, haptic, and olfactory immersion into virtual Iraq or Afghanistan," with events increasing in intensity from riding in an armored vehicle and a distant gun battle to an improvised explosive device [IED] detonating in front of the participant's vehicle causing a lead vehicle to flip.
Frequency: Up to 3 times a week (at least one day between sessions)
Treatment Duration Detail: Up to 6 sessions over 10 business days, with at least 1 day between sessions
Citation: van't Wout-Frank M, Arulpragasam AR, Faucher C, et al. Virtual reality and transcranial direct current stimulation for posttraumatic stress disorder a randomized clinical trial. JAMA Psychiatry. 2024;81(5):437-46. doi: 10.1001/jamapsychiatry.2023.5661. PMID: 38446471.

Arm N Randomized Detail: 29 randomized, 1 became ineligible due to increased suicidal ideation and was excluded
Treatment Name: Sham direct current stimulation (DCS) + warzone virtual reality
Treatment Description: Sham DCS delivered using NeuroConn study mode to ventromedial prefrontal cortex with 10 µA current pulse over 15 milliseconds every 550 milliseconds and 3 ms peak current, simultaneous with VR. Bravemind VR application included "visual, auditory, haptic, and olfactory immersion into virtual Iraq or Afghanistan," with events increasing in intensity from riding in an armored vehicle and a distant gun battle to an improvised explosive device [IED] detonating in front of the participant's vehicle causing a lead vehicle to flip.
Frequency: Up to 3 times a week (at least one day between sessions)
Treatment Duration Detail: Up to 6 sessions over 10 business days, with at least 1 day between sessions
Citation: van't Wout-Frank M, Arulpragasam AR, Faucher C, et al. Virtual reality and transcranial direct current stimulation for posttraumatic stress disorder a randomized clinical trial. JAMA Psychiatry. 2024;81(5):437-46. doi: 10.1001/jamapsychiatry.2023.5661. PMID: 38446471.

Standardized Treatment Name: Skills Training in Affect and Interpersonal Regulation (STAIR) + Eye Movement Desensitization and Reprocessing (EMDR)
Treatment Description: Phase-based approach with STAIR (8 sessions) followed by EMDR (16 sessions).
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: Early completer (defined as all trauma targets processed and no longer meet criteria for PTSD), included in count for completers: 50.9%
Trauma Detail (Study level): Child sexual abuse; Child physical abuse
Citation: Van Vliet NI, Huntjens RJC, Van DMK, et al. Phase-based treatment versus immediate trauma-focused treatment for post-traumatic stress disorder due to childhood abuse: randomised clinical trial. BJPsych Open. 2021 Nov;7(6):e211. doi: 10.1192/bjo.2021.1057.

Treatment Description: EMDR only (16 sessions)
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: Early completer (defined as all trauma targets processed and no longer meet criteria for PTSD), included in count for completers: 45.3%

Treatment Description: Individual therapy delivered following the culturally adapted Spanish version of PE manual; this version includes language, idioms, and examples relevant to Latino culture. An addition, optional introductory session was provided with participants and spouse or partner, giving an overview of PTSD and the goals and methods of PE. PE therapy included psychoeducation, imaginal exposure, in vivo exposure, discussion of exposure and processing of traumatic memories, and homework with imaginal and in vivo exposure.
Citation: Vera M, Reyes-Rabanillo ML, Juarbe D, et al. Prolonged exposure for the treatment of Spanish-speaking Puerto Ricans with posttraumatic stress disorder: a feasibility study. BMC Res. Notes. 2011 Oct 17;4:415. doi: 10.1186/1756-0500-4-415. PMID: 22005187.

Treatment Description: Participants referred to mental health provider at the study setting or could self-refer for outside provider; treatment in "most cases" included pharmacologic medication and/or psychotherapy; allowed changes in psychotropic medication.
Citation: Vera M, Reyes-Rabanillo ML, Juarbe D, et al. Prolonged exposure for the treatment of Spanish-speaking Puerto Ricans with posttraumatic stress disorder: a feasibility study. BMC Res. Notes. 2011 Oct 17;4:415. doi: 10.1186/1756-0500-4-415. PMID: 22005187.

Treatment Description: PE intervention culturally adapted for Spanish-speaking Latino population in Puerto Rico. Twelve sessions, with a possible extension of up to 15 sessions if needed to reinforce skills. Included breathing training, education about trauma and PTSD, and imaginal and in vivo exposure in sessions and at home.
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: 69.4% completed ≥12 sessions
Trauma Detail (Study level): Combat-related; Rape/sexual assault; Accidents; Community/school violence; Other (exposure to "unexpected or violent death")
Citation: Vera M, Oben A, Juarbe D, et al. A randomized clinical trial of prolonged exposure and applied relaxation for the treatment of Latinos with posttraumatic stress disorder. J Trauma Stress. 2022 Apr;35(2):593-604. doi: 10.1002/jts.22773. PMID: 34973048.

Treatment Description: Applied relaxation skills included detecting early signs of stress, and learning relaxation skills (diaphragmatic breathing and progressive muscle relaxation) to apply at initial signs of stress. Practiced skills in sessions and at home. Twelve sessions, with a possible extension of up to 15 sessions if needed to reinforce skills. Engagement session included to collect information on trauma exposure and reactions.
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: 71.4% completed ≥12 sessions
Trauma Detail (Study level): Combat-related; Rape/sexual assault; Accidents; Community/school violence; Other (exposure to "unexpected or violent death")
Citation: Vera M, Oben A, Juarbe D, et al. A randomized clinical trial of prolonged exposure and applied relaxation for the treatment of Latinos with posttraumatic stress disorder. J Trauma Stress. 2022 Apr;35(2):593-604. doi: 10.1002/jts.22773. PMID: 34973048.

Treatment Description: Second generation antipsychotic
Dose: Target 400 mg, initiated at 25 mg daily, titrate to 400 mg by 2 weeks. Could go up to 800 mg max (50 mg minimum)
Citation: Villarreal G, Hamner MB, Ca√±ive JM, et al. Efficacy of quetiapine monotherapy in posttraumatic stress disorder: a randomized, placebo-controlled trial. Am J Psychiatry. 2016 Dec;173(12):1205-12. doi: 10.1176/appi.ajp.2016.15070967. PMID: 27418378.

Treatment Description: Placebo titrated as per active study drug
Citation: Villarreal G, Hamner MB, Ca√±ive JM, et al. Efficacy of quetiapine monotherapy in posttraumatic stress disorder: a randomized, placebo-controlled trial. Am J Psychiatry. 2016 Dec;173(12):1205-12. doi: 10.1176/appi.ajp.2016.15070967. PMID: 27418378.

Arm N Randomized Detail: n=39 randomized; 6 excluded post-randomization for not meeting PTSD criteria
Treatment Name: Prebiotic bars + CPT-based intensive PTSD treatment program
Treatment Description:
Prebiotic bars using a proprietary formula, designed to promote complementary groups of core beneficial intestinal bacteria and augment production of short chain fatty acids. Bars contained 10 g fiber per bar from 4 prebiotic fibers: resistant starch, rice bran, resistant maltodextrin, and inulin. One bar daily during the first week, then two bars per day for the remaining 11 weeks (total 161 bars). Concurrent with intensive treatment program, and continued at home following completion of intensive treatment program.
All participants also attended the same two-week CPT-based intensive PTSD treatment program, which is comprised of 16 twice daily 50-min sessions of individual CPT as well as adjunctive services such as psychoeducation, art therapy, and mindfulness training.
Dose: 10 g prebiotic fiber/bar
Frequency:
Week 1: daily
Weeks 2-12: twice a day
Treatment Duration Detail: total 161 bars over 12 weeks; intensive PTSD treatment program 2 weeks
Participant Adherence Definition: Average compliance (%, bars consumed out of 161)
Participants Adhered Percent Detail: Mean bars consumed: 151
Trauma Detail (Study level): MST; Combat-related
Citation: Voigt RM, Engen PA, Villanueva M, Bambi SA, Green SJ, Naqib A, Raeisi S, Shaikh M, Hamaker BR, Cantu-Jungles TM, Pridgen SA, Held P, Keshavarzian A. Prebiotics as an adjunct therapy for posttraumatic stress disorder: a pilot randomized controlled trial. Front Neurosci. 2025 Jan 7;18:1477519. doi: 10.3389/fnins.2024.1477519. PMID: 39840022; PMCID: PMC11747240.

Treatment Name: Intensive trauma-focused treatment for PTSD + Physical activity
Treatment Description:
Physical activity: prescribed combination of aerobic and resistance training performed at moderate intensity, including outside walking sessions, aerobic group games, and online physical activity sessions in individual and group formats.
Intensive trauma-focused treatment for PTSD: daily treatment including individual PE, EMDR, and group psychoeducation. All participants received the same duration and frequency of these components.
Treatment Duration Detail: 8 sessions total over 2 weeks (2x4 consecutive days with a 3 day pause in between)
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: Not specified whether intervention completion definition included completion of both physical activity and intensive trauma-focused treatment for PTSD or physical activity sessions only
Trauma Detail (Study level): Natural or manmade disasters; Other (sexual abuse, not further specified; physical abuse, not further specified)
Citation: Voorendonk EM, Sanches SA, Tollenaar MS, et al. Adding physical activity to intensive trauma-focused treatment for post-traumatic stress disorder: results of a randomized controlled trial. Front Psychol. 2023;14 doi: 10.3389/fpsyg.2023.1215250. PMID: 37546473.

Treatment Name: Intensive trauma-focused treatment for PTSD + Non-physical activity
Treatment Description:
Non-physical activity: prescribed mix of guided (creative) tasks that did not involve physical activity and performed while seated, including craft activities, board games, or reading, and a mix of individual and group and indoor and outdoor activities.
Intensive trauma-focused treatment for PTSD: daily treatment including individual PE, EMDR, and group psychoeducation. All participants received the same duration and frequency of these components.
Treatment Duration Detail: 8 sessions total over 2 weeks (2x4 consecutive days with a 3 day pause in between)
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: Not specified whether intervention completion definition included completion of both non-physical activity and intensive trauma-focused treatment for PTSD or non-physical activity sessions only
Trauma Detail (Study level): Natural or manmade disasters; Other (sexual abuse, not further specified; physical abuse, not further specified)
Citation: Voorendonk EM, Sanches SA, Tollenaar MS, et al. Adding physical activity to intensive trauma-focused treatment for post-traumatic stress disorder: results of a randomized controlled trial. Front Psychol. 2023;14 doi: 10.3389/fpsyg.2023.1215250. PMID: 37546473.

Treatment Description: Identification and enactment of activities that are reinforcing to individual's long-term goals. Program includes identification of goals and activities, identification of patterns of avoidance that block attainment of these goals, and alternative coping strategies. Psychoeducation modified to include descriptions of PTSD symptoms and emphasize the role of avoidance in PTSD
Treatment Duration Detail: 4 to 6 sessions total, mean 9.8 (SD = 3.0) weeks from first session to last session
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: "One of the four patients was not done with treatment at the time of the 3-month assessment"
Citation: Wagner AW, Zatzick DF, Ghesquiere A, et al. Behavioral activation as an early intervention for posttraumatic stress disorder and depression among physically injured trauma survivors. Cogn Behav Pract. 2007 Nov;14(4):341-9. doi: 10.1016/j.cbpra.2006.05.002.

Treatment Description: Participants offered a list of community referrals
Citation: Wagner AW, Zatzick DF, Ghesquiere A, et al. Behavioral activation as an early intervention for posttraumatic stress disorder and depression among physically injured trauma survivors. Cogn Behav Pract. 2007 Nov;14(4):341-9. doi: 10.1016/j.cbpra.2006.05.002.

Treatment Description: Treatment following Bartell et al. 2001 protocol, including behavioral analyses for assessing avoidance patterns, activity scheduling and monitoring of reactions, present-centered strategies to decrease rumination, and psychoeducation
Trauma Detail (Study level): military-related
Citation: Wagner AW, Jakupcak M, Kowalski HM, et al. Behavioral activation as a treatment for posttraumatic stress disorder among returning veterans: a randomized trial. Psychiatr Serv. 2019 Oct 1;70(10):867-73. doi: 10.1176/appi.ps.201800572. PMID: 31337325.

Treatment Description: Participants were allowed any standard care, including PE, CPT, alternative treatments and coping-skills training (e.g., acceptance and commitment therapy, anger management). All patients were offered ≥6 individual psychotherapy appointments
Trauma Detail (Study level): military-related
Citation: Wagner AW, Jakupcak M, Kowalski HM, et al. Behavioral activation as a treatment for posttraumatic stress disorder among returning veterans: a randomized trial. Psychiatr Serv. 2019 Oct 1;70(10):867-73. doi: 10.1176/appi.ps.201800572. PMID: 31337325.

Arm N Randomized Detail: total n=114 randomized (Ns not given by arm), n=12 withdrew (Ns not given by arm), reports on and analyzed n=27
Treatment Description: Body scan mindfulness technique training; at each session the research assistant read a script defining mindfulness, explaining each aspect of the definition and provided examples for how to deepen the skills and their importance to mindfulness practice; training was with an audio recording, performed in silence, stillness and sitting upright; instructed to gently redirect wandering attention back to the body part that was the focus of awareness. Guided meditation did not direct attention to the breath or breathing process. Participants were asked to practice at home daily between sessions using the same recording, and submit weekly logs of practice.
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: publication reports study/assessment completion only, no information specifically on treatment completion
Citation: Wahbeh H, Goodrich E, Goy E, et al. Mechanistic pathways of mindfulness meditation in combat veterans with posttraumatic stress disorder. J Clin Psychol. 2016 Apr;72(4):365-83. doi: 10.1002/jclp.22255. PMID: 26797725.

Arm N Randomized Detail: total n=114 randomized (Ns not given by arm), n=12 withdrew (Ns not given by arm), reports on and analyzed n=25
Treatment Description: Used the RESPeRATE breathing biofeedback device designed to reduce respiratory rate.
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: publication reports study/assessment completion only, no information specifically on treatment completion

Arm N Randomized Detail: total n=114 randomized (Ns not given by arm), n=12 withdrew (Ns not given by arm), reports on and analyzed n=25
Treatment Description: Mindfulness training focusing attention on the breath; at each session the research assistant read a script defining mindfulness, explaining each aspect of the definition and provided examples for how to deepen the skills and their importance to mindfulness practice; training was with an audio recording and participants sat upright; attention directed to the breath with conscious observation of breathing, naturally slowing their breath. Participants were asked to practice at home daily between sessions using the same recording, and submit weekly logs of practice.
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: publication reports study/assessment completion only, no information specifically on treatment completion

Arm N Randomized Detail: total n=114 randomized (Ns not given by arm), n=12 withdrew (Ns not given by arm), reports on and analyzed n=25
Treatment Description: Participants sat quietly while listening to a neutral-content audiobook during sessions. Participants were asked to practice at home daily between sessions by sitting quietly alone and engaging in an activity besides watching TV or browsing the internet, asked to submit weekly logs of practice.
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: publication reports study/assessment completion only, no information specifically on treatment completion
Citation: Wahbeh H, Goodrich E, Goy E, et al. Mechanistic pathways of mindfulness meditation in combat veterans with posttraumatic stress disorder. J Clin Psychol. 2016 Apr;72(4):365-83. doi: 10.1002/jclp.22255. PMID: 26797725.

Treatment Description:
Traumatic stress protocol (TSP): simplified somatic EMDR
protocol consisting of simplified eye movement desensitization and reprocessing (EMDR) with bilateral tactile stimuli at 4 body points, in combination with microdosed pharmacotherapy and Kampo (traditional Chinese herbal medicines. Microdosed pharmacotherapy: 0.2 mg/day aripiprazole, 2 mg/day lithium carbonate, 0.8 mg/day ramelteon. Kampo: 5 g/day of Gui Zhi Jia Shao Yao Tang (GST) or Xiao Jian Zhong Wan (XJW) and 5 g/day or Si Wu Tang Wan (SWW) or Shi Quan Da Bu Wan (SDW).
Dose:
aripiprazole: 0.2 mg/day
lithium carbonate: 2 mg/day
ramelteon: 0.8 mg/day ramelteon
Chinese traditional herbal medicine (Kampo): total 10 g/day
Treatment Duration Detail: 4-5 EMDR sessions every 2-3 weeks, over about 2 months
Trauma Detail (Study level): Other ("childhood abuse" not further specified); Other (not specified)
Citation: Wakusawa K, Sugiyama T, Hotta H, et al. Triadic therapy based on somatic eye movement desensitization and reprocessing for complex posttraumatic stress disorder: a pilot randomized controlled study. Journal of EMDR Practice and Research. 2023;17(3):159-70. doi: 10.1891/EMDR-2023-0014.

Treatment Description: Waitlist
Trauma Detail (Study level): Other ("childhood abuse" not further specified); Other (not specified)
Citation: Wakusawa K, Sugiyama T, Hotta H, et al. Triadic therapy based on somatic eye movement desensitization and reprocessing for complex posttraumatic stress disorder: a pilot randomized controlled study. Journal of EMDR Practice and Research. 2023;17(3):159-70. doi: 10.1891/EMDR-2023-0014.

Treatment Name: diaphragmatic breathing with  BreatheWell Wear + TAU
Treatment Description:
Diaphragmatic breathing with BreatheWell Wear: twice daily during slow, calm periods and are encouraged to use DB when they experience stress or anxiety, with help from the BreatheWell Wear smartwatch App.

TAU: intensive outpatient rehabilitation program, SHARE, with individual and group therapies, including physical, occupational, recreational, speech-language/cognitive and behavioral health, targeted to support patient goal attainment, as well as instruction in diaphragmatic breathing  by their behavioral health provider; participants are instructed to practice diaphragmatic breathing
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: treatment completion not defined, reports study (assessment) completion (n=15); also reports app usability metrics

Treatment Description:

Treatment Description: Behavioral activation integrated with CPT: Manualized individual therapy; "selected content from the BATD-R (Brief Behavioral Activation Treatment for Depression: Revised) manual was incorporated into the CPT protocol. Specifically, BA content was the sole focus of the first two sessions and integrated into the CPT sessions thereafter." Session contents included psychoeducation, activity tracking, value and activity assessment, behavioral goals, and CPT content.
Treatment Duration Detail: 14 weekly sessions, goal to complete all within 20 weeks
Trauma Detail (Study level): Combat-related; Rape/sexual assault; Other (not specified)
Citation: Walter KH, Hunt WM, Otis NP, et al. Comparison of behavioral activation-enhanced cognitive processing therapy and cognitive processing therapy among U.S. service members: a randomized clinical trial. Psychiatry Res. 2023;326 doi: 10.1016/j.psychres.2023.115330. PMID: 37418778.

Treatment Description:
Manualized individual therapy; used the 12-session CPT Veteran/Military Version manual including the written trauma account. CPT treatment aims to "encourage examination and modification of
trauma-related beliefs, with the goal of adopting more realistic beliefs
and subsequent emotions". CPT did not include behavioral activation or psychoeducation about depression.
Treatment Duration Detail: 12 weekly sessions, goal to complete all within 20 weeks; some participants received additional sessions
Trauma Detail (Study level): Combat-related; Rape/sexual assault; Other (not specified)
Citation: Walter KH, Hunt WM, Otis NP, et al. Comparison of behavioral activation-enhanced cognitive processing therapy and cognitive processing therapy among U.S. service members: a randomized clinical trial. Psychiatry Res. 2023;326 doi: 10.1016/j.psychres.2023.115330. PMID: 37418778.

Standardized Treatment Name: Cognitive Behavioral Therapy for Insomnia (CBT-I) + Imagery Rehearsal Training (IRT)
Treatment Description:
IRT: manualized therapy for nightmares; did not include exposure to the nightmare



CBT-I: comprised of "psychoeducation on chronic insomnia, sleep restriction, stimulus control, sleep hygiene, stress reduction and relaxation, decatastrophization of consequences through cognitive restructuring, and relapse prevention"
Citation: Walters EM, Jenkins MM, Nappi CM, et al. The impact of prolonged exposure on sleep and enhancing treatment outcomes with evidence-based sleep interventions: a pilot study. Psychol Trauma. 2020 Feb;12(2):175-85. doi: 10.1037/tra0000478. PMID: 31246050.

Treatment Description: Nondirective Rogerian therapy, strictly avoided components of IRT and CBT-I. Uses empathetic listening, clarification of goals, and nondirective questioning to help participants "better understand their emotional response to PTSD symptoms and provide supportive, unconditional positive regard to managing their own PTSD symptoms".
Citation: Walters EM, Jenkins MM, Nappi CM, et al. The impact of prolonged exposure on sleep and enhancing treatment outcomes with evidence-based sleep interventions: a pilot study. Psychol Trauma. 2020 Feb;12(2):175-85. doi: 10.1037/tra0000478. PMID: 31246050.

Treatment Description: Scalp electroacupuncture on Sishencong, Baihui, Shenting, and Fengchi points using continuous wave of 100 Hz.

Treatment Description: Neuronetic 2100 (Neuronetics, LLC, Marietta, GA) used. Before the first session, the right motor threshold was determined by increasing the intensity of stimulation by 2.5% increments over the right motor cortex until there is any movement of the digits of the left hand. For subsequent treatments the coil was placed 4 cm anterior parasagittally and 2 cm laterally of the motor strip location that caused hand movement. This placement approximated the location of the right dorsolateral prefrontal cortex. Active rTMS was delivered to the right dorsolateral prefrontal cortex at 90% of motor threshold
Dose: Cycles were 1 Hz for a total of 20 minutes per day. Each 1 minute cycle consisted of a 20-second stimulation train with a 40-second intertrain interval.
Session Length: Cycles were 1 Hz for a total of 20 minutes per day. Each 1 minute cycle consisted of a 20-second stimulation train with a 40-second intertrain interval.
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: does not report any study or treatment dropouts
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, rape/sexual assault, community/school violence, other (multiple trauma)
Citation: Watts BV, Landon B, Groft A, et al. A sham controlled study of repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation for posttraumatic stress disorder. Brain Stimul. 2012 Jan;5(1):38-43. doi: 10.1016/j.brs.2011.02.002. PMID: 22264669.

Treatment Description: Motor threshold determined by increasing the intensity of stimulation by 2.5% increments over the right motor cortex until left-hand digit movement. Subsequent treatments given using a sham magnetic coil that looks and sounds identical to the active coil, but prevents magnetic energy from leaving the device.
Dose: Cycles were 1 Hz for a total of 20 minutes per day. Each 1 minute cycle consisted of a 20-second stimulation train with a 40-second intertrain interval.
Session Length: Cycles were 1 Hz for a total of 20 minutes per day. Each 1 minute cycle consisted of a 20-second stimulation train with a 40-second intertrain interval.

reports as app engagement -

Treatment Name: Skills training in affective and interpersonal regulation (STAIR) + eye movement desensitization and reprocessing (EMDR)
Standardized Treatment Name: Skills Training in Affect and Interpersonal Regulation (STAIR) + Eye Movement Desensitization and Reprocessing (EMDR)
Treatment Description:
STAIR followed by EMDR
STAIR: manualized therapy in which emotion dysregulation and interpersonal problems are targeted; first 4 sessions focus on enhancing emotion regulation skills, last 4 sessions on developing interpersonal skills.
EMDR: focuses on processing the memory of the trauma and/or its meaning; usedprotocol to process traumatic experiences (Dutch translation of Shapiro 1995) and advanced strategies 'Cognitive Interweaves' to facilitate trauma processing.
Completed Treatment Definition: Completing the whole course of treatment
Trauma Detail (Study level): Child physical abuse; Child sexual abuse; Other ("interpersonal trauma before the age of 17 years")
Citation: Wigard I, Meyerbröker K, Ehring T, Topper M, Arntz A, Emmelkamp P. Skills training followed by either EMDR or narrative therapy for posttraumatic stress disorder in adult survivors of childhood abuse: a randomized controlled trial. Eur J Psychotraumatol. 2024;15(1):2332104. doi: 10.1080/20008066.2024.2332104. Epub 2024 Apr 17. PMID: 38629403; PMCID: PMC11025408.

Treatment Name: Skills training in affective and interpersonal regulation (STAIR) + narrative therapy (NT)
Standardized Treatment Name: Skills Training in Affect and Interpersonal Regulation (STAIR) + Narrative Exposure Therapy
Treatment Description:
STAIR followed by NT
STAIR: manualized therapy in which emotion dysregulation and interpersonal problems are targeted; first 4 sessions focus on enhancing emotion regulation skills, last 4 sessions on developing interpersonal skills.
NT: manualized exposure treatment based on Prolonged Exposure, modified by replacing in vivor exposure to trauma stimuli with interpersonal skills practice, and introducing meaning analysis after the exposure in which abuse-related schemas embedded in the trauma narrative were identified and evaluated.
Completed Treatment Definition: Completing the whole course of treatment
Trauma Detail (Study level): Child physical abuse; Child sexual abuse; Other ("interpersonal trauma before the age of 17 years")
Citation: Wigard I, Meyerbröker K, Ehring T, Topper M, Arntz A, Emmelkamp P. Skills training followed by either EMDR or narrative therapy for posttraumatic stress disorder in adult survivors of childhood abuse: a randomized controlled trial. Eur J Psychotraumatol. 2024;15(1):2332104. doi: 10.1080/20008066.2024.2332104. Epub 2024 Apr 17. PMID: 38629403; PMCID: PMC11025408.

Treatment Description:
CBM-APP: "Computerized training procedure targeting dysfunctional appraisals about trauma." PTCI (all subscales) used to generate functional appraisal training sentences. Participants instructed to read a sentence, after which a word fragment appeared on the screen which they completed by pressing its missing letter. Word fragments were positive, so that participants completed each sentence in a functional/positive way. Each session included 66 trauma-related and 15 neutral sentences. Participants began randomized treatment about 2 weeks after admission.
TAU: multimodal treatment for PTSD in specialized inpatient unit, includes individual CBT, trauma group therapy, trauma stabilization group therapy, kinesitherapy, art therapy, and physiotherapy.
Treatment Duration Detail: 2 weeks (8 sessions) of study intervention during an 8-week inpatient stay for PTSD treatment
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: per flow diagram; also analyzed per protocol (n=29, completed at least 4 sessions and provided complete outcome data)
Trauma Detail (Study level): Rape/sexual assault; Accidents; Community/school violence; Other (captivity; war; witnessed violence [sexual or non-sexual] or sudden death; learned about murder)
Citation: Woud ML, Blackwell SE, Shkreli L, et al. The effects of modifying dysfunctional appraisals in posttraumatic stress disorder using a form of cognitive bias modification: results of a randomized controlled trial in an inpatient setting. Psychother Psychosom. 2021 Oct;90(6):386-402. doi: 10.1159/000514166. PMID: 33621970.

Treatment Description:
Peripheral Vision Task used as a sham training control condition. Computer screen showed a central fixation cross surrounded by 15 small grey circles arranged in a large circle. Participants focused on the cross while also paying attention to the small circles. They then heard several beeps and were instructed to shift their peripheral vision one small circle with each beep. Small circles then changed from grey to different colors, and participants were asked to identify by color the circle where their attention had ended. Participants began randomized treatment about 2 weeks after admission.
TAU: multimodal treatment for PTSD in specialized inpatient unit, includes individual CBT, trauma group therapy, trauma stabilization group therapy, kinesitherapy, art therapy, and physiotherapy.
Treatment Duration Detail: 2 weeks (8 sessions) of study intervention during an 8-week inpatient stay for PTSD treatment
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: per flow diagram; also analyzed per protocol (n=29, completed at least 4 sessions and provided complete outcome data)
Trauma Detail (Study level): Rape/sexual assault; Accidents; Community/school violence; Other (captivity; war; witnessed violence [sexual or non-sexual] or sudden death; learned about murder)
Citation: Woud ML, Blackwell SE, Shkreli L, et al. The effects of modifying dysfunctional appraisals in posttraumatic stress disorder using a form of cognitive bias modification: results of a randomized controlled trial in an inpatient setting. Psychother Psychosom. 2021 Oct;90(6):386-402. doi: 10.1159/000514166. PMID: 33621970.

Treatment Description:
Manualized trauma-focused narrative psychotherapy, individual via video call. NT intervention developed for use with clinical nurses; "drawing on techniques related to narrative psychotherapy theory and the appropriate application of problem externalization, deconstruction, reframing, external witnessing, and treatment documentation to effectively guide clinical nurses in narrating their stories." Publication references supplemental material for specific intervention protocol, but this was not available through the journal website.
Psychological stress leaflet (same for both groups): consisted of 3 main parts: processes and outcomes of psychological stress development, coping with traumatic events, and negative emotions and stress management. Participants were asked to read these frequently, and expecially when they experienced trauma or felt anxious and stressed.
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: "two members of the intervention group discontinued the intervention due to work-related reasons" but shown as lost to follow-up in Figure 1, unclear if other participants completed treatment or completed assessments (or both)
Trauma Detail (Study level): Community/school violence; Other (occupation/work-related events in clinical nursing)
Citation: Xue M, Yu P, Gu Z, Sun Y. Online narrative therapy intervention improves post-traumatic stress disorder symptoms, perceived stress, anxiety, and depression in nurses: a randomized controlled trial. Braz J Psychiatry. 2025;47:e20243740. doi: 10.47626/1516-4446-2024-3740. Epub 2024 Sep 27. PMID: 39331491.

Treatment Description: Intermittent theta burst stimulation with coil placed at 45 degree angle to sagittal plane above the right dorsolateral prefrontal cortex (selected target); treatment mode: series of intermittent 5 Hz stimuli, and 50 Hz stimuli burst in every 5 Hz stimulus, duration of treatment 9.5 minutes with total 1800 pulses.
Dose: intermittent 5 Hz stimuli, and 50 Hz stimuli burst in every 5 Hz stimulus, duration of treatment 9.5 minutes with total 1800 pulses.
Frequency: Daily for five days per week (weekdays)
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: not further described
Citation: Yuan H, Liu B, Li F, et al. Effects of intermittent theta-burst transcranial magnetic stimulation on post-traumatic stress disorder symptoms: a randomized controlled trial. Psychiatry Res. 2023 11;329:115533. doi: 10.1016/j.psychres.2023.115533. PMID: 37826976.

Treatment Description: rTMS with coil placed at 45 degree angle to sagittal plane above the right dorsolateral prefrontal cortex (selected target); treatment mode: continuous 10 Hz stimulus, duration of treatment 33 minutes with total 1800 pulses.
Dose: continuous 10 Hz stimulus, duration of treatment 33 minutes with total 1800 pulses.
Frequency: Daily for five days per week (weekdays)
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: not further described
Citation: Yuan H, Liu B, Li F, et al. Effects of intermittent theta-burst transcranial magnetic stimulation on post-traumatic stress disorder symptoms: a randomized controlled trial. Psychiatry Res. 2023 11;329:115533. doi: 10.1016/j.psychres.2023.115533. PMID: 37826976.

Treatment Description: Sham stimulation using methods and settings of intermittent theta burst stimulation but with coil placed perpendicularly on the scalp.

Treatment Description: Manualized intervention (Shapiro 2013) based on Recent Traumatic Episode Protocol (Shapiro and Laub, 2008) that includes procedures and measures for containment and safety
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: 18/28; n=18 analyzed only participants who "completed the two sessions" and met MINI critera for PTSD

Treatment Description: Hatha-style yoga (gentle, slower-paced practice) with modifications for differing abilitiies (e.g using a chair for balance) using manualized protocol. Developed for use by women with treatment-resistant, complex PTSD. Themes include establishing safety, individual choice, interoception (perceiving inner state), being in the present moment, and taking effective action. Co-facilitated by two teachers.
Citation: Zaccari B, Sherman ADF, Febres-Cordero S, et al. Findings from a pilot study of Trauma Center Trauma-Sensitive Yoga versus cognitive processing therapy for PTSD related to military sexual trauma among women Veterans. Complementary therapies in medicine. 2022;70:102850. doi: 10.1016/j.ctim.2022.102850. PMID: 35820575.

Arm N Randomized Detail: 1 withdrew before baseline assessment, excluded from ITT analysis
Treatment Description: Manualized therapy focused on identifying how thoughts change as a result of trauma exposure, evaluating maladaptive, rigid thoughts, and substituting more accurate, flexible, alternative thoughts. Elements include Socratic questioning, prioritizing assimilation, attending to practice assignments, and encouraging affect. Group sessions led by two LCSW's.
Citation: Zaccari B, Sherman ADF, Febres-Cordero S, et al. Findings from a pilot study of Trauma Center Trauma-Sensitive Yoga versus cognitive processing therapy for PTSD related to military sexual trauma among women Veterans. Complementary therapies in medicine. 2022;70:102850. doi: 10.1016/j.ctim.2022.102850. PMID: 35820575.

Treatment Description: Device emitting LED green light (~500 nm, 500 lux)
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: "all participants that were randomized completed the 4-week intervention"
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, rape/sexual assault, accidents, community/school violence
Citation: Zalta AK, Bravo K, Valdespino‐Hayden Z, et al. A placebo‐controlled pilot study of a wearable morning bright light treatment for probable PTSD. Depress Anxiety. 2019 Jul;36(7):617-24. doi: 10.1002/da.22897. PMID: 30995350.

Treatment Description: Same device with additional filter that reduces light intensity to a level that will not shift circadian timing (7 lux)
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: "all participants that were randomized completed the 4-week intervention"
Trauma Detail (Study level): combat-related, rape/sexual assault, accidents, community/school violence

Treatment Description: Treatment following Schauer et al. 2005 manual, includes patient constructing a detailed chronological report of his/her own biography with a special focus on traumatic experiences and encouraged to relive emotions.
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: not further described
Citation: Zang Y, Hunt NC, Cox T. A randomised controlled pilot study: the effectiveness of narrative exposure therapy with adult survivors of the Sichuan earthquake. BMC Psychiatry. 2013 Jan 31;13:41. doi: 10.1186/1471-244X-13-41. PMID: 23363689.

Zang Y, Hunt NC, Cox T. A randomised controlled pilot study: the effectiveness of narrative exposure therapy with adult survivors of the Sichuan earthquake. BMC Psychiatry. 2013 Jan 31;13:41. doi: 10.1186/1471-244X-13-41. PMID: 23363689.

Treatment Description: Standard Narrative Exposure Therapy; patients constructed detailed autobiography with special focus on traumatic experiences; encouraged to relive emotions while reporting events; received written report of narrative
Completed Treatment Definition: completed entire course of treatment and followup
Citation: Zang Y, Hunt NC, Cox T. Adapting narrative exposure therapy for Chinese earthquake survivors: a pilot randomised controlled feasibility study. BMC Psychiatry. 2014 Oct 3;14:262. doi: 10.1186/s12888-014-0262-3. PMID: 25927297.

Treatment Description: Revised Narrative Exposure Therapy adapted to a single traumatic event; patient first constructed detailed earthquake narrative, then completed chronologic autobiography; encouraged to relive emotions while reporting events; final reading of autobiography without written report
Completed Treatment Definition: completed entire course of treatment and followup
Citation: Zang Y, Hunt NC, Cox T. Adapting narrative exposure therapy for Chinese earthquake survivors: a pilot randomised controlled feasibility study. BMC Psychiatry. 2014 Oct 3;14:262. doi: 10.1186/s12888-014-0262-3. PMID: 25927297.

Treatment Description: Received NET-Revised after 3-week waiting period; assessed at 2 weeks after trial entry, comparable to post-treatment assessment for immediate treatment groups (T2)
Citation: Zang Y, Hunt NC, Cox T. Adapting narrative exposure therapy for Chinese earthquake survivors: a pilot randomised controlled feasibility study. BMC Psychiatry. 2014 Oct 3;14:262. doi: 10.1186/s12888-014-0262-3. PMID: 25927297.

Treatment Description: Trauma-focused CBT following an age and culturally adapted manual for Kurdish-speaking adult women; adaptations related to language and included use of local concepts to explain key components of the treatment. Sessions started with eliciting recent trauma recall, then practicing a trauma-processing protocol involving emotional regulation techniques. Delivered in 12 weekly 90-minute individual sessions.
Trauma Detail (Study level): Terrorism/political violence/forced displacement; Other (violent death of a relative; experienced or witnessed explosions; witnessed murder of nonfamily members; other life-threatening events)
Citation: Zemestani M, Mohammed AF, Ismail AA, et al. A Pilot Randomized Clinical Trial of a Novel, Culturally Adapted, Trauma-Focused Cognitive-Behavioral Intervention for War-Related PTSD in Iraqi Women. Behav Ther. 2022 Jul;53(4):656-72. doi: 10.1016/j.beth.2022.01.009. PMID: 35697429

Treatment Description: Waitlist; participants asked to come to the clinic to review their mental health status and complete assessments at baseline, 12 weeks (post-treatment for arm A), and 16 weeks (1-month followup for arm A).
Trauma Detail (Study level): Terrorism/political violence/forced displacement; Other (violent death of a relative; experienced or witnessed explosions; witnessed murder of nonfamily members; other life-threatening events)
Citation: Zemestani M, Mohammed AF, Ismail AA, et al. A Pilot Randomized Clinical Trial of a Novel, Culturally Adapted, Trauma-Focused Cognitive-Behavioral Intervention for War-Related PTSD in Iraqi Women. Behav Ther. 2022 Jul;53(4):656-72. doi: 10.1016/j.beth.2022.01.009. PMID: 35697429

Treatment Name: Traditional Chinese medicine (Anshen Dingzhi Prescription [ADP]) + paroxetine
Treatment Description:
Anshen Dingzhi prescription + Paroxetine
Anshen Dingzhi prescription includes ginseng and other herbal medications decocted in water, which "has the effect of tranquilizing the mind and calming the spirit, benefiting the vital energy and suppressing fright." One dose per day of 200 ml each time, in the morning and in the evening. Specific ingredients: poria (10 g), poriae cum radicise pini (10 g), ginseng radix et rhizome (10 g), and polygalae radix (10 g), along with acori tatarinowii rhizoma (5 g) and dens draconis (5 g).
Paroxetine hydrochloride: SSRI, 10 to 40 mg/day. Initial dose 10 mg/day, increased by 10 mg each week based on patient response, up to a maximum daily dose of 40 mg, administered as 20 mg in the morning and 20 mg in the evening.
Dose:
Paroxetine: 10 to 40 mg/day; initial dose 10 mg/day, increased by 10 mg/day weekly increments based on response to maximum 40 mg/day.
Anshen Dingzhi prescription: 200 mL twice a day
Citation: Zhang H, Zhu Y, Zhu G, et al. Clinical Efficacy and Mechanistic Insights of Anshen Dingzhi Prescription on Breast Cancer-Related PTSD Through Network Pharmacology and Molecular Docking. Integ Cancer Ther. 2024 Jan-Dec;23:15347354241285435. doi: 10.1177/15347354241285435. PMID: 39344020.

Treatment Description: Paroxetine hydrochloride: SSRI, 10 to 40 mg/day. Initial dose 10 mg/day, increased by 10 mg each week based on patient response, up to a maximum daily dose of 40 mg, administered as 20 mg in the morning and 20 mg in the evening.
Dose: 10 to 40 mg/day; initial dose 10 mg/day, increased by 10 mg/day weekly increments based on response to maximum 40 mg/day.
Citation: Zhang H, Zhu Y, Zhu G, et al. Clinical Efficacy and Mechanistic Insights of Anshen Dingzhi Prescription on Breast Cancer-Related PTSD Through Network Pharmacology and Molecular Docking. Integ Cancer Ther. 2024 Jan-Dec;23:15347354241285435. doi: 10.1177/15347354241285435. PMID: 39344020.

Treatment Description: fMRI neurofeedback focused on the region of the amygdala associated with trauma recall; personalized trauma scripts; provided personalized mental strategies (strategy use was optional)
Treatment Duration Detail: No mention of time to complete neurofeedback; total 3 training sessions of 6 runs per session
Completed Treatment Definition: Received intervention and did not discontinue
Citation: Zhao Z, Duek O, Seidemann R, et al. Amygdala downregulation training using fMRI neurofeedback in post-traumatic stress disorder: a randomized, double-blind trial. Transl Psychiatry. 2023;13(1):177. doi: 10.1038/s41398-023-02467-6. PMID: 37230984.

Treatment Description: Sham neurofeedback using recorded feedback from a matched participant from active group ("yoked" feedback); personalized trauma scripts; provided personalized mental strategies (strategy use was optional)
Treatment Duration Detail: No mention of time to complete neurofeedback; total 3 training sessions of 6 runs per session
Completed Treatment Definition: Received intervention and did not discontinue
Citation: Zhao Z, Duek O, Seidemann R, et al. Amygdala downregulation training using fMRI neurofeedback in post-traumatic stress disorder: a randomized, double-blind trial. Transl Psychiatry. 2023;13(1):177. doi: 10.1038/s41398-023-02467-6. PMID: 37230984.

Treatment Description: CBT following Beck model
Treatment Duration Detail: 10 sessions, allowed up to 15 weeks to complete sessions

Treatment Description: Intervention based on Linehan's Dialectical Behavior Therapy (Linehan, 1993) and Matsakis's Treatment Guide for Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (Matsakis, 1994). Intervention includes psychoeducation, skill building, and application skills. Materials covered include dissociation, flashbacks, "safe" sleep, identification of emotions, crisis planning, anger management, techniques for distraction, self-soothing, distress tolerance, and relaxation. Participants also received individual psychotherapy with medication management.
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: not further described, n=7 "failed to complete treatment" and n=16 "completed the treatment group" (this data entered for completed psychotherapy percent), unclear status for remaining n=1 participant
Citation: Zlotnick C, Shea MT, Rosen KH, et al. An affect-management group for women with posttraumatic stress disorder and histories of childhood sexual abuse. J Trauma Stress. 1997 Jul;10(3):425-36. doi: 10.1023/A:1024841321156. PMID: 9246650.

Treatment Description: Participants continued to receive individual psychotherapy with medication management
Completed Treatment Percent Detail: n=17 completed posttreatment measures
Citation: Zlotnick C, Shea MT, Rosen KH, et al. An affect-management group for women with posttraumatic stress disorder and histories of childhood sexual abuse. J Trauma Stress. 1997 Jul;10(3):425-36. doi: 10.1023/A:1024841321156. PMID: 9246650.

Treatment Description:
Seeking safety: group modality (3 to 5 women per group) while in prison, with optional individual "booster" sessions upon release from prison; "primary goals of SS are psychoeducation and the development of coping skills to help clients attain safety from both PTSD and SUD; it is present-focused, abstinence-oriented, and emphasizes an empowering, compassionate approach."



TAU: abstinence-oriented residential substance use treatment program following 12-step model in "psychoeducation large-group format, with weekly individual case management and drug counseling"; participants required to attend all components of TAU treatment to remain in program.
Session Length: Seeking Safety group sessions: 90 minutes; Seeking Safety individual sessions: 60 minutes; TAU: NR (total 30 hours per week)
Frequency: Seeking Safety group sessions: three times a week; Seeking Safety individual sessions: weekly; TAU: NR (total 30 hours per week)
Treatment Duration Detail: Seeking Safety group sessions: 6 to 8 plus; Seeking Safety individual sessions: 12 weekly sessions offered for all participants in the SS group after group sessions ended; TAU: 12
Psychotherapy Sessions Completed Detail: Seeking Safety group sessions: 15.6 (6.2); Seeking Safety individual sessions: 3.3 (3.8)
Trauma Detail (Study level): rape/sexual assault, community/school violence
Citation: Zlotnick C, Johnson JE, Najavits LM. Randomized controlled pilot study of cognitive-behavioral therapy in a sample of incarcerated women with substance use disorder and PTSD. Behav Ther. 2009 Dec;40(4):325-36. doi: 10.1016/j.beth.2008.09.004. PMID: 19892078.

Standardized Treatment Name: Treatment as usual (TAU) for substance use
Treatment Description: Abstinence-oriented residential substance use treatment program following 12-step model in "psychoeducation large-group format, with weekly individual case management and drug counseling"; participants required to attend all components of TAU treatment to remain in program.
Trauma Detail (Study level): rape/sexual assault, community/school violence
Citation: Zlotnick C, Johnson JE, Najavits LM. Randomized controlled pilot study of cognitive-behavioral therapy in a sample of incarcerated women with substance use disorder and PTSD. Behav Ther. 2009 Dec;40(4):325-36. doi: 10.1016/j.beth.2008.09.004. PMID: 19892078.

Dose: 260 mg
